subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Regalia Order Deadline Coming Up!'
html:
b'
Hello,


Just a friendly reminder from Stacy Miller at the Duck Store that faculty regalia orders are due May 18 (and she loves it when orders are turned in early). If you wait, you will not be guaranteed choice of hood color.  Order your regalia here:
http://uoduckstore.com/faculty/renting_regalia/  The cost of renting your regalia is covered by the COE, so there's no need to hesitate!

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.



I know some of you may own your own regalia and won't be on the order list, but here is the list so far of faculty who have ordered regalia from the Duck Store:

Joanna Goode
Deanna Linville
Jeanne Hall
Karen McLaughlin
Angela Whalen
Edward Kameenui
Roland Good
Kimberly Sherman
Marilyn Nippold
Cecilia Kirk
Surendra Subramani
Kevin Alltucker



Thanks,
Lisa



Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607
Fax:  541-346-5818


-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20120503/a8b84326/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Open Access Education'
html:
b'
A reminder:  David Wiley<http://davidwiley.org/>, nationally recognized scholar, teacher, and expert on open education, will speak on "Open Education, Open Access, and the Challenges to Higher Ed" today at 4:00 p.m. in Browsing Room of Knight Library. The lecture is co-sponsored by the COE.

In his talk Wiley will discuss how traditional degree-granting institutions might respond to technological, social, and political trends that have created new market forces, putting them in steep competition with a new wave of edupreneurs, for-profit education initiatives such as Udacity<http://www.udacity.com>, and open education prototypes such as MITx<http://mitx.mit.edu/>.


[cid:image001.jpg at 01CD2C30.B88D6920]

subject: b'coe-fac: Dead Week and Final Exam Policy'
html:
b'
Please forward to your GTFs as appropriate--

TO:                 Faculty and Graduate Teaching Fellows

FROM:           Russ Tomlin, Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs

RE:                  Dead Week and Final Exam Policy

I write to remind you of examination policies that may affect your course planning for the end of this term.  Faculty legislation controls assignments that may be required during the last week of regular classes, commonly known as "Dead Week," (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~assembly/Assembly1981-1982ALL.html#DeadWeek>):


1.       In the week preceding final examination during fall, winter, and spring terms:

*         No examination worth more than 20% of the final grade will be given, with the exception of make-up examinations.

*         No final examinations will be given under any guise.

*         No work that will be evaluated for grades/credit will be due unless it has been clearly specified on the class syllabus within the first two weeks of the term.

2.      Take-home examinations will be due no earlier than the day of the formally assigned final examination for the class in question.
This action clarifies and extends earlier faculty legislation (1911 Faculty Assembly archives) prohibiting the giving of final examinations earlier than officially scheduled.

In addition, you should be aware of the Faculty Advisory Council's statement on students with multiple exams:

"Examination schedules are listed each term in the Time Schedule.  Students who are scheduled to take more than three examinations within one calendar day may take the additional examination(s) as makeup examination(s) later in the examination week.  The instructor(s) of record for the course(s) beyond the third examination, counting in the order the examination(s) are scheduled, will arrange for (a) makeup examination(s)."

The following procedures were approved by the Undergraduate Council to address rare circumstances of competing exam times, (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~ucouncil/documents/resources/04222003-HO1_Resource_Final%20Exam%20Conflicts.pdf>).   Students with examination conflicts may contact the Office of Academic Advising for assistance.

"In the case of two examinations scheduled at the same time, the course with the largest enrollment must provide an alternate examination.  For conflicts between regular courses and combined examinations, the combined examination course must provide the alternate examination.  For combined examinations with conflicts, the largest combined enrollment course must provide the alternative examination."

Questions and concerns regarding this policy should be directed first to the relevant instructor, then the department head, and finally the dean if necessary.  You may also find reference to the policy on the Academic Affairs website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/dead-week-policy.    If additional input is needed, please contact me at 6-3029 or tomlin at uoregon.edu<mailto:tomlin at uoregon.edu>.

subject: b'coe-fac: 7th Annual Education Studies BBQ Olympics Invitation'
html:
b'
It is that time of year again.  

As a way of expressing gratitude and affection for our colleagues and
community partners who have supported us all year, you are cordially invited
to


 

The 7th Annual (yes
7th)

Over-Thought, Over-Wrought, Over-the-Top

UO Dept of EDUCATION STUDIES

BBQ Olympics

Starting 3pm on Sunday, June 17th, 2012

 

This year\xc2\x92s event will feature:


Pulled Pork sliders competition 

(it\xc2\x92s the grad students vs. faculty this year)

A Side Dish Competition (open to everyone)

A Vegetarian BBQ Entr\xc3\xa9e Competition

And

A Homebrewed Beer Competition 

(open, must deliver in keg the night before)

 

This year\xc2\x92s hosts are:


Joanna Goode, Jason Sydes, and family.

(See address and parking info in the attached flier.)

Family and children are welcome.

No need to bring anything besides an appetite.

 

Please join us for damn fine BBQ, good-natured fun, good community, and good
company!

subject: b'coe-fac: Blackboard Update'
html:
b'
Hi Colleagues - 
If you're not a user of Blackboard, you can stop reading now and go do something more fun.

For Blackboard users, please be aware that there is a major upgrade happening on Saturday, June 16.  The "new and improved" Blackboard that will appear after the down time will have major user interface differences, but no major content or function changes. Many of the small bugs reported in the past year are being eliminated in this upgrade.  Content from your current BB sites will not be lost and you should not have issues with downloading or upgrading grades.Watch for user trainings before fall term.  Those of us teaching in the summer (myself included) will be figuring things out on our own, but the BB support staff are always available for assistance.  There will be summaries of the changes appearing in emails and on Blackboard over the summer.

Have a great weekend everyone -
Deborah Olson
SPECS
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20120601/4b355043/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Survey Request for Feedback on COE Tutoring\tServices-teaching faculty only'
html:
b'
Dear College of Education Teaching Faculty,

I am writing to request your feedback regarding the COE Tutoring  Services.
Please complete this short survey to let us know how well we  

are meeting students' needs. The survey should only take 3-5 minutes to
complete. Responses will remain anonymous and will only be used 

for program improvement purposes to better serve our COE students.

 

Please follow the following link to complete the survey:
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_3fJJwhuNygMkEgk

This survey should only be taken by teaching faculty.  

 

We appreciate any feedback you are willing to provide. Thank you for your
participation!

 

Sincerely,

Heather Norland

Tutoring Services Coordinator

 

 

 

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20120613/dd499504/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Fw: Blackboard Mobile Learn changes'
html:
b'
Hi Colleagues - If you do not teach using Blackboard, you can stop reading now and delete.  Blackboard users might find this useful - deborah
----- Original Message ----- 
From: Nargas Oskui-Tabrizi 
To: Mike Price ; Nargas Oskui-Tabrizi ; Deborah Bauer ; Grace Golden ; Deborah Olson ; Skipper McFarlane ; Mary Ann Hyatt ; Pedro Garcia-Caro ; Timothy Boshart ; Michael Hennessy ; Sean Sharp ; Sue Eveland ; Prehoda Ken ; Robert Voelker-Morris ; Helen Chu ; Deborah Healey ; Anne van den Nouweland 
Cc: cmet_consulting at lists.uoregon.edu 
Sent: Wednesday, September 19, 2012 5:38 PM
Subject: Blackboard Mobile Learn changes


Hello Blackboard Advisory Committee,

Beginning September 2012, the Blackboard Mobile App for iOS & Android has moved to a subscription model that works on all carriers/networks as well as WiFi.

Previously, the Blackboard Mobile Learn App available to UO students and faculty was available only on WiFi, and not available via cell networks. Blackboard's new Personal License option allows students and instructors to access to the fully functional app. Bb users will be able to choose between two different introductory pricing options: $1.99 per year or a one-time / lifetime fee of $5.99. The app is available for iOS and Android users on all carriers and networks. 

For more information, please see attached or see Blackboard's official announcement:

http://www.blackboard.com/Platforms/Mobile/Products/Mobile-Learn.aspx

In case you are interested, we have also attached our communication plan about this change. And if you have any further questions please feel free to contact CMET Consulting.

Sincerely,

Nargas

Nargas Oskui, Manager

CMET Consulting

http://library.uoregon.edu/cmet/consulting/

 

University of Oregon Libraries

1299 University of Oregon                           Voice:  (541) 346-1688

Eugene, OR  97403                                           office: 19 Knight Library

                                                                                email: not at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: EDUC Course Nominations'
html:
b'
Colleagues,

The online nomination form for EDUC course instructors (AY 2013-14) is 
now available.

*OVERVIEW:* This is a self-nomination process.If you are interested in 
the possibility of teaching an EDUC course AY 2013-14, please nominate 
yourself.Note: You will be asked to indicate a COE Academic Department 
affiliation.If you are COE Research & Outreach faculty, please work with 
your R&O Unit Head to identify an appropriate COE Academic Department 
Affiliation and notify that Department Head (DH) of your interest in 
teaching an EDUC course. R&O Unit Heads and Academic DH's will work 
together in arranging appointments of R&O faculty to EDUC courses.

*TIMELINE & PROCESS:*Self-nominations will close on November 1^st @ 
5PM.Department & Unit Heads will review the nominations and appointments 
will be made based on their review.

*SELF-NOMINATION LINK: *Please click on the following link to nominate 
yourself:
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_0Tbjv7lkII9pHtb
(Note: If the above link doesn't work by clicking on it, please 
copy-and-paste it into your web-browser).

The link for self-nominations is also available on the COE Academic 
Affairs webpage:
https://education.uoregon.edu/governance/coe-and-uo-policies-and-procedures

All the best,

Ron Beghetto

-- 
==========================
Ronald A. Beghetto, PhD
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs
Associate Professor of Education Studies
College of Education
University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5277
(541) 346-1534
Webpage: http://pages.uoregon.edu/beghetto

subject: b'coe-fac: Open forum on UO research themes, Oct 23'
html:
b'
Subject: Open forum on UO research themes, Oct 23
Please distribute to the faculty in your units:

You are invited to an open forum on UO Strategic Research Themes, Tuesday October 23 at 11:00 in the EMU Walnut Room.

Last year several hundred faculty came together in a series of meetings to discuss areas of research strength and opportunity across the university. These ideas were captured in six broad research themes: Sustainable Futures; Developing Cells, Minds & Healthy Communities; Identities, Cultures & Connections; Tools & Technologies for Tomorrow; Oregon: a Place, a Laboratory, a Canvas; and Shaping the Information Society.

See http://research.uoregon.edu/highlights/university-oregon-strategic-research-strengths for a full description.

This open forum is intended to provide faculty who were not able to participate in the earlier discussion a chance to hear about the process and intent of the themes, as well as to discuss how their own research programs fit into these broad umbrellas.

Hope to see you there,

Patrick Phillips & Beth Stormshak
Associate Vice Presidents for Research
Research, Innovation and Graduate Education
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20121017/c4056a67/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Two new internal programs from Research Innovation and Graduate Education'
html:
b'
FYI-

Please distribute this announcement to your faculty.

The Vice President for Research and Innovation announces two new internal award programs.


*         Idea awards are designed to stimulate discussion and development of collaborative ideas for research projects that will enhance the UO's research strengths and that will be candidates for future external funding.  Funds may be used to sponsor an external speaker, engage in a planning workshop or retreat, retain a consultant to conduct a seminar or workshop, or in other ways that encourage collaborative research and engage faculty in projects to facilitate research excellence.  Idea awards will be made up to $5,000.  Deadlines for the submission of proposals are December 7, 2012, and April 5, 2013.


*         I3 (Incubating Interdisciplinary Initiatives) Awards are designed to support development of large-scale projects and programs that target specific federal agency programs that offer programmatic, large-scale funding.  I3 proposals should rely on collaborative partnerships across departments and colleges.  Partnerships may include external institutions of strategic importance.  I3 awards provide up to $50,000 for one year.  Deadline for the submission of proposals is February 1, 2013.

Idea and I3 Award guidelines and applications are available online in the Announcements sidebar at http://rfd.uoregon.edu/.  Questions should be directed to Lynn Stearney, Director, Research Development Services, 346-8308.

Best,

Moira Kiltie


Moira Kiltie
Assistant Vice President for Research
Chief of Staff, RIGE
Research, Innovation and Graduate Education (RIGE)
University of Oregon
541-346-3188
kiltie at uoregon.edu<mailto:kiltie at uoregon.edu>
http://research.uoregon.edu<http://research.uoregon.edu/>

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Workshop Opportunity'
html:
b'
FYI-

Please share this opportunity with your faculty.


Each year, the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art works closely with faculty across campus to support teaching and research. To expand its role as a faculty resource, this year the JSMA is pleased to offer a series of FREE JSMA Workshops<http://jsma.uoregon.edu/programs/faculty-students/default.aspx#New_Faculty> designed for first-time users as well as those familiar with the museum's resources.  We invite you to pick the ones right for you.



Designing Your Curriculum with the Museum in Mind: Tuesdays, November 13, 2-4pm, or January 15, 1-3pm



Using the Visual Arts in Your Teaching: Thursday, January 31, 9:30-11:30am



How to Submit Object Requests or an Exhibition Proposal: Friday, February 15, 10-11am

Writing from Art:  Tuesday, November 27, 9:30-11:30am, or Monday, February 25, 2-4pm



And click here<http://jsma.uoregon.edu/Post/sections/40/Files/FacultyGuide12.pdf> for a copy of "18 Ways to Use the Museum," a reference guide for faculty and staff.


To register or learn more, please contact Sharon Kaplan, museum educator, at kaplan at uoregon.edu<mailto:kaplan at uoregon.edu> or  541.346.0968.
Jill Hartz, Executive Director
President, Association of Academic Museums and Galleries

Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art
1223 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1223
Tel: 541.346.0972
Fax: 541.346.0976
Cell: 541.868.4138
Currently on view: Lesley Dill's Poetic Visions: From Shimmer to Sister Gertrude Morgan, Good Grief: A Selection from 50 years of Original Art from Charles M. Schulz's PEANUTS, The Female Figure: Artistic Multiplicities,History of Photography, Traditional & Contemporary Korean Art from the Mattielli & JSMA Collections, plus collections galleries devoted to art from China, Korea, Japan, the Americas, Russia and elsewhere.

Find us on Facebook<http://www.facebook.com/JordanSchnitzerMuseumofArt>
Follow us on Twitter<http://www.twitter.com/JSchnitzMOA>
Watch us on YouTube<http://www.youtube.com/JSchnitzMOA>
For more information and schedule of events, visit our website atjsma.uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Dead Week and Final Exam Policy'
html:
b'
FYI-

TO:                          Faculty and Graduate Teaching Fellows

FROM:                    Doug Blandy, Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs

RE:                          Dead Week and Final Exam Policy

This message is to remind you of examination policies that may affect your course planning for the end of this term.  Faculty legislation controls assignments that may be required during the last week of regular classes, commonly known as "Dead Week," (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~assembly/Assembly1981-1982ALL.html#DeadWeek>):


1.        In the week preceding final examination during fall, winter, and spring terms:

*         No examination worth more than 20% of the final grade will be given, with the exception of make-up examinations.

*         No final examinations will be given under any guise.

*         No work that will be evaluated for grades/credit will be due unless it has been clearly specified on the class syllabus within the first two weeks of the term.

2.       Take-home examinations will be due no earlier than the day of the formally assigned final examination for the class in question.
This action clarifies and extends earlier faculty legislation (1911 Faculty Assembly archives) prohibiting the giving of final examinations earlier than officially scheduled.

In addition, you should be aware of the Faculty Advisory Council's statement on students with multiple exams:

"Examination schedules are listed each term in the Time Schedule.  Students who are scheduled to take more than three examinations within one calendar day may take the additional examination(s) as makeup examination(s) later in the examination week.  The instructor(s) of record for the course(s) beyond the third examination, counting in the order the examination(s) are scheduled, will arrange for (a) makeup examination(s)."

The following procedures were approved by the Undergraduate Council to address rare circumstances of competing exam times, (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~ucouncil/documents/resources/04222003-HO1_Resource_Final%20Exam%20Conflicts.pdf>).   Students with examination conflicts may contact the Office of Academic Advising for assistance.

"In the case of two examinations scheduled at the same time, the course with the largest enrollment must provide an alternate examination.  For conflicts between regular courses and combined examinations, the combined examination course must provide the alternate examination.  For combined examinations with conflicts, the largest combined enrollment course must provide the alternative examination."

Questions and concerns regarding this policy should be directed first to the relevant instructor, then the department head, and finally the dean if necessary.  You may also find reference to the policy on the Academic Affairs website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/dead-week-policy.    If additional input is needed, please contact me at 6-3029 or dblandy at uoregon.edu<mailto:dblandy at uoregon.edu>.

Faculty legislation controls assignments that may be required during the last week of regular classes, commonly known as "Dead Week," (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~assembly/Assembly1981-1982ALL.html#DeadWeek>):


1.        In the week preceding final examination during fall, winter, and spring terms:

*         No examination worth more than 20% of the final grade will be given, with the exception of make-up examinations.

*         No final examinations will be given under any guise.

*         No work that will be evaluated for grades/credit will be due unless it has been clearly specified on the class syllabus within the first two weeks of the term.

2.       Take-home examinations will be due no earlier than the day of the formally assigned final examination for the class in question.
This action clarifies and extends earlier faculty legislation (1911 Faculty Assembly archives) prohibiting the giving of final examinations earlier than officially scheduled.

In addition, you should be aware of the Faculty Advisory Council's statement on students with multiple exams:

"Examination schedules are listed each term in the Time Schedule.  Students who are scheduled to take more than three examinations within one calendar day may take the additional examination(s) as makeup examination(s) later in the examination week.  The instructor(s) of record for the course(s) beyond the third examination, counting in the order the examination(s) are scheduled, will arrange for (a) makeup examination(s)."

The following procedures were approved by the Undergraduate Council to address rare circumstances of competing exam times, (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~ucouncil/documents/resources/04222003-HO1_Resource_Final%20Exam%20Conflicts.pdf>).   Students with examination conflicts may contact the Office of Academic Advising for assistance.

"In the case of two examinations scheduled at the same time, the course with the largest enrollment must provide an alternate examination.  For conflicts between regular courses and combined examinations, the combined examination course must provide the alternate examination.  For combined examinations with conflicts, the largest combined enrollment course must provide the alternative examination."

Questions and concerns regarding this policy should be directed first to the relevant instructor, then the department head, and finally the dean if necessary.  You may also find reference to the policy on the Academic Affairs website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/dead-week-policy.    If additional input is needed, please contact me at 6-3029 or dblandy at uoregon.edu<mailto:dblandy at uoregon.edu>.

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Photo Shoots, plus video info'
html:
b'
Good Morning,

Photo shoot tomorrow and Nov. 27
Tomorrow and the following Tuesday, a professional photographer will be on the premises as part of a coordinated shoot. The bulk of our digital photography is more than four years old and it's time to start refreshing it.

I have been working with a number of you behind the scenes to identify students and faculty to be part of the shoot, and things are lining up pretty well. These initial two shoots will focus on life in and around the complex, our undergraduate programs, and some examples of the work we do with children and families. Future shoots will focus on other areas. The photographer will be accompanied at all times.

We are a little thin on male students and faculty for tomorrow's shoot. If you fit that description, are willing to be photographed, and are available between 9 and 11 a.m., and/or from 3:30-5 p.m., please let me know. Even if you don't fit that description but you have something going on that might be interesting to shoot during those times, let me know that as well. The same afternoon window (3:30-5) may be available on the 27th as well. We'll have releases with us.

The scheduled shoot aside, the talent and equipment exists right here in the COE to capture events on a one-off basis. If your daytime plans include something photogenic, on campus or off, please don't hesitate to contact me.

COE video capabilities
On a related note, the COE now has pretty robust video-production capabilities that include lighting, professional audio, visual effects, motion graphics and more. Starting in January, we would like to produce at least one new short video per month promoting the COE. Some will be serious, some will be whimsical, but there must  be a mix. All will try and capture the academic and social life, and the spirit/energy of the College. If you would like to discuss a video idea for your department/unit/program, contact me after the 27th and I'll gladly meet to discuss it.

Thanks much,
Cody

subject: b'coe-fac: Last Day to Submit Proposals for Grad Research Forum is Dec 10-- Encourage your students!'
html:
b'
**SENT ON BEHALF OF THE GRADUATE SCHOOL**


Colleagues:

Please encourage your graduate students to submit a proposal for participation in this year's Graduate Student Research Forum by Monday, December 10. In its fourth year, the Forum provides a great opportunity to or discuss a work in progress or present completed research, obtaining valuable feedback from peers and faculty, and networking across disciplines, all in a fee-free, low-stakes setting.
The deadline to submit proposals is December 10 and there are five ways to participate: (1) Present a paper to become part of an interdisciplinary panel session to be organized by the Graduate School; (2) Propose an interdisciplinary panel session of the students' own (presenters must represent 3 or more disciplines); (3) Participate in a poster session; (4) Present a work of creative expression (exhibit, performance, etc.); or (5) Participate in one of six themed roundtables.

This year's Forum, "Research for Tomorrow," will be held on Friday, May 10, 2013. Find out more on our website: https://gradschool.uoregon.edu/current-students/grad-student-research-forum

Sandra Morgen
Vice Provost for Graduate Studies
Associate Dean, Graduate School



-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20121120/623a79ab/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Course Announcement - EDUC 620/621 Program Evaluation I/II'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues:
The following is information about and request for evaluation topics for the college-wide doctoral seminar, Program Evaluation I & II sequence (EDUC 620 and 621).
Description of Course:  The winter/spring Program Evaluation sequence will be offered this year and the winter class is scheduled for Thursdays from 2:00 - 5:50. Please pass this information along to any of your doctoral students who may be interested in this sequence. Students are better prepared for this course if they have had either the prerequisite research methods or a measurement course.

  *   The Winter course covers (a) models of evaluation, (b) types of evaluation (e.g., needs assessment, implementation, outcome/impact), (c) measurement issues and approaches, (d) standards of evaluation, and (e) the development of an evaluation proposal. The product for the term is the completion of an evaluability assessment for an evaluation project and a proposal for an evaluation negotiated with a client. Please see below if you or someone you know has an existing evaluation need.
  *   The Spring term, taken as practicum credits, involves completing the planned evaluation activities including the writing of a final evaluation report. Students who take only the Winter term negotiate that they will plan an evaluation for their client but not carry it out.
Request for Evaluation Topics: This e-mail is also an invitation to provide evaluation opportunities or projects appropriate for student completion (e.g., pieces of existing research projects, academic programs, or within community agencies you are affiliated). Evaluation projects should be of the scope that makes it possible for the planning to occur during winter term and the evaluation implemented AND completed at the end of spring term. For example, last year the FHS supervision of supervision model for the FHS student practicum was evaluated. Another evaluation was conducted in two middle schools measuring student's perception of school culture in schools implementing PBS. This evaluation was an expansion from an already funded grant, and the evaluators presented data from this evaluation in a conference poster session.
Please e-mail me directly a short description your ideas and projects prior to the start of winter term. I will present the evaluation opportunities early in the term for students to choose from and allow them to begin working with the client in the design of the evaluation. This activity is a valuable resource for students to provide them with evaluation experience with "real data" and also working directly with clients under guided supervision.
Please let me know if you have any questions or need additional information.
Sincerely,
CHiXapkaid
dpavel at uoregon.edu<mailto:dpavel at uoregon.edu>

URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20121203/57d92493/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Web style guide'
html:
b'
Good Morning,

At yesterday's meeting, Jeff Woodbury alluded to style guidelines and conventions for the Web as a way to establish consistency across our website, at least as it relates to content. To assist content owners in this regard, we've put together a COE style guide<https://coe.uoregon.edu/styleguide/>. It is meant to help answer questions about what to capitalize, how to abbreviate, and the like. Hopefully you will find it a useful resource. With your feedback, it will continue to grow and improve.

The biggest problems with consistency right now are:

  *   Lists. Drupal can automatically format bulleted or numbered lists for you. Separate each element, or line, with the RETURN key, select the whole block of text, and then click whichever list icon you wish. A bullet or number will be inserted where you've made line breaks. If you paste a list from another document, paste the plain text and remove existing numbers or bullets before applying the list style.
  *   Spaces. Just hitting RETURN after a line is called a hard return, and it automatically adds a space between lines or paragraphs. Word-processing programs don't do that by default, so if you hit RETURN twice to add a line break, you're actually adding two.
  *   Headings. Drupal offers a handful of options for formatting text. Most of your text will just use the "Normal" style. If you want a section heading, e.g. "Degree Requirements," you should use "Heading 3." Heading 2 is part of the style sheet because it's the default main page title heading, but you shouldn't use it in your copy.
  *   Hyperlinks. In general, avoid using the actual URL as the text for a hyperlink. But you should also avoid vague words or phrases. For example, say you want to link to information about academic advising. Avoid this: "To learn more about academic advising, go to https://education.uoregon.edu/student-academic-services/academic-advising." By the same token, don't be too vague: "To learn more about academic advising, click here<https://education.uoregon.edu/student-academic-services/academic-advising>." The preferred way is to make the hyperlinked text descriptive of the destination and incidental to the wording, e.g. "The COE offers dedicated academic advising services<https://education.uoregon.edu/student-academic-services/academic-advising> to help ensure steady progress toward your degree."
  *   Galleries. The spirit of a gallery is that it is updated relatively often with new photos. That's why, once you create one, it places thumbnails on your landing page with the heading, "Recent photos." In Drupal-speak, that means the most recently uploaded photos, not the most recently taken photos. If you want to re-order them, simply drag them around in the View window (from within your gallery, after you've logged in) so the four you want to feature are the first four in the group (going across).

Unfortunately, I need to address the erroneous, but apparently widespread, perception that the marketing office is in the business of changing people's website content without notice. To be clear, your content is YOUR content. The only changes site administrators would ever make without notifying you are the types listed above, which help ensure a clean, professional-looking website but do not materially affect the work you've done to that point. It's the difference between straightening someone's tie for them and replacing it with a bandana while they're not paying attention. If you believe someone has substantially changed your content, a respectful inquiry can determine what happened, when, why, and how to fix it.

Cheers,
Cody

________________________________
[Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: cid:3406876785_2874866]Cody Pinkston | Director of Marketing | cpinksto at uoregon.edu<mailto:cpinksto at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Distinguished Teaching Awards nominations open in January. Take the Academic Affairs website survey. Meet the staff.'
html:
b'

Distinguished Teaching Awards nominations open in January. Take the Academic Affairs website survey. Meet the staff.

Oregon College Students Rank 8th in the Nation for Volunteering<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage2.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=212f51f060&e=8533305d1c> (Corporation for National and Community Service)

Academic Affairs Staff
[Image removed by sender.]
Back (L-R): Tami Oar, Sonja Runberg, Ken Doxsee, Erin Flood Fortier
Front (L-R): Barbara Altmann, Doug Blandy, Pam Palanuk, Ruth D. Keele
Not pictured: Meg Mattson

[Image removed by sender.]
Contact the Editor
Do you know of an upcoming opportunity for faculty? Drop us a line to have it included in next month's e-news.
academicaffairs at uoregon.edu<mailto:academicaffairs at uoregon.edu?subject=E-newsletter>




Distinguished Teaching Awards - Nominations to Open in January
Each year, the University of Oregon awards crystal apples-symbols of teaching excellence-to three of its top teachers. The awards are supported by endowment funds and each faculty recipient receives a $2,000 stipend added to his or her salary base. Winners of each award are chosen on the recommendation of faculty members, staff, students and alumni. Nominations will be accepted beginning January 9, 2013. Read more about the awards<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=ab3a8c7861&e=8533305d1c>.
Academic Affairs Website - We Need Your Help
In the coming months, the Office of Academic Affairs will undertake a redesign and reorganization of its website to better serve faculty and staff needs surrounding hiring, retention, promotion, tenure processes, and other aspects of faculty life. For the website to be of value to you, it is important that you make your needs and expectations known to us. Please help by participating in a short survey<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=13367f9a84&e=8533305d1c>.
Introducing Academic Affairs: Barbara Altmann and Meg Mattson
[Image removed by sender.]Barbara Altmann, Vice Provost for Academic Affairs, began her appointment on July 1, 2012. In her new role, Barbara oversees NTTF appointments, contracts, and promotions. She also coordinates the academic program review process. Her direct reports are Undergraduate Studies, Graduate Studies, and International Affairs.
[Image removed by sender. Meg Mattson]Meg Mattson is our newest staff member. As Executive Assistant to Barbara Altmann, Meg assumes management of her calendar and schedule. She provides support to the NTTF promotion process and staffs program review, along with Sonja Runberg. Meg will also be working with Ruth D. Keele to implement CourseLeaf and will assume primary responsibility for the internal approval processes for new curriculum proposals.










Forward to a colleague<http://us5.forward-to-friend1.com/forward?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=42509bc185&e=8533305d1c>.

You are receiving this email because you are a member of the University of Oregon faculty or administration.

Our mailing address is:
Academic Affairs

text:
b"Subject: Distinguished Teaching Awards nominations open in January. Take the Academic Affairs website survey. Meet the staff.

Distinguished Teaching Awards nominations open in January. Take the Academic Affairs website survey. Meet the staff.

Is this email not displaying correctly?
View it in your browser<http://us5.campaign-archive1.com/?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=42509bc185&e=8533305d1c>.



[Image removed by sender.]





[Image removed by sender.]
In This Issue


  *   Distinguished Teaching Awards - Nominations to Open in January
  *   Academic Affairs Website - We Need Your Help
  *   Introducing Academic Affairs: Barbara Altmann and Meg Mattson

Upcoming Opportunities

Promotion and Tenure Workshop for Department Heads, Office Managers, and Support Staff<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=f79ca96b1f&e=8533305d1c>


Around the Web

Flipping the Curriculum: Introductory Courses Should Be Just as Good as the Capstone Experience<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=ca93da9c24&e=8533305d1c> (The Chronicle of Higher Education)

Oregon College Students Rank 8th in the Nation for Volunteering<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage2.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=212f51f060&e=8533305d1c> (Corporation for National and Community Service)

Fixing Humanities Grad Programs<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage1.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=e40bbfa617&e=8533305d1c> (Inside Higher Ed)

Dual Career Academic Couples: What Universities Need to Know<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=e7e359226f&e=8533305d1c> (The Clayman Institute for Gender Research)

Academic Affairs Staff
[Image removed by sender.]
Back (L-R): Tami Oar, Sonja Runberg, Ken Doxsee, Erin Flood Fortier
Front (L-R): Barbara Altmann, Doug Blandy, Pam Palanuk, Ruth D. Keele
Not pictured: Meg Mattson

[Image removed by sender.]
Contact the Editor
Do you know of an upcoming opportunity for faculty? Drop us a line to have it included in next month's e-news.
academicaffairs at uoregon.edu<mailto:academicaffairs at uoregon.edu?subject=E-newsletter>




Distinguished Teaching Awards - Nominations to Open in January
Each year, the University of Oregon awards crystal apples-symbols of teaching excellence-to three of its top teachers. The awards are supported by endowment funds and each faculty recipient receives a $2,000 stipend added to his or her salary base. Winners of each award are chosen on the recommendation of faculty members, staff, students and alumni. Nominations will be accepted beginning January 9, 2013. Read more about the awards<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=ab3a8c7861&e=8533305d1c>.
Academic Affairs Website - We Need Your Help
In the coming months, the Office of Academic Affairs will undertake a redesign and reorganization of its website to better serve faculty and staff needs surrounding hiring, retention, promotion, tenure processes, and other aspects of faculty life. For the website to be of value to you, it is important that you make your needs and expectations known to us. Please help by participating in a short survey<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage.com/track/click?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=13367f9a84&e=8533305d1c>.
Introducing Academic Affairs: Barbara Altmann and Meg Mattson
[Image removed by sender.]Barbara Altmann, Vice Provost for Academic Affairs, began her appointment on July 1, 2012. In her new role, Barbara oversees NTTF appointments, contracts, and promotions. She also coordinates the academic program review process. Her direct reports are Undergraduate Studies, Graduate Studies, and International Affairs.
[Image removed by sender. Meg Mattson]Meg Mattson is our newest staff member. As Executive Assistant to Barbara Altmann, Meg assumes management of her calendar and schedule. She provides support to the NTTF promotion process and staffs program review, along with Sonja Runberg. Meg will also be working with Ruth D. Keele to implement CourseLeaf and will assume primary responsibility for the internal approval processes for new curriculum proposals.










Forward to a colleague<http://us5.forward-to-friend1.com/forward?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=42509bc185&e=8533305d1c>.

You are receiving this email because you are a member of the University of Oregon faculty or administration.

Our mailing address is:
Academic Affairs
1258 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403

Add us to your address book<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage2.com/vcard?u=931d38d409da92c60ebe48f66&id=69a927b783>

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Faculty Candidate Talk, PPPM dept'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

The PPPM Department is holding a talk by a faculty candidate with the title "The Educational Impact and Policy Implications of a Middle-Grades Literacy Intervention: Lessons from a Regression-Discontinuity Design".  This will take place tomorrow, Wednesday January 9, from 2:00-3:15pm in Room 403 of the Ford Alumni Center.

The candidate, Shaun Dougherty, has applied for a core assistant-level teaching position in the Master of Public Administration program and PPPM thought the subject might be of interest to both our teaching and research faculty.  The flyer for this talk is attached.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

subject: b'coe-fac: COE SAS Workshops'
html:
b'
Hello,
Please feel free to forward information on these workshops to students who might be interested.  An email with this info went out to both the graduate and undergraduate listservs last week, but I know some students may need additional encouragement:). Let me know if you have any questions or suggestions for other workshops.
Thanks,
Lisa

Hello,
The COE\xe2\x80\x99s Student Academic Services office is offering some great workshops for COE students this term.

Here are our Winter Term workshops:
Jan 17th:  Student Diversity Affairs Committee Meeting
Jan 25th:  NES/ORELA Review
Feb 8th:  APA Style
Mar 5th:  Caffeine with the Dean


SDAC Meeting:  Learn About Non Traditional Students
Thursday, January 17th, Noon \xe2\x80\x93 1:30 p.m.
Lokey ED 119
Learn about what it means to be a non-traditional student with discussion from special guest, Gretchen Jewett, Director of Nontraditional and Veteran Education and Support from the Office of the Dean of Students.


Friday, Jan 25th, 3-5:30 pm
NES/ORELA Review
HEDCO 230T
The NES/ORELA Review workshop covers the NES/ORELA Elementary Education Subtest I and II exams.  Join us for this interactive review!
RSVP here to attend:  https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_daJyXVypgdQjiOp

APA Style
Friday, Feb 8th, 12:30 p.m. - 1:30 p.m.
Lokey ED 119
Have questions about mastering APA (American Psychological Association) style for your papers?  This workshop will help you learn to create properly spaced documents, insert headers and create a properly formatted cover page.  In addition, you will learn how to cite valid research sources in the body of the document, tying those citations to the correctly formatted source listed on the reference page.  The workshop will also help you learn how to navigate the APA manual and where to find online APA resources.  RSVP here to attend<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_9Sljd15fjWBULQx> the APA Style workshop.

Tuesday, March 5th, 2 p.m.-4 p.m.
Caffeine with the Dean
HEDCO 130B
The only thing Dean Bullis likes more than talking is listening (and maybe fly fishing). Drop by to have a chat, and the coffee\xe2\x80\x99s on him!  Topics could include anything from out-of-print books to breathable waders.

Let me know if you have any questions or suggestions for additional workshops.  For information, please visit our website at https://education.uoregon.edu/sas-workshops.

Lisa

Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607
Fax:  541-346-5818

subject: b'coe-fac: Library fund awards'
html:
b'
FYI-

Dear Colleagues,

I would like to encourage you and your faculty to apply for the Library's 33rd Annual Stanley B. Greenfield Faculty Awards Program.  This endowed program gives faculty an opportunity to request special funds for library research materials that typically fall outside of departmental acquisition budgets.

This year we will be granting up to $50,000 in awards...typically, awards values have ranged from $100 - $2,000 per request.  Faculty may submit more than one request and may also submit collaborative proposals.

Follow this link for guidelines and the online application.

http://library.uoregon.edu/info/greenfield/index.html

Deadline for submissions is Friday, March 29, 2013.  Awards are announced mid-spring.


Deborah A. Carver
Philip H. Knight Dean of Libraries
UO Libraries
University of Oregon
541-346-1892
dcarver at uoregon.edu<mailto:dcarver at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Wayne Morse Center announces Resident Scholars for 2013-14'
html:
b'
FYI - see below

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218
Eric Priest and Colin Koopman selected

Is this email not displaying correctly?
View it in your browser<http://us5.campaign-archive1.com/?u=8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127&id=461a4ab805&e=>.



[Wayne Morse Center]<http://www.waynemorsecenter.uoregon.edu/>


The Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics is pleased to announce the appointment of UO faculty as Resident Scholars for 2013-14. Both scholars are active in media and internet studies, and will participate with the Wayne Morse Center in its upcoming theme of inquiryMedia and Democracy<http://waynemorsecenter.uoregon.edu/current-theme/2013-15-theme-media-and-democracy/>. >From fall 2013 through spring 2015 the center will examine evolving changes in our contemporary media as well as the dramatic cultural, political, and legal transitions influenced by new media.

Eric Priest - Resident Scholar in Law
[http://gallery.mailchimp.com/8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127/images/priest3a5cd2.jpg]Eric Priest is an assistant professor of law specializing in intellectual property law and responses to new technology. He will continue his research on Copyright, Media and Democracy in China. China is the world's fastest growing media market, but is a market evolving in the shadow of pervasive censorship.  Some Western scholars argue that copyright plays a key role in free discourse by enabling media producers to be self-sustaining and therefore freer from government largesse and control. China is now revising its copyright law. Does copyright law have the potential to promote a more independent media in China?

Priest has been at the UO since 2009. He was a resident fellow at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard Law School, where he researched internet content filtering in Asia for the OpenNet Initiative. He also worked in China as the CEO of Noank Creative Internet Technologies.

Professor Priest will co-teach a fall 2013 class on Advanced Topics in Intellectual Property Law with 2013 Wayne Morse Chair of Law and Politics William "Terry" Fisher. Fisher, a noted scholar in intellectual property, is on the faculty of Harvard Law School and director of the Berkman Center for Internet and Society. The class will examine emerging issues that are important to lawyers and practitioners of new media and will be open to both law and graduate students.

Colin Koopman - Resident Scholar in Philosophy
[http://gallery.mailchimp.com/8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127/images/Koopman_Colin_2__OFFICIAL_UO15da5a.jpg]Colin Koopman<http://pages.uoregon.edu/uophil/faculty/profiles/koopman/>, assistant professor in philosophy, is an innovative scholar specializing in political theory with a current focus on the history and future of the politics of information. He will work on his third book, titled Infopolitics:Transformations of Public and Private, focusing on how "infopolitics" is radically reshaping publicity and privacy today through socio-technologies such as the internet. Information is becoming politicized, and politics increasingly uses information in new and different ways. Koopman is writing on the philosophical meanings of these transformations.

Koopman has been at the UO since 2009. His previous books are Pragmatism as Transition and Genealogy as Critique. He received funding for a new class on "Internet, Society and Philosophy" and a Rippey Innovative Teaching Award for "Justice Matters" with Wayne Morse Senior Faculty Fellow Dan Tichenor. He was featured in A Philosopher Ponders the Public Sphere<http://cascade.uoregon.edu/spring2011/humanities/a-philosopher-ponders-the-virt/> in UO's CASCade Magazine.

Koopman will assist the Wayne Morse Center in a symposium in January 2014 on Information, Technology and Social Progess. He will also help plan the visit of Wendy Hui Kyong Chun of Brown University. Chun will visit the UO in winter 2015 as Wayne Morse Chair of Law and Politics.



 <https://twitter.com/morsecenter> follow on Twitter<https://www.twitter.com/morsecenter/>| friend on Facebook<http://www.facebook.com/waynemorsecenter>

Copyright (c) 2013 Wayne Morse Center, All rights reserved.

Our mailing address is:
Wayne Morse Center
1515 Agate Street
Eugene, Or 97403

Add us to your address book<http://uoregon.us5.list-manage2.com/vcard?u=8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127&id=ddcd36c508>

haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218
Eric Priest and Colin Koopman selected

Is this email not displaying correctly?
View it in your browser<http://us5.campaign-archive1.com/?u=8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127&id=461a4ab805&e=>.



[Wayne Morse Center]<http://www.waynemorsecenter.uoregon.edu/>


The Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics is pleased to announce the appointment of UO faculty as Resident Scholars for 2013-14. Both scholars are active in media and internet studies, and will participate with the Wayne Morse Center in its upcoming theme of inquiryMedia and Democracy<http://waynemorsecenter.uoregon.edu/current-theme/2013-15-theme-media-and-democracy/>. >From fall 2013 through spring 2015 the center will examine evolving changes in our contemporary media as well as the dramatic cultural, political, and legal transitions influenced by new media.

Eric Priest - Resident Scholar in Law
[http://gallery.mailchimp.com/8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127/images/priest3a5cd2.jpg]Eric Priest is an assistant professor of law specializing in intellectual property law and responses to new technology. He will continue his research on Copyright, Media and Democracy in China. China is the world's fastest growing media market, but is a market evolving in the shadow of pervasive censorship.  Some Western scholars argue that copyright plays a key role in free discourse by enabling media producers to be self-sustaining and therefore freer from government largesse and control. China is now revising its copyright law. Does copyright law have the potential to promote a more independent media in China?

Priest has been at the UO since 2009. He was a resident fellow at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard Law School, where he researched internet content filtering in Asia for the OpenNet Initiative. He also worked in China as the CEO of Noank Creative Internet Technologies.

Professor Priest will co-teach a fall 2013 class on Advanced Topics in Intellectual Property Law with 2013 Wayne Morse Chair of Law and Politics William "Terry" Fisher. Fisher, a noted scholar in intellectual property, is on the faculty of Harvard Law School and director of the Berkman Center for Internet and Society. The class will examine emerging issues that are important to lawyers and practitioners of new media and will be open to both law and graduate students.

Colin Koopman - Resident Scholar in Philosophy
[http://gallery.mailchimp.com/8a06b91ec7529a459284ee127/images/Koopman_Colin_2__OFFICIAL_UO15da5a.jpg]Colin Koopman<http://pages.uoregon.edu/uophil/faculty/profiles/koopman/>, assistant professor in philosophy, is an innovative scholar specializing in political theory with a current focus on the history and future of the politics of information. He will work on his third book, titled Infopolitics:Transformations of Public and Private, focusing on how "infopolitics" is radically reshaping publicity and privacy today through socio-technologies such as the internet. Information is becoming politicized, and politics increasingly uses information in new and different ways. Koopman is writing on the philosophical meanings of these transformations.

Koopman has been at the UO since 2009. His previous books are Pragmatism as Transition and Genealogy as Critique. He received funding for a new class on "Internet, Society and Philosophy" and a Rippey Innovative Teaching Award for "Justice Matters" with Wayne Morse Senior Faculty Fellow Dan Tichenor. He was featured in A Philosopher Ponders the Public Sphere<http://cascade.uoregon.edu/spring2011/humanities/a-philosopher-ponders-the-virt/> in UO's CASCade Magazine.

Koopman will assist the Wayne Morse Center in a symposium in January 2014 on Information, Technology and Social Progess. He will also help plan the visit of Wendy Hui Kyong Chun of Brown University. Chun will visit the UO in winter 2015 as Wayne Morse Chair of Law and Politics.

subject: b'coe-fac: Post Season Contests and Final Examinations'
html:
b'
FYI - if you have not received this message already.  Please share with your GTFs with teaching responsibilities.

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218


MEMORANDUM

TO:                              University of Oregon Faculty

FROM:                         Doug Blandy, Senior Vice Provost
                                    Academic Affairs

SUBJECT:                     Post Season Contests and Final Examinations

Several University of Oregon athletic teams have a strong possibility of being invited to post-season competition.  This type of representation of our University can have many positive ramifications for the full University community.

The athletic events listed below are official "University-sponsored events," and as such, provide a legitimate excuse for student participants (e.g. team members, cheerleaders, band members, etc.) to be absent from regularly scheduled final exams.  Student members of these tournament groups are encouraged to speak with their instructors, prior to the athletic event, to arrange for the completion of course work and final examinations in the case of such an anticipated absence.  Faculty can verify a student's membership in an affected group by contacting Leanne Brooks, Assistant Athletic Director at lrbrooks at uoregon.edu<mailto:lrbrooks at uoregon.edu> or 346-2255.

Faculty are authorized to use the following procedures to conduct final exams of affected students:


  1.  Official proctored examinations may be given off-campus and administered by a senior tenured faculty member and a senior representative of the Department of Intercollegiate Athletics.  The University Testing Center is also available to proctor exams.  The Assistant Athletic Director for Academics will work with the faculty member to arrange for the exam, including picking it up from the faculty member and returning the completed exam to the faculty member by express mail.  Each exam will be proctored by the senior faculty member.  This option is open to student athletes and support group students (e.g. cheerleaders, band members, etc.)
  2.  Make up examinations may be arranged by the affected student and faculty member.  The make up examination should be scheduled prior to the second week of the following term and at the soonest opportunity as mutually agreed upon by the student and faculty member.  Faculty members should submit grades of incomplete pending completion of the make up examination.

Both of the suggested alternatives reflect one type or another of special accommodations that individual faculty have made in the past to individual students or groups of students in some of our courses.  I recognize that considerable extra work by faculty may be involved in preparing a duplicate examination, and those efforts are greatly appreciated.  President Michael Gottfredson, Provost Jim Bean, Athletic Director Rob Mullens, and I sincerely thank you for your cooperation in this matter.

If you are faced with a situation you are unable to resolve, please contact me at dblandy at uoregon.edu<mailto:dblandy at uoregon.edu> or 346-3081.

Potential NCAA Championship Schedule Conflicts for Winter

Men's Basketball, Women's Basketball

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: deans-dirs: A Request for Your Help in Identifying Potential Distinguished Scholarship Applicants'
html:
b'
FYI - please keep these opportunities in mind for your deserving students.  Note the deadline for submission of names - March 15th.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

From:             Dave Hubin
                     Senior Assistant to the President

Subject:        A "Distinguished Scholarships" Reception for Outstanding Sophomores and Juniors
The University continues its commitment to strengthen institutional support for outstanding undergraduate students who may be competitive for such distinguished national scholarships as the Rhodes, the Marshall, the Truman, the Churchill, the Mitchell, the Gates/Cambridge, the Fulbright, the Boren, and so forth.  During the last three years, 106 nationally competitive scholarships have been awarded to our students--honors that could not have occurred without referrals from our faculty.
I am writing again this year to ask your help in developing a list of students the President will invite to a reception and information session this spring. The gathering will be for this year's juniors who might compete for scholarships like the Rhodes, the Marshall, the Mitchell next fall and for outstanding sophomores who might consider the Goldwater, the Udall or the Hollings or begin taking steps that would lead to competitive future applications.  President Gottfredson will be extending them a personal invitation to the reception.
I hope you will share this request with colleagues, including of course faculty advisors, who might also be in positions to suggest students.  Thank you for your help.
Please send the names (including student numbers and e-mail addresses if possible) of sophomores and juniors who you believe should be encouraged to apply for a distinguished scholarship, to pkegel at uoregon.edu<mailto:pkegel at uoregon.edu>, by Friday, March 15th. The reception this year for students will be held on Thursday, April 25th.
Feel free to call if you have any questions.

P.S.  I also invite you to look at our new website to learn more about our Distinguished Scholarships Initiative -( http://distinguishedscholars.uoregon.edu/.  Through this website and other communications, we will be keeping you apprised of additional activities and events related to these opportunities.


David R. Hubin, Ph.D.

Senior Assistant to the President

University of Oregon

541-346-3036

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Fulbright Opportunity in Norway - Secondary Education'
html:
b'
FYI - please share as appropriate.

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218
From: Rena Levin <rena at fulbright.no<mailto:rena at fulbright.no>>
Date: March 15, 2013, 3:45:14 AM PDT
To: "sbaker at uoregon.edu<mailto:sbaker at uoregon.edu>" <sbaker at uoregon.edu<mailto:sbaker at uoregon.edu>>, "bullism at uoregon.edu<mailto:bullism at uoregon.edu>" <bullism at uoregon.edu<mailto:bullism at uoregon.edu>>, "ekamee at uoregon.edu<mailto:ekamee at uoregon.edu>" <ekamee at uoregon.edu<mailto:ekamee at uoregon.edu>>
Cc: "cmaas at oregon.uoregon.edu<mailto:cmaas at oregon.uoregon.edu>" <cmaas at oregon.uoregon.edu<mailto:cmaas at oregon.uoregon.edu>>, "ctl at uoregon.edu<mailto:ctl at uoregon.edu>" <ctl at uoregon.edu<mailto:ctl at uoregon.edu>>, "coesas at uoregon.edu<mailto:coesas at uoregon.edu>" <coesas at uoregon.edu<mailto:coesas at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: Fulbright Opportunity in Norway - Secondary Education
Dear Drs. Bullis, Kame'enui and Baker,

This is a quick note that I hope you will share with your colleagues at the University of Oregon. We at the US-Norway Fulbright Foundation are trying to spread the word about our Roving Scholar grant-a unique Fulbright opportunity in Norway for those who have teaching experience, are interested in secondary education and have a keen interest in American Studies (history, geography, literature, cultural studies, etc.) Roving Scholars are based in Oslo but spend up to 50% of their time traveling all over Norway visiting secondary schools. Roving scholars are primarily guest speakers who engage secondary students in English on a variety of self-determined topics related to American Studies. A portion of their time is also spent offering workshops for teachers-in-service and teachers-in-training.  The Fulbright grant includes a healthy stipend, on top of which all travel expenses, including a generous per diem, are paid for by the Fulbright Roving Scholars Program. This unique opportunity is currently only available for U.S. Scholars to Norway.

We are seeking scholars who are interested in the intersection of the theory, policy, and practicalities of education. As a Roving Scholar, one is offered an unparalleled opportunity to build teaching experience in a new educational setting while forging professional and personal ties through hands-on academic immersion.

We are seeking applications from interested and qualified candidates, through the usual Fulbright process (deadline August 1 for the 2014-15 school year). Please note a Ph.D. is not required for this Fulbright grant. University faculty as well as field supervisors, adjuncts or lecturers, and experienced classroom teachers with master's degrees are encouraged to apply.

For more information please see our Roving Scholar Program web pages: http://www.fulbright.no/RovingScholars.  Several Roving Scholar alumni are available to communicate with interested applicants. Please feel free to contact me, if you would like more information.

The program has been growing in recent years. Please help us recruit exceptional candidates by sharing this information with colleagues, or posting this information to relevant lists and emailing your educational contacts in other parts of the country. We sincerely appreciate your help in spreading the word.

Sincerely,

Rena Levin
Program Officer
US-Norway Fulbright Foundation

Subject: Fulbright Opportunity in Norway - Secondary Education
Dear Drs. Bullis, Kame'enui and Baker,

This is a quick note that I hope you will share with your colleagues at the University of Oregon. We at the US-Norway Fulbright Foundation are trying to spread the word about our Roving Scholar grant-a unique Fulbright opportunity in Norway for those who have teaching experience, are interested in secondary education and have a keen interest in American Studies (history, geography, literature, cultural studies, etc.) Roving Scholars are based in Oslo but spend up to 50% of their time traveling all over Norway visiting secondary schools. Roving scholars are primarily guest speakers who engage secondary students in English on a variety of self-determined topics related to American Studies. A portion of their time is also spent offering workshops for teachers-in-service and teachers-in-training.  The Fulbright grant includes a healthy stipend, on top of which all travel expenses, including a generous per diem, are paid for by the Fulbright Roving Scholars Program. This unique opportunity is currently only available for U.S. Scholars to Norway.

We are seeking scholars who are interested in the intersection of the theory, policy, and practicalities of education. As a Roving Scholar, one is offered an unparalleled opportunity to build teaching experience in a new educational setting while forging professional and personal ties through hands-on academic immersion.

We are seeking applications from interested and qualified candidates, through the usual Fulbright process (deadline August 1 for the 2014-15 school year). Please note a Ph.D. is not required for this Fulbright grant. University faculty as well as field supervisors, adjuncts or lecturers, and experienced classroom teachers with master's degrees are encouraged to apply.

For more information please see our Roving Scholar Program web pages: http://www.fulbright.no/RovingScholars.  Several Roving Scholar alumni are available to communicate with interested applicants. Please feel free to contact me, if you would like more information.

The program has been growing in recent years. Please help us recruit exceptional candidates by sharing this information with colleagues, or posting this information to relevant lists and emailing your educational contacts in other parts of the country. We sincerely appreciate your help in spreading the word.

Sincerely,

Rena Levin
Program Officer
US-Norway Fulbright Foundation

subject: b'coe-fac: Using Online Video Oral Histories'
html:
b'
FYI -

Upcoming presentation that may be of interest to those that want to incorporate oral histories into courses.

Katy Lenn


"Using Online Video Oral Histories in University Courses across Disciplines"
Jill Goodman Gould and Gail Gradowski, Santa Clara University
Wednesday, March 20, 10:30 a.m.
Knight Library Browsing Room

The use of online video oral histories in university courses across the disciplines will be the subject of a talk by Santa Clara University English Professor Jill Goodman Gould and SCU Instruction Librarian Gail Gradowski on Wednesday, March 20, at 10:30 a.m. in Knight Library's Browsing Room.

Thanks to the Internet, a wide range of oral histories is now readily available to educators, from small collections like Ball State University's video interviews of 40 members of the U.S. Army's First Infantry Division from the Vietnam War to large archives of oral histories such the Densho Digital Archive of over 600 video interviews documenting the Japanese American internment during WWII.

Jill Goodman Gould and Gail Gradowski will share their own experiences using a videotape collection of Holocaust testimonies in an advanced writing course at Santa Clara University and will survey a range of other university courses in various disciplines that currently use online interviews and testimonies as part of their curriculum.
Please join us on Wednesday, March 20, to learn about the wealth of oral history material and supporting resources available for teaching in multiple disciplines.

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20130315/47117337/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Commencement Regalia Rental'
html:
b'
Hello,
Commencement is Monday, June 17 and like last year, the COE ceremony will be held from 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm in Matthew Knight Arena.  Here is information about ordering your regalia for the ceremony.

Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. To guarantee exact hood colors please make your order by May 2.  After that time it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.  The cut off for ordering faculty regalia is May 17.  After that date, the Duck Store will charge a late fee.  If you are interested in custom regalia, that takes 8 weeks, so please contact Stacy Miller at the Duck Store no later than April 19.

Order your regalia here:
http://uoduckstore.com/faculty/renting_regalia/
On the order form, choose the Spring 2013 ceremony.  The COE will cover the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, so choose 'bill department' in the payment area.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607
Fax:  541-346-5818

subject: b'coe-fac: New free CCSS book from two retired CoE faculty'
html:
b'
Moursund, D. and Sylwester, R. Editors (March 2013). Common Core State Standards for K-12 Education in America. Eugene, OR: Information Age Education. 

The Common Core State Standards (CCSS) initiative began in the United States in 2010. Its initial emphasis on Math and English Language Arts has grown to include Science and History/Social Studies.

Recently, Information Age Education has published a series of ten IAE Newsletters on CCSS. These ten newsletters have been integrated into a book, Common Core State Standards for K-12 Education in America. The set of newsletters has been augmented by an Appendix, Goals of Education in the United States. The book is available free. See http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/249-common-core-state-standards-for-k-12-education-in-america.html for the Microsoft Word document and http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/248-common-core-state-standards-for-k-12-education-in-america.html for the PDF.

This book is an experiment in a new way to put together an edited collection of writings. Chapter 10 of the book contains a brief introduction to a number of topics that are suitable for making into additional chapters. Potential authors are encouraged to contact David Moursund (moursund at uorgon.edu) or Robert Sylwester (bobsyl at uoregon.edu) about submitting a chapter based on Chapter 10 ideas or other ideas of their own choice. The book will \xe2\x80\x9cgrow\xe2\x80\x9d as new chapters are integrated in.

For other free math education materials from Information Age Education see http://iae-pedia.org/Free_Math_Education_Materials. To access all of the free Information Age Education materials go to http://iae-pedia.org/Main_Page. 

I would appreciate it if you would give this book some publicity.

Thanks,

Dave
-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: Position Opening - Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies'
html:
b'
FYI-

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies
Posting: 13083I
Location: Eugene
Closes: Open Until Filled

Note: UO Employees only



The Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies oversees undergraduate education at the University of Oregon. Primary responsibility is to lead the university community in providing exceptional undergraduate education within the environment of a major research institution. The Vice Provost coordinates a range of programs and services, working with the Office of Academic Affairs and academic units across the campus to ensure coherent curricula and policies, stimulate academic engagement and research opportunities, and cultivate a culture of intellectual curiosity for UO undergraduates.
The Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies reports to the Vice Provost for Academic Affairs and is a member of the Vice Provosts' Council. The Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies has management and budget authority over all component programs in the Division of Undergraduate Studies: Academic Advising, Accessible Education Center, First-Year Programs, and the Teaching and Learning Center. The Vice Provost is expected to marshal the units around a common vision to enhance the academic success of undergraduate students.

The Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies works closely with the Undergraduate Council to review curricular proposals, develop policies, and set short and long-term goals for undergraduate education. The Vice Provost works with academic units to implement new programs and revisions to undergraduate education. The Vice Provost also works with and facilitates communication among the UO President, Provost and vice presidents; academic deans and associate deans; faculty and administrative committees; student groups; Associated Students of the University of Oregon; and other constituencies dedicated to the success and excellence of undergraduate education at the University.

Major Duties:

  *   Participate in and provide leadership for University and OUS initiatives in areas such as general education design and outcomes; curriculum and program development; grade culture; excellence in undergraduate teaching; distance and online education; articulation and transfer arrangements; and student retention and academic success.
  *   Work with the Office of Academic Affairs and the Dean and Associate Deans of the Graduate School to review academic departments and programs.
  *   Formulate and implement a strategy of short- and long-term goals for faculty and student engagement in all stages of the undergraduate experience.
  *   Coordinate with the College of Arts and Sciences, the largest provider of undergraduate instruction, on initiatives related to undergraduate education.
  *   Help build and oversee targeted programs for undergraduates in the lower division, including Freshman Interest Groups, Freshman Seminars, and programs for students on probation.
  *   Collaborate with other units on and help oversee such upper-division initiatives as distinguished scholarship opportunities and undergraduate research.
  *   Work with the Division of Student Affairs to oversee such academic initiatives as the Global Scholars Hall, Residential Freshman Interest Groups, SuperNova, and Community Conversations.
  *   Work closely with the Vice President for Development to cultivate fund-raising strategies that directly support undergraduate teaching and education.
  *   Work with the Division of Enrollment Management and Office of Equity and Inclusion to develop programs for outreach to and recruitment of underrepresented students.  Support the University's commitment to creating a more inclusive and diverse undergraduate experience.
  *   Collaborate with the Office of International Affairs and other units to support the academic success of international undergraduate students.
  *   Convene and work closely with the Undergraduate Council to establish criteria for excellent general education courses and to ensure coherence, quality, and rigor across the curriculum.
  *   Work with the Office of the Dean of Students to combat academic dishonesty and with other units campuswide to promote a culture prizing academic integrity.
  *   Oversee continued development of outstanding academic services for undergraduate students, including Academic Advising, Accessible Education Center, Center for Multicultural Academic Excellence, First-Year Programs, PE and Recreation, and the Teaching and Learning Center (including the Teaching Effectiveness Program, PathwayOregon, MacNair Scholars, TRiO, and Student Support Services), and liaise effectively with other divisions such as Student Affairs and Enrollment Management.
  *   Work with and facilitate communication among affiliated programs that foster academic excellence such as the Robert D. Clark Honors College<http://honors.uoregon.edu/>, College Scholars Program, Faculty Perspective Seminars, Faculty Firesides, Community Conversations, Phi Beta Kappa, and Distinguished Scholarships.
Experience and Education

  *   Doctoral degree (or its equivalent) and excellent record of scholarship. Rank of professor highly desirable.
  *   Demonstrated commitment to excellence in undergraduate education, preferably at the university, state, national and international levels.
  *   Demonstrated leadership and administrative experience.  This administrative experience should give evidence of an ability to:
1.       Support and enhance a diverse learning environment;
2.       Work effectively with faculty, staff and students from a variety of diverse backgrounds;
3.       Relate well to students, faculty, and staff, especially in a team setting;
4.       Manage complex programs;
5.       Manage major operational budgets;
6.       Engage fully with the missions of a research university;
7.       Speak and write effectively across a variety of professional settings;
8.       Facilitate undergraduate student success and retention;
9.       Cultivate campus, state, national and international relationships to strengthen undergraduate education.

  *   Demonstrated ability to cultivate collaborative relationships with faculty, staff, students, other administrators, as well as constituencies at state, national and international levels.
Salary

Salary range is $145,000 to $160,000 based on experience and qualifications; excellent benefit package.
This position is subject to a credit and criminal background check.

Application Procedure:

To assure full consideration, applications must be received by April 22, 2013. The position will remain open until filled.

Please send:

  1.  A cover letter, which addresses applicants qualifications and interest in the position
  2.  Current Curriculum Vitae that includes dates of employment
  3.  Name, phone number, and address for five professional references

Electronic PDF submissions are preferred, but not required.
Send to: email - undergradvpsrch at uoregon.edu<mailto:undergradvpsrch at uoregon.edu>

Mail:

Office of Senior Vice President and Provost
1258 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1258



The University of Oregon is an equal-opportunity, affirmative-action institution committed to cultural diversity and compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act.
