subject: b'coe-fac: 2013 RIGE I3 Awards Announcement'
html:
b'
FYI - Congratulations to Jeff Sprague and his team!

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

From: "kiltie at uoregon.edu<mailto:kiltie at uoregon.edu>" <kiltie at uoregon.edu<mailto:kiltie at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Monday, April 15, 2013 10:54 AM
To: "deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>" <deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Subject: deans-dirs: 2013 RIGE I3 Awards Announcement

Research, Innovation and Graduate Education (RIGE) congratulates the recipients of the 2013 Incubating Interdisciplinary Initiatives (I3) Award:


*         Chris Bone, Geography, "Drivers of the Beetle Empire: Understanding the Coupling of Climate Change and Forest Management in Bark Beetle Outbreaks," with team members: Patrick Bartlein, Geography; Daniel Gavin, Geography; Allen Malony, Computer and Information Science; Cassandra Moseley, Institute for a Sustainable Environment. Award amount: $49,969.


*         Patricia Dewey, Arts and Administration Program, "The Role of Arts Programs in Fostering an Organizational Culture of Patient-Centered Care and an Environment of Healing in Hospitals and Hospices," with team members: Pranjal Mehta, Psychology; Josh Snodgrass, Anthropology; Kristin Yarris, International Studies; Laura Zaerr, School of Music and Dance. Research will take place at PeaceHealth Sacred Heart Medical Center, RiverBend and Samaritan Health Services' Center for Health Research and Quality. Award amount: $50,000.


*         Jeffrey Sprague, College of Education and Institute on Violence and Destructive Behavior, "PRIDE: Positive and Restorative Investment in Discipline Reform in Education," with team members: John A. Inglish, Technical Assistance and Consulting Services; Erik Girvan, School of Law; Claudia G. Vincent, Institute on Violence and Destructive Behavior. Award amount: $48,499.


*         Richard Taylor, Physics Department and Material Science Institute, "Fractal Interconnects as a Generic Interface to Neurons," with team members: Darren Johnson, Chemistry and Materials Science Institute; Miriam Deutsch, Physics and Oregon Center for Optics; Cris Niell, Biology and Institute of Neuroscience. Award amount: $50,000.

The I3 awards furnish twelve months of funding to support the research projects listed above. These four teams were chosen from a pool of fifteen applicant teams.

Applications were reviewed and considered by a group composed of faculty from the Research Advisory Board and key RIGE staff members who made recommendations to the Vice President for Research and Innovation for final decision.

"The submissions we received for this award program provided significant evidence that interdisciplinarity is integral to the way UO researchers view and address major challenges in all areas of life - from health care to the environment to education. I have great appreciation for the faculty members and staff on the review group for their thoughtful consideration and comments on each proposal. These reviews were essential to the decision-making process. I also appreciate the teams who submitted proposals," said Kimberly Andrews Espy, vice president for research and innovation. "It was gratifying to our office to receive so many outstanding proposals."

The I3 award program is new this year. It aims to foster interdisciplinary research groups at UO in support of developing of large-scale projects. I3 partnerships emerge from shared research interests across UO departments and colleges, and are developed with an eye towards external funding opportunities, UO's institutional strengths, and academic priorities. Partnerships may also include external institutions of strategic importance. Awards were distributed to teams that span academic divisions: natural science, social science, education, law, arts, music, education and two external organizations.

More information about the 2013 I3 Awards and other programming offered through Research Development Services can be found at http://rfd.uoregon.edu/.

Subject: deans-dirs: 2013 RIGE I3 Awards Announcement

Research, Innovation and Graduate Education (RIGE) congratulates the recipients of the 2013 Incubating Interdisciplinary Initiatives (I3) Award:


*         Chris Bone, Geography, "Drivers of the Beetle Empire: Understanding the Coupling of Climate Change and Forest Management in Bark Beetle Outbreaks," with team members: Patrick Bartlein, Geography; Daniel Gavin, Geography; Allen Malony, Computer and Information Science; Cassandra Moseley, Institute for a Sustainable Environment. Award amount: $49,969.


*         Patricia Dewey, Arts and Administration Program, "The Role of Arts Programs in Fostering an Organizational Culture of Patient-Centered Care and an Environment of Healing in Hospitals and Hospices," with team members: Pranjal Mehta, Psychology; Josh Snodgrass, Anthropology; Kristin Yarris, International Studies; Laura Zaerr, School of Music and Dance. Research will take place at PeaceHealth Sacred Heart Medical Center, RiverBend and Samaritan Health Services' Center for Health Research and Quality. Award amount: $50,000.


*         Jeffrey Sprague, College of Education and Institute on Violence and Destructive Behavior, "PRIDE: Positive and Restorative Investment in Discipline Reform in Education," with team members: John A. Inglish, Technical Assistance and Consulting Services; Erik Girvan, School of Law; Claudia G. Vincent, Institute on Violence and Destructive Behavior. Award amount: $48,499.


*         Richard Taylor, Physics Department and Material Science Institute, "Fractal Interconnects as a Generic Interface to Neurons," with team members: Darren Johnson, Chemistry and Materials Science Institute; Miriam Deutsch, Physics and Oregon Center for Optics; Cris Niell, Biology and Institute of Neuroscience. Award amount: $50,000.

The I3 awards furnish twelve months of funding to support the research projects listed above. These four teams were chosen from a pool of fifteen applicant teams.

Applications were reviewed and considered by a group composed of faculty from the Research Advisory Board and key RIGE staff members who made recommendations to the Vice President for Research and Innovation for final decision.

"The submissions we received for this award program provided significant evidence that interdisciplinarity is integral to the way UO researchers view and address major challenges in all areas of life - from health care to the environment to education. I have great appreciation for the faculty members and staff on the review group for their thoughtful consideration and comments on each proposal. These reviews were essential to the decision-making process. I also appreciate the teams who submitted proposals," said Kimberly Andrews Espy, vice president for research and innovation. "It was gratifying to our office to receive so many outstanding proposals."

The I3 award program is new this year. It aims to foster interdisciplinary research groups at UO in support of developing of large-scale projects. I3 partnerships emerge from shared research interests across UO departments and colleges, and are developed with an eye towards external funding opportunities, UO's institutional strengths, and academic priorities. Partnerships may also include external institutions of strategic importance. Awards were distributed to teams that span academic divisions: natural science, social science, education, law, arts, music, education and two external organizations.

More information about the 2013 I3 Awards and other programming offered through Research Development Services can be found at http://rfd.uoregon.edu/.

subject: b'coe-fac: Regalia for Commencement'
html:
b'
Hello,
Commencement is Monday, June 17 and like last year, the COE ceremony will be held from 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm in Matthew Knight Arena.  The cut off for ensuring accurate hood colors for faculty regalia is MAY 2.  If you have not yet ordered your regalia, please do so today or tomorrow to ensure you get the correct colors.  A list of faculty who have already ordered regalia is below.

Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. After May 2,  it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.  The cut off for ordering faculty regalia is May 17.  After that date, the Duck Store will charge a late fee.

Order your regalia here:
http://uoduckstore.com/faculty/renting_regalia/

On the order form, choose the Spring 2013 ceremony.  The COE will cover the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, so choose 'bill department' in the payment area.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu.

As of last Friday, here are the faculty who have ordered rental regalia from the Duck store:

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Merit Raise Review Process'
html:
b'
COE Faculty:

I write to inform you of the upcoming review process that we in the COE will follow in assigning the merit raises that were announced by the UO this spring

Please know that the salary adjustment program for faculty is only for those individuals who the UO and United Academics (the union that has been established this academic year) have determined not to be represented by the union. Therefore, at this point, only those faculty who are unrepresented by the union are eligible for the merit raise. The list of eligible faculty was established through an extensive legal review process on the part of the union and the UO. I must be honest that the list of unrepresented faculty is short and most of you will not be eligible for this merit raise at this point in time.

In the next few weeks, we will be gathering personnel reviews on faculty who are  not represented by the union and eligible for the merit raise. Parallel with that faculty review process will be a performance review of COE Officers of Administration. Eligible faculty and Officers of Administration in the COE will be recommended for raises by the end of the spring term with raises beginning July 1.

It is my understanding that part of the collective bargaining agreement will address the terms governing faculty salary adjustments in the future. Accordingly, faculty who are represented by the union may be assigned raises based on those yet to be finalized guidelines.

This current salary adjustment process is unique for us all as we move to become a unionized faculty. If you have questions, please feel free to contact your immediate supervisor, your union representative, or me.


Mike

-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: All Commencement Rental Regalia Must be Reordered!'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,
According to my contact at the Duck store, their system did not record all of the data for faculty regalia orders (see the message below).  I'm afraid I must ask anyone who plans on renting regalia from the Duck store for Commencement to go and order your regalia again (or for the first time if you've yet to order it) and they will ensure that there are no duplicate orders.  Thanks for your patience!  Order your regalia here:  http://uoduckstore.com/faculty/renting_regalia/

Lisa

From: Stacy Miller [mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu]
Sent: Monday, April 29, 2013 13:56
To: Lisa Fortin
Subject: RE: COE Faculty

Lisa

WE found out this morning that our system had an intermittent problem that may have caused some order not to be captured and some orders have only partial information.  This is a far bigger problem than we originally thought.  The system has been fixed but I just sent a message to Amy asking her to relay my request to have all Faculty orders re-submitted in case the system did not capture some of them.  If you could request that your Faculty re-submit that would be great.  We will not duplicate orders so there is no reason for anyone to be concerned about that.  Sorry for the trouble and have a good week.

Stacy Miller
Academic Regalia Coordinator
Main Store Sportswear Supervisor
The Duck Store

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Innovation Series - Sharing with others'
html:
b'
FYI - please note that RSVPs are requested due to limited space.

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

You're Invited:

UO's Technology Transfer Services invites you to join us for the next Innovation Management Workshop:

The "O"s of Sharing:  Options, Obligations, and Opportunities

Whether you are sharing research tools, know-how, software, or digital works, you should know about the three "O"s of sharing with others.  Join us at this workshop to learn about tools for managing sharing, when to use which one, and items for consideration when sharing with others.  At the presentation, you will also meet the TTS staff who are here to assist you with sending and receiving research materials through material transfer, data use, and confidentiality/non-disclosure agreements.

When:  Tuesday May 21st at 3:00 PM
Where:  Walnut Room at the EMU (across from the old post office)

The workshop is free and open to the UO community, but space is limited so reservations are requested. Please RSVP to Evey Lennon at evey at uoregon.edu<mailto:evey at uoregon.edu> by May 17th.  Light snacks will be provided.

        [cid:image003.jpg at 01CE4BC6.A4204870]

subject: b'coe-fac: Dead Week and Final Exam Policy Reminder'
html:
b'
TO:                 Faculty and Graduate Teaching Fellows

FROM:           Doug Blandy, Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs

RE:                 Dead Week and Final Exam Policy

This message is to remind you of examination policies that may affect your course planning for the end of this term.  Faculty legislation controls assignments that may be required during the last week of regular classes, commonly known as "Dead Week," (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~assembly/Assembly1981-1982ALL.html#DeadWeek>):


1.       In the week preceding final examination during fall, winter, and spring terms:

*         No examination worth more than 20% of the final grade will be given, with the exception of make-up examinations.

*         No final examinations will be given under any guise.

*         No work that will be evaluated for grades/credit will be due unless it has been clearly specified on the class syllabus within the first two weeks of the term.

2.      Take-home examinations will be due no earlier than the day of the formally assigned final examination for the class in question.
This action clarifies and extends earlier faculty legislation (1911 Faculty Assembly archives) prohibiting the giving of final examinations earlier than officially scheduled.

In addition, you should be aware of the Faculty Advisory Council's statement on students with multiple exams:

"Examination schedules are listed each term in the Time Schedule.  Students who are scheduled to take more than three examinations within one calendar day may take the additional examination(s) as makeup examination(s) later in the examination week.  The instructor(s) of record for the course(s) beyond the third examination, counting in the order the examination(s) are scheduled, will arrange for (a) makeup examination(s)."

The following procedures were approved by the Undergraduate Council to address rare circumstances of competing exam times, (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~ucouncil/documents/resources/04222003-HO1_Resource_Final%20Exam%20Conflicts.pdf>).   Students with examination conflicts may contact the Office of Academic Advising for assistance.

"In the case of two examinations scheduled at the same time, the course with the largest enrollment must provide an alternate examination.  For conflicts between regular courses and combined examinations, the combined examination course must provide the alternate examination.  For combined examinations with conflicts, the largest combined enrollment course must provide the alternative examination."

Questions and concerns regarding this policy should be directed first to the relevant instructor, then the department head, and finally the dean if necessary.  You may also find reference to the policy on the Academic Affairs website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/dead-week-policy.    If additional input is needed, please contact me at 6-3029 or dblandy at uoregon.edu<mailto:dblandy at uoregon.edu>.


[cid:image001.png at 01CE3ABB.AD963200]

text:
b'TO:                 Faculty and Graduate Teaching Fellows

FROM:           Doug Blandy, Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs

RE:                 Dead Week and Final Exam Policy

This message is to remind you of examination policies that may affect your course planning for the end of this term.  Faculty legislation controls assignments that may be required during the last week of regular classes, commonly known as "Dead Week," (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~assembly/Assembly1981-1982ALL.html#DeadWeek>):


1.       In the week preceding final examination during fall, winter, and spring terms:

*         No examination worth more than 20% of the final grade will be given, with the exception of make-up examinations.

*         No final examinations will be given under any guise.

*         No work that will be evaluated for grades/credit will be due unless it has been clearly specified on the class syllabus within the first two weeks of the term.

2.      Take-home examinations will be due no earlier than the day of the formally assigned final examination for the class in question.
This action clarifies and extends earlier faculty legislation (1911 Faculty Assembly archives) prohibiting the giving of final examinations earlier than officially scheduled.

In addition, you should be aware of the Faculty Advisory Council's statement on students with multiple exams:

"Examination schedules are listed each term in the Time Schedule.  Students who are scheduled to take more than three examinations within one calendar day may take the additional examination(s) as makeup examination(s) later in the examination week.  The instructor(s) of record for the course(s) beyond the third examination, counting in the order the examination(s) are scheduled, will arrange for (a) makeup examination(s)."

The following procedures were approved by the Undergraduate Council to address rare circumstances of competing exam times, (Link here<http://www.uoregon.edu/~ucouncil/documents/resources/04222003-HO1_Resource_Final%20Exam%20Conflicts.pdf>).   Students with examination conflicts may contact the Office of Academic Advising for assistance.

"In the case of two examinations scheduled at the same time, the course with the largest enrollment must provide an alternate examination.  For conflicts between regular courses and combined examinations, the combined examination course must provide the alternate examination.  For combined examinations with conflicts, the largest combined enrollment course must provide the alternative examination."

Questions and concerns regarding this policy should be directed first to the relevant instructor, then the department head, and finally the dean if necessary.  You may also find reference to the policy on the Academic Affairs website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/dead-week-policy.    If additional input is needed, please contact me at 6-3029 or dblandy at uoregon.edu<mailto:dblandy at uoregon.edu>.


[cid:image001.png at 01CE3ABB.AD963200]

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Oregon University/School Partnership grant RFP released'
html:
b'
Hello All,

I have attached the RFP for the 2013-14 Title II-A University/School Partnership (USP) Professional Development program. An Intent-to-Apply form is due October 15 and the final proposal is due November 1, 2013. Successful projects may begin in January 2014, and projects can last up to two years. The maximum two-year funding for projects is $240,000. Oregon has funding for five projects in this competitive grant that is focused on teacher/principal professional development in mathematics, science, and English language arts/literacy.

There are 51 high-poverty school districts in Oregon that also meet the USP eligibility requirement of 1.7% or more classes taught by teachers who are not highly qualified to teach those classes or 1.44% or more teachers on emergency or conditional licenses. This list is at the end of the RFP. All University/School Partnership projects are required to have at least three partners:

1.      At least one eligible school district

2.      The unit of a college or university that prepares teachers

3.      The College or Department of liberal arts and sciences at a university or college.

The RFP has also been posted on the OACTE home page: http://oacte.org. You are encouraged to share this RFP with potential partners and begin planning for your proposal submission.


Bonnie

Bonnie Morihara, Ph.D.
Title II-A Oregon University/School Partnership Coordinator
The Teaching Research Institute
Western Oregon University
345 N. Monmouth Avenue
Monmouth, OR 97361
Fax: 503.838.8150
Tel: 503.838.8413
http://www.wou.edu/tri

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity'
html:
b'
Hello,

I write to seek your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL Reading Clinic. In 2013-2014, we will be offering tutoring services to struggling readers in the elementary grades, in Bethel School District. The program will be held at three of Bethel's schools, after school (approximately 2:15-3:15 p.m., or 3:00-4:00 p.m., depending on the time school lets out at participating sites). Tutoring sessions will begin in week 2 of each quarter and conclude in week 10 of each quarter. Selected Bethel students will participate in one hour of small group reading instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each week, delivered by trained tutors. Training will be held in two, 2-hour sessions during the first week of the term. UO students may volunteer to tutor, or tutor for credit, with the option of earning 1-2 credits depending on whether they teach a small group every day or tutor for only 2 days per week. I am hoping you can share this opportunity with your students or others in the community that may be interested in gaining teaching experience.

I have attached the 2013-2014 tutor application. If you or your students have any questions, please contact me or Anna Ingram (annad at uoregon.edu). More information about the CTL Reading Clinic can be found here: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic!

Nancy

-----------------------------------------------------------
Nancy J. Nelson-Walker, Ph.D., NCSP
Research Associate
Center on Teaching and Learning
5292 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR  97403
(541) 346-8446
nnelson3 at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Workshop: NTTF Evaluation and Promotion Processes (November 12, 2013)'
html:
b'
FYI-

This message is sent on behalf of Barbara Altmann, Vice Provost for Academic Affairs. Please forward to faculty who might be interested in attending.


NTTF Evaluation and Promotion Processes

This workshop is for non-tenure track faculty who want to know more about the evaluation and promotion process at the University of Oregon. Topics covered include the timeline; candidate responsibilities; research, teaching, and service expectations; and vitae and personal statement preparation. Addressing these issues now will enable candidates to be better prepared at the time of review.

When:
November 12, 2013
12:00-2:00 p.m.
Lunch will be provided

Where:
Knight Library, Browsing Conference Room

RSVP:
Please RSVP at https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_8hMkt5LSqrMAOTb no later than Thursday, November 7.

Thank you!

____________________
Sonja K. Runberg
Executive Assistant
207 Johnson Hall
1258 University of Oregon
Eugene OR 97403-1258
T: 541-346-4345
F: 541-346-2023

<image001.png>

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Collective Bargaining Agreement Implementation\tUpdate'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Ron Beghetto and Lauren Lindstrom:

Dear Colleagues -

As you know, the UO recently ratified our first faculty collective bargaining agreement (CBA).  We've been spending quite a bit of time in the Dean's Office gathering information regarding the details of implementation.

One way for you to stay updated is through the CBA Implementation website.  There is some new information posted on the web site concerning the faculty union contract implementation and the upcoming salary increase salary process.

 You can also sign up to receive an e-mail whenever a new post goes up on the site.   Check out -- http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu/

Assistant Dean Diane O'Keefe and the Business Managers will be working closely with your Department Head on the details of the CBA implementation.  In brief, there are a few upcoming changes that we wanted to highlight for you -

1.   1.    1.5% raises for all bargaining unit faculty retroactive  to January 2013  (to be received in November paychecks)
2.    2.    An additional 1.5%  raise retroactive to July 2013  (to be received in January 2014 paychecks)
3.    3.    One time payments of $350 for all bargaining unit faculty who were employed on October 9,  2013.  (prorated for part time faculty)
4.    4.   Merit raises.  You will have an opportunity to review the criteria for merit increases with your  Department Head.

Please feel free to check in with your Department Head and/or Business Manager as we work through all these details.


Ron Beghetto  and Lauren Lindstrom
Associate Deans
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20131108/8366c472/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Merit Increase Process for Eligible Faculty Bargaining\tUnit Members'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues,
As you know, the University is in the process of implementing the first ever Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) for represented faculty. There are many moving parts to the CBA and the implementation work will be ongoing through this academic year and beyond. While institutional change of this magnitude comes with its share of bumps, we are all committed to working together to emerge a much more equitable, inclusive, and transparent organization.
I write today about implementation of the merit salary increases for FY14 for eligible represented faculty. (FY 14 includes the time period from July 1, 2013 to June 30, 2014)
In addition to the two retroactive salary increases (1.5% each), the CBA also specifies a merit pool equivalent to 2% of salary for eligible represented faculty, retroactive to July 1, 2013.
As part of the CBA, all faculty in the College will have an opportunity to respond to policies pertaining to the criteria used to determine merit increases.
The Provost expects to have the list of eligible faculty available to us by November 22. It is important to note that all faculty may not be eligible for across-the-board or merit increases due to a variety of factors, such as hiring date and/or whether or not you are represented by the Union. If you have questions concerning your eligibility, we suggest you contact United Academics for more information (uauoregon.org).
Because we are working from an abbreviated timeline this year, we have decided to submit the proposed merit criteria to all faculty members within the COE at once to facilitate timely feedback. Below we provide an overview of our proposed criteria and procedures.
In the College of Education, department heads are working with college leadership to draw from our already established review practices in framing the process for merit raise recommendations for FY14. The proposed process is as follows:

1.    Annual Review. Information from the most recent annual review routinely conducted by the department or research unit will form the basis of merit determinations. If no annual review is on file reflecting activities from calendar year 2012 or more recently, the faculty member will be reviewed according to established departmental/unit procedures. Generally, the procedure includes having faculty members submit written summaries of activities from the past year in distinct categories (e.g., teaching, research and scholarly activity, service and professional activity, and diversity enhancing activities). Summaries of activities may be supplemented through reference to particular sections of a faculty member's current CV. Please work with your department head to ensure that you have a current evaluation on file to assist in this process.



2.    One-time, Expedited Review. Faculty who are in positions that have not been subject to annual reviews in the past (e.g. practicum supervisors) will be evaluated by their supervisors using available data (e.g. student feedback/evaluation and field placement coordinators' feedback).



3.    Department  Head or Unit Director Ratings. For the purpose of the FY13-14 merit increases, the department head or research unit director will assign a global rating of the faculty member's performance, taking into account that faculty member's position description/duties, utilizing the following descriptors: Does Not Meet Expectations; Meets Expectations; and Exceeds Expectations. The global ratings will reflect relative weighting in terms of teaching, research, and service based on the specific position and job classification (e.g., for lecturer positions with primarily teaching responsibilities, performance in teaching will be weighted more heavily than research).



4.    Merit Increase Recommendation.  Only faculty who meet or exceed expectations will be eligible for a merit increase. The department head will make a recommendation for merit increase based on the global rating, and final adjustments will be made at the college level to ensure the proper accounting of the 2% merit pool. It is important to note here that the 2% merit pool for NTTF will be kept separate from the 2% pool for tenure line faculty to ensure that the full 2% is available to members of each respective group. The Provost or designee has final decision making authority regarding merit increases.
In order to meet the internal deadline of November 22, I invite you to provide your department head with your questions, feedback, thoughts, and concerns about this proposed process for FY14 merit increases for eligible represented faculty. Each department head will distribute information to their faculty about specific avenues to provide this feedback. Along with others in COE leadership, I will integrate your feedback as judiciously and respectfully as possible as we work in the College to finalize the process.
This is not the final word on how merit raises will be administered in our college. In fact, soon after we conclude these immediate implementation steps in the CBA, we will move to a more refined and deliberate process of working together with all faculty to clarify criteria for merit increases for FY15 and beyond.
As always, your collegial support in this process is much appreciated as we move forward together as an academic community.
Mia




-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20131115/61f00551/attachment.html>
'

The global ratings will reflect relative weighting in terms of teaching, research, and service based on the specific position and job classification (e.g., for lecturer positions with primarily teaching responsibilities, performance in teaching will be weighted more heavily than research).



4.    Merit Increase Recommendation.  Only faculty who meet or exceed expectations will be eligible for a merit increase. The department head will make a recommendation for merit increase based on the global rating, and final adjustments will be made at the college level to ensure the proper accounting of the 2% merit pool. It is important to note here that the 2% merit pool for NTTF will be kept separate from the 2% pool for tenure line faculty to ensure that the full 2% is available to members of each respective group. The Provost or designee has final decision making authority regarding merit increases.
In order to meet the internal deadline of November 22, I invite you to provide your department head with your questions, feedback, thoughts, and concerns about this proposed process for FY14 merit increases for eligible represented faculty. Each department head will distribute information to their faculty about specific avenues to provide this feedback. Along with others in COE leadership, I will integrate your feedback as judiciously and respectfully as possible as we work in the College to finalize the process.
This is not the final word on how merit raises will be administered in our college. In fact, soon after we conclude these immediate implementation steps in the CBA, we will move to a more refined and deliberate process of working together with all faculty to clarify criteria for merit increases for FY15 and beyond.
As always, your collegial support in this process is much appreciated as we move forward together as an academic community.
Mia

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity: Winter Term'
html:
b'
Hello,

I write to seek your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL Reading Clinic this winter. In 2013-2014, we are offering tutoring services to struggling readers in the elementary grades, in Bethel School District. Our after school program serves three of Bethel's schools, approximately 2:15-3:15 p.m., or 3:00-4:00 p.m., depending on the time school lets out at participating sites. Tutoring sessions will begin in week 2 of each quarter and conclude in week 10 of each quarter. Selected Bethel students will participate in one hour of small group reading instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each week, delivered by trained tutors. Training will be held in two, 2-hour sessions during the first week of the term. UO students may volunteer to tutor, or tutor for credit, with the option of earning 1-2 credits depending on whether they teach a small group every day or tutor for only 2 days per week. I am hoping you can share this opportunity with your students or others in the community that may be interested in gaining teaching experience.

I have attached the 2013-2014 tutor application. If you or your students have any questions, please contact me or Anna Ingram (annad at uoregon.edu). More information about the CTL Reading Clinic can be found here: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic!

Nancy

---------------------------------------------------------------------
Nancy J. Nelson Walker, Ph.D., NCSP
Research Assistant Professor
SPECS Courtesy Research Associate
Director, Reading Clinic & External Relations 
Center on Teaching and Learning
5292 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR  97403
(541) 346-8446
nnelson3 at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Work schedule for bargaining unit faculty members'
html:
b'
FYI-

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2013 10:19:23 -0800
Subject: Work schedule for bargaining unit faculty members
This is a reminder that under Article 32, Section 21, of the United Academics Collective Bargaining Agreement, bargaining unit officers of instruction who do not earn vacation will be considered to be on paid leave during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day (and during the week of Spring Break).
Christmas Day and New Year's Day are paid holidays. However, bargaining unit faculty members (typically some officers of research) may be required to work on these holidays if necessary to maintain or operate critical facilities or operations. If a bargaining unit faculty member is required to work on a holiday for that reason, he or she may take an equivalent amount of time off with pay at a later date, as approved by the bargaining unit faculty member's supervisor.
Otherwise, as provided in Article 17, Section 7, of the CBA, each bargaining unit faculty member must be fully engaged in teaching, research, and service work for the university to the extent of his or her appointment, and must be engaged in work or reasonably available for work for the entirety of the term for which the bargaining unit member is employed unless on approved leave. There is no blanket leave for the period between fall and winter terms.
You previously received information about the Governor's Day.
Faculty members who are not subject to the United Academics CBA may make individual arrangements with their supervisors regarding work schedules.
Randy Geller
General Counsel
University of Oregon
-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: UO CBA Implementation: Exclusions for Supervisory Duties'
text:
b'Dear COE Faculty:

The information below was posted this week to the UO CBA implementation web site (uo-cba.uoregon.edu) concerning process for requesting exclusion from the bargaining unit based on supervisory duties.  I am forwarding the information to you because of the short timeline for submission of exclusion requests for this quarter (January 27th is the deadline).  If you have any questions on this or other union-related matters, please contact United Academics directly (uauoregon.org).

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>

Important Update on Supervisory Exclusions<http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu>
Important Update on Supervisory Exclusions<http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu>
Posted on January 15, 2014 by UO CBA Implementation Team <http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu>
The University and United Academics have agreed on a process to determine whether a faculty member meets the definition of a \xe2\x80\x9csupervisor\xe2\x80\x9d such that she or he should be excluded from the bargaining unit. Faculty members who believe that the supervisory duties they perform should be considered for supervisory exclusion must complete a form and have it approved by their unit. Please contact Jane Gordon by January 27th to obtain the form. If this deadline is missed, your request will be considered in the next quarterly analysis period.<http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: UO CBA Implementation: Exclusions for Supervisory Duties'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

As a follow-up to my message last week about requests for exclusion from the faculty bargaining unit based on supervisory authority, below please find information on what constitutes supervisory authority (taken from the uo-cba.uoregon.edu site FAQs).

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218
Q: How are decisions made about who is in and out of the bargaining unit, and how will the university and union track faculty as they move in and out of the bargaining unit?
A: A faculty member\xe2\x80\x99s status as represented or non-represented is straightforward in most circumstances. Faculty with instructional or research appointments who do not fall into an excluded class of employees,  are in the United Academics bargaining unit.
Oregon law excludes supervisory and \xe2\x80\x9cconfidential\xe2\x80\x9d employees from collective bargaining units.

  *   In general, a supervisory employee is someone having the authority \xe2\x80\x9cto hire, transfer, suspend, layoff, recall, promote, discharge, assign, reward or discipline other employees, or responsibly direct them, or to adjust their grievances, or to effectively recommend such action.\xe2\x80\x9d
  *   In general, a \xe2\x80\x9cconfidential\xe2\x80\x9d employee\xe2\x80\x9d is \xe2\x80\x9cone who assists and acts in a confidential capacity to a person who formulates, determines and effectuates management policies in the area of collective bargaining.\xe2\x80\x9d
All UO faculty who hold administrative appointments with \xe2\x80\x9cpresident,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdean,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cprovost,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cdepartment head\xe2\x80\x9d in their titles are non-represented faculty. The areas where the distinction becomes more complicated are related to program directors and principal investigators on funded research grants. Here the determinative question is the level of supervisory authority over bargaining unit members. Generally, if the principal investigator on a grant supervises  bargaining unit members, he or she is not in the union.
Department heads and other faculty who move from instructional to administrative appointments are not represented by the union while holding an administrative position, but return to the union when they leave administration, unless they qualify as a supervisor.
The CBA requires the University to provide United Academics with a list of faculty appointments on a regular basis.

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Internal Governance Policies - Feedback Requested (From Dean Tuan)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues,

The University is currently working to ensure that all the provisions of the new faculty collective bargaining agreement (CBA) are effectively implemented.  One key part of this effort involves making internal governance policies transparent, accessible and consistent.

The COE Dean's Office and department heads have been gathering existing policies, soliciting input on common practices across the college, and synthesizing the information into a framework to guide our policy development. The framework document is attached for your review and feedback. We hope that your input will help to make it the strongest and most effective statement of our principles and policies. There are two venues for providing feedback:

  *   Department and unit level meetings: department and unit directors will be in touch soon with information on when and where these meetings will take place.
  *   A link<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_6JoXI18xEIs38GN> has been created in the event you prefer to provide direct feedback to the Dean's Office.

In order to have enough time to synthesize and incorporate your comments before we submit the document to the Provost for final approval, please provide your feedback by 5pm on February 28th. Upon approval, the Dean's Office will post the document on the COE website under a new "Governance" section, which will go live later this term.

I look forward to your invaluable participation in this important process. As always, please feel free to contact me if you have any questions.

Warmly,
Mia

subject: b'coe-fac: Review and Promotion Criteria'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Lauren Lindstrom-



Dear COE Colleagues -- In accordance with the CBA guidelines, I am

 providing all College faculty with information about our existing

 review and promotion criteria. The COE Tenure Promotion and Policy as

 well as our NTTF Promotion Policy and procedures are posted on the

 Academic Affairs page (under governance) on the College of Education

 web site.  You will find links to both policies near the bottom of the COE academic affairs page.

PLEASE NOTE:  Our policies have NOT been updated yet to reflect all of the changes

required by the new collective bargaining agreement.



https://education.uoregon.edu/governance/coe-and-uo-policies-and-procedures





These are the policies in place for this year -- however there will

 be an opportunity next year for a more in depth conversation about

any changes or additions needed. If you have individual questions

 about these policies/procedures please contact your Department Head,

Research/Outreach Unit Director, or me at lindstrm at uoregon.edu<mailto:lindstrm at uoregon.edu>.



In addition, for those faculty who will be going up for promotion or

tenure during the 2014/15 year and beyond, there are a few additional

requirements based on the language in the CBA. Those additional

components are described on the CBA implementation web site.



http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu/2014/02/10/cba-contract-additions-to-tenure- and-promotion-dossier/<http://uo-cba.uoregon.edu/2014/02/10/cba-contract-additions-to-tenure-%20and-promotion-dossier/>



all the best,

Lauren

Lauren Lindstrom, Ph.D
Associate Dean of Research and Academics
Director, Center at Oregon for Research in Education (CORE)
College of Education, University of Oregon
(541) 346-1399
lindstrm at uoregon.edu<mailto:lindstrm at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Internal Governance'
html:
b'
Hi Colleagues -
I would like to comment on the shared governance process we are undertaking in the COE.  Though time consuming, it's tremendously important for our long-term operations and I hope all the depts/units are having robust discussions.  The document that Mia sent out reflected a lot of work from her office and the dept heads and it is a helpful starting point.  Article 4 of the CBA states that the "faculty shall first consider any input provided by the appropriate department or unit head, dean, vice-president, Provost, or designee."  The spirit of shared governance opens up this process by giving all faculty the opportunity to develop these policies, which will then be submitted "to the appropriate dean, vp or designee for review.  The dean (etc.) will provide written explanation to the faculty and an opportunity to discuss any alterations he or she makes to the recommenced policy before submission to the provost or designee." (page 3 of the CBA)
Mia's memo of 2/7 describes a process of synthesizing and incorporating our comments before passing them on to the provost that might be interpreted by some that this is not a full review of the entire policy or that we can only tinker with this document.  I'm sure this wasn't the intention, so faculty should know that this is just a starting place and that they can look at all aspects of the document.  This includes the voting matrix attached to the document. They can also examine other models from other departments.  There is also a tension between college-wide policies and dept policies that is not easily resolvable by the process described in the memo.  I guess we will see how different departments/units respond to this task and then decide a course of action.
Lastly, I'd like to draw people's attention to the composition of the Faculty Personnel Committee (page 3).  It is in violation of Art. 19, section 2 (page 24) of the CBA. Departments might come up with creative solutions to fix this.
Happy policy making!
Deborah

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20140218/b8da60ad/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity: Spring Term'
html:
b'
Hello,

I write to seek your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL Reading Clinic this winter. In 2013-2014, we are offering tutoring services to struggling readers in the elementary grades, in Bethel School District. Our after school program serves several of Bethel's schools, approximately 2:15-3:15 p.m., or 3:00-4:00 p.m., depending on the time school lets out at participating sites. Tutoring sessions will begin in week 2 of each quarter and conclude in week 10 of each quarter. Selected Bethel students will participate in one hour of small group reading instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each week, delivered by trained tutors. Training will be held in two, 2-hour sessions during the first week of the term. UO students may volunteer to tutor, or tutor for credit, with the option of earning 1-2 credits depending on whether they teach a small group every day or tutor for only 2 days per week. I am hoping you can share this opportunity with your students or others in the community that may be interested in gaining teaching experience.

I have attached the 2013-2014 spring tutor application and our program flyer. If you or your students have any questions, please contact our Reading Clinic Coordinator, Shaheen Munir-McHill (munir at uoregon.edu), or our Program Assistant, Anna Ingram (annad at uoregon.edu). More information about the CTL Reading Clinic can be found at our website, currently under construction: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic!

Nancy

---------------------------------------------------------------------
Nancy J. Nelson, Ph.D., NCSP
Research Assistant Professor
SPECS Courtesy Research Associate
Director, Reading Clinic & External Relations 
Center on Teaching and Learning
5292 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR  97403
(541) 346-8446
nnelson3 at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Internal Governance Update'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues:

I am writing today to offer some clarifications concerning my email of February 7th and the internal governance policy development currently underway.

In the initial email I included a draft document that was meant to serve as a starting point for the development of department or unit level internal governance policies. I apologize if my intent in this email was unclear-let me clarify by saying that, as you develop your department/unit level internal governance policies, you are free to adopt the draft document entirely, start from scratch, or anything in between. In recognition of the need expressed by some units for more time to develop their internal governance policies, the deadline for input has been moved to March 7th (in lieu of February 28th).

Core to the Collective Bargaining Agreement is the premise that "all faculty in each department or unit shall have the opportunity to participate in the development of that department or unit's internal governance policy." Your involvement in the development of your unit's policies is very important for the long-term credibility and legitimacy of these policies and I encourage you to participate in any way you see fit. This includes the two venues mentioned in my earlier email: 1) department and unit level meetings, and 2) direct input to the Dean's Office through a Qualtrics link<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_6JoXI18xEIs38GN>. I am pleased to report that faculty workgroups are meeting on a regular basis in some departments and units, engaging in robust discussion about shared governance and developing policies that address local level needs.

I would like to propose a third venue for participation, a college-wide internal governance workgroup comprised of faculty from all ranks, departments, and units. I invite volunteers to participate in several meetings from March 7th until March 21st to help develop the COE college-level internal governance draft document that provides the necessary structure, flexibility to accommodate diversity in department/unit level policies, and assurance of equitable participation by faculty in the governance process. If you are willing to participate in this workgroup, please contact Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) expressing your interest.

As for what happens after March 7th, here is what I propose:

  *   For department/unit level policies, department heads and unit directors will be asked to post the internal governance policy drafts for faculty within their units to review and provide additional input before ratification. Drafts will be posted for five days and then a vote will be taken. Policies that are ratified will be forwarded to the Provost for final review.
  *   For the COE college-level policy, the Dean's Office will post the policy draft for all faculty to review and provide additional input before ratification. The draft will be posted for five days and then a vote will be taken. Once the policy is ratified, it will be forwarded to the Provost for final review.
Whatever your method of participation, I strongly encourage you to be involved in the development of these policies. Any policy document is a statement of principles of what we value and how we understand ourselves. Your voice and input are crucial at this important moment of clarifying and establishing our principles.

Best wishes,
Mia

________________________________
[COE logo]


Mia Tuan | Interim Dean
tuan at uoregon.edu<mailto:tuan at uoregon.edu> | 541.346.3405
170 Lokey Ed | 1215 University of Oregon Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: EDUC Instructor Nominations'
html:
b'
Hello everyone.  We are currently in the process of nominating instructors for the 2014/15 EDUC courses.  In case you are not familiar with the "EDUC" designation - these are primarily research classes designed to meet requirements for graduate students from all departments in the College.  You can nominate yourself or other potentially interested faculty to teach one of these EDUC courses for 2014/15.

Please submit your nomination using the Instructor Nomination Form in the EDUC courses section of the following web page:
The deadline is noon on March 12.

https://education.uoregon.edu/governance/coe-and-uo-policies-and-procedures

Department Heads will be meeting on March 13 to review all nominations, and make assignments for next year.


All the best,

Lauren


Lauren Lindstrom, Ph.D
Associate Dean of Research and Academics
Director, Center at Oregon for Research in Education (CORE)
College of Education, University of Oregon
(541) 346-1399

subject: b'coe-fac: Curriculum Changes review - Qualtrics'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues -  It's time for faculty review of Winter term curriculum changes!
We have a number of proposals for curriculum changes this term in the College.  Your curriculum committee (which includes reps from all 4 departments)  has already completed an initial review of these courses.  The curriculum committee requested some additional information as well as a number of changes/additions.  The proposals you see here have been revised based on input from the curriculum committee.
This next step is an opportunity for the faculty as a whole to review the proposals, and provide any comments on the proposed changes. Please provide your comments by 5:00 Monday March 10
The qualtrics link will take you to a survey that includes five proposals:
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_02HmStWKKs8UvRj



1.    1. Communication Disorders/Sciences.  Request to drop an existing course (CDS 411) and  add two new courses CDS 430 and 431 to the undergraduate program.

2.       2. Counseling Psychology.  Request to add CPSY 626 and CPSY 508.  These are 2 new courses being developed as part of the Spanish Language specialization.

3.       3. Educational Leadership. Request permanent course number for EDLD 610: Leading Change

4.       4. Educational Studies.  Request to drop EDST 431 and replace with EDST 464 Multicultural Literacy

5.       5. School Psychology.  Requesting permanent course numbers for 5 existing SPSY 610 courses.
 Thanks for your participation,
Lauren
Lauren Lindstrom, Ph.D
Associate Dean of Research and Academics
Director, Center at Oregon for Research in Education (CORE)
College of Education, University of Oregon
(541) 346-1399
lindstrm at uoregon.edu<mailto:lindstrm at uoregon.edu>

1215 University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403-1215

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Merit Pool Distribution Policy'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues:

We are moving into another phase in the CBA implementation process - this time the establishment of a merit pool distribution policy for all faculty. Attached are two drafts documents offered as "seeds" for your deliberations on the policy and process:

  *   Faculty Merit Pool Distribution Policy draft
  *   Faculty Self-Review Form draft
As you review the drafts, keep in mind that, as with the Internal Governance policy draft, you are free to adopt it wholesale, start from scratch, or anything in between. However, because faculty merit pools are ultimately administered and tallied at the college level, we have envisioned the merit pool distribution policy as a single, college-wide policy. Departments and units are encouraged to further specify and document, at the local level, how they will enact the college-wide policy.

Your involvement in the development of the merit pool distribution policy is very important for its long-term credibility and legitimacy and I encourage you to participate in any way you see fit. This includes: 1) direct input to the Dean's Office through a Qualtrics link<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_8pQmv8NWMO5aTiZ>, and 2) a college-wide workgroup comprised of faculty from all ranks, departments, and units. I invite volunteers to participate in several meetings from April 16th to April 28th to synthesize faculty input and further develop the merit pool distribution policy drafts to be presented for college-wide review and ratification. If you are interested in participating in this workgroup, please contact Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>).

As for what happens after April 30th (the date specified in the CBA timeline for the Dean's Office to provide feedback to faculty), here's what I propose:

The Dean's Office will post the merit pool distribution policy draft developed by the workgroup and any accompanying documents for all faculty to review and provide additional input before ratification. The draft will be posted for five days and then a vote will be taken. Once the policy is ratified, it will be forwarded to the Provost for final review.

Thanks to everybody for participating in this important work - your contributions in developing the merit pool distribution policy are valued and appreciated.

Best wishes,
Mia

________________________________
[COE logo]


Mia Tuan | Interim Dean

text:
b'Dear COE Colleagues:

We are moving into another phase in the CBA implementation process - this time the establishment of a merit pool distribution policy for all faculty. Attached are two drafts documents offered as "seeds" for your deliberations on the policy and process:

  *   Faculty Merit Pool Distribution Policy draft
  *   Faculty Self-Review Form draft
As you review the drafts, keep in mind that, as with the Internal Governance policy draft, you are free to adopt it wholesale, start from scratch, or anything in between. However, because faculty merit pools are ultimately administered and tallied at the college level, we have envisioned the merit pool distribution policy as a single, college-wide policy. Dear Faculty,

This email is a gentle reminder that today is the last day to vote on curriculum changes.

Thank you for your participation.


Juli Deskin  | jdeskin at uoregon.edu<mailto:jdeskin at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-1408
Administrative Assistant
College of Education, Office of the Dean
1215 University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403-1215

From: Juli Deskin
Sent: Wednesday, March 12, 2014 4:33 PM
To: coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu
Subject: Winter Term Curriculum Proposals

Dear Colleagues -  It's time for the faculty vote of Winter term curriculum changes!
The faculty has had the opportunity to comment on the proposed changed. You may view the comments by clicking the Faculty Comments link in the Qualtrics survey.
This next step is an opportunity for the faculty as a whole to vote on the proposed changes. Please vote by 5:00pm Monday March 17th.
The Qualtrics link will take you to a survey that has five proposals to vote on:
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_eDKvThmZDxq96iV
Thanks for your participation,
Lauren

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Funding Opportunity: ED Releases Pre-application for i3 Development Grants'
html:
b'
FYI -

From: Vidusha Devasthali
Sent: Thursday, March 20, 2014 9:41 AM
Subject: FW: Funding Opportunity: ED Releases Pre-application for i3 Development Grants

Dear College of Ed Faculty,

We received the following note from our colleagues at Lewis Burke regarding the recent call for pre-applications for the Dept. of Ed i3 program.  Please feel free to forward this to your colleagues who may be interested in this opportunity.

Best,

Vidusha Devasthali

Research Development Services
University of Oregon
677 E. 12th Ave., Suite 500
vidusha at uoregon.edu<mailto:vidusha at uoregon.edu>
541-346-6391

From: Krieger, Bridget [mailto:bridget at lewis-burke.com]
Sent: Wednesday, March 19, 2014 4:00 PM
To: Betsy Boyd; Vidusha Devasthali; Moira Kiltie
Cc: Thompson, Alison
Subject: Funding Opportunity: ED Releases Pre-application for i3 Development Grants

All-

Below and attached is a note from Ali on the Department of Education's FY 2014 Investing in Innovation (i3) program. Like previous years, the Department is holding a pre-application process for one of the three grant categories, development grants.  These are the early stage proposals and have been the most popular in the past competitions.  Only the proposals that rank highest in the pre-proposal process will be invited to submit full proposals.  We're not expecting the other two types of grants (validation and scale-up) to have this pre-application process, and those solicitations are expected to be released this spring.

Please note that pre-applications are required and are due by April 14.


Funding Opportunity:  ED Releases Call for Pre-applications for 2014 i3 Grant Competition

Lewis-Burke Associates LLC - March 19, 2014


The Department of Education (ED) recently released the pre-application for fiscal year (FY) 2014 Development grants within the Investing in Innovation (i3) program.  Interested applicants must submit a pre-application by April 14.  The purpose of the i3 program is to provide funding to develop or expand promising, innovative practices that improve education and student outcomes.  The grants also encourage partnerships between the private sector, non-profits, and local educational agencies (LEAs), and require non-profit applicants, like institutions of higher education, to demonstrate a strong partnership with an LEA.



The i3 program solicits grants in three categories: Development, Validation, and Scale-Up.  Each category requires an increasing amount of evidence and applicants are required to identify a category at the time of application.  Similar to previous years, the Department is requiring a pre-application for Development grants to streamline the process and reduce the burden for ED and its reviewers.  As a result of the pre-application process, the Department will invite selected applicants to submit a full-application for consideration.  The Scale-Up and Validation grant solicitations are not expected to include a pre-application process; these solicitations are expected to be released this spring.


ED has included six absolute priorities for the 2014 competition.  Similar to last year, subparts have been added for some priorities.  For priorities with subparts, applicants are required to choose and address one absolute priority and one of its subparts.

The absolute priorities and their subparts are:


1.       Improving the Effectiveness of Teachers or Principals.

a.       "Developing and implementing models for principal preparation that deepen leadership skills which have been demonstrated to improve student achievement [...].

b.      Increasing the equitable access to effective teachers or principals for low-income and high-need students [...], which may include increasing the equitable distribution of effective teachers or principals for low-income and high-need students across schools."

2.       Improving Low-Performing Schools.

a.       "Changing elements of the school's organizational design to improve instruction by differentiating staff roles and extending and enhancing instructional time.

b.      Implementing programs, supports, or other strategies that improve students' non-cognitive abilities (e.g., motivation, persistence or resilience) and enhance student engagement in learning or mitigate the effects of poverty, including physical, mental, or emotional health issues, on student engagement in learning."

3.       Improving Academic Outcomes for Students with Disabilities.

4.       Improving Outcomes for English Learners (ELs).

a.       "Increasing the number and proportion of ELs successfully completing courses in core academic subjects by developing, implementing, and evaluating new instructional approaches and tools that are sensitive to the language demands necessary to access challenging content, including technology-based tools.

b.      Preparing ELs to be on track to be college- and career-ready when they graduate from high school by developing comprehensive, developmentally appropriate, early learning programs (birth-grade 3) that are aligned with the State's high-quality early learning standards, designed to improve readiness for kindergarten, and support development of literacy and academic skills in English or in English and another language."

5.       Effective Use of Technology.

a.       "Providing access to learning experiences that are personalized, adaptive, and self-improving in order to optimize the delivery of instruction to learners with a variety of learning needs.

b.      Integrating technology with the implementation of rigorous college- and career-ready standards to increase student achievement [...], student engagement, and teacher efficacy, such as by providing embedded, real-time assessment and feedback to students and teachers."

6.       Serving Rural Communities (note: applications submitted under this priority must identify an additional absolute priority and a subpart).

In addition to one absolutely priority, applications must "propose projects designed to implement practices that serve students who are in grades K-12 at some point during the funding period."  Also, as in previous years, the Department requires all i3 projects to demonstrate additional evidence of effectiveness and incorporate plans for an independent evaluation of the proposed project.

Eligibility:  Eligible applicants include local educational agencies (LEAs); LEAs partnered with nonprofit organizations, including institutions of higher education; and consortia of schools.  A matching requirement of 15 percent is required, and successful applications must demonstrate evidence of 50 percent of the required match prior to any award of a grant.

Key Dates:

*         Pre-Applications became available on March 17

*         Deadline for Notice of Intent to Submit Pre-Application: April 3

*         Deadline for Transmittal of Pre-Application: April 14


Funding: The Department anticipates the availability of total grant funds for the i3 program amounting to $134.8 million.  The breakdown by type of grant is:






Development


Validation


Scale-up


Funding per grant


Up to $3 million


Up to $12 million


Up to $20 million


Number of grants expected in FY 2014


10-20


4-8


0-2


Sources and Additional Information:

*         Additional information on the 2014 i3 competition is available at http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2014-03-14/pdf/2014-05706.pdf.



Alison Thompson
Lewis-Burke Associates LLC
1341 G Street, NW
Eighth Floor
Washington, D.C.  20005
p: 202.289.7475
f: 202.289.7454


Disclaimer:  This message is intended only for the named

recipient.  If you are not the intended recipient you are notified

that disclosing, copying, distributing or taking any action in

reliance on the contents of this information is strictly prohibited.

subject: b'coe-fac: New free book on complexity in teaching and learning'
html:
b'
Bob Sylwester and I have just completed an edited book of possible interest to teachers and teachers of teachers.

Dave Moursund

===============
Sylwester, R., & Moursund, D., eds. (March, 2014). Understanding and Mastering Complexity. Eugene, OR: Information Age Education. Download the PDF file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/256-understanding-and-mastering-complexity.html. Download the Microsoft Word file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/255-understanding-and-mastering-complexity.html.

This new book from Sylwester and Moursund is designed for people interested in exploring ways that informal and formal education can help all of us to deal more easily with the complexity of many of our problems and tasks.

Progress in research and development helps to simplify some complex problems, and also can add to the complexity of others. For example, our authors consider the rapidly growing understanding of the human brain. They explore some of the ways in which the education profession has had to shift its perspective from a lack of understanding of functional brain organization to one in which such understanding can help to provide a foundation for improving our educational systems.

Or, consider Information and Communication Technology (ICT), a major change agent. Children who grow up making routine use of ICT do not view this \xe2\x80\x9ccomplexity\xe2\x80\x9d in the same manner as adults who find some aspects of this rapidly changing technology to be such a challenge. These are only two of the complexities we are working to understand and master.

This new book is the fourth in a series based on the Information Age Education (IAE) Newsletters. All of the books and newsletters are free.

Sylwester, R., & Moursund, D., eds. (June, 2013). Consciousness and Morality: Recent Research Developments. Eugene, OR: Information Age Education. Download the Microsoft Word file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/252-consciousness-and-morality-recent-research-developments.html. Download the PDF file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/251-consciousness-and-morality-recent-research-developments.html.

Moursund, D., & Sylwester, R., eds. (March, 2013). Common Core State Standards for K-12 Education in America. Eugene, OR: Information Age Education. Download the Microsoft Word file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/249-common-core-state-standards-for-k-12-education-in-america.html. Download the PDF file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/248-common-core-state-standards-for-k-12-education-in-america.html.

Sylwester, R., & Moursund, D., eds. (August, 2012). Creating an Appropriate 21st Century Education. Eugene, OR: Information Age Education. Download the Microsoft Word file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/242-creating-an-appropriate-21st-century-education.html. Download the PDF file from http://i-a-e.org/downloads/doc_download/243-creating-an-appropriate-21st-century-education.html.

Moursund, D., & Sylwester, R., eds. Information Age Education Newsletter. Biweekly since August, 2008. Access at http://i-a-e.org/iae-newsletter. 



-------------- next part --------------

subject: b"coe-fac: OPB's Rob Manning on campus April 4"
html:
b'
Good Afternoon,

Oregon Public Broadcasting\xe2\x80\x99s Rob Manning is working on a radio documentary he\xe2\x80\x99s referring to as the \xe2\x80\x9cClass of 2025 Project,\xe2\x80\x9d in which he'll chronicle the lives of five current first-graders over the next decade or so. Now that he has his pool of subjects, he knows what he wants to learn and is hoping to speak with subject-matter experts from the COE, particularly on the following topics:

  *   The implications of an ADHD diagnosis, or misdiagnosis, in terms of development, schooling, parenting, etc.
  *   The implications of having a sibling on the spectrum
  *   Primary education for kids whose parents do not speak English
  *   Socio-economic stressors related to childhood development, particularly families near the poverty line
  *   Minority issues related to primary education

Rob will be here from about 10:30 a.m. - 2:30 p.m. on Friday, April 4. Ideally, he would use most of that time moving from office to office, learning about some of these issues. The interviews would be recorded for use in the documentary (audio only) and would last 20-30 minutes.

If you can comment generally on these topics and and are available during that window, please let me know asap. I will likely follow up early next week with specific individuals who may be a fit for this opportunity.

Thanks much,
Cody

________________________________
[http://streamingmedia.uoregon.edu/coe/comm/EducationLogo_4c.png]

Cody Pinkston | Director of Marketing
cpinksto at uoregon.edu<mailto:cpinksto at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-1392
270 Lokey Ed | 1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403


        [http://streamingmedia.uoregon.edu/coe/comm/Facebook.png] <http://www.facebook.com/uoeducation>         [http://streamingmedia.uoregon.edu/coe/comm/Twitter.png] <http://www.twitter.com/uoeducation>   [http://streamingmedia.uoregon.edu/coe/comm/Flickr.png] <http://www.flickr.com/uoeducation>     [http://streamingmedia.uoregon.edu/coe/comm/YouTube.png] <http://www.youtube.com/uoeducation>           Whenever we do something that fills us with enthusiasm,
we are following our legend. - Paul Coelho

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: [Uosenate2013_2014] Motion regarding final examination\tschedule\trevision posted'

subject: b'coe-fac: Internal Governance Workgroup'

The College of Education is glad to announce the members of the newly formed Internal Governance Workgroup. The group will be providing input on shaping the final college wide Internal Governance policy.  Attached is a draft of the Internal Governance policy.  Please contact one of the members of the workgroup with your feedback.

subject: b'coe-fac: Clusters of Excellence Hiring Initiative'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues,

As many of you know, the Provost has announced a Faculty Cluster of Excellence Hiring Initiative. Details regarding that initiative may be found on the Provost's website<%20http:/provost.uoregon.edu/content/faculty-cluster-excellence-hiring-initiative>. This initiative is an EXCELLENT opportunity for the college to grow its tenure-line faculty and I strongly encourage you to consider submitting a proposal.

While proposals are due in the Provost's Office on May 1, all proposals involving COE faculty or units should be delivered to the Dean's Office by Friday, April 25. All proposals must be reviewed at the college level so that we can prepare an accompanying letter from the dean. Cross-college collaborations are highly encouraged by the Provost, which means an additional layer  of coordination. For those of you submitting cross-college proposals, please do keep this in mind as you prepare your proposal(s) for submission.

If you are planning to submit a proposal, please send an email to Shaun (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) with a brief description of your proposal and the other collaborators involved.

As always, Lauren and I stand ready to assist. Feel free to contact us with questions.

Best,
Mia



________________________________
[COE logo]


Mia Tuan | Interim Dean
tuan at uoregon.edu<mailto:tuan at uoregon.edu> | 541.346.3405
170 Lokey Ed | 1215 University of Oregon Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: Colloquium: Dr. Russell Almond, "An Introduction to Evidence Centered Assessment Design", May 13'
html:
b'
To the COE Community:



Behavioral Research and Teaching (BRT) and the Office for Research, Innovation and Graduate Education (RIGE) would like to announce a colloquium by Dr. Russell Almond: "An Introduction to Evidence Centered Assessment Design." The colloquium will be held in 146 HEDCO on Tuesday, May 13, from 12:00pm - 1:30pm. Please see the attached announcement.



Evidence Centered Design (ECD) is an approach to constructing assessments in terms of evidentiary arguments and supports a broad range of assessment types, including standardized tests, classroom quizzes, coached practice systems, portfolios, and student-tutor interaction. In 2000, ECD won the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME) Award for Outstanding Scientific or Technical Contribution to Educational Measurement.



Dr. Almond is one of the developers of ECD. He is a statistician with extensive training and interest in artificial intelligence, and a leader in the use of and research on Bayesian networks in assessment (http://ralmond.net). His research interests include the use of artificial intelligence in data analysis, Bayesian computation, and statistical model engineering.

subject: b'coe-fac: Commencement Regalia Rental-Order by May 2'
html:
b'
Hello,
Just a reminder that Commencement is Monday, June 17 and like last year, the COE ceremony will be held from 3:00 pm \xe2\x80\x93 5:00 pm in Matthew Knight Arena.  Here is information about ordering your regalia for the ceremony.  The COE covers the cost of your regalia for the ceremony.

Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. To guarantee exact hood colors please make your order by May 2.  After that time it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.  The cut off for ordering faculty regalia is May 17.  After that date, the Duck Store will charge a late fee.  If you are interested in custom regalia, that takes 8 weeks, so please contact Stacy Miller at the Duck Store no later than April 19.

Order your regalia here:
http://uoduckstore.com/faculty/renting_regalia/
On the order form, choose the Spring 2013 ceremony.  The COE will cover the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, so choose \xe2\x80\x98bill department\xe2\x80\x99 in the payment area.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607
Fax:  541-346-5818
