subject: b'coe-fac: IES Releases all FY2015 Requests for Applications for Grant Competitions in Education Research and Research Training'
html:
b'
In case you did not see this announcement earlier - here is the information about IES competitions for 2015.

-Lauren Lindstrom

From: IES Newsflash Subscription Service [mailto:IESWebmaster at ed.gov]
Sent: Wednesday, April 30, 2014 12:22 PM
To: Lauren Lindstrom
Subject: IES Releases all FY2015 Requests for Applications for Grant Competitions in Education Research and Research Training

[Institute of Education Sciences - Newsflash]

IES Releases all FY2015 Requests for Applications for Grant Competitions in Education Research and Research Training


The National Center for Education Research competitions are:

  *   Education Research Grant Programs (84.305A)
  *   Research Training Programs in the Education Sciences (84.305B)
  *   Education Research and Development Centers (84.305C)
  *   Statistical and Research Methodology in Education (84.305D)
  *   Partnerships and Collaborations Focused on Problems of Practice and Policy (84.305H)

The National Center for Special Education Research competitions are:

  *   Special Education Research Grant Programs (84.324A)
  *   Research Training Program in Special Education: Early Career Development and Mentoring (84.324B)

All applications for FY2015 funding are due by 4:30 pm, Washington, DC time on August 7, 2014.

The Request for Applications for each competition is available here:
http://ies.ed.gov/funding/15rfas.asp

Please see the Federal Register<http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2014-04-10/pdf/2014-08107.pdf> notice for more information.


...connecting research, policy and practice


You have received this message because you subscribed to a newsflash service through IES or one of its centers.
Change your options or unsubscribe from this service<http://ies.ed.gov/newsflash/?email=lindstrm%40uoregon%2Eedu>.

By visiting Newsflash<http://ies.ed.gov/newsflash/> you may also sign up to receive information from IES<http://ies.ed.gov/> and its four Centers NCES<http://nces.ed.gov/>, NCER<http://ncer.ed.gov/>, NCEE<http://ncee.ed.gov/>, & NCSER<http://ncser.ed.gov/> to stay abreast of all activities within the Institute of Education Sciences (IES).

To obtain hard copy of many IES products as well as hard copy and electronic versions of hundreds of other U.S. Department of Education products please visit http://www.edpubs.org or call 1-877-433-7827 (877-4-EDPUBS).

subject: b'coe-fac: APA Division 45 Research Conference: May 11 deadline for\tbest rates'
html:
b'


[cid:image001.jpg at 01CF69DF.04AF8930]

The third biennial American Psychological Association Division 45 Conference will be held June 19-21, 2014 at the University of Oregon. APA Division 45 is the Society for the Study of Culture, Ethnicity and Race. The conference will feature outstanding plenary speakers and symposia, preconference workshops for professional development, and continuing education opportunities. Social events include entertainment by a jazz trio and a conference basketball game. View the conference program and register at http://center.uoregon.edu/APA/Div45/2014. Register by May 11 for the best conference registration and hotel rates.

Speakers for plenary sessions include:

Ethnic/Racial Identity

William Cross, University of Denver
Adriana Uma\xc3\xb1a-Taylor, Arizona State University
Moin Syed, University of Minnesota
Stephanie Fryberg, University of Arizona
Richard Lee, University of Minnesota

Race, Ethnicity and Schooling: From the Cradle to College

Margaret Beale Spencer, University of Chicago
Tiffany Yip, Fordham University
Charles Martinez, University of Oregon
Sandra Graham, UCLA

Join your friends and colleagues in Eugene, Oregon this summer and experience state of the science research on culture, race, and ethnicity.

subject: b'coe-fac: VOTE REQUIRED - COE Merit Distribution Policy'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues:
The time has come to present the college-wide faculty merit policy for review and ratification. As with the college's internal governance document, the merit policy document is intended to always be a work in progress and subject to revision on an as-needed basis.
According to the CBA implementation timeline provided by Academic Affairs, we are now at the stage in the process where I present the policy resulting from the input and feedback received from the faculty over the past several weeks. The document attached is a college-level policy for faculty merit distribution to guarantee consistency and equity across units as much as possible through the merit review process, while recognizing that faculty profiles vary considerably within and across units.
The document is now ready for a five day period of college-wide faculty review and voting before submission to the Provost for approval. You may find the policy document and the Faculty Review Form which will be a tool for supervisors to guide performance review going forward attached, and you can submit your vote at the following LINK<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_eSdXFqOEjFhnTmd>. A simple majority of those who vote will be sufficient to ratify the document.
Please note that the deadline for review and voting is 5pm, Wednesday May 14.
Up next for CBA implementation and policy development:

TTF equity pool distribution (in development)

faculty promotion and review (summer - fall)

assignment of professional responsibilities (summer - fall)
Again, thanks to everybody for your good will and participation.
Best wishes,
Mia

________________________________
[COE logo]


Mia Tuan | Interim Dean
tuan at uoregon.edu<mailto:tuan at uoregon.edu> | 541.346.3405
170 Lokey Ed | 1215 University of Oregon Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: Order Regalia by May 16'
html:
b'
Hello,
If you are a faculty member and would like the COE to cover the rental cost of your regalia for commencement, please complete your order by this Friday, May 16th.  After May 16th, the Duck Store will charge a late fee.  The list of faculty who have ordered regalia as of May 6 are listed below.

Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. The cut off to guarantee an exact hood color has passed so it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.

Order your regalia here:
http://uoduckstore.com/faculty/renting_regalia/
On the order form, choose the Spring 2014 ceremony.  The COE will cover the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, so choose 'bill department' in the payment area.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity: Summer Term'
html:
b'
Hello,

I write to seek your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL
Reading Clinic this summer. In 2013-2014, we are offering tutoring services
to struggling readers in the elementary grades, in Bethel School
District. Selected Bethel students will participate in two hours of small
group reading and writing instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each
week, delivered by trained tutors.

Our summer program takes place at Clear Lake Elementary, from 8:30 am -
10:30 am. Tutoring sessions will begin on July 7 and conclude on August 7.
 Training will be held in three, 2-hour sessions during the week of June
23. UO students may volunteer to tutor, or tutor for credit, with the
option of earning 1-2 credits depending on whether they teach a small group
every day or tutor for only 2 days per week. I am hoping you can share this
opportunity with your students or others in the community that may be
interested in gaining teaching experience.

I have attached the summer 2014 tutor application and our program flyer. If
you or your students have any questions, please contact me, Shaheen
Munir-McHill (munir at uoregon.edu), or our Program Assistant, Anna Ingram (
annad at uoregon.edu). More information about the CTL Reading Clinic can be
found at our website, currently under construction:
http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic!

 Shaheen
--
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
Reading Clinic Coordinator
Center on Teaching and Learning
University of Oregon
541.346.8388
munir at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Merit Review Policy Ratified'
html:
b'
Dear COE:
Thank you for your valuable work in developing the COE faculty merit review policy.  The final vote for ratification of the policy was 34 votes in favor and 15 votes against.
The vote was enough of a margin to move the document forward to the Provost for review and approval. That said, the 15 "no" votes reflect dissatisfaction among some faculty concerning the annual review template distributed alongside the merit review policy.  At issue are concerns that the template does not adequately represent student supervisor job duties and contributions.
To address these concerns, department heads have committed to developing specific review templates for faculty in student supervisor roles to use as part of their performance evaluations.  Some department heads already have implemented this or are in the process of doing so, so please consult with them directly with questions or to offer your input.  I expect to receive electronic copies of the materials being used in this way from the department heads by June 2 to add to our policy and process library.
This summer we will launch the next phase of CBA policy development, addressing the assignment of professional responsibilities and the management of summer session. Thank you for the hard work and effort you have put into developing the college's policies, both this past year and the work that lies ahead. This task is a collective effort and your contributions are much appreciated.
Best wishes,
Mia
-------------- next part --------------

text:
b'Dear COE:
Thank you for your valuable work in developing the COE faculty merit review policy.  The final vote for ratification of the policy was 34 votes in favor and 15 votes against.
The vote was enough of a margin to move the document forward to the Provost for review and approval. That said, the 15 "no" votes reflect dissatisfaction among some faculty concerning the annual review template distributed alongside the merit review policy.  At issue are concerns that the template does not adequately represent student supervisor job duties and contributions.
To address these concerns, department heads have committed to developing specific review templates for faculty in student supervisor roles to use as part of their performance evaluations.  Some department heads already have implemented this or are in the process of doing so, so please consult with them directly with questions or to offer your input.  I expect to receive electronic copies of the materials being used in this way from the department heads by June 2 to add to our policy and process library.
This summer we will launch the next phase of CBA policy development, addressing the assignment of professional responsibilities and the management of summer session. Thank you for the hard work and effort you have put into developing the college's policies, both this past year and the work that lies ahead. This task is a collective effort and your contributions are much appreciated.
Best wishes,
Mia

subject: b'coe-fac: UO Library Catalog'
html:
b'
I want to alert you to changes to the Library search mechanism taking place June 16th.  This will mainly effect the library catalog/WorldCat portion - it should have little or no effect on individual databases such as PsycINFO (PsycNet) .

We're still testing the system so I cannot provide you with solid particulars at this point.  If you are a "super user" (especially if you have created lists in WorldCat)  you might want to talk to me before the 16th  so you don't lose information stored in WorldCat.  (Plus, I would really like to meet all you super users!)

If your summer session course will be working on research projects - give me a call so we can talk about a possible classroom presentation.

More about the change available at:   http://library.uoregon.edu/node/4283

Feel free to contact me with any questions you may have.



Katy
-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: TTF Equity Increases'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty,
This email provides information concerning how equity adjustments for COE tenured and tenure-track faculty (TTF) were calculated. As you know, the University of Oregon is providing funds for equity adjustments to TTF salaries for fiscal year 15, effective July 1, 2014.  To address issues of salary compression and salary inversion, the College of Education has a pool of funds based on 1.5% of the sum of the annual salaries for COE TTF.  To manage this pool of funds and to determine where adjustments were made, the COE Leadership Team established the following:

GUIDING PRINCIPLES:
*  Equity increases need to address salary compression and inversion
*  Equity increases to be done in an objective manner
*  Equity to be applied within a rank (assistant, associate, full) and an eligibility pool (represented TTF or non-represented TTF)
*  Retired faculty are excluded from consideration for equity increases

ELIGIBILITY and AMOUNT for equity increases were determined using the following steps:
*  Sorted all tenure-line faculty by their rank (assistant, associate, full)
*  Noted obvious equity gaps within ranks and years within same rank
*  Eligible faculty sorted into two pools, represented TTF and non-represented TTF; each pool has its own dollar amount to use for equity increases, determined by calculating 1.5% of all TTF salaries within that pool
*  Established a Target Salary for each rank by years in rank
*  Since both promotion and review options are available to increase pay after 6 years in rank, the target salary scale was capped at 6 years
*  Equity funds were distributed to raise everyone within the same pool (represented or non-represented) to the same percent of target salary
*  Given different equity funds available to each pool, the percent of target salary is different within the two pools
* For non-represented TTF, anyone falling below the Target Salary (for their rank/years in rank) by more than 3.6% was eligible for an equity increase
* For represented TTF, anyone falling below the Target Salary (for their rank/years in rank) by more than 3.7% was eligible for an equity increase

Feel free to contact me with your questions.

Best,
Mia


________________________________
[COE logo]


Mia Tuan | Interim Dean
tuan at uoregon.edu<mailto:tuan at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-3405
170 Lokey Ed | 1215 University of Oregon Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity: Fall Term'
html:
b'
Hello,

As another year is beginning, I am writing again to seek your help in
recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL Reading Clinic this fall. In
2014-2015, we are offering tutoring services to struggling readers in the
elementary grades in the Bethel School District. Selected Bethel students
will participate in two hours of small group reading and writing
instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each week, delivered by
trained tutors.

Tutors will receive training during Week 1 of the term, and begin teaching
intervention groups in Week 2 (note: all tutoring takes place in Bethel
schools).  Students may tutor two or four days per week.  Students may
tutor for credit, to complete a field experience requirement, or to
volunteer.  This is an excellent opportunity for UO students who are
interested in instruction or literacy or are considering a career in K-12
education.

I have attached a number of documents:
1) Program flyer.  If you have a door or display area in your department,
we would greatly appreciate your help in posting this flyer.
2) Tutor information.  This document outlines tutor responsibilities and
the tutoring experience in greater depth than this email.
3) Tutor application.

If your students have any questions, they can contact me, Shaheen
Munir-McHill (munir at uoregon.edu).  More information about the CTL Reading
Clinic can be found at our website: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic and our
mission, which includes providing meaningful training opportunities to COE
students!

Best,
Shaheen
--
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
Reading Clinic Coordinator
Center on Teaching and Learning
University of Oregon
541.346.8388
munir at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Curriculum Committee Membership (from Brigid Flannery)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

I am writing as we need to establish the membership for the COE Curriculum Committee. Each department has two faculty members on the committee who can represent them and their departments curriculum.

This committee will have most of its work at three points of the year -  the end of October, the beginning of February, and the beginning of May (along with a planning meeting early in October).  We are expecting a number of proposed course changes as well as new courses this year.

Below you will list of opening by department for next year. The new internal governance policy indicates that the process for filling positions on committees is:

"In the interest of transparency and inclusivity, all openings on college-wide committees shall be announced via email to all faculty, who will then contact their Department/Unit/Program Heads about their interest. The Department/unit or program head shall forward names for consideration by the chair of that committee."

If you are interested in serving on this committee, please contact your Department Head by 9/23/2014. Department Heads please let me know your representatives by 9/26/2014.


1.       CPHS -needs 1 new member

2.       SPECS -needs 1 new member

3.       EMPL - needs 2 new members

4.       EDST -needs 1 new member

Thanks
Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Educational and Community Supports
1235 University of Oregon
Eugene, Oregon 97403-1235
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20140916/683674db/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: YE/TAG Open House and Marji DeBuse Retirement Celebration'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues:

The Center for Youth Enrichment/TAG Education enthusiastically invites you to our open house and celebration for our Director, Dr. Marji DeBuse, who is retiring at the end of September.

Please join us in recognizing her years of innovative programming for K-12 students, mentoring of teachers, providing COE undergraduate and graduate coursework related to education of high potential, high performing children and adults, and service in support of gifted education at the local and state levels, nationally and internationally---and ALWAYS advocating for talented and gifted students.

Date: Friday, September 26
Time: 3:00PM - 6:00PM
Where: YE/TAG Office at 1859 E. 15th (house on the NE corner of 15th and Villard Alley, one block east of the Bean dorm complex). Free parking on Villard St. by Maude Kerns Art Center.

RSVP! To Rita Svanks at supers at uoregon or 541.346.3084

text:
b'Dear Colleagues:

The Center for Youth Enrichment/TAG Education enthusiastically invites you to our open house and celebration for our Director, Dr. Marji DeBuse, who is retiring at the end of September.

Please join us in recognizing her years of innovative programming for K-12 students, mentoring of teachers, providing COE undergraduate and graduate coursework related to education of high potential, high performing children and adults, and service in support of gifted education at the local and state levels, nationally and internationally---and ALWAYS advocating for talented and gifted students.

Date: Friday, September 26
Time: 3:00PM - 6:00PM
Where: YE/TAG Office at 1859 E. 15th (house on the NE corner of 15th and Villard Alley, one block east of the Bean dorm complex). Free parking on Villard St. by Maude Kerns Art Center.

RSVP! To Rita Svanks at supers at uoregon or 541.346.3084

subject: b'coe-fac: Welcome, Faculty'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

I am writing to formally welcome all new and returning faculty. I have had the pleasure of speaking with many of you in the past few days and weeks, and I look forward to many more conversations.

We are embarking on an exciting academic year, one that affords us opportunities to hire new faculty colleagues, revisit and renew all aspects of our work, and pursue rewarding new instructional, research, and service initiatives.

In the coming weeks I hope that you will attend our upcoming welcome events occurring on the next two Fridays; the COE Welcome luncheon on September 26 (RSVP to Lisa Fortin - lfortin at uoregon.edu<mailto:lfortin at uoregon.edu>), and the all COE faculty and staff meeting on October 3 at 1pm in CSB 250. Communication, in the service of inclusive decision making, is one of my priorities for this year. You will be invited to numerous additional opportunities to communicate about all aspects of our work, in both informal and formal venues. With regard to the former, when you see me around the COE complex, or anywhere else, please stop me whenever you wish, to discuss whatever you wish. I do not want to miss any opportunities to learn about you and your work. I need this information in order to do my job better. For example, I have to be maximally informed in order to represent you better to both internal and external constituencies.

Again, welcome to our community of extraordinary scholars, capable staff, and talented and interesting students. Please let me know how I may make your year more rewarding.

Until we meet again, or for the first time,

Randy





-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20140919/cc5af6a9/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Internal Governance Revisions'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

In the winter and spring of this past academic year, our college began to engage in the important work of fully articulating the policies and processes by which we will govern ourselves in the future.  That work continues, and will require commitment and a sincere effort from us all going into the future.  I am writing today with some updates on the process of implementation of the faculty collective bargaining agreement that went into effect at roughly this time last year.

First, the CBA implementation team, made up of representatives from United Academics and personnel at Academic Affairs, has reviewed our internal governance documents and provided feedback designed to assist us in ensuring that the requirements of the CBA are not lost or overlooked as we codify our practices.  The most significant of these requirements is the necessity to ensure "appropriate and equitable participation" in governance for both tenure-track and non-tenure track faculty, and I have attached language regarding this from the implementation team to this message.  This mandate exists both at the college level and the unit level, and the important first step in our work this fall is to return to the documents we developed last academic year to make necessary revisions in keeping with the CBA.  I have attached a line-numbered version of the COE Internal Governance Framework with some tracked edits and notes calling attention to areas that must be addressed.

While the college's policy work is the purview of all faculty, I understand that gathering the 500+ members of the COE faculty in one place for a productive discussion is an impossible task.  That being said, I am asking for volunteers among the faculty to step forward and make their voices heard as part of a college-wide workgroup similar to the one that was convened last year to provide revised language to this office for review before we send the document back to you for your ratification.  Academic Affairs expects a ratified document by November 1, so our work must begin quickly and proceed quickly.  I propose the following:


1.       Any faculty member interested in immediately beginning work on revising our COE Internal Governance Framework document should email my assistant Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) directly to indicate their desire to participate in a college-wide workgroup.  In order to ensure that its work is undertaken quickly, requests to join this group will only be accepted until 5pm this Friday, October 3, and the first meeting of this group will take place 3:00-4:30pm next Wednesday, October 8.

2.       This college-wide workgroup will have its membership announced broadly once it is assembled so that all faculty members can provide input and feedback to the members of the workgroup directly.

3.       The workgroup shall be substantively finished with its policy development and submit the results to my office as soon as feasible.  At that time,  my office will make a review of the document and then submit it for college-wide ratification.  This will provide necessary time for unit-specific policies to be modified to be in accord with both the feedback provided by the implementation team and the COE-level policy document and to be ratified at the unit level.

Unit-specific policies will need to be revised as well.  Brigid Flannery, our Interim Assistant Dean for Academic Affairs, will send the implementation team's feedback and some supporting documents to individual unit heads in the coming days, along with guidance to assist the unit faculty in revising and ratifying those documents.  I would ask you to return your revised unit-level policies to my office for review before the November 1 deadline.

Once we have successfully completed a revision of our internal governance policies that ensure appropriate and equitable participation for both TTF and NTTF, we will spend the remainder of the term engaged with the equally-important work of establishing policies around the assignment of professional responsibilities (workload) for NTTF.  My office and Academic Affairs will assist units in organizing to prepare for this work during the month of October, so that it will go as smoothly as possible during November and December.

For a view of the year's CBA implementation-related activities, you can refer to the timeline on the following website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/cba-implementation-calendar

I look forward to working with you all this year on these important activities.

Randy

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Internal Governance Workgroup'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

The volunteer workgroup charged with revising the college-wide internal governance document according to the feedback provided by the CBA implementation team has been assembled and begun its work.  I am writing today to inform you of the composition of that group so that you can provide input directly to the members as they engage in the revision process.

The members and their email addresses are:

Tiffany Brown (tiffanyb at uoregon.edu<mailto:tiffanyb at uoregon.edu>)
Edward Kame'enui (ekamee at uoregon.edu<mailto:ekamee at uoregon.edu>)
Charles Martinez (charlesm at uoregon.edu<mailto:charlesm at uoregon.edu>)
Benedict McWhirter (benmcw at uoregon.edu<mailto:benmcw at uoregon.edu>)
Deborah Olson (dlolson at uoregon.edu<mailto:dlolson at uoregon.edu>)

The work of this group is intended to proceed quickly so that we have the maximum possible time to engage in unit-level revisions before our internal deadline of October 28.  As a result, I encourage you to provide any input you have before the group meets next on Monday, October 13th at 3pm.

Finally, please join me in thanking these faculty members for their service in this important task.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins

subject: b'coe-fac: College-Wide NTTF Workload and Promotion/Review Workgroups'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

As Brigid mentioned at the faculty meeting on October 3, this fall and winter our college will engage in the important work of developing the policies and process for NTTF Professional Responsibilities ("workload") and NTTF Promotion and Review.

As I also mentioned in my email on internal governance revisions earlier this month, gathering the 500+ members of the COE faculty in one place for a productive discussion is an impossible task.  That being said, I am once again asking for volunteers among the faculty to step forward and make their voices heard as part of two college-wide workgroups similar to the ones that have been convened in the past in order to provide language to this office for review before we send the document back to faculty for ratification. I would like this workgroup to include representatives from TTF and NTTF (including instructional and research). Brigid Flannery will lead these groups with support from Shaun.

Academic Affairs expects these two proposals to be sent from the faculty to myself by December 15 (end of the term) and then I will review and provide feedback by January 9, 2015. The final COE policy will be sent to Academic Affairs after faculty ratification by January 20.  To meet these deadlines we must begin and proceed quickly.  I propose the following:


1.      Any faculty member interested in immediately beginning work on developing the NTTF Professional Responsibilities ("Workload") document should email my assistant Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) and indicate their desire to participate in a NTTF Professional Responsibilities college-wide workgroup.  In order to ensure that its work is undertaken quickly, requests to join this group will only be accepted until 5pm this Monday, October 20, 2014 and the first meeting of this group will be scheduled once we have a group of volunteers.

2.      Any faculty member interested in immediately beginning work on developing the NTTF Promotion and Review document should email my assistant Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) and indicate their desire to participate in a NTTF Promotion and Review college-wide workgroup.  In order to ensure that its work is undertaken quickly, requests to join this group will only be accepted until 5pm this Monday, October 20, 2014, and the first meeting of this group will be scheduled once we have a group of volunteers.

3.      These college-wide workgroups will have their membership announced broadly once they are assembled so that all faculty members can provide input and feedback to the members of the workgroups directly.


The workgroups shall be substantively finished with policy development and submit the results to my office as soon as feasible but no later than December 15.  At that time,  my office will make a review of the documents and then submit them to the committees for review of the comments by January 9.  There will be an opportunity for college-wide review and ratification prior to submission to Academic Affairs no later than January 20, 2015.

For a view of the year's CBA implementation-related activities, you can refer to the timeline on the following website: http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/cba-implementation-calendar

I look forward to working with you all this year on these important activities.

Randy

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20141014/fba20aaf/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Work Sessions on COE Development'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

On behalf of Dean Kamphaus, I would like to formally invite you to attend one of two lunchtime work sessions scheduled for next week at which the dean will discuss our strategic vision for development of the COE over the next several years.  This is an exciting time for the COE and the University, and it is the dean's desire that you be well-informed about how our vision has taken shape and what it will mean for the coming years.  These lunch sessions are intended as the timely beginning of a longer conversation on these important topics.

The two lunch sessions will take place from noon to 1:00pm next Monday and Tuesday, October 20 and 21.  If you are interested in attending, please RSVP using the link below-lunch will be served:

https://jfe.qualtrics.com/form/SV_0qxpVpDEMtLdRPL

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215

541-346-1218

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Research Award program announcement'
html:
b'
The Vice President for Research & Innovation invites faculty from all academic disciplines to apply for 2015 Faculty Research Awards.

The purpose of the Faculty Research Awards program is to stimulate research by providing faculty with support for research expenses including travel, summer stipend, equipment, supplies, contractual services, shared facility use, and graduate or undergraduate student research assistance.

Faculty Research Awards are eligible for funding up to $5,500.

    The deadline for receipt of 2015 Faculty Research Award proposals is 5:00 PM, December 1, 2014.

Awardees will be notified in February, 2015.  Projects should begin by July 1, 2015, and be completed by June 30, 2016.  Final reports are due by July 31, 2016.

Guidelines and the application form are available online<http://rds.uoregon.edu/content/2015-faculty-research-awards> on the Research Development Services website.

The Faculty Research Awards Committee, composed of faculty designated by the University Senate, will evaluate proposals on the basis of their intellectual or artistic merit and make recommendations to the Vice President for Research & Innovation.

An information session on the Faculty Research Awards will be held on Tuesday, November 4, 2014, from 12:00 - 1:00 in the Metolius River Room of the Erb Memorial Union.  This session will provide an opportunity for prospective applicants to ask questions about eligibility, proposal requirements, award conditions or any other aspects of the Faculty Research Award program.

Questions should be directed to Research Development Services, rds at uoregon.edu.


Moira Kiltie
Sr. Assistant Vice President for Research
Chief of Staff, Division of Research and Innovation
University of Oregon
541-346-3188
kiltie at uoregon.edu<mailto:kiltie at uoregon.edu>
http://research.uoregon.edu<http://research.uoregon.edu/>


-------------- next part --------------

URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20141016/7c1461b2/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: NTTF Policy Committees (from Brigid Flannery)'
html:
b'
COE Faculty,

The following faculty have volunteered to serve on the NTTF policy proposal committees. We do not plan to develop department/unit policies.  Also at this time the policy for workload is only for Instructional faculty as research faculty's workload is determined by their job description.   If you have input or questions, please contact these committee members or myself (brigidf at uoreogn.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoreogn.edu>).

The committee will begin work on the policies after I attend a university wide meeting on November 4th and is to be submitted to the Dean by December 15.  Similar to previous policy development, there will be opportunities for feedback from faculty. Again we have a fast turnaround on these policy proposals so I encourage you to reach out to the committee members and I will be encouraging them to reach out to you.

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity: Winter Term'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

As we pass the halfway point in the term, Nancy and I are writing again to
seek your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL Reading Clinic
this winter. In 2014-2015, we are offering tutoring services to struggling
readers in the elementary grades in the Bethel School District. Selected
Bethel students will participate in two hours of small group reading and
writing instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each week, delivered
by trained tutors.

Tutors will receive training during Week 1 of the term, and begin teaching
intervention groups in Week 2 (note: all tutoring takes place in Bethel
schools).  Students may tutor two or four days per week.  Students may
tutor for credit, to complete a field experience requirement, or to
volunteer.  This is an excellent opportunity for UO students who are
interested in instruction or literacy or are considering a career in K-12
education.

I have attached the following documents:
1) Program flyer.  If you have a door or display area in your department,
we would greatly appreciate your help in posting this flyer.
2) Tutor information.  This document outlines tutor responsibilities and
the tutoring experience in greater depth than this email.
3) Tutor application.

If your students have any questions, they can contact me, Shaheen
Munir-McHill (munir at uoregon.edu).  More information about the CTL Reading
Clinic can be found at our website: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic and our
mission, which includes providing meaningful training opportunities to COE
 students!

Best,
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Clinic Coordinator
Nancy Nelson, Clinic Director
--
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
Reading Clinic Coordinator
Center on Teaching and Learning
University of Oregon
541.346.8388
munir at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Invited Talk: Dr. Lynne Schrum, "Developing 21st Century Environments for Learning and Teaching: Lessons Learned from Exemplary Schools"'
html:
b'
You are invited to attend:

"Developing 21st Century Environments for Learning and Teaching: Lessons Learned from Exemplary Schools"

Monday, November 17 - 3:00pm, HEDCO 230T

Featuring

Dr. Lynne Schrum
Dean, College of Education and Human Services, West Virginia University

Refreshments Provided

Lynne Schrum is Dean of the College of Education and Human Services, West Virginia University. Her research and teaching focus on appropriate uses of technology, preparing school leaders and teachers for the 21st century, and effective and successful online teaching and learning. She is a past elementary and special education teacher. She has written and edited ten books and numerous articles and recently completed ten years as editor of the Journal of Research on Technology in Education (JRTE) (2002-2012); she is also a past-president of the International Society for Technology in Education (ISTE). She has had the honor to work with teachers and leaders in many states and countries as they strive toward establishing 21st century schools, develop STEM initiatives, and design effective learning environments, including a recent investigation into exemplary school leaders throughout the US.
-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: Review of NTTF Review and Promotion Policy for COE (on behalf of the Faculty Workgroup on NTTF Promotion)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

We are soliciting faculty comments on the revised NTTF Promotion Policy, attached. We were charged with bringing our existing policy in compliance with the CBA. Although the intent and content of the existing COE NTTF Promotion Policy remains largely the same, changes were mostly to add clarity and specifics around appointment definitions, timelines, materials and the actual activities involved in promotion.

The largest changes were to the matrix at the end of the document (labeled Figure 1) that delineates the NTTF Ranks and Appointment Criteria. We made changes in the general language in order to have parallel structure across appointments and ranks. We also provided examples of how the criteria are instantiated at each level. The policy also now includes provisions for adjunct faculty and postdoctoral fellows as instructed by the CBA.

PLEASE NOTE: We did NOT develop the descriptions for the Clinical Practice Professor or the Research Professor appointments. These will be developed winter term to allow for a wider range of discussion by COE faculty.

We apologize for having a very tight deadline. In order to incorporate your feedback get the revised policy to the Dean by the deadline, we need your feedback by NOON on FRIDAY December 12th. Thank you for your participation in generating this critical COE policy.

Feedback can be provided at the following link: https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_3U8EtR1tQ5msVZX

Committee:
McKay Sohlberg
Mark Horney
Erin Chaparro
Jo Smith
Seth May
Soshana Kerewsky
Rob Horner
Heather Moore
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20141206/8f56cb43/attachment-0001.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Clinical Professor Classification Discussion'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

You are cordially invited to join members of the COE Work Group on NTTF Promotion Policy for a discussion of the new Clinical Professor classification.  The work group seeks input from all faculty regarding the definition of various elements of this series of NTTF instructional ranks so that it can be fully implemented within our college according to the guidelines laid out in the faculty CBA (Article 15, Section2a).

This discussion/work session will take place from noon to 1:00pm on January 7, 2015 in Hedco 240.

We look forward to seeing you there.

Regards,

subject: b'coe-fac: Jan 14 - Research Faculty Work Group Meeting (from Lauren\tLindstrom)'
html:
b'

I have attached the research faculty appointment  guidelines from Academic Affairs.  The purpose of our meeting on January 14 is to clarify the requirements for Research Associates in comparison to Research Professors within the College of Education.

Lauren

subject: b'coe-fac: New Courses and Curriculum Changes for 2015-2016 (from Brigid Flannery)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

I Hope winter term has gotten off to a good start for you all. I just wanted to alert you that submissions for Curriculum Committee are due January 23, 2015 by 3:00 pm.

Any changes to curriculum (new or modifications) need to be submitted through the online link on the COE Academic Affairs webpage (https://education.uoregon.edu/governance/coe-and-uo-policies-and-procedures).

Please be sure to develop syllabi based on COE template (attached and online), secured department  approval,  and have a memo from the department head (describing, at a minimum: change, rationale for change and that it was approved by faculty vote).

Have a good term... looking ahead, the Spring deadline is April 17, 2015 by 3:00 pm

K. Brigid Flannery

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Faculty Fund Awards - Call for Proposals - Due Feb 2'
html:
b'
COLLEGE OF EDUCATION FACULTY FUND AWARDS<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/>

The College of Education's Faculty Fund Awards provide financial support for the innovative ideas that contribute to the development of the early career of our faculty members. Funding is meant to catalyze projects and help faculty members achieve sustainability.

Eligibility: All College of Education faculty (FTE of .5 or greater) are eligible to apply for awards.

Applications will be based on meritorious factors that include:

  *   Projects which are not yet funded or have no other funding sources available
  *   Projects in a current area of priority or importance for the college
  *   High visibility projects
  *   Applicants that have not received a faculty fund award in the past three years

Application Steps:

  *   Complete and submit the proposal application<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/> by February 2, 2015.
  *   Deans of the College of Education will notify applicants being considered by March 2, 2015.
  *   Preliminary proposal applicants chosen will submit fuller proposals that:
     *   Develop the design and implementation plans
     *   Propose a plan to evaluate the initiative
     *   Propose a detailed budget
  *   Final applications will be due March 20, 2015. Applications will be reviewed and award decisions made by the deans of the College of Education. The COE Office of Development will review applications for alignment with the fund's intention.
  *   Project funding will be announced by April 3, 2015.
  *   Lead faculty in any funded project will give an annual written update to the donor. The awardees will also provide the COE Office of Development with necessary narrative and fiscal information to submit an annual report to the donor on the use and impact of funds.

Preliminary Proposal deadline: February 2, 2015

Review the funds available and determine which funding source is the best fit for your proposed project, then complete and submit the proposal form: https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/.

Please direct questions to Andrea Olson (andreao at uoregon.edu<mailto:andreao at uoregon.edu>).

subject: b'coe-fac: VPRI announcement of two programs in support of faculty research, scholarship and creative inquiry'
html:
b'
The Vice President for Research & Innovation invites faculty from all academic disciplines to apply for two new award programs:  Faculty Seed Grants and Faculty Research Travel Grants.

The purpose of the Faculty Seed Grant program is to support new programs of research, scholarship and creativity likely to result in published research, intellectual productivity, creative endeavors, and external grant proposals to foundations or agencies.  Faculty Seed Grants are available to scholars from all disciplines.  They are awarded during each academic term of the year beginning in the spring of 2015.  Faculty Seed Grants provided a maximum award of $2,500.  The deadline for receipt of 2015 spring term Faculty Seed Grant applications is 5:00 PM on March 20, 2015.  Deadlines for receipt of applications for upcoming academic terms are posted in the guidelines.

The Faculty Research Travel Grant program aims to improve the competitiveness of research proposals from UO faculty by facilitating interactions with prospective federal or foundation sponsors.  The program grants travel funds of up to $1,000 for faculty to meet with program officers at federal funding agencies and private foundations.  The program is available to faculty members at all career stages and from all disciplines.  There are no deadlines for applications for Faculty Research Travel Grants; applications will be accepted at any time.

Guidelines and the application forms for Faculty Seed Grants and Faculty Research Travel Grants are available online<http://rds.uoregon.edu/content/internal-funding-opportunities> on the Research Development Services website.

Questions about either of these programs should be directed to Research Development Services, rds at uoregon.edu<file:///F:\Internal%20Award%20Programs\Faculty%20Research%20Awards\Faculty%20Research%20Awards%202014-2015\Announcements\rds@uoregon.edu>.


Moira Kiltie
Sr. Assistant Vice President for Research
Chief of Staff, Division of Research and Innovation
University of Oregon
541-346-3188
kiltie at uoregon.edu<mailto:kiltie at uoregon.edu>
http://research.uoregon.edu<http://research.uoregon.edu/>

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Instructional NTTF Workload Policy Update (on behalf of Policy Development Workgroup)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

The instructional NTTF workload policy committee has sent a draft policy to the dean and after he gives his feedback to the committee on January 16th, it will be rolled out to the faculty on January 21st.

Please make time on your calendars now to review this document. A Qualtrics site will be set up to receive your written comments.

The committee will hold one college-wide meeting to discuss and answer questions about it on Friday, January 23rd, 9-10 am in Hedco 230T.  An executive summary is attached.  After this meeting, your comments will be considered for incorporation into the document before it returns to the dean for final COE approval.  It will then be sent to Academic Affairs for final approval.  This policy will guide determination of workload FTE for all instructional NTTF (not research) in the college.


Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

The instructional NTTF workload policy committee has sent a draft policy to the dean and after he gives his feedback to the committee on January 16th, it will be rolled out to the faculty on January 21st.

Please make time on your calendars now to review this document. A Qualtrics site will be set up to receive your written comments.

The committee will hold one college-wide meeting to discuss and answer questions about it on Friday, January 23rd, 9-10 am in Hedco 230T.  An executive summary is attached.  After this meeting, your comments will be considered for incorporation into the document before it returns to the dean for final COE approval.  It will then be sent to Academic Affairs for final approval.  This policy will guide determination of workload FTE for all instructional NTTF (not research) in the college.


Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

subject: b'coe-fac: Reclassification Committee - Call for Volunteers (for Lauren Lindstrom)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty -- I am writing to invite your participation on a special ad hoc committee - the Reclassification Review Committee for career non tenure track research faculty.   The purpose of this committee will be to review and make recommendations for research faculty who are requesting reclassification into the new Research Professor ranks (Research Assistant Professor, Research Associate Professor, and Research Professor). The committee will meet once in early February to review requests and  make recommendations to the Dean.

We are specifically recruiting faculty for the committee representing the following groups:
1) Research Associate or Sr. Research Associates in College of Education research/outreach units
2)  TTF or NTTF Faculty with experience supervising and reviewing performance for research/outreach faculty

Please contact Lauren Lindstrom (lindstrm at uoregon.edu<mailto:lindstrm at uoregon.edu>) by Wednesday Jan 28  if you have questions or would like to volunteer for committee service.

all the best,

Lauren

Lauren Lindstrom, Ph.D.
Associate Dean of Research and Outreach
-------------- next part --------------

URL: <https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/private/coe-fac/attachments/20150121/e909aa87/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Save the Date for AERA Conference Attendees April 18'
html:
b'
Hello,

For those faculty and students who are attending the AERA Conference in Chicago, this year the University of Oregon College of Education will be hosting a reception to showcase the great COE faculty and student research that is presented at the conference.  The reception will be held on Saturday, April 18th from 7 to 9 pm at the University Club of Chicago.  In addition to our own AERA attendees, we are inviting local COE alumni, giving them the chance to hang out, chat with faculty and students, and learn about the world class research the COE does.

Could you please let us know:

1)            If you will be in attendance at this conference;

2)            If you are making a presentation let us know what that presentation title is, along with the names of any co-presenters;

3)            Names and email addresses of any colleagues from other universities you would like us to personally invite.  Our event will be announced in the AERA conference program, so all AERA attendees will know about the reception.

This notice serves as a "Save the Date".  An invitation that will allow you to RSVP will arrive in your mailbox sometime in late February or Early March.
Let me know if you have any questions!

Thanks,
Lisa




[April 18-AERA 2015]


Save the Date


College of Education reception
AERA 2015
University Club of Chicago<http://www.ucco.com>
7-9 p.m. Saturday, April 18


E-mail invitation with additional
details to follow in late February.





[http://pages.uoregon.edu/edmatters/big-questions/icon-www.png]




education.uoregon.edu<https://education.uoregon.edu/>





[http://pages.uoregon.edu/edmatters/big-questions/icon-email-send.png]




edmatters at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20edmatters at uoregon.edu>





[http://pages.uoregon.edu/edmatters/big-questions/icon-address-hedco.png]




College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215

subject: b'coe-fac: NTTF Assignment of Professional Responsibilities Policy\tReview'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

Attached please find the policy on assignment of professional responsibilities for non-tenure track faculty in the COE ("NTTF workload") as crafted by the volunteer policy workgroup and amended with feedback from the dean.  It comprises three elements: an executive summary of the policy, a policy document, and an FTE calculator spreadsheet.

Your review and input on all three documents is requested to ensure that the policy they outline meets with your approval and can be forwarded to the dean for final review and submission to academic affairs on behalf of the college.  The workgroup has established a Qualtrics survey for collecting your input at the following location:

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_51GMNoRB46dBwm9

Please provide your feedback before 5pm on Thursday, January 27.

Additionally, the members of the workload work group can address any questions or concerns you have directly.  The members of the work group are:

-Susan Boettcher, Communication Disorders and Sciences
-Tiffany Brown, Couples and Family Therapy
-Johanna Larson, Communication Disorders and Sciences
-Christopher Murray, SPED
-Deborah Olson, SPED
-Alison Schmitke, UOTeach
-Mark Van Ryzin, EMPL

The work group is hosting an open general discussion of the policy on Friday, January 23 at 9am in Hedco 230T, and a luncheon will be hosted by the dean in early February (stay tuned for details) to discuss any final amendments he is making to the policy before submission to academic affairs.

Thank you for your attention to this important policy development process, and please join me in thanking the work group for the tremendous effort they have put forth to generate this policy.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1218

subject: b'coe-fac: Candidates for Dean of UO Graduate School'
html:
b'
COE Faculty,

As a college with a large number of graduate programs,  the Graduate School and its work is important to our future and the future of our students. For the first time in a while there will be a Dean of the UO Graduate School.

I know it is a busy time of year and you may not have had time to go to the presentations by the three internal candidates. There is still an opportunity to have input into the selection of the Dean of the Graduate School. I encourage you to read the materials, view their presentations, and provide comments to the surveys  - due 5pm on Tuesday January 27. See the message below.

Thanks
Brigid
Member of the Dean of Graduate School Search Committee


From: Provost Office [mailto:provost at uoregon.edu]
Sent: Thursday, January 22, 2015 9:37 AM
To: Brigid Flannery
Subject: Dean of Graduate School Finalists' Survey reminder


[http://www.blackboardconnected.com/images/InstitutionLogos/logo_176761.jpg]

Colleagues:

We have been very fortunate to have outstanding finalists for the Dean of the Graduate School visit with campus groups during the past week.

If you met with them or attended their presentations, please take a few minutes and complete the feedback survey for the candidates.  This mechanism provides feedback to the Provost.  You will find the surveys listed for each candidate at: http://provost.uoregon.edu/content/dean-graduate-school-finalists  The feedback surveys will be open until 5:00 pm, Tuesday, January 27.

If you missed the presentations or want to view them again, the links to each candidate\xe2\x80\x99s presentation are active and found on the site listed above.   They will also be available until 5:00 pm on January 27.

Thank you,
Kathy L.Warden
Project & Operations Manager
Dean of Graduate School Search Committee
Office of the Sr. Vice President and Provost
Note:  We are having some technical problems with Blackboard, our mass e-mail communication system. This message may contain one or more stray "!" within the text. We are working with Blackboard's customer service staff to fix the problem in future messages.

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150123/86c66d93/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: NTTF Policy Feedback Lunch'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

I am happy to invite you to a luncheon with Dean Kamphaus and members of the workgroups responsible for development of the policies for NTTF workload and promotion and review.  The purpose will be for the dean to present any changes he is introducing to the final policy documents before they are forwarded to academic affairs, and to provide a venue for discussion of those changes.  Additionally, it will a good opportunity to thank the work groups and other faculty involved in this development process for their efforts.

The luncheon is currently scheduled for February 4, from 1:00 to 2:30pm in Hedco 340.  Please RSVP by the end of the day Friday, January 30, at the following link if you plan to attend:

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_abHxFxURTbOMezj

The location will be changed if the number of attendees warrants-all those who have RSVPed will receive a notice of the change if it takes place.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean

The luncheon is currently scheduled for February 4, from 1:00 to 2:30pm in Hedco 340.  Please RSVP by the end of the day Friday, January 30, at the following link if you plan to attend:

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_abHxFxURTbOMezj

The location will be changed if the number of attendees warrants-all those who have RSVPed will receive a notice of the change if it takes place.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Travel Awards Update'
html:
b'
Hello,
Additional funding has been made available to the COE Travel Awards program, giving us the opportunity to provide more awards and open the application process to a broader pool of students.  Any doctoral student traveling to a professional conference with the express purpose of presenting a poster/paper may now apply.  For more information or to submit an application, please click here to visit our website<https://education.uoregon.edu/college-education-scholarships/coe-2014-travel-conference-award>.

subject: b'coe-fac: NTTF Promotion and Review policy'
html:
b'
COE Faculty,

The NTTF Promotion and Review Committee thanks you for attending meetings on the new research and instructional ranks. The committee has reviewed the comments from those meetings and the feedback that was submitted directly to them.  Attached you will find the new policy based on comments received.  We will need to submit out final policy to the Dean by late Friday.

We would like you to have one more chance to review the policy. Please review and comment on the following items that had significant changes a) Clinical Professor Rank (pp 9-10),  b) the Research Professor Rank (pp 15-16 ; Table 1) (and Research Associate as a result; pp. 13-15),c) changes to Professor of Practice (pp 10-11) and d) Reclassification procedures (pp 22-24).
Please use the Qualtrics at https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_86OZp3RGJc9DO5L
Feedback needed to be provided by noon on Friday January 30th.

Thank you
NTTF Promotion and Review Committee

541-346-2496

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: COE Faculty Fund Awards - Call for Proposals - Due Feb\t2'
html:
b'
COLLEGE OF EDUCATION FACULTY FUND AWARDS<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/>

The College of Education's Faculty Fund Awards provide financial support for the innovative ideas that contribute to the development of the early career of our faculty members. Funding is meant to catalyze projects and help faculty members achieve sustainability.

Eligibility: All College of Education faculty (FTE of .5 or greater) are eligible to apply for awards.

Applications will be based on meritorious factors that include:

  *   Projects which are not yet funded or have no other funding sources available
  *   Projects in a current area of priority or importance for the college
  *   High visibility projects
  *   Applicants that have not received a faculty fund award in the past three years

Application Steps:

  *   Complete and submit the proposal application<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/> by February 2, 2015.
  *   Deans of the College of Education will notify applicants being considered by March 2, 2015.
  *   Preliminary proposal applicants chosen will submit fuller proposals that:
     *   Develop the design and implementation plans
     *   Propose a plan to evaluate the initiative
     *   Propose a detailed budget
  *   Final applications will be due March 20, 2015. Applications will be reviewed and award decisions made by the deans of the College of Education. The COE Office of Development will review applications for alignment with the fund's intention.
  *   Project funding will be announced by April 3, 2015.
  *   Lead faculty in any funded project will give an annual written update to the donor. The awardees will also provide the COE Office of Development with necessary narrative and fiscal information to submit an annual report to the donor on the use and impact of funds.

Preliminary Proposal deadline: February 2, 2015

Review the funds available and determine which funding source is the best fit for your proposed project, then complete and submit the proposal form: https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/.

Please direct questions to Andrea Olson (andreao at uoregon.edu<mailto:andreao at uoregon.edu>).

subject: b'coe-fac: Grant Writing Seminar March 20 (on behalf of Lauren\tLindstrom)'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues - I wanted to make you aware of an upcoming grant writing seminar offered through the UO Research Office - See below for details.

The Office of Research & Innovation, through its Research Development Services unit, is sponsoring a one-day seminar, "Write Winning Grant Proposals", on Friday, March 20, 2015, from 8:30 - 5:00 pm.  All faculty members and post-doctoral appointees are eligible to attend.

The seminar will be presented by Grant Writers Seminars and Workshops.  This organization, composed of successful university researchers, is well known for their comprehensive and high quality training programs for faculty investigators.  They present this seminar at many of the nation's best research universities.  We last hosted them on our campus in the Fall of 2012, and their workshop was very well received.

This one-day seminar provides a step-by-step guide to developing successful applications for funding by federal funding agencies, with a specific focus on NIH and NSF.  The trainer for our seminar is Peg AtKisson, Ph.D., previously a federally funded faculty member at Tufts University School of Medicine.   She founded Proposal Development Services at Tufts, assisting faculty there in competing successfully for external awards from a wide range of agencies and private funders.

All faculty registered will receive a comprehensive reference workbook in either NSF or NIH format provided as a part of their participation at no cost, courtesy of my office.  Postdoctoral appointees are also encouraged to attend, and the Research office will split the cost of their workbooks ($70) with their labs.

Please register with Research Development Services by contacting them at rds at uoregon.edu<mailto:rds at uoregon.edu> .  Questions may be directed to Lynn Stearney, Director, Research Development Services at stearney at uoregon.edu<mailto:stearney at uoregon.edu> or 346-8308


Lauren

Lauren Lindstrom, Ph.D
Associate Dean of Research and Outreach
Director, Center at Oregon for Research in Education (CORE)
College of Education, University of Oregon
(541) 346-1399
lindstrm at uoregon.edu<mailto:lindstrm at uoregon.edu>

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150130/3d658228/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: NTTF Policies to be Forwarded to Academic Affairs (from Dean Kamphaus)'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

We had a wonderful meeting Wednesday where we discussed the results of the faculty work on these policies. I appreciate the work of Lisa Fortin who provided us with a tasty lunch in a relaxed venue - Gerlinger Alumni Lounge. I also appreciated the opportunity to thank the committee members personally for their many hours of work. As a reminder, the combined list of members for these two groups is:

Susan Boettcher
Tiffany Brown
Erin Chaparro
Rob Horner
Mark Horney
Shoshana Kerewsky
Johanna Larson
Seth May
Heather Moore
Chris Murray
Deborah Olson
Alison Schmitke
Jo Smith
McKay Sohlberg
Mark Van Ryzin

In addition, Brigid Flannery devoted innumerable hours to this effort with the support of Shaun Haskins. Nice work, all.

As promised, I am providing copies of the policies as I will submit them to Academic Affairs. My changes and revisions are provided as are my rationales. Please see the 'comments' boxes included. I did share this same feedback with the faculty in attendance at lunch, and received their questions and concerns.  Chief among these was the role of the FTE calculation spreadsheet that accompanied the policy document in making FTE decisions.

As follow up, I have an idea for expediting our work on the load "calculators" addressed in this draft. I propose asking Department and Research Unit Heads to use the calculators on a trial basis this year, and submit the results for analysis by NTTF faculty/committee, Brigid, and myself. This process would give us data from a real world trial that could inform any future consideration of the method, and provide information on the philosophical and practical implications of the use of this tool for our college. With this information COE would be better prepared to consider any necessary revisions of the calculator, or to consider alternative approaches. Of course, we would have to be careful to analyze only group data so that we do not violate the personnel confidentiality of individual NTTF faculty.

For now, we turn our attention to the TTF policies. I thank you for your effort and collaboration in this important governance work.

Regards,

Randy

b'Dear Faculty,

We had a wonderful meeting Wednesday where we discussed the results of the faculty work on these policies. I appreciate the work of Lisa Fortin who provided us with a tasty lunch in a relaxed venue - Gerlinger Alumni Lounge. I also appreciated the opportunity to thank the committee members personally for their many hours of work. As a reminder, the combined list of members for these two groups is:

Susan Boettcher
Tiffany Brown
Erin Chaparro
Rob Horner
Mark Horney
Shoshana Kerewsky
Johanna Larson
Seth May
Heather Moore
Chris Murray
Deborah Olson
Alison Schmitke
Jo Smith
McKay Sohlberg
Mark Van Ryzin

In addition, Brigid Flannery devoted innumerable hours to this effort with the support of Shaun Haskins. Nice work, all.

As promised, I am providing copies of the policies as I will submit them to Academic Affairs. My changes and revisions are provided as are my rationales. Please see the 'comments' boxes included. I did share this same feedback with the faculty in attendance at lunch, and received their questions and concerns.  Chief among these was the role of the FTE calculation spreadsheet that accompanied the policy document in making FTE decisions.

As follow up, I have an idea for expediting our work on the load "calculators" addressed in this draft. I propose asking Department and Research Unit Heads to use the calculators on a trial basis this year, and submit the results for analysis by NTTF faculty/committee, Brigid, and myself. This process would give us data from a real world trial that could inform any future consideration of the method, and provide information on the philosophical and practical implications of the use of this tool for our college. With this information COE would be better prepared to consider any necessary revisions of the calculator, or to consider alternative approaches. Of course, we would have to be careful to analyze only group data so that we do not violate the personnel confidentiality of individual NTTF faculty.

For now, we turn our attention to the TTF policies. I thank you for your effort and collaboration in this important governance work.

Regards,

Randy

subject: b'coe-fac: Sabbatical Application Deadline - Feb 28'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

This is a reminder that the university-wide deadline for sabbatical leave requests for academic year 15-16 is February 28, 2015.  Applications for sabbatical leave must be submitted to your department head or unit director for review, then to the dean's office, before final submission to Academic Affairs for approval.

Policies and processes governing sabbatical leave applications, including criteria for eligibility, can be found at the Academic Affairs website under "Leaves & Retirement" (http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/academic-and-sabbatical-leaves), as well as in the United Academics Faculty Collective Bargaining Agreement, Article 33.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403
541.346.1218

subject: b'coe-fac: Working Group Invitation for Tenure-Track Policies (from Lauren Lindstrom)'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues:
As many of you know, the new Collective Bargaining Agreement has provided an opportunity for us to review and update many of our internal policies and procedures.  During Spring term, Shaun Haskins and I will be facilitating a working group to  focus on policies related to tenure track faculty (TTF).   I am currently asking for volunteers from the TTF to participate in this group. I do anticipate there being opportunities for input from additional faculty during the development process. Specifically, the group will be developing and revising College level policies for:

1.       TTF promotion and tenure including post-tenure reviews

2.       TTF professional responsibility (aka "workload")
We intend to have one organizational meeting prior to Spring break but the majority of this review and development work will occur between April 1 and May 18.
Please let Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) in the Dean's office know if you would like to serve on this important working group.  We'd like to have names of interested faculty by Wednesday March 4.
Thanks very much,
Lauren
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150226/5f02d63a/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Curriculum Change Requests \xe2\x80\x93 Qualtrics link'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty
A number of your colleagues have been working on changes to improve  their curriculum offerings for their students. We have proposals for curriculum changes from four program areas: FHS (ECE), CPSY (Prevention Science), CPSY (UG), and CPSY (CFT).  -*
Your curriculum committee (which includes reps from all 4 departments  - see below)  has already completed an initial review of these courses.  The COE Curriculum Committee requested some additional information as well as a number of changes/additions for these proposals.  The proposals you see here have been revised based on input from the curriculum committee and include a memo about how they addressed or why they did not address the recommendations of the COE Curriculum Committee.
This step is an opportunity for the faculty as a whole to review the proposals, and provide any comments on the proposed changes. Please provide your comments by Tuesday March 4th at 3pm. Then there will be a second email and Qualtrics link to allow an opportunity to vote on these proposals between March 9th  and 12th , 2015.
The Qualtrics link below will take you to a survey to review the proposals and offer comments. The survey is organized by submission packets. There are four packets but several have several courses in each packet . The link is:
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_6eRsK01UMBMRGIZ
Thanks for actively participating in the internal governance and curriculum approval process of the COE.


Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Interim Assistant Dean of Academic Affairs
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>

Curriculum Committee

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: grad-heads: Dixon Innovation Award, Teaching Awards, Sylff- Deadline: April 28'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Brandy Teel.  For questions, contact her at bota at uoregon.edu<mailto:bota at uoregon.edu>

**PASS THIS ALONG TO GRADUATE STUDENTS AND TO FACULTY WHO ADVISE GRADUATE STUDENTS**

Award season is upon us! The Graduate School invites nominations and applications for the following four awards:

Julie and Rocky Dixon Graduate Innovation Award
The Office of the Vice President for Research & Innovation and the Graduate School are pleased to announce the call for nominations for the Julie and Rocky Dixon Graduate Innovation Award.  This fellowship is designed to support up to four doctoral students who are interested in pursuing innovative experiences that will prepare them for careers outside of academia in areas including but not limited to industry, business, and the non-profit and government sectors.  Awards include a $14,000 stipend and more. To be eligible, students must be advanced to candidacy by Fall 2015.
Deadline: Tuesday, April 28, 2015
https://gradschool.uoregon.edu/dixon-innovation-award

Oregon Sylff Graduate Fellowship for International Research
Master's and doctoral students are eligible for this award, which recognizes graduate work involving research and scholarly endeavors in programs and projects with an international dimension. Awards of up to $6,000 are made to master's level recipients and up to $12,000 are made to doctoral level recipients. In 2014-15, six awards were made.
Deadline: Tuesday, April 28, 2015
http://gradschool.uoregon.edu/SYLFF

Graduate Teaching Excellence Award
This award recognizes outstanding teaching performances by experienced graduate teaching fellows (GTFs) who have demonstrated a commitment to developing their instructional skills, while at the same time excelling in their academic degree program. Up to two awards of $1,000 each will be made.
Deadline: Tuesday, April 28, 2015
http://gradschool.uoregon.edu/teaching-excellence-award

The Kimble First Year Teaching Award
This award is designed to recognize outstanding teaching performances by graduate teaching fellows (GTFs) leading a discussion section or lab in the first year of teaching, or as the sole instructor for a course in the first year of teaching, while maintaining a strong academic record. Up to two awards of $500 will be made.
Deadline: Friday, June 26, 2015
https://gradschool.uoregon.edu/kimble-teaching-award

**PASS THIS ALONG TO GRADUATE STUDENTS AND TO FACULTY WHO ADVISE GRADUATE STUDENTS**

Sincerely,

Brandy Teel
Student Engagement and Opportunities Manager
Graduate School
133 Susan Campbell Hall
University of Oregon
bota at uoregon.edu<mailto:bota at uoregon.edu>
541-346-2489
gradschool.uoregon.edu
[cid:D0C10156-F793-42C0-B92A-A5C616314FA2]<https://www.facebook.com/pages/University-of-Oregon-Graduate-School/358578800834363>

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic Tutor Opportunity: Winter Term'
html:
b'
Hello everyone,

Just a heads up that we are currently recruiting tutors for spring term.
If you have students who are interested in a field experience, please
encourage them to contact me for more information!

Best,
Shaheen

--
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
Reading Clinic Coordinator
Center on Teaching and Learning
University of Oregon
541.346.8388
munir at uoregon.edu

On Tue, Nov 4, 2014 at 12:44 PM, Shaheen Munir-McHill <munir at uoregon.edu>
wrote:

> Hello COE faculty,
>
> As we pass the halfway point in the term, Nancy and I are writing again to
> seek your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in our CTL Reading Clinic
> this winter. In 2014-2015, we are offering tutoring services to struggling
> readers in the elementary grades in the Bethel School District. Selected
> Bethel students will participate in two hours of small group reading and
> writing instruction per day, Monday through Thursday each week, delivered
> by trained tutors.
>
> Tutors will receive training during Week 1 of the term, and begin teaching
> intervention groups in Week 2 (note: all tutoring takes place in Bethel
> schools).  Students may tutor two or four days per week.  Students may
> tutor for credit, to complete a field experience requirement, or to
> volunteer.  This is an excellent opportunity for UO students who are
> interested in instruction or literacy or are considering a career in K-12
> education.
>
> I have attached the following documents:
> 1) Program flyer.  If you have a door or display area in your department,
> we would greatly appreciate your help in posting this flyer.
> 2) Tutor information.  This document outlines tutor responsibilities and
> the tutoring experience in greater depth than this email.
> 3) Tutor application.
>
> If your students have any questions, they can contact me, Shaheen
> Munir-McHill (munir at uoregon.edu).  More information about the CTL Reading
> Clinic can be found at our website: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.
>
> Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic and our
> mission, which includes providing meaningful training opportunities to COE
>  students!
>
> Best,
> Shaheen Munir-McHill, Clinic Coordinator
> Nancy Nelson, Clinic Director
> --
> Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
> Reading Clinic Coordinator
> Center on Teaching and Learning
> University of Oregon
> 541.346.8388
> munir at uoregon.edu
>
>
> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
> University of Oregon
> College of Education
> http://education.uoregon.edu
> This mailing list is for for official UO College of Education
> communications. See:  https://it.uoregon.edu/acceptable-use-policy
> For help in using the list please contact Kenneth Loge at
> kloge at uoregon.edu
>
>
