subject: b'coe-fac: AERA Brochure'
html:
b'
Hello,
Attached is a draft of the text that will go into our forthcoming AERA brochure.  If you are participating in AERA, please take a moment to find the information relating to your presentations or sessions and let me know if it looks correct or if there are changes I need to make.  Please submit your comments by Friday, March 13th.  Also, if you or someone you know is receiving special recognition of some sort at AERA and it's not included, please let me know so we can add it.

This isn't meant to be in APA Style or any specific format.  The sessions are listed by date and time and the participants for the sessions are in alphabetical order.  It's solely a listing of faculty and students we have participating in AERA, so please think of it in that regard and not as an academic document.


Thanks,
Lisa



Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Outreach
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: Thanks and Congratulations (from Dean Kamphaus)'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

I congratulate all of you on your many accomplishments that will be highlighted at the AERA meeting in Chicago this week. I am impressed by both the breadth and depth of our participation in this high profile meeting.

I also wish to thank Lisa Fortin, Cody Pinkston, and Lillian Winkler-Rios for their extraordinary work to create our first College-wide reception on Saturday night at the University Club, our agenda of U of O awards and presentations distributed yesterday, and all ancillary support activities. These individuals and others are allowing us to respond forcefully to the request of our many alumni for engagement with them at AERA.

The U of O has been well represented at many meetings, including the recent meeting of the Council for Exceptional Children (CEC) where Kent McIntosh received an early career research award. Please see his story on Around the O at http://around.uoregon.edu/content/college-education-professor-wins-prestigious-award.

It's been a great year, and I look forward to celebrating your work at future events in Chicago, Eugene, and elsewhere.

Gratefully,

Randy
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150415/e24c5270/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Agenda Item for May 1 Faculty/Staff Meeting (from Dean\tKamphaus)'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

I am writing today with a proposal to strengthen faculty governance. I seek greater access to faculty advice and counsel than is available in our current governance structure. I brought this desire to the attention of our faculty governance committee in the Fall, with a promise to make a concrete proposal at a later date.

In brief, I propose that we form a standing Dean's Faculty Advisory Committee, not unlike our currently functioning Dean's Student Advisory Committee. I propose further that we discuss this IDEA at the next faculty meeting on May 1. My initial thought is to form a faculty nominated committee on an annual basis, one that includes broad representation from the College instructional, clinical, and research units.

I offer the following examples of issues, decisions, and plans from my recent agenda, for which I seek more timely faculty input than is practical in our current governance structure.

a. Space allocations for GTFs, research units, student diversity GTF, etc.,
b. Responses to requests for input regarding University, State, and National legislative and regulatory proposals,
c. Responses to requests for College, community, university, corporate, and other collaborations,
d. Academic planning,
e. Enrollment management,
f. Fiscal planning and management,
g. Development and donor relations, and
e. Computer equipment replacement cycles.

My optimistic view is that we discuss the general parameters of this proposal, take some action at our next meeting, and begin committee operations in the Fall.

I thank you for considering my request,

Randy
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150423/29da46f9/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Reminder:  Commencement Regalia Rental for Faculty'
html:
b'
Hello,
For those of you who don't own your own regalia, the COE will pay for your rental for our graduation ceremony.  Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. To guarantee exact hood colors please make your order by April 30 (TODAY).  After that time it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.  The cut off for ordering faculty regalia is May 15.

On the order form, choose the Spring ceremony.  As the COE covers the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, choose 'bill department' in the payment area.

Order your regalia here:
https://uoduckstore.com/form/faculty/regalia/  For some unknown reason this link still include 2014 dates.  I have been assured by the Duck Store folks that the information is being collected correctly for 2015.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Services
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Research Internships'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues -  As I mentioned at the faculty meeting last week, one of my priorities this year has been to create research internship opportunities for graduate students across the College.  We have developed a blog that allows faculty to post research openings and graduate students to get connected to research opportunities.

These internships may be especially helpful for first and second year doctoral students who are interested in exploring a variety of research experiences.  Please share this link with your graduate students -- so they can explore options for  2015/16 academic year internships.

http://blogs.uoregon.edu/internshipscoe/


Any questions, feel free to contact me or Jillian Tuso (jtuso at uoregon.edu<mailto:jtuso at uoregon.edu>).  Jillian is a GTF in the Dean's office who is helping to coordinate these internship opportunities.

thanks

Lauren


Lauren Lindstrom, Ph.D
Associate Dean of Research and Faculty Development

subject: b'coe-fac: Summer Tutoring Opportunity'
html:
b'
Dear COE faculty,

The CTL Reading Clinic is once again recruiting tutors for our summer
reading program.  This summer, we are partnering with the Bethel School
District to provide intervention services to students who will be entering
2nd grade in the fall.  An exciting change for this summer is that tutors
will have the opportunity to provide instruction in both reading and math.
General information can be found in the attached flyer, so please
disseminate to any student you think might be interested in this
experience.  Students can get more information by contacting me (
munir at uoregon.edu) or Anna Ingram (annad at uoregon.edu).

Thank you for your support!
Shaheen
--
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
Reading Clinic Coordinator
Center on Teaching and Learning
University of Oregon
541.346.8388
munir at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: RFP: Global Oregon Faculty Collaboration Fund -\tdeadline\tJuly 1'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Dennis Galvan--

Office of International Affairs: Global Studies Institute
Global Oregon Faculty Collaboration Fund
Made possible with the generous support of Jim and Florence Shephard

Description
The Global Studies Institute (GSI) in the UO Office of International Affairs announces a new initiative, the Global Oregon Faculty Collaboration Fund, to promote research collaboration between UO faculty and colleagues at prestigious international partner institutions.

The University of Oregon is keen to enhance faculty publication productivity, citation rates, and grant-writing success.  Internationalization is also a major priority in our Academic Plan.  To advance these goals, the Global Studies Institute identifies a list of 100 highly ranked, strategic partner universities outside the US, and provides a modest incentive for UO faculty to undertake research collaborations with colleagues at these institutions.  Such partnerships have the potential to enhance our international standing, and support faculty research.

UO faculty are invited to apply to this fund for an award to bring colleagues from a carefully selected list of top international partner universities to the UO for collaboration visits (approximately 3-6 week duration).

Awards will cover the following expenses for visiting faculty:

1)    Economy class round-trip airfare from home institution location to Eugene

2)    Housing costs while in Eugene

3)    Stipend of $350 per week while in Eugene

4)    "Global Oregon Collaboration Lecture" expenses (venue rental, publicity, a/v, etc.)

In return, visiting faculty and their UO faculty hosts are required to:

1)    Work in close collaboration during the visit on a shared research project or, where appropriate by field, other creative endeavor.

2)    Make a joint public presentation of their project during the collaboration visit as part of our new Global Oregon Collaboration Lecture series.

3)    Produce, as a result of the collaboration visit, a co-authored paper submitted for publication or for presentation at a major international conference, to be followed by submission for publication.  Depending on discipline, other possible collaboration products may include a major grant proposal or other creative product.

4)    Offer a separate, structured opportunity for students in relevant disciplines or research areas to interact directly and dynamically with the visitor during their visit to the University of Oregon.  Ideally, this visit will tie into an existing course.

Visiting colleagues funded under the Global Oregon Faculty Collaboration Fund will be designated Global Oregon Collaboration Scholars.

The next deadline is July 1, 2015.

For more information, please review the application instructions at  http://gsi.uoregon.edu/content/global-oregon-faculty-collaboration-fund<http://gsi.uoregon.edu/funding>


-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150526/684f3a89/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Undergraduate Research Award'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty:

As your undergraduates turn in those outstanding research papers you might encourage them to submit their work for consideration for a UO Libraries Undergraduate Research Award.

UO Libraries Undergraduate Research Awards recognize students who demonstrate excellent library research skills and high-quality academic work with $1,000 - $1,500 award prizes.

Final deadline is  Friday, February 12, 2016 but they can submit papers at any time.

See:  https://library.uoregon.edu/undergrad-research-award

Thanks,

Katy Lenn

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Commencement'
html:
b'
Hello,
Commencement is next Monday, June 15th from 6-8 pm in the Matthew Knight Arena.  Attached is a set of instructions for faculty participating in the COE Commencement Ceremony.  Platform party members will receive additional information.  Let me know if you're not on the list and will be joining us.  For those of you who ordered your regalia from the Duck Store, we will send out an email when it comes in (probably Wed. or Thurs.) and arrange for pick up or delivery.  Let me know if there are any questions I can answer for you.
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: Instructional FTE Calculator Pilot Program (from Dean\tKamphaus)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

Last Fall, a group of our colleagues developed a policy to guide and govern the composition of FTE for Career Track (the name I prefer over non-tenure track) instructional faculty within the COE. One of the comments I provided to them at the time that policy was submitted to the UO administration was that the FTE Calculator tool attached to it should receive further testing and vetting by the faculty at large to determine whether it serves the purposes the policy workgroup envisioned for it and whether there are ways that it could be refined to improve its accuracy.

As a result of my conversations with the workload policy development group, I have asked the academic department heads to perform a "test-run" estimation of FTE using the tool for each of their instructional career track faculty before the end of October 2015. The group has spent a generous amount of time developing resources to aid department heads, academic program coordinators, and Career Track Faculty in the use of this tool, as well as a survey to collect data on several aspects of its use.

In order to support our Career Track Faculty and the efforts of the workload committee, I would like to encourage all instructional Career Track faculty (NTTF) in the COE to follow the link below to learn more about the FTE Calculator and to take time to use the tool along with your supervisor (department head or program director) to create an estimate of FTE for your expected workload for the upcoming year, and then follow the second link below to provide feedback to the policy group once you have done so.

More information about the policy and the calculator tool, as well as the tool itself, can be found at:

https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/confluence/display/NTTFWP/NTTF+Workload+Policy+Home

Provide your feedback on the tool once you have used it with your supervisor via the survey below:

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_doqwEPreGvwDSgR

I look forward to a discussion in the Fall about what this pilot effort tells us about the tool and our ongoing efforts to guarantee that the principles of equity and fairness are upheld in the distribution of workload within the College.

With gratitude to all who worked on these policies,

Randy

-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: Request for Volunteers: COE Faculty Advisory Council'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

At our faculty-staff meeting in May, I indicated my desire to increase the participation of faculty in the day-to-day governance of the College in some key areas. Specifically, I find that we have had few mechanisms in the past to gather faculty input on communications to external policy and regulatory entities, and that I often wish I had a more direct connection to the will of the faculty when considering mundane matters concerning the direction of the college. I recently met with a group of volunteers from the faculty and staff and am pleased to announce that together we built a model that I believe will get us on the right path. The other participants in this conversation were:

Mark Horney, CATE
Richelle Krotts, Office of the Dean
Deanna Linville, CPHS
Deb Olson, SPECS
Alison Schmitke, EDST

Before asking for volunteers, let me take a moment to provide some more details on what we decided.

First, our collective sense was that this group should not be overly large in order to make it easier to meet routinely throughout the academic year. I have settled on 6 as a starting number.

Second, we agreed that this group should be convened on an ad hoc basis for its first two years, to provide me and the members latitude to determine what the long-term charge, structure and mode of operation for this group should be before we attempt to codify it in our internal governance policies.

Third, it was clear from our discussions that because the issues this group will tackle are overwhelmingly (but not exclusively) academic in nature, the composition should be primarily (but not exclusively) faculty from our academic departments. I believe 4 instructional faculty, 1 research faculty and 1 clinical/outreach faculty member should provide a good starting point. Further, because the purpose of the group is to offer a sense of collective faculty wisdom in addition to personal perspectives, only faculty in their second or later year of employment with the College and with an appointment at .75 FTE or higher will be eligible to serve. My hope is that the faculty selected for this committee will represent a broad range of instructional activities across our undergraduate, masters and doctoral programs.

Fourth, I have a secondary objective in convening this group. I hope to provide additional opportunities for professional development of our faculty in the area of leadership, and I believe service on a body like this one will offer meaningful exposure to and engagement with the issues and concerns of department heads, associate deans, and deans in the management of an academic enterprise like ours.  In order to maximize these opportunities for all faculty, as well as to provide some continuity, my plan is to have a mix of one-year and two-year appointments in this body.

Finally, let me emphasize the importance of this service to my job as well as to the college as a whole. Participation on this body will be a real commitment, and I expect that we will meet biweekly for as long as ninety minutes per session. Given those expectations, consistent attendance and a high level of participation will be baseline expectations of service. I do not want anyone to be surprised by the demands I plan to make of this group both as we negotiate its ultimate role and moving forward in service to the college.

If you are interested in serving, please contact Shaun Haskins (haskins at uoregon.edu<mailto:haskins at uoregon.edu>) to submit your name for consideration before the close of business on September 28, 2015.

Thank you,

Randy
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150619/5843a4da/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Summer'
html:
b'
Hello,

Are you teaching this summer? Are you spending this summer researching or writing grants?

If not, you can stop reading and get back to your fun.  For the rest of us:

If teaching and asking your students to do a little research, you might consider - you may have students new to campus that might need some guidance on the UO Library system.  With the compressed summer class schedule and the summer hours of the Library novices may find locating material a frustrating experience.  Consider a presentation about library resources - I am here this summer and would be delighted to speak to your class.  Getting them off to a quick and productive start could reduce stress.  Some students have already contacted me, and while I love meeting one-on-one with students, I do have a limited calendar and I worry about the students that need help but are reticent to ask -a class presentation usually works best.

If needing a little help on your own projects - I am here and am available for consultation.

Cheers,

Katy

P.S. A reminder:  As the temperature rises, the Library is deliciously air-conditioned!


-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150624/a4240c19/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Media Summary'
text:
b'On behalf of Dean Randy Kamphaus


Dear Faculty and Staff,


You may find this report on UO media activity of interest, in particular, because of the mentions of our own Atika Khurana and Yong Zhou in national and international outlets.


Regards,


Randy


Media Report: Saturday, June 13 - Friday, June 19
Total hits: Approximately 194
Highlights:

*        Commencement

*        School of Music and Dance's Aca-College Day

*        Teens with weak working memory 'more likely to engage in risky sex'(21+)

*        UO students present ideas to make Redmond more bike-friendly (19+)

*        No evidence children of same sex couples negatively impacted (15+)
Commencement 2015 Coverage:
University of Oregon graduation confers nearly 6,000 degrees<http://registerguard.com/rg/news/local/33199952-73/uo-graduation-makes-them-want-to-shout.html.csp>
The Register-Guard: A photo gallery of the UO's 2015 commencement.
University of Oregon celebrates Class of 2015<http://www.kval.com/news/local/University-of-Oregon-celebrates-Class-of-2015-307456181.html?tab=gallery>
KVAL: A photo gallery of the UO's 2015 commencement.
Congratulations, University of Oregon Class of 2015<http://www.kmtr.com/news/local/Congratulations-University-of-Oregon-2015-307455301.html>
KMTR: A photo gallery of the UO's 2015 commencement.
Graduation 2015: Ducks and well-wishers reflect on Sunday's festivities<http://www.dailyemerald.com/2015/06/14/graduation-2015-ducks-and-well-wishers-reflect-on-sundays-festivities-storify/>
Daily Emerald: A storify from the Emerald that captures commencement 2015.
University of Oregon graduate Liz Zarro creates 'products that are more than just products'<http://www.oregonlive.com/education/index.ssf/2015/06/uo_graduate_creates_products_t.html>
The Oregonian: A profile on recent graduate Liz Zarro, who was part of the UO's product design program.
Commencement the University of Oregon Social Media Channels:
Four commencement posts on the UO Facebook

*         "What you need to know"

o   Reach: 40,000 impressions

*        "Duck Walk Video"

o   Reach: 84,640 impressions

o   22,406 views

*        "Photo album" 2,005 likes, 48 shares, 29 comments,

o   Reach: 65,472 impressions

*        "Commencement Video"

o   Reach: 54,048 impressions
One UO YouTube Channel Video:

*        1,805 views
18 UO Commencement Tweets:

*        Reach: 147,896 impressions
22 UO Instagram Posts:

*        23,823 engagements
Media Mentions:
Oregon State Bar finds no wrongdoing in how UO lawyers handled student's records<http://www.oregonlive.com/education/index.ssf/2015/06/oregon_state_bar_finds_no_wron.html>
The Oregonian: The Oregon State Bar has dismissed a complaint against two UO attorneys.
How CEO dads cope with taking paternity leave<http://fortune.com/2015/06/17/ceo-dads-paternity-leave/>
Fortune: A study by UO Interim President Scott Coltrane on parental leave in the work force is cited.
In Pursuit of Knowledge: Students from the Middle East face unique challenges in Eugene<http://eugeneweekly.com/20150618/lead-story/pursuit-knowledge>
The Eugene Weekly: A cover story focusing on the challenges of international students.
CDC to Consider Routine Recommendation of Meningococcal Vaccine<https://www.thelundreport.org/content/cdc-consider-routine-recommendation-meningococcal-vaccine>
The Lund Report: The panel's recommendation comes after an outbreak at the University of Oregon.
Easy Colleges Training China's Cheaters<https://beijingtoday.com.cn/2015/06/easy-colleges-training-chinas-cheaters/>
Bejing Today: Education professor Yong Zhao is briefly quoted in this story about Chinese students being expelled from US universities for cheating.
Discipline Disparities<http://www.northcoastjournal.com/humboldt/discipline-disparities/Content?oid=2997238>
The North Coast Journal: A report released bythe UO Institute on Violence and Destructive Behavior and the Law School is cited.
Rachel Dolezal and cultural appropriation<http://www.msnbc.com/nerding-out/watch/rachel-dolezal-and-cultural-appropriation-466187843603>
MSNBC: Joseph Lowndes, professor of political science, weighs in on MSNBC's Nerd Talk. Part 1<http://www.msnbc.com/nerding-out/watch/rachel-dolezal-and-cultural-appropriation-466187843603>, Part 2<http://www.msnbc.com/nerding-out/watch/occupy-the-faculty-lounge-466241091738>, Part 3<http://www.msnbc.com/nerding-out/watch/rachel-dolezal-and-race-as-a-social-construct-466170947925>.
University of Oregon Wins AdMall Best Use of Marketing Research Award at National Student Ad Competition<http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read?GUID=30099026>
PRWeb: Upstream Advertising, the UO School of Journalism and Communication's advertising team, earned first prize at the national competition held June 10-13 at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas.
Teens with weak working memory 'more likely to engage in risky sex'<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/295536.php>
Medical News Today: A UO study by Atika Khurana, assistant professor of counseling psychology found that young people with weak working memory were more likely to end up with sexually transmitted diseases and unintended pregnancies.

*        This UO study<https://around.uoregon.edu/content/weak-working-memory-linked-higher-sexual-risk-taking-uo-study-finds> was picked up by more 20 outlets.
Why Isn't Self-Defense Training Available to Every Woman Who Wants It?<http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jocelyn-hollander/why-isnt-self-defense-training-available-to-every-woman-who-wants-it_b_7577472.html>
The Huffington Post: UO Sociologist Jocelyn Hollander pens an article on the importance-and proven benefit- of self-defense classes for women.
Trained that 'No Means No,' young Kenyan men act to stop rape<http://www.foxnews.com/health/2015/06/18/trained-that-no-means-no-young-men-act-to-stop-rape/>
FOX News: UO Sociologist Jocelyn Hollander is quoted in this article about stopping violence aimed at women in Kenya.
Archaeological Digs Continue in Burns<http://kbnd.com/kbnd-news/local-news-feed/146951>
KBND: UO Department of Archeology continues work in the Burns area.
National Society of Accountants Announces 2015 Scholarship Winners<http://www.cpapracticeadvisor.com/news/12083907/national-society-of-accountants-announces-2015-scholarship-winners>
Accounting Today Online: UO student Jordan Hamada is listed as one of the recipients.
University of Oregon to hire faculty under auspices of researchers Jim Hutchison, Eric Selker and Elizabeth Stormshak<http://registerguard.com/rg/news/local/33181753-75/selker-cell541-221-1267.html.csp>
Register Guard: Thanks to a $20 million donation, the UO is pushing to hire more scientists and researchers as part of its "clusters of excellence" program.
CU Denver researcher says no evidence children of same sex couples negatively impacted<http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2015-06/uoca-cdr061415.php>
Eureka Alert: University of Colorado releases a study on same sex couples and their children that was co-authored by Ryan Light in the Department of Sociology<http://around.uoregon.edu/content/uo-study-finds-no-disadvantages-kids-raised-same-sex-parents>.

*        This release was picked up/covered by several outlets including KATU<http://www.katu.com/news/local/Study-No-difference-in-kids-raised-by-same-sex-couples-308337261.html>.
The Disappointing Truth About the 'Jurassic' Raptors & 3 Other Dinos<http://www.zimbio.com/Beyond+the+Box+Office/articles/E3DM6pz8qMe/Disappointing+Truth+Jurassic+Raptors+3+Other>
Zimbo: Kent Stevens, professor of computer science, is quoted on how dinosaurs would look and act in real life, as opposed to the representations in the Jurassic World movie.
Expanding horizons at the UO<http://registerguard.com/rg/opinion/33174680-78/story.csp>
The Register-Guard: Abe Schafermeyer, director of international student and scholar services, pens a letter to the editor that applauds a May 23 guest viewpoint from Professor Lamia Karim calling on the UO to implement a "curriculum that is global in its scope."
UO School of Music hosts 'Aca-College' Day<http://www.kval.com/news/local/UO-School-of-Music-hosts-Aca-College-Day-307320291.html>
KVAL: The school of music hosted middle and high school students, teaching them techniques in the world of acapella music.

*        Also covered by KTMR and the Register-Guard<http://registerguard.com/rg/news/local/33196001-75/young-would-be-a-cappella-singers-learn-how-its-done-at-university-of-oregon-aca-college-workshop.html.csp>.
Redmond biking boom?<http://www.bendbulletin.com/localstate/3243266-151/redmond-biking-boom>
Bend Bulletin: UO's Sustainable Cities Program has partnered with the city of Redmond to make it more bike-friendly.

*        This story was picked up by the Register Guard<http://projects.registerguard.com/apf/ore/or-redmond-bicycling/> and several other outlets.
Fed Decision Day Guide: Interest-Rate Projections, Gradual Pace<http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-06-16/fed-decision-day-guide-interest-rate-projections-gradual-pace>
Bloomberg Business: Tim Duy, professor of economics, is quoted regarding possible interest rates from the Federal Reserve.
Janet Yellen's Prediction Last Month Is Already Being Vindicated<http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-06-16/janet-yellen-s-prediction-last-month-is-already-being-vindicated>
Bloomberg Business: Tim Duy, professor of economics, writes an article on future changes in monetary policy.
UN report promotes encryption as fundamental and protected right<http://www.cpj.org/blog/2015/06/un-report-promotes-encryption-as-fundamental-and-p.php>
CPJ: UO journalism GTF Endalk Chala is quoted over freedom of expression in the internet ago.
Most discussions on climate change ignore these 10 basic facts about human nature<http://www.vox.com/2015/6/14/8767823/psychology-global-warming>
Vox: Psychology Professor Paul Slovic is quoted.
Kids meet Olympic athletes at McArthur Court for 'Olympic Day'<http://www.kval.com/news/local/Kids-meet-Olympic-athletes-at-McArthur-Court-for-Olympic-Day-307274561.html>
KVAL: McArthur Court hosts special event, where kids from around Eugene meet and speak with Olympic athletes.
Education Dept. Official Responds to Inquiry Into Release of Student's Therapy Records<http://chronicle.com/blogs/ticker/education-dept-official-responds-to-inquiry-into-release-of-students-therapy-records/100647>
The Chronicle of Higher Education: The U.S. Department of Education is reviewing possible loopholes in privacy laws.
Marcus Mariota receives inaugural "Play it Forward" honor at Oregon Sports Awards<http://www.oregonlive.com/premium/living-plus/2015/06/marcus_mariota_receives_inaugu.html>
The Oregonian: Former Ducks' quarterback wins award for community outreach.
Compensation 101<http://registerguard.com/rg/opinion/33182896-78/compensation-101.html.csp>
The Register-Guard: An image of Incoming President Michael Schill is used in this opinion piece that discusses how higher pay for private university presidents better reflects the value of leadership.
Get INSPired with Real Change at the Global Street Paper Summit<http://www.realchangenews.org/2015/06/17/get-inspired-real-change-global-street-paper-summit>
Real Change News: Mike Fancher, interim director of UO's Center for Journalism Innovation and Civic Engagement, will give a keynote titled "Re-Imagining Journalism."
New documents show new obstacles for Eugene Water & Electric Board riverfront redevelopment<http://registerguard.com/rg/news/local/33189169-75/new-documents-show-new-obstacles-for-eugene-water--electric-board-riverfront-redevelopment.html.csp>
The Register-Guard: The UO Foundation's decision to drop out of purchasing the property.
U.S. Department of Education Awards $12.8 Million in Grants to Improve Services, Outcomes for Children with Disabilities<http://www.ed.gov/news/press-releases/us-department-education-awards-128-million-grants-improve-services-outcomes-children-disabilities>
U.S. Department of Education: UO is listed as receiving grants from the Department of Education.

subject: b'coe-fac: Ordering Summer Regalia'
html:
b'
Hello,
The Duck Store is revamping their regalia ordering website, so any orders should just be emailed to me.  If you will be participating in either the UO Summer Commencement or in Convocation in the fall and need to rent regalia, the information the Duck Store needs is below.  For summer commencement, your order needs to be in by July 17th.  When you reply, please also let me know which ceremony you are participating in.
Thanks,
Lisa

Fill in the information below:
FACULTY MEMBER INFORMATION

NAME:       First and Last

SCHOOL:  Name of College or University

CITY:        The city where that College or University Campus is located.  The satin lining
                      colors of a hood can be different for each individual campus.  For example the
                      University of Michigan has two different hood satin combinations; Ann Arbor
                      and Dearborn are Maize and Royal Blue, Flint is Maize and Navy Blue.  If we
                      don't know the city we don't know which color of blue to provide.

COLORS:   If they know them, list them for us.  If not we can research them.

HEIGHT:    Feet and inches or meters.  Gowns are available in even-inch increments.

DEGREE:   Usually Ph.D. or Masters.  If the degree is a Masters or a Bachelors we need to
                       know the field of emphasis (History,  Biology, etc).

OTHER:    Anything special about the order.  A good example would be someone who
                      needs only part of the Regalia, for example only the gown or cap.



Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Services
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150710/36aad665/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Fall Course Offerings from EMPL'
html:
b'
The Educational Methodology, Policy and Leadership (EMPL) department is pleased to offer the following Fall courses for your consideration. Please forward to prospective students you think will benefit from these classes.
EDLD 610 Intro Mixture Models - Mondays, 9:00am-12:50pm, 4 credits taught by Mark Van Ryzin

This course will review Mixture Models, a group of techniques that evaluate the potential for distinct sub-groups or classes within a sample. The course will use Mplus for Latent Class Analysis, CACE modeling, and Growth Mixture Modeling, and will use SAS for Latent Class Trajectory Analysis (i.e., Proc Traj)



Prerequisite: Students in the class will be expected to have a working knowledge of regression and to understand the basics of growth models, but will not be expected to know the specifics of Mplus or SAS.

EDLD 625 Survey and Questionnaire Design- Wednesdays, 4:00pm-7:50pm, 4 credits taught by Mike Bullis
The course is designed for graduate students who have completed an introductory research design course and a statistics course. The course will offer an overview of the core aspects of the survey process. At various points in the course, faculty will be invited to discuss surveys they have, or are, conducting.

The primary product of the course is a proposal describing a survey project that will, or could be, conducted. Accordingly, it is essential for the student to have a solid idea for such a project before the course begins.

EDLD 659 Scholarly Writing  - Tuesdays, 1:00pm-3:50pm, 4 credits taught by Mike Bullis
The course is designed for advanced doctoral students who are at the point of preparing, or starting to prepare, a manuscript for professional publication. The primary product of the course will be a manuscript that will be submitted for publication. Before starting the course, prospective students must have a clear idea for a publication. In most cases students should have a dataset they have analyzed, or will analyze, for the manuscript.

Throughout the course senior faculty have been invited to discuss their respective careers, achievements and challenges, recommendations for career success, writing style, and publication strategies.
Please contact the instructors with any questions and have a great end of the summer.

subject: b'coe-fac: Please Join us!'
html:
b'
Hi!
We hope you have space in your calendar to join us for a great film and conversation later this month about some of the issues families in our country are facing as they struggle to combine work and family caregiving in a way that works for kids and families.
Here\xe2\x80\x99s the scoop:

Family Forward Oregon is hosting a screening of the documentary film Raising of America at the Eugene Public Library on Tuesday, August 25th from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m., followed by an interactive panel discussion with some terrific local thought leaders:

Colt Gill, Superintendent of Bethel Schools, is our moderator. Panelists are:

  *   Sharon Bernstein, Co-founder and Deputy Director, Family Forward Oregon
  *   Judy Newman, Co-director, Early Childhood CARES
  *   Sabrina Berry Parsons, CEO, Palo Alto Software Company
  *   Carmen Urbina, Equity & Diversity Inclusion Manager, 4j

We hope you will join us to learn about the care crisis in the U.S. and how we can change the conversation to create a better way that works for kids, families, our economy and our communities.
Details, details:


  *   What: Raising of America documentary and panel discussion (check out trailers & info here<http://www.raisingofamerica.org/>).
  *   Where: The Eugene Public Library @ 100 W. 10th Ave, Eugene, OR 97401 (here's a map<http://bit.ly/1MdNbvV>).
  *   When: Tuesday, August 25th, from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m.
  *   Who: You! Your friends! (Your friends with kids. Your friends without kids. FREE & open to all.)
  *   Why: Because to predict how our nation will fare tomorrow, we need to look at how our youngest are faring today \xe2\x80\x94 and the numbers are not all that promising. Raising of America hopes to change the conversation so that more parents and children have access to the kind of care they need \xe2\x80\x94 but we can't do it without first knowing about the problem (and hatching a plan to solve it!).
  *   RSVP: No need, this one is first come, first served \xe2\x80\x94 until space runs out!

Special thanks to United Way of Lane County and the Early Learning Alliance for their partnership and support in organizing this event. I look forward to seeing you for an interesting and important conversation on the 25th,

Judy

PS \xe2\x80\x94 Please help us spread the word by sharing our Facebook event!<http://bit.ly/EugeneRaisingofAmerica>






[cid:23959517-A2AC-4907-B06F-92B98192C73D at uoregon.edu]

subject: b'coe-fac: Sept 16 12-1pm Colloquium Presentation for Health Promotion & Obesity Prevention Cluster Hire Search'
html:
b'
Dear all,

Please join us for a research colloquium presentation on Sept 16th from 12-1pm in Hedco 230T for our Health Promotion and Obesity Prevention faculty search. Details are below.


Ann Davis, PhD, MPH
University of Kansas Medical Center
Pediatric Obesity Intervention Efforts Among Underserved Children
Colloquium Wednesday September 16, 2015 12:00 - 1:00 pm
Informal Q & A 1:00 - 1:30 pm
Hedco 230T
Refreshments Served
Ann McGrath Davis received her undergraduate degree in Psychology and English from the University of Kansas in 1991, and her PhD in Clinical Psychology from Western Michigan University in 1999.  She completed her predoctoral internship year at Father Flanagan's Boys Home in Boystown, Nebraska and a two year postdoctoral fellowship at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.  She joined the University of Kansas Medical Center Department of Pediatrics in 2001 as an Assistant Professor.  In 2007 she was promoted to Associate Professor with tenure. Because of her long standing interest in pediatric obesity and other chronic health conditions, Dr. Davis earned her Master's in Public Health at KUMC in 2008. Dr. Davis has teaching, clinical and research interests.  She teaches medical students, medical residents, and psychology graduate students, and teaches one semester long class at the medical center focused on teaching behavioral skills to students in Dietetics & Nutrition. Clinically, she is board certified and serves as a member of the multidisciplinary KUMC Pediatric Feeding Team and as Director of the KUMC Pediatric Obesity Program, called Healthy Hawks, which is a community based program.  Dr. Davis' NIH funded research has focused in two main areas, pediatric obesity treatment in school based programs and pediatric feeding disorders. She is currently a full, tenured professor, Vice Chair for Research, Director of the Center for Children's Healthy Lifestyles & Nutrition, a joint center between KUMC and Children's Mercy Hospital.

Hope to you see you on the 16th!
Laura Lee

--
Laura Lee McIntyre, PhD, BCBA-D
Professor & Director, School Psychology
Associate Director, Child and Family Center
Prevention Science Institute
5208 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5208
Ph: 541-346-7452
Fax: 541-346-0683

subject: b'coe-fac: OPPORTUNITY 2015-2016:  on-line course development'
html:
b'
Faculty,

In response to faculty requests, and in the interest of facilitating curricular experimentation, the College is supporting a new small grant program designed to adapt existing coursework to digitally enhanced delivery formats. This initiative will provide financial and expertise support to faculty who would like to convert a currently offered course in COE into an online format. A total of five to ten grants will be awarded depending on the availability of donor funds. Please see the attached proposal for more information including eligibility, course requirements, resources  and  intellectual property rights.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Reminder - Sept 16 12-1pm Colloquium Presentation for Health Promotion & Obesity Prevention Cluster Hire Search'
html:
b'
Dear all,

This is a reminder email about next Wednesday's research colloquium for our cluster hire search in obesity prevention and health promotion. Ann Davis, PhD, MPH will be interviewing on Wednesday 9/16. The colloquium is at noon. Lunch will be provided.

Please RSVP to Emily Cornell (ecornell at uoregon.edu<mailto:ecornell at uoregon.edu>) if you plan to attend the research colloquium. We want to get an accurate head count to ensure that our venue will be comfortable and accommodating.

Best,
Laura Lee

She teaches medical students, medical residents, and psychology graduate students, and teaches one semester long class at the medical center focused on teaching behavioral skills to students in Dietetics & Nutrition. Clinically, she is board certified and serves as a member of the multidisciplinary KUMC Pediatric Feeding Team and as Director of the KUMC Pediatric Obesity Program, called Healthy Hawks, which is a community based program.  Dr. Davis' NIH funded research has focused in two main areas, pediatric obesity treatment in school based programs and pediatric feeding disorders. She is currently a full, tenured professor, Vice Chair for Research, Director of the Center for Children's Healthy Lifestyles & Nutrition, a joint center between KUMC and Children's Mercy Hospital.

Hope to you see you on the 16th!
Laura Lee

--

Please RSVP to Emily Cornell (ecornell at uoregon.edu<mailto:ecornell at uoregon.edu>) if you plan to attend the research colloquium. We want to get an accurate head count to ensure that our venue will be comfortable and accommodating.

From: Laura Lee McIntyre
Sent: Thursday, August 27, 2015 11:46 AM
To: 'coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu'
Subject: Sept 16 12-1pm Colloquium Presentation for Health Promotion & Obesity Prevention Cluster Hire Search

Dear all,

Please join us for a research colloquium presentation on Sept 16th from 12-1pm in Hedco 230T for our Health Promotion and Obesity Prevention faculty search. Details are below.


Ann Davis, PhD, MPH
University of Kansas Medical Center
Pediatric Obesity Intervention Efforts Among Underserved Children
Colloquium Wednesday September 16, 2015 12:00 - 1:00 pm
Informal Q & A 1:00 - 1:30 pm
Hedco 230T
Refreshments Served
Ann McGrath Davis received her undergraduate degree in Psychology and English from the University of Kansas in 1991, and her PhD in Clinical Psychology from Western Michigan University in 1999.  She completed her predoctoral internship year at Father Flanagan's Boys Home in Boystown, Nebraska and a two year postdoctoral fellowship at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center.  She joined the University of Kansas Medical Center Department of Pediatrics in 2001 as an Assistant Professor.  In 2007 she was promoted to Associate Professor with tenure. Because of her long standing interest in pediatric obesity and other chronic health conditions, Dr. Davis earned her Master's in Public Health at KUMC in 2008. Dr. Davis has teaching, clinical and research interests.  She teaches medical students, medical residents, and psychology graduate students, and teaches one semester long class at the medical center focused on teaching behavioral skills to students in Dietetics & Nutrition. Clinically, she is board certified and serves as a member of the multidisciplinary KUMC Pediatric Feeding Team and as Director of the KUMC Pediatric Obesity Program, called Healthy Hawks, which is a community based program.  Dr. Davis' NIH funded research has focused in two main areas, pediatric obesity treatment in school based programs and pediatric feeding disorders. She is currently a full, tenured professor, Vice Chair for Research, Director of the Center for Children's Healthy Lifestyles & Nutrition, a joint center between KUMC and Children's Mercy Hospital.

Hope to you see you on the 16th!
Laura Lee

--

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic: Tutoring Opportunity at Hedco Clinic'
html:
b'
Dear faculty,

Welcome back!  As you prepare for the coming school year, the CTL Reading
Clinic has some exciting news to share -- we have returned to campus and
will be providing direct reading intervention services at the Hedco
Clinic!  We are currently looking for student tutors, and hope that this
move will allow us to reach a broader range of interested students.  Here's
a little bit of information about what our program will look like in the
fall:

-Students will tutor a small group (2-4 students) of 1st or 2nd grade
students using a direct, evidence-based reading intervention program.
-Tutoring will take place from weeks 3-10.
-Students will receive 4 hours of initial program training in weeks 1 or 2
of the term, and 1 hour of weekly supervision and training in weeks 3-10.
-Students can tutor 2 days per week for 1 credit hour or 2 days per week
for 2 credit hours.

I have attached a flyer and tutoring application.  Please share this
information with your students.  Questions can be directed to me or Anna
Ingram (annad at uoregon.edu).

Thank you for your time.

Best,
Shaheen
--
Shaheen Munir-McHill, Ph.D., NCSP
Reading Clinic Coordinator
Center on Teaching and Learning
University of Oregon
541.346.8388
munir at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: OPPORTUNITY 2015-2016:  on-line course development'
html:
b'
As you all return to the COE thought I would send out a reminder about this opportunity......
Brigid

From: Brigid Flannery
Sent: Thursday, August 27, 2015 11:45 AM
To: 'coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu'
Subject: OPPORTUNITY 2015-2016: on-line course development

Faculty,

In response to faculty requests, and in the interest of facilitating curricular experimentation, the College is supporting a new small grant program designed to adapt existing coursework to digitally enhanced delivery formats. This initiative will provide financial and expertise support to faculty who would like to convert a currently offered course in COE into an online format. A total of five to ten grants will be awarded depending on the availability of donor funds. Please see the attached proposal for more information including eligibility, course requirements, resources  and  intellectual property rights.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496

subject: b'coe-fac: Reminder: Instructional FTE Calculator Pilot Program'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

I hope that you had a productive, pleasant and regenerative summer! I'm writing today to offer a brief reminder that all instructional Career Track faculty (NTTF) in the COE are expected to work with their supervisors (Department Head or Program Director) to complete an estimate of their workload for this year using the FTE Calculator Tool and offer feedback via survey to the NTTF Workload Policy Development committee. This estimate should be completed by the end of October. I have copied and pasted the Dean's previous message (from June) on this topic below.

For quick reference: the NTTF workload policy and supporting documentation, including the FTE calculator tool, are all available here:

https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/confluence/display/NTTFWP/NTTF+Workload+Policy+Home

The survey to provide your feedback can be found at the link below:

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_doqwEPreGvwDSgR

Regards, and thank you all for participating in this important policy development work.

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403
541.346.1218


Dear COE Faculty:

Last Fall, a group of our colleagues developed a policy to guide and govern the composition of FTE for Career Track (the name I prefer over non-tenure track) instructional faculty within the COE. One of the comments I provided to them at the time that policy was submitted to the UO administration was that the FTE Calculator tool attached to it should receive further testing and vetting by the faculty at large to determine whether it serves the purposes the policy workgroup envisioned for it and whether there are ways that it could be refined to improve its accuracy.

As a result of my conversations with the workload policy development group, I have asked the academic department heads to perform a "test-run" estimation of FTE using the tool for each of their instructional career track faculty before the end of October 2015. The group has spent a generous amount of time developing resources to aid department heads, academic program coordinators, and Career Track Faculty in the use of this tool, as well as a survey to collect data on several aspects of its use.

In order to support our Career Track Faculty and the efforts of the workload committee, I would like to encourage all instructional Career Track faculty (NTTF) in the COE to follow the link below to learn more about the FTE Calculator and to take time to use the tool along with your supervisor (department head or program director) to create an estimate of FTE for your expected workload for the upcoming year, and then follow the second link below to provide feedback to the policy group once you have done so.

More information about the policy and the calculator tool, as well as the tool itself, can be found at:

https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/confluence/display/NTTFWP/NTTF+Workload+Policy+Home

Provide your feedback on the tool once you have used it with your supervisor via the survey below:

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_doqwEPreGvwDSgR

I look forward to a discussion in the Fall about what this pilot effort tells us about the tool and our ongoing efforts to guarantee that the principles of equity and fairness are upheld in the distribution of workload within the College.

With gratitude to all who worked on these policies,

Randy

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150921/e1460f10/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Faculty Advisory Council Nominations'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

The COE Faculty Advisory Council, which Dean Kamphaus proposed last Spring, is still in need of members! This body will meet roughly five times per term during the academic year and consult with the dean on a range of administrative and academic matters. If you are interested, please send me a brief note indicating your interest in serving on this important body for a one or two year term, along with an outline of your ongoing institutional commitments (teaching hours and unit meetings), by the close of business on Monday, September 28.

Regards,

Shaun Haskins

Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: Latina/os and K-12 Education Oct 15th 4 pm'
html:
b'
On behalf of Ellen McWhirter





[cid:image001.png at 01D0F6CA.7C6B5520]


Center for Latino/a and Latin American Studies                      For Immediate Release
Website: http://cllas.uoregon.edu/    cllas at uoregon.edu<mailto:cllas at uoregon.edu>                     541-346-5286

"Latina/os and K-12 Education: Bridging Research and Practice"

In celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month, the University of Oregon Center for Latino/a and Latin American Studies (CLLAS) brings together new Eugene School District 4J superintendent Dr. Gustavo Balderas and visiting scholar Dr. Patricia G\xc3\xa1ndara, co-director of the Civil Rights Project of UCLA, for an informative session on public school education K-12 for Latina/os in Oregon. Dr. G\xc3\xa1ndara is the Visiting Distinguished Scholar at UO Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics and the College of Education during fall term 2015.

Meeting at the Ford Alumni Center, 1720 E. 13th Ave. on the UO campus on Thursday, October 15, from 4 p.m. to 6:30 p.m., this session offers an opportunity for the K-12 education community, the community at large, and the university community to talk about the state of education for Oregon Latina/os. The gathering will feature talks by the two principal speakers, followed by a question-and-answer session with the audience.

The event also will showcase examples of UO faculty research addressing Latina/os and K-12 education, with brief presentations to be made by College of Education faculty members Audrey Lucero, Assistant Professor, Education Studies; Charles Martinez, Department Head and Professor, Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership; Ellen McWhirter, Ann Swindells Professor in Counseling Psychology; Edward Olivos, Professor, Education Studies, and Ilana Umansky, Assistant Professor, Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership. Roundtable discussions over hors d'oeuvres will give participants an opportunity for network building, back-and-forth sharing of information regarding education research and practice on campus and in the community, and a chance to explore opportunities to move forward. CLLAS co-director Gerardo Sandoval, assistant professor in the UO Department of Planning, Public Policy, and Management, will emcee the event.

Sponsors include the College of Education; Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics; School of Architecture and Allied Arts; UO Libraries; Department of Counseling Psychology & Human Services; Latin American Studies Program; and the Office of Academic Affairs, College of Arts & Sciences Humanities Division, College of Arts & Sciences Social Sciences Division, Division of Equity and Inclusion, Centro Latino Americano, and the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC) of Lane County. SELCO is the community sponsor of this event.

Place: Ford Alumni Center, 1720 E. 13th Ave., Eugene, OR  97403
University of Oregon campus
Time:   4:00-6:30 p.m.  October 15, 2015
Event Chair: Ellen McWhirter, Ann Swindells Professor in Counseling Psychology, College of Education, ellenmcw at uoregon.edu<mailto:ellenmcw at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Dynamic Conversation Exploring Your Research!'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Mary Hanabury, UO Research Compliance Services


Are you conducting or expecting to conduct research with human subjects? If so, please join staff from the UO's Research Compliance Services (RCS) and your colleagues for a dynamic conversation exploring your research interests, research ethics and practical approaches to working with the IRB*!  Together we will discuss challenges to research involving human participants and how to apply best practices to your research.

Date:  Wednesday, October 28, 2015
Time: 12pm - 1pm
Location:  119 Lokey
Questions?  Contact:  Mary Hanabury, RCS Assistant Director, hanabury at uoregon.edu<mailto:hanabury at uoregon.edu>, 541-346-3621

We hope to see you there!  (No RVSP necessary)

*Everyone at the UO conducting research with human subjects is required to obtain approval from the UO's IRB (Institutional Review Board).  The RCS staff work with researchers and the IRB to facilitate this process.  More information about the IRB is available at:  http://humansubjects.uoregon.edu/index.cfm?action=irb
-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20150928/f705fca8/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Curriculum update'
html:
b'
Welcome back!
Rather than share during our faculty meeting in October 6,  I thought I would share through some of last year's COE curriculum accomplishments, some work Shaun and I finished up this summer, and then what is ahead for 2015-2016. Read below to learn more about.....
2014-2015: Year in review

*         New or Changes to Courses

*         New or Changes to Programs, Specializations, Certificates
2015-2016

*         Curriculum Committee membership

*         New website for curriculum materials calendar and information sheets

*         EDUC scheduling and course instructor nomination

*         Courseleaf as our electronic curriculum management system

*         Collegewide course on foundations of educational research course

*         Revision of COE Curriculum Policy

*         Online course development initiative
Review of 2014-2015
Curriculum committee approved a number of new or changes to courses.
Fall term: Three courses were reviewed. All were approved and were modifications of existing courses (no new courses). No courses were returned to faculty for further action and no courses were denied.
Winter term: Thirteen total courses were reviewed. Eight were approved including five current course modifications and three new courses. None of these courses were returned to faculty for further action, two courses were placed on hold pending the approval of the Prevention Science proposals, and three course changes were denied primarily due to duplication or low enrollment.
Spring term: Seven total courses were reviewed. Three current courses were approved and no new courses. Four courses were returned to faculty for further action and no courses were denied.  The returned courses were a series proposed by FHS to form an Early Childhood Emphasis (FHS-ECE). These will be resubmitted in fall.
Three new graduate programs (MA, MEd and PhD) were proposed and approved by COE in Prevention Science and Health Promotion (CPHS). These degrees will be in CPHS. These programs have now been approved by the Graduate Council, Senate, Board of Trustees and Provosts' Council. It will go through its final approval step early this fall. This was the first program approval for COE under the new Board of Trustees structure so had a few bumps but we now know the process - thanks to all who worked on this proposal process.
One new specialization has progressed to the Graduate School. This is a specialization in Higher Education Administration that will be part of a Master's degree in EMPL.  The Committee reviewed the initial proposal in spring of 2014. The Committee also completed an initial review of a FHS minor last spring.  The FHS program was provided feedback and will be formally submitting again in fall 2015.
Looking Ahead to 2015-2016 Academic Year
There is a lot already planned for 2015-2016 so for a sneak-peek read below:
There have been some changes in the COE Curriculum Committee membership.  There is one TTF and one CNTTF from each department on this committee. Please note the faculty representing your program. If you have questions regarding the curriculum process, please contact them or myself.  If you submit new courses or programs or changes to existing programs/courses to the committee be sure that you department representative is familiar with these. If they can address questions of the committee members it could move your proposal along more quickly.

o   EMPL: Gina Biancarosa, Jo Smith

o   EDST: Lisa Mazzei, Jeanne Hall

o   SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

o   CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The committee is only one step in the process. Please participate in the commenting and approval of courses, programs, specializations. Besides some new/changes to courses there are a number of discussions are happening in departments/programs for new minors, specializations and certificates such as: Undergraduate secondary education (Certificate), Leadership (Minor), FHS (Minor), Research Methodology (Specialization).
There is a new COE Academic Affairs website https://coe.uoregon.edu/governance/curriculum-review-policies. This site will have the most current information related to COE curriculum - information sheets, UO links, and college curriculum calendars. There is a calendar of the critical dates for this year along with the forms and information sheets on the Academic Affairs site. You can find information about the process for courses, programs (majors, minors) and other topics. Be sure to get the most current syllabus template when submitting new courses or course changes to the COE Curriculum Committee. Not using the template could cause unnecessary delays in the submission of your proposal.
In addition, check the calendar as I will also host an "orientation" each term for faculty who are thinking of submitting a course, program, or specialization.  Please plan to attend these prior to your submission to be sure you understand the requirements and process.  The orientation this fall is Fri, Nov 13 -1-2pm, HEDCO 230U.
                The EDUC courses are scheduled for next year (the schedule for 2016-2019 will be available by March, 2016). You can find the course listing on the policy site mentioned above.  The course times have been set in advance in order to allow all programs to schedule around them.  They are reviewed each year by department heads and the Student Service Coordinators. Please remember that the instructors for EDUC courses are determined through a two-step process. First is through self nomination. The materials for nomination and the requirements are available on the Academic Affairs site. This year these will be due on February 20, 2016. The second step is review and discussion by the Department Head Council. This full process is scheduled to be completed by spring break.
Starting this Fall, the UO will use CourseLeaf as our electronic curriculum management system (https://nextcatalog.uoregon.edu/courseadmin). As before, the Student Services Coordinators will support the use of this system, but any faculty will be able to initiate the process to change a course or propose a new one. Program or department-level approval will be managed within the unit, but will require department head approval to begin moving through the CourseLeaf system for COE level faculty voting and comment. CourseLeaf does have "help" (available by hovering over an item in the interface) but training will be available at our quarterly curriculum orientations, and a tip sheet is available at: https://coe.uoregon.edu/governance/curriculum-review-policies

When the current version of the COE Curriculum Policy was developed in 2008, it stated that the foundations of educational research course would be offered in 2007-2008 using the existing course TED 610, Philosophy of Research, but the course will eventually have an EDUC course prefix. This has never been addressed. Since there are no department faculty to start this process and it should be a collegewide group, in the spring of 2015 I made a call for faculty to serve on an ad hoc subcommittee to the Curriculum Committee to design an EDUC course on foundations of educational research and submit it through the COE curriculum process. This committee will begin its work in the fall and target completion by spring term (or if possible by winter term so can be reviewed at the spring UOCC meeting and approved by Fall 2016).
Gina Biancarosa will chair this committee. The faculty volunteers who will comprise the committee are:

o   EMPL: Gina Biancarosa, Mike Bullis

o   EDST: Lisa Mazzei, Jerry Rosiek

o   SPECS: Rob Horner, Kent McIntosh

o   CPHS: Atika Kurhana, Elizabeth Skowron
The COE Curriculum Policy needs to be updated due to changes from CBA and COE procedures. This was begun with some clarification from Department Head Council and will now go to a subcommittee of the COE Curriculum Committee.  The committee will propose comments/changes to the Curriculum Committee and then post the proposed policy for COE faculty comment and vote.  This work is targeted for Fall and winter term with a faculty vote by end of school year (May 2016).
In response to faculty requests, and in the interest of facilitating curricular experimentation, the College is supporting a new small grant program designed to adapt existing coursework to online or hybrid delivery formats. This initiative will provide financial and expertise support to faculty who would like to convert a currently offered course in COE into an online format. A total of five to ten grants will be awarded depending on the availability of donor funds. Please see the attached proposal for more information including eligibility, course requirements, resources, and  intellectual property rights.

Enjoy your 2015-2016 academic year and look forward to your participation in the curriculum activities this year.
Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: Oct.15- Latin at s and K-12 Education, 4PM'
html:
b'
On Behalf of Ellen McWhirter

In celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month, the Center for Latino/a and Latin American Studies (CLLAS) and the UO Division of Equity and Inclusion present:

Latin at s and K-12 Education: Bridging research and practice

Followed by a reception in celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month at 6:30pm

Details-

Location: Giustina Ballroom, Ford Alumni Center, UO campus
Time: 4-6:30, reception starts at 6:30

This exciting event brings together new Eugene School District 4J superintendent Dr. Gustavo Balderas and scholar Dr. Patricia G\xc3\xa1ndara, co-director of the Civil Rights Project of UCLA, for an informative session on public school education K-12 for Latina/os in Oregon. Dr.
G\xc3\xa1ndara is the Visiting Distinguished Scholar at UO Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics and the College of Education during fall term 2015.

Meeting at the Ford Alumni Center, 1720 E. 13th Ave. on the UO campus on Thursday, October 15, from 4 p.m. to 6:30 p.m., this session offers an opportunity for the K-12 education community, the community at large, and the university community to talk about the state of education for Oregon Latina/os. The gathering will feature talks by the two principal speakers, followed by a question-and-answer session with the audience.

The event also will showcase examples of UO faculty research addressing Latina/os and K-12 education, with brief presentations to be made by College of Education faculty members Audrey Lucero, Assistant Professor, Education Studies; Charles Martinez, Department Head and Professor, Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership; Ellen McWhirter, Ann Swindells Professor in Counseling Psychology; Edward Olivos, Professor, Education Studies; and Ilana Umansky, Assistant Professor, Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership. Roundtable discussions will give participants an opportunity for network building, back-and-forth sharing of information regarding education research and practice on campus and in the community, and a chance to explore opportunities to move forward.
CLLAS co-director Gerardo Sandoval, assistant professor in the UO Department of Planning, Public Policy, and Management, will emcee the event. A reception in celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month to follow.
Hors d'oeuvres provided.

Cosponsors include the College of Education; Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics; UO Libraries; Department of Counseling Psychology & Human Services; Latin American Studies Program; UO Division of Equity and Inclusion; Office of Academic Affairs; College of Arts & Sciences Humanities Division; College of Arts & Sciences Social Sciences Division; Centro Latino Americano; and the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC) of Lane County. SELCO is the community sponsor of this event.


Best,


Amanda Eakins
Administrative Assistant to the Dean
Office of the Dean| Student Academic Services
130 HEDCO  Education Bldg.
1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403
p: 541-346-6467 | email: aeakins at uoregon.edu<mailto:aeakins at uoregon.edu>

text:
b"On Behalf of Ellen McWhirter

In celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month, the Center for Latino/a and Latin American Studies (CLLAS) and the UO Division of Equity and Inclusion present:

Latin at s and K-12 Education: Bridging research and practice

Followed by a reception in celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month at 6:30pm

Details-

Location: Giustina Ballroom, Ford Alumni Center, UO campus
Time: 4-6:30, reception starts at 6:30

This exciting event brings together new Eugene School District 4J superintendent Dr. Gustavo Balderas and scholar Dr. Patricia G\xc3\xa1ndara, co-director of the Civil Rights Project of UCLA, for an informative session on public school education K-12 for Latina/os in Oregon. Dr.
G\xc3\xa1ndara is the Visiting Distinguished Scholar at UO Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics and the College of Education during fall term 2015.

Meeting at the Ford Alumni Center, 1720 E. 13th Ave. on the UO campus on Thursday, October 15, from 4 p.m. to 6:30 p.m., this session offers an opportunity for the K-12 education community, the community at large, and the university community to talk about the state of education for Oregon Latina/os. The gathering will feature talks by the two principal speakers, followed by a question-and-answer session with the audience.

The event also will showcase examples of UO faculty research addressing Latina/os and K-12 education, with brief presentations to be made by College of Education faculty members Audrey Lucero, Assistant Professor, Education Studies; Charles Martinez, Department Head and Professor, Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership; Ellen McWhirter, Ann Swindells Professor in Counseling Psychology; Edward Olivos, Professor, Education Studies; and Ilana Umansky, Assistant Professor, Educational Methodology, Policy, and Leadership. Roundtable discussions will give participants an opportunity for network building, back-and-forth sharing of information regarding education research and practice on campus and in the community, and a chance to explore opportunities to move forward.
CLLAS co-director Gerardo Sandoval, assistant professor in the UO Department of Planning, Public Policy, and Management, will emcee the event. A reception in celebration of Latin@ Heritage Month to follow.
Hors d'oeuvres provided.

Cosponsors include the College of Education; Wayne Morse Center for Law and Politics; UO Libraries; Department of Counseling Psychology & Human Services; Latin American Studies Program; UO Division of Equity and Inclusion; Office of Academic Affairs; College of Arts & Sciences Humanities Division; College of Arts & Sciences Social Sciences Division; Centro Latino Americano; and the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC) of Lane County. SELCO is the community sponsor of this event.


Best,


Amanda Eakins
Administrative Assistant to the Dean
Office of the Dean| Student Academic Services
130 HEDCO  Education Bldg.
1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403
p: 541-346-6467 | email: aeakins at uoregon.edu<mailto:aeakins at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Tenure-Track Policies on Promotion & Tenure and Assignment of Professional Responsibilities (Workload)'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

A working group of ten of your peers has been engaged since March of this year in revising and updating the COE's policy on promotion and tenure, and developing and refining a new policy on determination of workload and FTE, both geared toward tenure-track faculty, much as a similar group did during the last academic year for Career Track (NTTF) faculty.

These policy documents (attached) are now ready for your review, comment and ratification. I encourage you all to review these documents, and all tenure-track faculty to follow the survey link below to offer input and vote on whether to move the documents forward for administrative review. The documents can also be accessed from within the survey.

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_2mgsVGsmuXns6Q5

Please complete the survey, if you plan to do so, by 8am on Thursday, October 8, in order for the Dean to make a thorough review of the documents you vote to move forward as well as your comments and make any needed adjustments. Academic Affairs has asked the Dean to forward the finalized versions of these documents by the close of business on Thursday, October 15. If either of these documents are not ratified at this time, they (and your collated comments and concerns) will be provided to a new faculty working group that will be formed to complete the needed adjustments before resubmission to the entire faculty. In this case, we have received word from Academic Affairs that an extension of the October 15 deadline can be negotiated.

Please join me in thanking the members of the working group responsible for updating and developing these policies (listed below), and I thank you all in advance for your participation in this important element of our governance process.

Krista Chronister
Elizabeth Harn
Edward Kame'enui
Lauren Lindstrom
Audrey Lucero
Wendy Machalicek
Kent McIntosh
Benedict McWhirter
Joseph Stevens
Gerald Tindal

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions or concerns.

Warm regards,

Shaun Haskins
Executive Assistant to the Dean
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403
541.346.1218

subject: b'coe-fac: NNTF Promotion Workshop Oct 9 (from Lauren Lindstrom)'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues  - This is a reminder about the NTTF Promotion workshop on October 9.

This year we have a record number of career non tenured faculty who are preparing for the promotion process.  In order to respond to the growing interest, we have scheduled a workshop where Amy Green and I can provide you with detailed information and answer your questions about NTTF promotion requirements and process within the College.  I have also invited a panel of recently promoted career NTTF to join us and share their experiences.

So if you are thinking about going up for promotion or just interested in learning about promotion process - please come to the workshop!

The workshop will be Friday October 9 from 2:00 to 3:30 in 102K Lokey.

RSVP to Amy Green (amygreen at uoregon.edu<mailto:amygreen at uoregon.edu>)

An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20151001/3aca2510/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Faculty Advisory Committee (from Dean Kamphaus)'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues:

In the spring, I solicited nominations from interested faculty to serve on a new governance body within the COE that will provide me with faculty advice and counsel on a wide range of issues, both administrative and academic, that require our action. Because this governance body is a new one, I have composed it on an ad hoc basis for now, until we have the opportunity to include this committee in our normal course of governance. I look forward to collaborating closely with them this year. The members of this committee are:

Edward Kame'enui
Gerald Rosiek
Elizabeth Skowron
McKay Sohlberg
Elizabeth Stormshak
Gerald Tindal
Angela Whalen

Our first meeting will be October 12. Please join me in thanking them for agreeing to undertake this significant, and important, service to the college.

Until our Tuesday meeting,

RWK

subject: b'coe-fac: CASE Quantitative Methods Workshop Series on Bayesian Data\tAnalysis'
html:
b'
The Center for Assessment, Statistics, and Evaluation (CASE<http://case.uoregon.edu/>) is excited to announce its fall Quantitative Methods Workshop Series on Bayesian Data Analysis.  The two 2-day workshops are designed to emphasize the application of Bayesian methods and will address essential theory as a means of strengthening conceptual understanding.

WORKSHOP 1: Introduction to Bayesian Modeling: Why and How
Instructor: Rose Maier
Dates:
Friday, 10/23: 1:00 \xe2\x80\x93 4:00pm
Saturday 10/24: 9:00 \xe2\x80\x93 4:00 (lunch 12:00 \xe2\x80\x93 1:00; on your own)

This workshop provides an introduction to Bayesian modeling with a strong focus on practical applications for social and life science researchers. The 2-day hands-on workshop will address special considerations for running Bayesian models such as convergence diagnostics, interpretation of parameter estimates, and strategies for presentation results. All examples will be done using R and Stan.

Suggested prerequisites:  Familiarity with multiple regression will be helpful. No previous experience with R or Stan is required.

WORKSHOP 2: Hierarchical Bayesian Modeling
Instructor: Tyler Matta
Dates:
Friday, 11/6: 1:00 \xe2\x80\x93 4:00pm
Saturday 11/7: 9:00 \xe2\x80\x93 4:00 (lunch 12:00 \xe2\x80\x93 1:00; on your own)

This workshop extends the topics presented in Workshop 1 to introduce hierarchical Bayesian modeling.  The 2-day hands-on workshop will address estimating and interpreting hierarchal Bayesian models in the context of clustered data and will provide experience writing programs in R and Stan to fit Bayesian model.

Suggested prerequisites:  Familiarity with multilevel modeling will be helpful. Exposure to the ideas covered in Workshop 1.

COST:


One Workshop

Both Workshops

Non-Student

$110

$160

Student

$60

$80


LOCATION
Friday Workshop Location:
University of Oregon Main Campus, 115 Lokey Education Building

Saturday Workshop Location:
University of Oregon Main Campus, 117 Lokey Education Building

SIGN UP HERE
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_aVhrfeDyeATcFQp

QUESTIONS
Please contact Tyler Matta, tmatta at uoregon.edu<mailto:tmatta at uoregon.edu> if you have any questions about the CASE Quantitative Methods Workshops
