subject: b'coe-fac: FW: deans-dirs: Honors College call for 2016-2017 teaching proposals, due November 18'
html:
b'
FYI
Brigid

From: deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu [mailto:deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu] On Behalf Of Kathy Warden
Sent: Friday, November 06, 2015 9:37 AM
To: 'deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu' <deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>
Subject: deans-dirs: Honors College call for 2016-2017 teaching proposals, due November 18

Sent on behalf of Mark Carey, Associate Dean, Robert D. Clark Honors College
 The Clark Honors College (CHC) is now soliciting course proposals for the 2016-2017 academic year.  The due date is Wednesday, November 18, 2015.
Proposals are welcome from all faculty -- tenured, tenure-related, and NTTF. The CHC seeks proposals for 400-level colloquia, which are to be discipline-based, but interdisciplinary in scope and designed to address students in all majors, as well as 200-level introductory courses in the sciences, humanities, and social sciences. Each course should be designed to encourage critical and creative thinking, writing, reading, and discussion.  We are looking for a variety of topics across all fields in the University, and we encourage faculty members to experiment and propose new courses that stretch disciplinary boundaries.  For more information, please visit our website at: http://honors.uoregon.edu/content/teaching-chc<https://outlook.uoregon.edu/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=DkPFHoQ1zTR3vu6oKp-0s9rwNMW9IHswvoVWgSmWhDtIpsggf-bSCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AaABvAG4AbwByAHMALgB1AG8AcgBlAGcAbwBuAC4AZQBkAHUALwBjAG8AbgB0AGUAbgB0AC8AdABlAGEAYwBoAGkAbgBnAC0AYwBoAGMA&URL=http%3a%2f%2fhonors.uoregon.edu%2fcontent%2fteaching-chc>
Course proposals must be submitted via the Clark Honors College Affiliated Faculty Course Proposal online form located on forms.uoregon.edu<https://outlook.uoregon.edu/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=yJXEFOBNXs8X7wldMGd9yQsBM8DCam-F8I-wQLOZmV1Ipsggf-bSCGgAdAB0AHAAcwA6AC8ALwBmAG8AcgBtAHMALgB1AG8AcgBlAGcAbwBuAC4AZQBkAHUALwA.&URL=https%3a%2f%2fforms.uoregon.edu%2f> under "Clark Honors College."  Note that proposals and signatory approvals must be logged by 5:00 p.m. on Wednesday, November 18, 2015.
Questions regarding course proposals and suitability for the Clark Honors College should be directed to Mark Carey, CHC Associate Dean at carey at uoregon.edu<https://outlook.uoregon.edu/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=qVs9JlJ9ijgsVXaaI1xtfaERKO2MLonYmOsT_6rYnftIpsggf-bSCG0AYQBpAGwAdABvADoAYwBhAHIAZQB5AEAAdQBvAHIAZQBnAG8AbgAuAGUAZAB1AA..&URL=mailto%3acarey%40uoregon.edu>.
Questions regarding the online form should be directed to Beth Bonamici, CHC Reception, at bethb at uoregon.edu<https://outlook.uoregon.edu/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=wpkn45LgytUHqa6LCNkrttkYdpz5wohqN9CnNK9S1RhIpsggf-bSCG0AYQBpAGwAdABvADoAYgBlAHQAaABiAEAAdQBvAHIAZQBnAG8AbgAuAGUAZAB1AA..&URL=mailto%3abethb%40uoregon.edu>.


-------------- next part --------------

'

subject: b'coe-fac: Voting on COE Curriculum - courses and programs'
html:
b'
Faculty,

It is the time of year when faculty participate in the curricular decisions of the COE. There are some changes so please read below....

PROGRAMS (MINOR, SPECIALIZATION, CERTIFICATES, MAJORS)
The approval of programs will be sent to you via email with a link for qualtrics. I will send a notice to faculty who have been identified with instructional voting rights that the programs are available for comment (Nov 19-25). These same faculty will be notified about a vote (Dec 1-7). I expect 4-5 programs.


COURSES
The new Courseleaf system is up and running. We are to use this system starting this fall so this means we do not get a trial period but just dive in. So please bear with us as we move this forward.  Currently this is only for courses.

The Curriculum Service Coordinators in your departments were trained by Shaun before he left to upload the courses. The Curriculum Committee has been using it to review the submitted courses.

The Courseleaf system sends a notice to faculty who have been identified with instructional voting rights that the courses are available for comment (Nov 19-25). You will receive an email for each course - currently expect 11-12 courses to be sent for vote. These same faculty will be notified about a vote (Dec 1-7). - NOTE all comments are public and will remain with the course once it leaves the COE.

I have shared information with the department heads about access and some tips for voting. For those interested I will host a couple of orientations to Courseleaf review and voting on 11/18/2015 12:00-1:00 and 4:00-5:00 11/24/2015 in HEDCO 230U.

Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Annual Report'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty and Staff,

A hard copy of our college annual report will be placed in your mailbox in the next few days. This report is but one of our many efforts to document the effectiveness, importance, and scope of your fine work. It is also a key component of our efforts to demonstrate our public accountability.

We have shown drafts of this report to various faculty, staff, donors, UO administrators, and other stakeholders. While there were many suggestions for improvements, the general feedback has been highly positive. Please provide any additional suggestions for improving next year\xe2\x80\x99s report directly to Cody Pinkston.

We have a limited number of copies that you may request through Cody\xe2\x80\x99s office. I have found them useful, for example, for new faculty recruitment, communication with student groups, and in meetings with past and prospective donors.

Regards,

Randy


-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20151116/4eae8b36/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Colloquium: Learning and Metacognition: Bridging Cognitive Science and Education, November 18th'
html:
b'
You are invited to attend a colloquium (part of the Dean's Distinguished Lecture series) being given by a visiting scholar.  Dr. Ludmila Nunes, a postdoctoral researcher at Purdue, will make a presentation on her research in "Learning and Metacognition: Bridging Cognitive Science and Education."  The colloquium will be held Wednesday, November 18 from 11 am - noon in Lokey ED 119.  Light refreshments will be served.  For more information about Dr. Nunes, please visit:  http://learninglab.psych.purdue.edu/people/nunes/.  Her vita is also attached for your reference.  No formal RSVP is necessary, but please let me know if you wish to attend.
Thanks,
Lisa


Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: Fwd: Colloquium_Terrazas'
html:
b'

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Sandra Epple" <sepple at uoregon.edu<mailto:sepple at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Mon, Nov 23, 2015 at 10:59 AM -0800
Subject: Colloquium_Terrazas
To: "COE Events" <coeevents at uoregon.edu<mailto:coeevents at uoregon.edu>>


Center for Equity Promotion (CEQP) would like to invite faculty, staff, and students to the following colloquium:
[Screen Shot 2015-11-19 at 9 25 31 AM]

The Internet and mobile devices, such as global positioning system (GPS) navigation devices, tablets, and smart phones, have transformed the way people behave, interact, and communicate with others.  These technologies are also changing the way educators think about education and literacy. Schools and universities are making large investments in new technologies, but educators are struggling to keep pace with the speed of technological development and demand (Pilgrim, Bledsoe, & Reily, 2012) and have been unable to impact education systems as expected (Zhao, Zhang, Lei, & Qiu, 2016). In this research presentation, Fatima Terrazas-Arellanes will present her work on applications of new technologies in middle school classrooms. She will discuss how her evidence-based models for online instruction can inspire educators to teach 21st-century skills.

Tuesday, December 1st
HEDCO 240
1:00 \xe2\x80\x93 2:00 pm
2:00 \xe2\x80\x93 2:30 Q&A
*coffee and sweet snacks provided

Dr. Fatima E. Terrazas Arellanes is a Research Assistant Professor at the Center for Equity Promotion at the University of Oregon College of Education. She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Psychology from the Universidad Autonoma de Sinaloa in 2000, a Master of Science degree in Special Education from the University of Oregon in 2008, and a Doctor of Philosophy degree from the University of Oregon School Psychology Program in 2009.
She is the Principal Investigator of two federally funded projects focused on technology
in education. One study (Project ESCOLAR) supports science learning for students with learning
disabilities and the other (Project S-SOAR) develops professional development models to
support teaching strategies for conducting research online. In Project ESCOLAR, she also leads efforts to provide Hispanic teachers and students in Mexico with translated instructional websites and resources. In previous studies, she helped develop and evaluate bilingual online science modules for Hispanic English learners (Project COPELLS) and eText supports for improving Hispanic English learners\xe2\x80\x99 reading comprehension (Project ESTRELLAS).

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: COE Community Gathering, Monday, November 30'
html:
b'
Hello,
Below is an email that went out to students Wednesday afternoon inviting them to a gathering this evening.  For any questions, please contact Randy or Krista.
Thanks,
Lisa

From: Lisa Fortin
Sent: Wednesday, November 25, 2015 10:21 AM
To: coegr at lists.uoregon.edu; coeug at lists.uoregon.edu
Subject: COE Community Gathering, Monday, November 30

Dear Students,

The recent news of harm, unrest, and threats on college campuses and elsewhere are deeply affecting our College community, especially our students who routinely face inequities, exclusion, racism, or other acts of marginalization.   The closure of Western Washington University today is just the most recent example.  We have had several students come by Student Services to talk about their concerns related to these events, or seek information about campus and community resources.  Please continue to come to our office for these reasons.

As one step toward  helping students thrive personally and professionally, I ask that you join us next Monday, November 30, in the HEDCO building lobby from 5 to 7 pm.  I will be there, as will Dr. Krista Chronister, our Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion, our Student Diversity Affairs Committee (SDAC) members, and our COE Dean's Student Advisory Board (DSAB) members.  We will all be there for a singular reason; to listen to you and assist as requested.

Pizza will be served and please come by.

Until then,

Randy


For scheduling, please contact Amanda Eakins at aeakins at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20aeakins at uoregon.edu> or 541-346-6467.
________________________________
[COE logo]

R.W. Kamphaus, Ph.D. | Professor and Dean
randyk at uoregon.edu<mailto:randyk at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-3405
HEDCO 130
1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403

Center for Equity Promotion (CEQP) would like to invite faculty, staff, and students to the following colloquium:
[Screen Shot 2015-11-19 at 9 25 31 AM]

The Internet and mobile devices, such as global positioning system (GPS) navigation devices, tablets, and smart phones, have transformed the way people behave, interact, and communicate with others. subject: b'coe-fac: Nomination for Instructors of EDUC courses'
html:

subject: b'coe-fac: Thanks for joining us Monday night'
html:
b'
Dear COE Students,



I am most appreciative of the honesty and concern that you shared with Dr. Chronister and myself on Monday. I also want to acknowledge Lisa Fortin, our events coordinator, for putting together this event on such short notice, and our Student Diversity Advisory Board and Dean's Student Advisory Board for their attendance. As expected, I learned a great deal from my conversations with so many of you, and I appreciated your listening attentively. As I expressed to you then, I am fully aware that our work to create an inclusive and equitable learning environment in the college will require long term commitment and the efforts of many.



As I mentioned to some of you, we have at least begun the work. Listed below are some of the efforts we have made in the past year to begin to move our college toward the dual goals of improving inclusion and equity.



We created an Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion position this summer.  Dr. Krista Chronister serves in this role at .40 FTE (Full Time Equivalent), and her charge is to support the intellectual and civic excellence of our students, faculty, and staff by helping to establish equitable and inclusive practices across our instructional, training, service, and research activities.

In collaboration with our Student Diversity Affairs Committee (SDAC), we administered a College student survey last spring to assess the quality of students' learning experiences.

We now have a student, staff, and faculty representative to the UO Diversity Committee.  Each representative reports back to Krista.

We meet quarterly with the Dean's Student Advisory Board to hear from students about their experiences and needs as well as to share College information.

We maintain a College Diversity Advisory Committee comprised of community members specializing in education and social services.

We formed new collaborative partnerships with UO and local community groups to foster the post-secondary development of youth in our community and connection between College of Education students and community leaders.

We maintain an active Student Diversity Affairs Committee and support this committee formally with a GTF (Graduate Teaching Fellow position). SDAC and the GTF are supervised by Krista.

We started the Our Space art initiative. The purpose of Our Space is to bring into our College learning spaces artwork that reflects the diversity of our College student community and the diversity of the children and families our graduates will serve.

We collaborated with United Academics and Academic Affairs to offer two new faculty mentoring initiatives that aim to increase retention of faculty from traditionally underrepresented groups in higher education.

We are devoting much time and collaborative energy to creating a plan that meets the requirements of House Bill 3375; a plan to articulate how the College will increase recruitment, retention and graduation rates of UO domestic minority education personnel.

I also heard you and your colleagues across campus ask for more participation in the faculty hiring process. We began this Fall by routinely including both a student and staff member on every new faculty search committee. But, I am well aware that one of your central goals for us is to create a workforce of faculty and staff that better reflects our local, national, and international leadership aspirations. We did make some progress last year (See our new faculty hires at : https://education.uoregon.edu/office-dean/new-faculty-2015-16) by hiring new faculty that meet the highest standards of academic excellence. We are vigorously pursuing the same goal this year with your assistance.

I am grateful to all of your for participating in this important work,

Randy


For scheduling, please contact Amanda Eakins at aeakins at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20aeakins at uoregon.edu> or 541-346-6467.
________________________________
[COE logo]

R.W. Kamphaus, Ph.D. | Professor and Dean
randyk at uoregon.edu<mailto:randyk at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-3405
HEDCO 130
1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403

Please help me fill the empty bookshelves outside HEDCO room 230T. We have many visitors to this area, which makes it an ideal location for showcasing faculty research. subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Solidarity with our Muslim colleagues, students, and community members'
html:
b'
Dear COE,
We live in a time of wide-spread anti-Muslim and anti-middle eastern sentiment in Western countries.  The actions of a few are taken to be indications of the character of most, creating an atmosphere of threat and intimidation for Muslim citizens throughout the West.  Recent highly publicized comments by national political figures have intensified this atmosphere of threat and intimidation in the United States.  Assaults against citizens believed to be Muslim has risen lately.  And reports of unkind and bigoted remarks are increasing.  This is having effects on the daily experiences of our Muslim colleagues, students, and community members as well as anyone presumed to be Muslim.
 To our Muslim colleagues we say: Although we cannot change the national and international discourse, we can make clear that the voices of hate do not speak for us.  On behalf of the Education Studies faculty and staff, we want to state clearly our solidarity with our Muslim colleagues and students, their families, and their community.  We stand with you against this hate and bigotry.  When you walk in our door we see good people whom we want to know and with whom we want to work.
 For individual faculty and staff who are looking for a way to signal this solidarity, some of us will be posting fliers on our doors that say \xe2\x80\x9cAs-salamu alaykum\xe2\x80\x9d which translates roughly to \xe2\x80\x9cpeace be upon you.\xe2\x80\x9d  It is a greeting regularly used in Muslim gatherings.  The Arabic spelling is: \xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd8\xb3\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85 \xd8\xb9\xd9\x84\xd9\x8a\xd9\x83\xd9\x85\xe2\x80\x8e    I have attached a sample pdf.  The greeting has religious origins, but has become a casual (though still meaningful) convention.  It will serve to signal solidarity with and respect for Muslim community members.  (The idea for this gesture was inspired by this article: http://everydayfeminism.com/2015/12/letter-to-non-muslim-allies/ )
As-salamu alaykum,
Jill Baxter, Jerry Rosiek, and the EDST Department

subject: b'coe-fac: progress on cluster hire search'
html:
b'
Happy New Year Colleagues!

Many of you have been wondering about our progress in the search for the cluster hire positions in obesity prevention and health promotion this year.  As you may have noticed, we interviewed a group of candidates this fall and completed those interviews in November.   There were multiple goals in hiring these positions. First, we wanted to bring in the best candidates on the job market this year in this topic area.  Next, we wanted to recruit faculty whose research was synergistic with our strengths in the College of Education and participating departments/units.  Last, we wanted to make sure the group would form a true \xe2\x80\x9ccluster\xe2\x80\x9d,  with research interests that were related to each other in order to promote future collaboration.    I believe we have succeeded in all of these goals and we have now completed this search.

We made offers to 4 talented faculty and all 4 have now accepted their positions and will join us in the Fall of 2016.  Below is a list of our new colleagues and their research interests.

Nichole Kelly (Ph.D. Counseling Psychology, Virginia Commonwealth University). Her research focuses on cognitive models for energy intake and excess weight gain in adolescent girls.
Nicole Giuliani (Ph.D. Psychology, Stanford University)  Her work focuses on understanding neural mechanisms underlying intervention effects on health outcomes in overweight and at-risk individuals.
Tasia Smith (Ph.D. Counseling Psychology, University of Florida) Her research focuses on health disparity, depression, and obesity prevention in adolescence.
Elizabeth Budd (Ph.D. Public Health, Washington University, St. Louis). Her research focuses on physical activity interventions in schools and health outcomes for adolescents.

We look forward to welcoming these new colleagues next Fall!  Thanks to all of you who participated in this process.

Beth




Beth Stormshak, Ph.D.
Professor, College of Education
Director, Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403
http://psi.uoregon.edu
phone: 541-346-3538

subject: b"coe-fac: Dean's Distinguished Lecture Series - Dr. Trina Spencer on Tues 1/5 at 3:30 pm"
html:
b'

Dear all,

On behalf of the Special Education and Clinical Sciences Department, please join us for a research colloquium presentation as part of the Dean\xe2\x80\x99s Distinguished Lectures Series on Tuesday January 5th from 3:30 \xe2\x80\x93 4:30 pm in Hedco 230T. Details are below.


Trina Spencer, PhD, BCBA-D
University of Northern Arizona
Multi-Tiered System of Language Support: The Data and the Dream!
Colloquium Tuesday January 5, 2016 3:30 \xe2\x80\x93 4:30 pm
Informal Conversation 4:30 \xe2\x80\x93 5:00 pm
Hedco 230T
Refreshments Served
Multi-tiered models of differentiation instruction for decoding are ubiquitous in schools. To align with the simple view of reading, which postulates reading comprehension is the product of decoding and language comprehension, more attention should be given to the promotion of language comprehension in schools. In her talk, Dr. Spencer will provide a cogent argument for the need to have a dual focus on decoding and language comprehension, present a series of studies reflecting the iterative development of a multi-tiered academic language curriculum, and introduce innovative screening and progress monitoring tools.

Bio of Trina Spencer, PhD, BCBA-D
Dr. Spencer currently serves as the Research Director at the Institute for Human Development (IHD) and has an associate research faculty appointment in the Department of Educational Psychology at Northern Arizona University. She earned a specialist degree in School Psychology and a PhD in Disability Disciplines from Utah State University. She has been a board certified behavior analyst since 2001. Dr. Spencer has worked with culturally, linguistically, and economically diverse children as well as children with disabilities, their teachers, and their families for 15 years. She has published 28 articles in peer-reviewed journals, 5 book chapters, and 13 non-peer reviewed articles or encyclopedia entries. Her publications and editorial service span a number of disciplines including speech-language pathology, early childhood education, special education, applied linguistics, and school psychology. Benefitting from strong collaborations with practitioners and other researchers, Dr. Spencer maintains a spirited research agenda targeted at improving reading comprehension and academic outcomes of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most vulnerable students. Specifically, she has developed screening, curriculum-based measurement, and intervention tools so that schools can implement a multi-tiered system of language support to complement schools\xe2\x80\x99 decoding efforts. Finally, Dr. Spencer writes extensively on evidence-based practice and promotes interdisciplinary, collaborative relationships among clinicians, educators, and researchers.

text:
b'

Dear all,

On behalf of the Special Education and Clinical Sciences Department, please join us for a research colloquium presentation as part of the Dean\xe2\x80\x99s Distinguished Lectures Series on Tuesday January 5th from 3:30 \xe2\x80\x93 4:30 pm in Hedco 230T. Details are below.


Trina Spencer, PhD, BCBA-D
University of Northern Arizona
Multi-Tiered System of Language Support: The Data and the Dream!
Colloquium Tuesday January 5, 2016 3:30 \xe2\x80\x93 4:30 pm
Informal Conversation 4:30 \xe2\x80\x93 5:00 pm
Hedco 230T
Refreshments Served
Multi-tiered models of differentiation instruction for decoding are ubiquitous in schools. To align with the simple view of reading, which postulates reading comprehension is the product of decoding and language comprehension, more attention should be given to the promotion of language comprehension in schools. In her talk, Dr. Spencer will provide a cogent argument for the need to have a dual focus on decoding and language comprehension, present a series of studies reflecting the iterative development of a multi-tiered academic language curriculum, and introduce innovative screening and progress monitoring tools.

Bio of Trina Spencer, PhD, BCBA-D
Dr. Spencer currently serves as the Research Director at the Institute for Human Development (IHD) and has an associate research faculty appointment in the Department of Educational Psychology at Northern Arizona University. She earned a specialist degree in School Psychology and a PhD in Disability Disciplines from Utah State University. She has been a board certified behavior analyst since 2001. Dr. Spencer has worked with culturally, linguistically, and economically diverse children as well as children with disabilities, their teachers, and their families for 15 years. She has published 28 articles in peer-reviewed journals, 5 book chapters, and 13 non-peer reviewed articles or encyclopedia entries. Her publications and editorial service span a number of disciplines including speech-language pathology, early childhood education, special education, applied linguistics, and school psychology. Benefitting from strong collaborations with practitioners and other researchers, Dr. Spencer maintains a spirited research agenda targeted at improving reading comprehension and academic outcomes of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most vulnerable students. Specifically, she has developed screening, curriculum-based measurement, and intervention tools so that schools can implement a multi-tiered system of language support to complement schools\xe2\x80\x99 decoding efforts. Finally, Dr. Spencer writes extensively on evidence-based practice and promotes interdisciplinary, collaborative relationships among clinicians, educators, and researchers.

'

subject: b'coe-fac: SPSS License Renewal for 2016'
html:
b'
Hi,

The 2016 license for SPSS is now available. If your UO-owned computer is a laptop, you can update the license yourself by following the steps from the link below. Otherwise, please submit a COE IT support ticket by going to http://coehelp.uoregon.edu<http://coehelp.uoregon.edu/>, and include SPSS in the subject field of the form.

Detailed steps for renewing the SPSS license can be found here:

http://blogs.uoregon.edu/coehelp/how-to-guides/renewing-the-spss-license-code/

Regards,

- Ken

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Spring 2016 NCFDD Programming'
html:
b'
Dear College Faculty and Graduate Students:

I want to remind you that you are invited to be a member of the National Center for Faculty Development and Diversity.  The University of Oregon has an institutional membership that allows you access to impressive resources and programming like those featured this quarter, please see below.  We have a large number of UO faculty and graduate students who are members and have shared very positive experiences with the NCFDD.

Thank you,
Krista

If you have any questions or concerns, never hesitate to reach out to us. We look forward to working with you!

Warm Regards,

Amy Johnson

National Center for Faculty Development & Diversity

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Faculty Fund Awards - Call for Proposals - Due Feb 8'
html:
b'
COLLEGE OF EDUCATION FACULTY FUND AWARDS<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/>

The College of Education's Faculty Fund Awards provide financial support for the innovative ideas that contribute to the development of the early career of our faculty members. Funding is meant to catalyze projects and help faculty members achieve sustainability.

Eligibility: All College of Education faculty (FTE of .5 or greater) are eligible to apply for awards.

Applications will be based on meritorious factors that include:

  *   Projects which are not yet funded or have no other funding sources available
  *   Projects in a current area of priority or importance for the college
  *   High visibility projects
  *   Applicants that have not received a faculty fund award in the past three years

Application Steps:

  *   Complete and submit the proposal application<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/> by February 8, 2016.
  *   Deans of the College of Education will notify applicants being considered by March 18, 2016.
  *   Preliminary proposal applicants chosen will submit fuller proposals that:
     *   Develop the design and implementation plans
     *   Propose a plan to evaluate the initiative
     *   Propose a detailed budget
  *   Final applications will be due March 30, 2016. Applications will be reviewed and award decisions made by the deans of the College of Education. The COE Office of Development will review applications for alignment with the fund's intention.
  *   Project funding will be announced by April 15, 2016.
  *   Lead faculty in any funded project will give an annual written update to the donor. The awardees will also provide the COE Office of Development with necessary narrative and fiscal information to submit an annual report to the donor on the use and impact of funds.

Preliminary Proposal deadline: February 8, 2016

Review the funds available and determine which funding source is the best fit for your proposed project, then complete and submit the proposal form: https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/.

Please direct questions to Andrea Olson (andreao at uoregon.edu<mailto:andreao at uoregon.edu>).



________________________________

subject: b'coe-fac: Fall Curriculum update'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Hope 2016 is off to a good start for you. This email will update you to the curriculum happenings in Fall and expectations for winter.
Course and Program Review for Fall 2015

*       Course Review

*       Program Review
Looking ahead to Winter 2016

*       Important dates and Curriculum Committee Membership

*       COE Curriculum Resources

*       Foundations of educational research workgroup

*       New Programs review for spring
Course and Program Review for Fall 2015

Course Review. Fifteen courses were reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee.  One course was deactivated (CDS Audiological Rehabilitation). One course was sent back for revisions and all others were approved by faculty. These were moved forward to UOCC. Just a reminder you can track the status of any course by looking it up in CourseLeaf (https://nextcatalog.uoregon.edu/courseadmin/ ).

About 50% of the courses needed to have some adjustments to them before going forward to the COE Curriculum Committee.  A large number of these were because faculty are not using the most current syllabi template.  We had syllabi that clearly had not been updated as they included contacts such as David Chard and Joe Stevens, much less statements and links that were out of date. Please look at all your syllabi and be sure to update each year. The link for syllabi information is available at bottom of https://coe.uoregon.edu/governance/curriculum-review-policies. This has tips about what is expected as well as the required statements.

We used CourseLeaf for the first time at UO in the Fall (https://nextcatalog.uoregon.edu/courseadmin/ ). There have been a few glitches in process but overall went smoothly. The Curriculum Committee will look at the process to see if any changes need to be made internally due to this management system. I am continuing to meet with Ron Bramhall and Kathy Warden to better manage our system and to address faculty concerns regarding the visibility of comments and voting. I will keep you posted as I learn more.

Program review. Four programs were reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee: Family and Human Services Minor, Quantitative Research Methods Graduate Specialization, Educational Foundations: Secondary Undergraduate Certificate, Foundations in Special Education Undergraduate Certificate.  All were approved by the faculty and have moved forward to Academic Affairs and the Graduate School (where appropriate).

Higher Education Administration Graduate Specialization which was approved last year by faculty.  It had an initial review by Academic Affairs and questions sent to the department for response.

Looking Ahead to Winter 2016
Dates for winter term
February 1 - new course proposals are due in CourseLeaf
February 26 -1:00-2:00 in 260 U Information (Q &A) for faculty submitting new courses or programs
February 29 - 10:00-12:00 in 260 U COE Curriculum Committee Meeting - Courses only

You committee representatives are listed below. I strongly recommend that you keep them informed of any course or program modifications or additions.

o   EMPL: Gina Biancarosa, Jo Smith

o   EDST: Lisa Mazzei, Jeanne Hall

o   SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

o   CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The COE Curriculum resources are available at https://coe.uoregon.edu/governance/curriculum-review-policies. Please be sure to use the most current syllabi information when preparing your courses.

Foundations of educational research course workgroup has begun its work (Robert Horner, Kent McIntosh, Jerry Rosiek, Lisa Mazzei Elizabeth Skowron, Atika Khurana, Michael Bullis, Gina Biancarosa (Chair)).
Charge for workgroup:

1)      to design a foundational research course that will be required of all COE PhD students. As a group will define (a) clear student learning objectives, (b) some course parameters that ensure quality delivery (such as describing instructor qualifications, course format, timing, etc.), and (c) potentially some critical core assignments and readings. Then a subcommittee would draft the syllabus based on our consensus.

2)      define core research competencies that we think any PhD graduating from a leading research College of Education should have as a preliminary exercise to defining learning objectives for this new course (from Dean Kamphaus)
I will update you as I have more information.

New programs for review in Spring.  The first step in developing a new program is approval of a synopsis by the Department Head Council and Dean (meet about 2x per month). Things to consider for the synopsis are:

1.       General information about a) rationale information about the rationale (why needed, how will enhance or complement the COE programs/mission), b) the key features of the design (e.g., format (online/in person), built off existing program or brand new), c) targeted audience (UG/G), d) anticipated start

2.       Program description - number of credits, new/existing/shared courses, open to others or limited to certain degrees, expected enrollment

3.       Financial or other resources that might be needed to support the program- what will the extra investments be for long term and short term.

4.       List of programs that might be impacted positively or negatively (COE/UO) and if you have talked with any of them.
February 26 1:00-2:00 in 260 U Information (Q &A) for faculty submitting new courses or programs


Curriculum policy. The COE Curriculum Committee will begin the review of the current COE policy and procedures. The first meeting is January 13. Once they have completed their proposed revisions it will be posted for comment and later for vote. I hope this work will be finished before June 2016.
Thanks for all the work of faculty to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions check in with your Program Director,  Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative attend the Q & A session(February 26) or if necessary schedule a time to meet with me.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20160111/b30d37f2/attachment-0001.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Honoring Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'
html:
b'
Dear College Community,

There are several upcoming university and community events to honor the work and legacy of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.   Please find below a sample of these events, service opportunities, and award ceremonies.  The College of Education is pleased to co-sponsor some of these events and to have members of our College community involved with, and recognized for, their part in raising the questions that illuminate injustice and taking action to challenge the status quo.


NAACP of Lane County MLK Community March
http://naacplanecounty.org/event/2016-mlk-community-march/
January 18
Co-sponsored by the College of Education and UO
Please view other community events on the NAACP website.


Rev. Dr.  Martin Luther King, Jr. Awards Luncheon
http://inclusion.uoregon.edu/
January 20
Sponsored by the UO Division on Equity and Inclusion
College of Education faculty member, Ellen McWhirter, to receive an award.


MLK Jr. Day of Service
http://holden.uoregon.edu/service
Sponsored by the UO Holden Center for Leadership and Community Engagement


Best,
Krista

_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education
5251 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5251
https://education.uoregon.edu/users/chronister
www.access-dv.org<http://www.access-dv.org/>
(off) 541.346.2415
(fax) 541.346.6778

We are growing at the University of Oregon College of Education.  Learn more about our open faculty positions at http://jobs.uoregon.edu/unclassified.php?subtype=academic and our innovations in research and teaching at https://education.uoregon.edu/

subject: b'coe-fac: Managing Hot Moments in the Classroom - RSVP by Jan 25'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

As I shared during our faculty meeting this week, please find below information about the Managing Hot Moments in the Classroom workshop that the College is co-sponsoring with the UO Division of Equity and Inclusion.  RSVP using the link below.  Space is limited and food is provided.


College of Education Workshop: Managing Hot Moments in the Classroom

Many instructors avoid controversial topics in the classroom because of the difficulty involved in managing heated discussions.  Instructors who are willing to bring up such issues may face disheartening challenges in the classroom or low student ratings, in part, because of their identity-their race, gender, accent, etc.  Controversy can be a useful, powerful, and memorable tool to promote learning.  Research has demonstrated that conflict or controversy during classroom discussion can promote cognitive gains in complex reasoning, integrated thinking, and decision-making.  During this workshop we will discuss how instructors can successfully manage discussions on controversial topics.  Participants will consider problematic scenarios and discuss approaches to avoid problems.

Workshop Leader:  Dr. Joan Middendorf, Center for Innovative Teaching and Learning and Educational Leadership, Indiana University
Venue:  ED 176
Date:  Monday, February 8
Time:  2:00pm - 3:30pm
RSVP:  Space is limited. RSVP by Monday, January 25 at noon: http://tinyurl.com/j2fl66x


_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education
5251 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5251
https://education.uoregon.edu/users/chronister
www.access-dv.org<http://www.access-dv.org/>
(off) 541.346.2415
(fax) 541.346.6778

We are growing at the University of Oregon College of Education.  Learn more about our open faculty positions at http://jobs.uoregon.edu/unclassified.php?subtype=academic and our innovations in research and teaching at https://education.uoregon.edu/

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Faculty Fund Awards - Call for Proposals - Due Feb 8'
html:
b'
COLLEGE OF EDUCATION FACULTY FUND AWARDS<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/>

The College of Education's Faculty Fund Awards provide financial support for the innovative ideas that contribute to the development of the early career of our faculty members. Funding is meant to catalyze projects and help faculty members achieve sustainability.

Eligibility: All College of Education faculty (FTE of .5 or greater) are eligible to apply for awards.

Applications will be based on meritorious factors that include:

  *   Projects which are not yet funded or have no other funding sources available
  *   Projects in a current area of priority or importance for the college
  *   High visibility projects
  *   Applicants that have not received a faculty fund award in the past three years

Application Steps:

  *   Complete and submit the proposal application<https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/> by February 8, 2016.
  *   Deans of the College of Education will notify applicants being considered by March 18, 2016.
  *   Preliminary proposal applicants chosen will submit fuller proposals that:
     *   Develop the design and implementation plans
     *   Propose a plan to evaluate the initiative
     *   Propose a detailed budget
  *   Final applications will be due March 30, 2016. Applications will be reviewed and award decisions made by the deans of the College of Education. The COE Office of Development will review applications for alignment with the fund's intention.
  *   Project funding will be announced by April 15, 2016.
  *   Lead faculty in any funded project will give an annual written update to the donor. The awardees will also provide the COE Office of Development with necessary narrative and fiscal information to submit an annual report to the donor on the use and impact of funds.

Preliminary Proposal deadline: February 8, 2016

Review the funds available and determine which funding source is the best fit for your proposed project, then complete and submit the proposal form: https://coe.uoregon.edu/scholarships/coe-faculty-fund-awards/.

Please direct questions to Andrea Olson (andreao at uoregon.edu<mailto:andreao at uoregon.edu>).

subject: b'coe-fac: Joan Middendorf: Managing Hot Moments'
html:
b'
A reminder, please, to reserve your space for Dr. Joan Middendorf\xe2\x80\x99s workshop on Managing Hot Moments in the Classroom.  The UO Division on Equity and Inclusion and our College of Education is pleased to co-sponsor this professional development event.  Food is provided.  Location is College of Education, room TBA.

Information below and attached.

Thank you,
Krista

_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education
5251 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5251
https://education.uoregon.edu/users/chronister

[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/548a392f-c2fe-4262-bd28-4c2e3926e33c.png]<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FzMKW97xLDeDh1T8qzAfGJ-3c8avWMaYD_eqYRM1mrOI0xmJnmlxStfLjjiOg68Vt4jWVooq-UkdK5YTZ9V0GrxvU0aMKrEXRNMQe2CpC2I=>






The University of Oregon's Division of Equity and Inclusion
invites you to join us in welcoming
 Dr. Joan Middendorf
February 8th & 9th, 2016





[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/8e402d3c-d710-419e-bdf2-f1920d6216e7.png]






Workshop: Managing Hot Moments in the Classroom
Monday, February 8 from 2:00-3:30 p.m.
Venue will be confirmed via e-mail after your RSVP
Workshop hosted by the College of Education

Many instructors avoid controversial issues in the classroom because of the difficulty involved in managing heated discussions. Instructors who are willing to bring up such issues may face disheartening challenges in the classroom or low student ratings, in part, because of their identity-their race, gender, accent, etc. Controversy can be a useful, powerful, and memorable tool to promote learning.

Research has demonstrated that conflict or controversy during classroom discussion can promote cognitive gains in complex reasoning, integrated thinking, and decision-making. In this session we will discuss how instructors can successfully manage discussions on controversial topics. Participants will consider problematic scenarios and discuss approaches to avoid problems.


Please join us!





[Sylvio's]






Space is limited. Please register by Wednesday, January 27th at noon.


 Click to RSVP<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FzMKW97xLDeDh1T8qzAfGJ-3c8avWMaYD_eqYRM1mrOI0xmJnmlxStfLjjiOg68Vt4jWVooq-UkZwhCdfQP1bhx5nwhQjP_jG97i9IbtVJ8=>



Contact Dr. Sari Pascoe, Assistant Vice President for Campus and Community Engagement at
spascoe at uoregon.edu<mailto:spascoe at uoregon.edu> for any questions you may have.

Visit our website<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FzMKW97xLDeDh1T8qzAfGJ-3c8avWMaYD_eqYRM1mrOI0xmJnmlxStfLjjiOg68Vt4jWVooq-UkdK5YTZ9V0GrxvU0aMKrEXRNMQe2CpC2I=> for more information.

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: February Implicit Bias Workshops'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty and Staff:

Please see below for an important opportunity offered by the UO Division on Equity and Inclusion.

Dr. Erik Girvan, UO Law School faculty, has been working with Colleges, search committees, admissions committees, etc. across our campus to share about implicit bias and how it influences our every-day decision making.  Colleagues across the University have shared very positive feedback about Dr. Girvan's workshops and have used his information to make immediate and concrete changes in their respective units.

Space is limited.

Thank you,
Krista

_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion

Subject: codaclist: February Implicit Bias Workshops













[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/548a392f-c2fe-4262-bd28-4c2e3926e33c.png]<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001N-e5LYg5kqhdK__fMJTr1u2y1UUIUooj-Dgg7daGxlymEi5VU43qqERAoYt8hhWPM_kqcd_IUTbAW1LWusYmEN6Fgsz4GGlUAuSfl2tVi2s=>






The University of Oregon's Division of Equity and Inclusion
invites you to participate in
Implicit Bias in Decision Making
February 11th & 16th, 2016





[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/55ce7519-5238-4a58-a887-4e7274d7d825.jpg]






Implicit Bias in Decision-Making: An Introduction
Thursday, February 11th | Noon -12:30 p.m.
Knight Library Browsing Room
Workshop conducted by Erik J. Girvan, J.D., Ph.D., UO School of Law

How can someone's race, sex, age, or other characteristics influence how we see and treat them even when we are genuinely trying to be unbiased? What concrete steps can we take to help prevent this from happening? To help answer these questions, this workshop introduces the concept of implicit bias. Through a mix of short presentations, lively activities, and discussions, we will explore some harmful side effects of how our brains naturally perceive, categorize, and draw inferences about the world, including other people. We will also examine when this kind of bias is most likely to occur. And we will talk about what practical steps we can all take to try to reduce or eliminate it as well as what has been shown not to work.


Implicit Bias in Decision-Making: Specific Applications
Tuesday, February 16th | Noon -12:30 p.m.
Knight Library Browsing Room
Workshop conducted by Erik J. Girvan, J.D., Ph.D., UO School of Law

Knowing about implicit biases is not enough to reduce it or keep it from impacting what we do. Building on the introduction to implicit bias, in this workshop participants will work with the presenters to identify specific policies and practices in their workplace that are most likely to be affected by implicit bias and brainstorm concrete changes that they can make to minimize those effects.


Please join us!





[Sylvio's]






Space is limited. Please register by Tuesday, February 9th.


Click to RSVP<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001N-e5LYg5kqhdK__fMJTr1u2y1UUIUooj-Dgg7daGxlymEi5VU43qqERAoYt8hhWPM_kqcd_IUTaRgs5q7SnW1wzWbllw-3c2HIapx5Srdd0=>

text:
b"Dear COE Faculty and Staff:

Please see below for an important opportunity offered by the UO Division on Equity and Inclusion.

Dr. Erik Girvan, UO Law School faculty, has been working with Colleges, search committees, admissions committees, etc. across our campus to share about implicit bias and how it influences our every-day decision making.  Colleagues across the University have shared very positive feedback about Dr. Girvan's workshops and have used his information to make immediate and concrete changes in their respective units.

Space is limited.

Thank you,
Krista

_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education

Eugene, OR 97403-5251

subject: b'coe-fac: Library'
html:
b'
Hello all,

Every now and then I like to remind people what I (and the Library) can do for them.

Here is a quick list of things I can assist you with:


*         Want to suggest books or DVDs? - send me the title and any other information you have (budget permitting, of course)

*         Thinking of a new program or area? Want to know if we have the materials to support it? - I can give you a view of the landscape

*         Students need some research guidance?  Want a class presentation? - shoot me an email and I'm there!

*         Looking for Foundation money?  (I am the Foundation Database contact) - I would love to show individuals or groups the money

*         Candidate interviews - want tour of Library? - I can show off our facilities and discuss access to research/teaching materials

*         Writing a grant? - I can help you out of a research corner and assist with finding articles

*         Writing accreditation report  - need a report on library resources? - no problem (advance notice always appreciated)

*         Would you like an office visit to talk about setting up bookmarks for databases, or instructions on setting up a system to alert you to new books or journal articles, or talk about other research/instructional issues? - I'd love to show you how to make your life easier

*         EndNote, Zotero, or Mendeley questions? - you've been meaning to ...

Any suggestions?  Any complaints?  Any compliments?  Would you like to chat over a cup of coffee?

Looking forward to hearing from you.

Katy
klenn at uoregon.edu<mailto:klenn at uoregon.edu>
541-346-3072

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Tenure and Promotion Files - Natural Sciences Faculty Luncheon Workshop on Equity and Inclusion'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty:

College of Education faculty interested in learning more about how to feature their equity and inclusion work in their tenure and promotion materials are invited to the workshop below.   Please RSVP because space is limited.

Best,
Krista



Please join us for the Natural Sciences Faculty Luncheon Workshop on Equity and Inclusion. Sponsored by Academic Affairs, the College of Arts and Sciences, and the Center on Diversity and Community (CoDaC), and United Academics, this workshop will feature a panel to highlight the work of natural sciences faculty members towards equity and inclusion.

Date: Friday, February 26th, 2016
Time: 12:00 - 1:30 p.m.
Location: Global Scholars Hall

We kindly request that you RSVP to http://tinyurl.com/codacnatsci by Thursday, February 18th at 5:00pm.


[cid:image001.jpg at 01D16266.3C014F00]

subject: b'coe-fac: FW:  Productivity, Creativity and Work-Life Balance Before Tenure: Faculty Workshop, 2/26, 10 AM'
html:
b'
"Productivity, Creativity and Work-Life Balance Before Tenure"

This 90-minute workshop focuses on productivity, creativity and work-life balance before tenure. Learn how to establish a regular writing routine amidst the demands of teaching and service, plan your time efficiently as you work toward tenure, and find time for life outside of work. Open to pre-tenure faculty from all disciplines, departments and schools.

Tanya Golash-Boza<http://www.ucmerced.edu/content/tanya-golash-boza>, Associate Professor of Sociology, UC Merced is the workshop facilitator. Professor Golash-Boza is a prolific scholar-in the last seven years, she has authored five books and has published more than 15 peer reviewed articles across an array of disciplines.
[Description: https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/681929983669870593/LCvUjmZn.jpg]She is also the author of the blog "Get a Life PhD<http://www.getalifephd.blogspot.com>," which includes a wealth of articles for faculty on professional development and personal well-being. (See getalifephd.blogspot.com) and facilitates writing retreats and workshops for faculty across the country.

When: Friday, February 26, 10-11:30 AM. Light refreshments provided.

Where: HEDCO 220

RSVP: Click here to RSVP<https://docs.google.com/a/uauoregon.org/forms/d/1QjD6yS5L4X6QpBZ7dsKVjzBaRj-0dwGhCruUrF2iLUw/viewform?c=0&w=1>:

Sponsored by United Academics, Academic Affairs, and the College of Education.For more information contact Prof. Daniel HoSang, Chair of UA Diversity and Equity Committee, dhosang at uoregon.edu
<mailto:dhosang at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Interim Appointment of Chris Krabiel'
html:
b'
Dear COE Colleagues,

I write today to inform you about the appointment of Chris Krabiel as interim chief information officer at the University of Oregon. Although it is a challenging endeavor, please be assured that Chris and I have plans in place to cover many of his duties while he serves our institution in an expanded role. At this point, please join me in congratulating Chris on this recognition of his work by his colleagues.

Warm regards,

Randy




For scheduling, please contact Maggie Bosworth  at magboz at uoregon.edu<mailto:magboz at uoregon.edu>  or 541-346-6467.
________________________________
[COE logo]

R.W. Kamphaus, Ph.D. | Professor and Dean

1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: Greenfield Award'
html:
b'
Time to think about your research needs - Is there an expensive title crucial to your research?  Is there a data set you've been coveting?

Time for the Stanley B. Greenfield Faculty Awards Program.

The Stanley B. Greenfield Faculty Awards Program recognizes the need to enhance the Library's collection of research materials. Through this program, UO faculty members nominate significant research titles for possible purchase. Library collection managers will select titles from the nominees and make awards to acquire those titles. All purchases are funded through the combination of the Greenfield Awards Endowment Fund and designated private gifts. More information, detailed guidelines, and the online application are available here:  https://library.uoregon.edu/info/greenfield/index.html
If you're considering submitting a request, please let me know - I can assist with the application and can champion it during the decision process.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Katy
(6-3072)
-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20160223/d1a26901/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Work-Life Balance - workshop reminder'
html:
b'
Dr. Golash-Boza was featured recently in The Chronicle of Higher Education.  Her work centers on increasing faculty creativity and productivity.

Thank you,
Krista


Work-Life Balance: Get a Life, PhD"

This 90-minute workshop focuses on productivity, creativity and work-life balance for faculty on the tenure-track. Learn how to establish a regular writing routine amidst the demands of teaching and service, plan your time efficiently, and find time for life outside of work. Separate workshops for pre-tenure faculty and those at mid-career. Open to faculty from all disciplines, departments and schools.

Tanya Golash-Boza<http://www.ucmerced.edu/content/tanya-golash-boza>, Associate Professor of Sociology, UC Merced is the workshop facilitator. Professor Golash-Boza is a prolific scholar-in the last seven years, she has authored five books and has published more than 15 peer reviewed articles across an array of disciplines. She is also the author of the blog "Get a Life PhD<http://www.getalifephd.blogspot.com/>," which includes a wealth of articles for faculty on professional development and personal well-being and facilitates writing retreats and workshops for faculty across the country.
[Description: https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/681929983669870593/LCvUjmZn.jpg]
When: Friday, February 26
10-11:30 AM, HEDCO 220, for pre-tenure faculty. RSVP here<https://docs.google.com/a/uauoregon.org/forms/d/1QjD6yS5L4X6QpBZ7dsKVjzBaRj-0dwGhCruUrF2iLUw/viewform?c=0&w=1>.  Light refreshments provided
2-3:30 PM, HEDCO 144, for mid-career and senior faculty. RSVP here<https://docs.google.com/a/uauoregon.org/forms/d/1-ejewc28WfIJbsqnMzD21jcdFbUOGxZSsrQgnt1h4BI/viewform?c=0&w=1>  Light refreshments provided

Sponsored by United Academics, Academic Affairs, and the College of Education. For more information contact Prof. Daniel HoSang, Chair of UA Diversity and Equity Committee, dhosang at uoregon.edu<mailto:dhosang at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Memo: Senate HELP Committee ESSA Implementation Hearing on Education Leaders\xe2\x80\x99 Perspectives'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty and Staff,

Please see the most recent update (appended) regarding ESSA (Every Student Succeeds Act) implementation, which is a result of our membership in the LEARN coalition - The Learning and Education Academic Research Network \xe2\x80\x93 comprised of 24 leading research university colleges of education. You may find the membership roster and further information about the work of LEARN at https://learncoalition.wordpress.com/membership/.

Our UO Washington DC consulting firm, Lewis-Burke, also monitors ESSA implementation, as well as all federal matters with the potential to impact our university, as does our Office of Governmental Affairs (i.e., Betsy Boyd). We receive one or more email updates weekly from the LEARN consulting firm; Penn Hill Group. Both Lewis Burke and Penn Hill Group were most help recently in support of our efforts to argue for greater funding of education research.

The work of ESSA implementation is proceeding rapidly. Meetings to draw up implementation regulations will occur in March. I have been nominated by a professional society to serve on the implementation committee, as has probably been the case for some of you. Regardless of whether or not any of us are called to serve, we will be monitoring ESSA implementation closely thanks to our membership in LEARN and our collaboration with Lewis-Burke.

Regards,

Randy

For scheduling, please contact Maggie Bosworth at  magboz at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20magboz at uoregon.edu> or 541-346-6467.

1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403



From: Aileen Ma [mailto:ama at pennhillgroup.com]
Sent: Wednesday, February 24, 2016 1:33 PM
Subject: Memo: Senate HELP Committee ESSA Implementation Hearing on Education Leaders\xe2\x80\x99 Perspectives

Hello,

Attached please find a memo summarizing yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions (HELP) Committee hearing to examine implementation of the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA), which reauthorizes the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA), in states and school districts, focusing on perspectives from education leaders.


Key Issues Discussed:

Members and witnesses discussed the monumental \xe2\x80\x9creset\xe2\x80\x9d ESSA has brought and discussed issues regarding implementation of ESSA in states and local school districts, as well as the role of the U.S. Department of Education (ED) in this work.

Witnesses from an array of organizations discussed the work they are advancing with state and local partners and in coalitions to help states develop plans to implement ESSA and follow through on these plans.

Members and witnesses discussed the feasibility of ED\xe2\x80\x99s request for states to turn in new Title I and Title II plans by July 1, 2017 so they can be effective in the 2017-2018 school year.
Please let us know if you have any questions.

- Penn Hill Group

subject: b'coe-fac: 2 new courses in spring: VideoLab: on Education.......Youth and Social Change'
html:
b'
Faculty there are a couple of new courses offered this spring.  Both faculty instructors have offered to come and talk to your students at a meeting or in a class - contact them directly to make arrangements.  Also the posters are attached.


EDST 410/510 VideoLab: On Educaiton (Dr. Ed Madison)  is a course that is co-sponsored by College of Education and the School of Journalism.  The course focuses on the intersection of media, education, and technology, with specific emphasis on digital storytelling and interview methods. It explores personal and professional narratives surrounding education through critique
of societal notions and media representations about teaching, student achievement, and education reform. Students will draw from journalistic interview methods to identify and examine stories of individuals from underrepresented populations, focusing on issues of gender, race/ethnicity, and class.


Law 399 Youth and Social Change (Dr. Michael Musheno)  is a course the law school is offering and thought it might be of interest to many of our students.  This course interrogates adult-centered representations of youth, their problems, and the supposed solutions to these problems. We explore how adult world constructs and acts on youth through the institutions they control, including law and criminal justice. Concurrently, we investigate how these institutional domains are imagined and acted on by youth, differently situated, bringing to intellectual life a rarely considered youth-centered perspective of social life and activism. Throughout the course, we give attention to histories, tensions, and implications of different ways of thinking about and acting on youth. As a legal studies endeavor, this course encompasses cases, policy and regulations as they are lived, shaped and encountered by youth of different backgrounds. We bring forward ideas about identities, trust, agency and space as well as methodological tools that allow us to understand how youth make sense of their lives, assert their views of justice, fairness, and legality, and act on them as agents of change. To accomplish this, we engage in classroom and field-related learning.

Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: meeting with Sudbury Charter School'
html:
b'
COE Faculty

We have received a request from Eugene Sudbury Charter School in Eugene to participate with them on a new project they recently started.  Sudbury is a 4J charter with 66 students currently enrolled and the plan is for 120 students. Their program is a blend of the Sudbury model (democratic immersion),  project based practices, STEAM curriculum (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Math,) with traditional classroom instruction.

The project goals include: Implement marketing plan, specifically geared toward at-risk/underserved populations; administer professional development to provide staff with the tools and understanding of our diverse student population, and capacity building for our Board / Sponsor; and align STEAM labs with project-based curriculum and Common Core to ensure all students meet state and federal requirements.


Rather than have them contact you each individually I agreed to send an email to identify faculty interested in participating in a meeting to learn more and will arrange a space for such a meeting here on campus. Please send an email to Maggie Bosworth magboz at uoregon.edu<mailto:magboz at uoregon.edu> if you would like to be included in a meeting.  Please respond by Wednesday March 2nd.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs
College of Education
brigidf at uoregon.edu
-------------- next part --------------

Please let us know if you have any questions.

-Penn Hill Group

Policy Update:  Acting Secretary of Education Called to Capitol Hill

Lewis-Burke Associates LLC \xe2\x80\x93 February 26, 2016

On February 24, Acting Secretary of Education John King testified before the House Committee on Education and the Workforce about the President\xe2\x80\x99s fiscal year (FY) 2017 budget request for the Department of Education (ED) during its hearing titled \xe2\x80\x9cExamining the Policies and Priorities of the U.S. Department of Education.\xe2\x80\x9d  The hearing was one of three this week at which Acting Secretary King testified.  During the hearing, King emphasized that that the actions of ED are guided by three main principles: ensuring every child has the opportunity to receive an excellent education; supporting teachers and elevating the teaching profession; and improving access, affordability, and completion in higher education.

The hearing was widely attended by Members from both sides of the aisle, alternating praise and criticism for the proposed ED budget.  Chairman John Kline (R-MN) led his party\xe2\x80\x99s opposition to the proposals in the budget request by criticizing the utilization of mandatory funding streams, the creation of new expensive programs, and the perceived underfunding of special education.  Virginia Foxx (R-NC), who is the presumed successor as Chair of the House Ed and Workforce Committee upon Chairman Kline\xe2\x80\x99s retirement, questioned the actions and authority of the Office of Civil Rights at ED.  Other Members touched upon the issues of student loan debt and federal loan interest rates; criticized the College Scorecard; and questioned the regulatory burden placed on colleges and universities.  Representatives Ruben Hinojosa (D-TX) and Raul Grijalva (D-AZ) expressed concern that ED had overlooked Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs) in its budget request.  Other Members lauded ED\xe2\x80\x99s expansion of the Pell Grant program to include year-round Pell Grants, income-driven repayment programs, and targeting Federal Work Study funds to students with the greatest financial need.  The budget request for ED is unlikely to gain traction in Congress due to partisan disagreements and the budget request\xe2\x80\x99s reliance on mandatory funding for new programs.


The following day, King was back on the Hill, this time on the Senate-side. On February 25, the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions (HELP) Committee held a hearing to examine King\xe2\x80\x99s nomination to serve as Secretary of Education, focusing on implementation of the Every Student Succeeds Act and higher education issues including preventing campus sexual assault; simplifying the financial aid process; and addressing student loan servicing, interest rates, and repayment.  This hearing followed President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s nomination of John King as Secretary of Education on February 11.  King, formerly an Acting Deputy Secretary of Education, has served as Acting Secretary since Arne Duncan stepped down from the post at the end of 2015.  Chairman of the Senate HELP Committee Lamar Alexander (R-TN) encouraged the President to appoint a nominee, and has promised an expedited confirmation hearing.  The Committee will consider the mark-up of King\xe2\x80\x99s nomination on March 9.

Sources and Additional Information:

\xc2\xb7         An archived webcast and witness testimony for the hearing on the ED budget request can be found at http://edworkforce.house.gov/calendar/eventsingle.aspx?EventID=400263.

\xc2\xb7         A full archived webcast and witness testimony for the February 25 hearing on King\xe2\x80\x99s nomination can be found at http://www.help.senate.gov/hearings/nomination-of-dr-john-king-to-serve-as-secretary-of-education.


Lewis-Burke Associates, LLC
1341 G Street, N.W.
Eighth Floor
Washington, D.C. 20005

________________________________
Disclaimer: This message is intended only for the named recipient. If you are not the intended recipient you are notified that disclosing, copying, distributing or taking any action in reliance on the contents of this information is strictly prohibited.
________________________________

\xc2\xb7         A full archived webcast and witness testimony for the February 25 hearing on King\xe2\x80\x99s nomination can be found at http://www.help.senate.gov/hearings/nomination-of-dr-john-king-to-serve-as-secretary-of-education.

subject: b'coe-fac: Graduate Study Rooms available to book'
html:
b'
Please share this announcement with your graduate students:



The Knight library now has two study rooms for use by graduate students currently enrolled at UO.

Rooms 419 and 419A are small study spaces - each with a capacity of 2-3 people. More information and booking link available at:  http://library.uoregon.edu/reserve/gradstudy.<http://library.uoregon.edu/reserve/gradstudy>



Katy Lenn

Education Librarian

subject: b'coe-fac: nominations for position of Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty,

I am writing to open the search for our associate dean who will continue the fine work done by Lauren Lindstrom in this position. Accordingly, I am appending below the position description and nomination process from our COE Bylaws. Our incumbent will be joining a high performing leadership team that is committed to academic and research excellence, and student success. Please submit nominations to me (with a copy to Maggie Bosworth) by Monday, March 14, 2016. I do ask that you obtain the assent of the nominee prior to submitting the nomination. Self-nominations will be accepted. Subsequently, Maggie will request a CV from all nominees, which will be shared with "constituent faculty," as described below, as part of the selection process. I anticipate making a selection by March 28, 2016.

Thanks, in advance, for your assistance in this matter,

Randy
C COE Staff, Maggie

"The Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development (ADRFD) is responsible for overseeing, guiding, and promoting the COE research efforts, and is responsible for integration of the academic and research enterprises of the COE. Additionally, the ADRFD coordinates all faculty promotion and tenure processes, and offers professional development activities that foster faculty success."

"The Associate Deans shall be selected by the Dean from COE career faculty members at the rank of Associate Professor or higher. In the case of the Associate Dean for Service and Outreach, and the Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development, a nominee at the rank of either Senior Research Associate I or Associate Research Professor or higher may be appointed. The Dean shall solicit and consider nominations from representative faculty. Preference for both of these positions shall be given to candidates with the rank of full Professor, Senior Research Associate II of Full Research Professor and relevant University level experience. The Dean shall consult with constituent faculty (i.e., department heads, unit directors, Program Directors) in the final decision making process.  An Associate Dean is appointed at 0.50 FTE for three years, beginning September 16 and ending September 15. The Associate Deans shall receive annual performance reviews, performed by the Dean, based on their responsibilities. The Dean shall solicit input (e.g., electronic, meeting) from representative faculty and staff within this process. These reviews shall be completed before the beginning of the fall term and address service during the prior academic year."



For scheduling, please contact Maggie Bosworth at  magboz at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20magboz at uoregon.edu> or 541-346-6467.
________________________________
[COE logo]

R.W. Kamphaus, Ph.D. | Professor and Dean
randyk at uoregon.edu<mailto:randyk at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-3405
HEDCO 130
1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: Deadline Extended: Register for Showcase Oregon by March\t2nd'
html:
b'
Sent: Monday, February 29, 2016 2:18 PM
Subject: Deadline Extended: Register for Showcase Oregon by March 2nd












[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/548a392f-c2fe-4262-bd28-4c2e3926e33c.png]<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hOnOdVFLWqreEuGNqSPVNjazXS2pUdQeniwzd_ESe7YeRcyoUilg-tUVvyjMWhobbczL_giuufmvh6TmChA6wTQxsJi-W4w3ltdShJUZWMw=>






Register today for the Division of Equity and Inclusion's
Showcase Oregon 2016:
"Race, Gender, Faith, and Justice: Empowering Women, Transforming Our World"





[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/396103fc-e2ab-4d93-a935-ba44ecdc626c.png]






March 7th, 2016
8:00 a.m.-5:00 p.m.
Ford Alumni Center
University of Oregon

The second-annual Showcase Oregon will focus on the theme of justice as it relates to the intersectional identities of race, gender and faith. Our hope is that this year's theme will allow our campus and surrounding community to reflect on the multifaceted meaning of justice in the academy and beyond and the ways in which empowered women facilitate justice by using their skills, talents and wisdom to transform lives and institutions.

In addition to hearing from women academics, entrepreneurs, community activists and higher education leaders, the one-day symposium will feature a breakfast panel on student activism as well as a Teach In on the Movement for Black Lives over lunch by Professor Brittney Cooper, Assistant Professor of Women's and Gender Studies and Africana Studies at Rutgers University and Co-founder of the Crunk Feminist Collective. The closing reception will include a call to action by Dr. Belle Wheelan, President of Southern Commission on Colleges and a poster session by local student activists.

Showcase has something for everyone. All faculty, staff, students, alumni and community members are encouraged to attend. A description of the panels, panelists and their bios is posted on our website.


The event is free and open to the public.

The deadline for registration has been extended to Wednesday, March 2nd, 2016!


 Click to RSVP<http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001hOnOdVFLWqreEuGNqSPVNjazXS2pUdQeniwzd_ESe7YeRcyoUilg-tUVvyjMWhobbczL_giuufmvh6TmChA6wTQxsJi-W4w3B2wpfRGYyzL-beFBUH0ShIrFHlyXso6GgVFSkZnH7Ws=>




Contact the Division of Equity and Inclusion at  vpinclusion at uoregon.edu<mailto:vpinclusion at uoregon.edu?subject=Showcase%20Oregon%202016> for any questions you may have.





[https://mlsvc01-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/3f1bf366501/63b28cf6-d52a-4276-a03c-54e39699810a.png]




Office of the Vice President for Equity and Inclusion
Division of Equity and Inclusion
1 Johnson Hall, 6216 East 13th Avenue, Eugene, OR 97403
E-mail:vpinclusion at uoregon.edu   <mailto:vpinclusion at uoregon.edu>
| Phone: <mailto:vpinclusion at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Join UO College of Education at AERA 2016 Reception'
html:
b'
Hello,
For those faculty and students who are attending the AERA Conference in Washington, DC, we will once again be hosting a reception to showcase the great COE faculty and student research that is presented at the conference.  The reception will be held on Saturday, April 9th from 6 to 8 pm at Elizabeth's on L.  In addition to our own AERA attendees, we are inviting local COE alumni, giving them the chance to hang out, chat with faculty and students, and learn about the world class research the COE does.  You can RSVP here<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3dU2KNK5uwTVRg9> or at the link below.  Please feel free to forward this invitation to any colleagues coming to AERA who might like to attend as well.  Please let me know if you have any questions.
Lisa



[AERA 2016]





JOIN THE COE AT AERA 2016




The UO College of Education will once again host a reception during the American Educational Research Association's annual conference in Washington, DC. Our event will be held at the legendary Elizabeth's on L<http://elizabethsonlstreet.com/#home> from 6-8 p.m. Saturday, April 9 and features a veritable Who's Who of educational research-in other words, you. We hope to see you there!




RSVP Now<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_3dU2KNK5uwTVRg9>











[http://pages.uoregon.edu/edmatters/big-questions/icon-www.png]




education.uoregon.edu





[http://pages.uoregon.edu/edmatters/promos/question-mark.png]




lfortin at uoregon.edu<mailto:lfortin at uoregon.edu>





[http://pages.uoregon.edu/edmatters/big-questions/icon-address-hedco.png]




College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215

subject: b'coe-fac: No UO Summer Commencement Ceremony'
html:
b'
Hello,
The UO will no longer be hosting a summer commencement ceremony (see message below).  Please let me know if you have any questions or if you foresee any problems with this.  I don't think we've had more than a handful of students participate in the summer event, so there shouldn't be a huge impact.  Students do not need any particular number of credits to walk in our spring ceremony or in the UO main spring ceremony, so even if the student is graduating in summer or next fall, they can still walk in June.
Thanks,
Lisa

From: Amy Quiring
Sent: Thursday, March 10, 2016 4:45 PM
To: Amy Quiring
Subject: Graduation Email to Seniors and Summer Commencement Update

Hello everyone,

I wanted to share content that we will be sending out to all seniors tomorrow with general information about degree application deadlines, university commencement ceremony, Grad Fair dates, and events that might interest graduating students.

There is also an announcement that we will not be holding a university commencement ceremony in August this year. Around 130 students have participated in that ceremony in the past 3-4 years, so you may receive questions and concerns about that decision. Please encourage students to contact our office if they would like to speak with someone about that decision. The attendance at this summer ceremony has been steadily declining, and the equity in dollars invested per student between the spring ceremonies and the summer ceremony has been extremely imbalanced. All students graduating in any term are welcome to participate in the spring ceremonies.

Please take a peek at your materials to remove any links or references to summer commencement for this upcoming year.

Let me know if I can help answer any questions. See attached for the email information that will be distributed to all seniors.

Thanks!

[cid:12E5AA4E-DC0B-4C53-BCB6-D30404BE3AC8]

Amy Quiring, Director of Major Student Events
Division of Student Life
University of Oregon
1715 Franklin Blvd.
p: 541-346-4557
e: aquiring at uoregon.edu<mailto:aquiring at uoregon.edu>
w: studentlife.uoregon.edu<http://studentlife.uoregon.edu/>
