subject: b"coe-fac: Minoru Yasui Day - FREE BOOKS in Dean's Office"
html:
b'
Dear College of Education Community,

House Bill 4009 designates March 28 of each year as Minoru Yasui Day in honor of the Oregon hero who fought against the unfair treatment of Japanese Americans during WWII.

Born in Hood River to Japanese immigrant parents in 1916, Yasui graduated from University of Oregon School of Law and was the first Japanese American admitted to the Oregon State Bar.  On Feb. 19, 1942, Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_Order_9066>, which eventually authorized the forced relocation and incarceration of more than 120,000 Japanese Americans just because they looked like the enemy.  Yasui believed Roosevelt's order was unconstitutional.  On March 28 of that year, he deliberately broke the curfew placed on all people of Japanese ancestry under the order and walked at night around Portland, Oregon.  His case was taken to the U.S. Supreme Court.
If you are interested in learning more about this UO Alum, civil rights activist, and recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, there are free copies of the book, Stubborn Twig, available outside the Dean\xe2\x80\x99s Office (130 HEDCO).  Stubborn Twig details the lives of three generations of the Yasui family, including Minoru\xe2\x80\x99s time at the UO, and was written by UO Journalism Professor, Dr. Lauren Kessler.
[https://external-lax3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/safe_image.php?d=AQDKX9xJ7n1tEDIQ&w=470&h=246&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fads%2Fimage%2F%3Fd%3DAQJslmgOuoHnmOocsKiQUar_fI-mPV3gBcoxAXs_U6g1oCk2QMmJUaQAhcO4q2rM4kmVUbXARKod3Uf0N4gQp010NQ6KoWvAEOPCZfcYqHZjhtVdbIOt33svpJnBIOxNqlGk7-wDHCuk-Q6QBWz8i83b&cfs=1&upscale=1&sx=0&sy=41&sw=585&sh=306&ext=png2jpg]

Best,
Krista


_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education
5251 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5251
https://education.uoregon.edu/users/chronister
www.access-dv.org<http://www.access-dv.org/>
(off) 541.346.2415
(fax) 541.346.6778


[cid:image001.gif at 01CE1104.B9070730][cid:D6D06192-19A7-41CE-ABDC-5707DE50B987 at uoregon.edu]

subject: b'coe-fac: Research Grant Competitions Announced; New Topic Areas include Arts, Career Technical Education, and Student Mobility'
html:
b'
Dear colleagues -- The US Department of Education, Institute for Educational Sciences just announced several new research competitions for FY 2017.  We expect to see awards from the National Center for Special Education research later this week.  See details from IES below.

If you would like more information and guidance on submitting a proposal to IES, I will be offering a IES grant writing workshop for COE faculty and grad students on Friday May 20 from 1:00 to 2:30.  We'll provide more details about the May workshop in the next few weeks.

Best,

Lauren Lindstrom
Associate Dean of Research and Faculty Development


[Institute of Education Sciences - Newsflash]

Research Grant Competitions Announced - New Topic Areas include Arts, Career Technical Education, and Student Mobility

The Institute for Education Sciences (IES) is the nation's engine for research that can be used to improve teaching, learning, and student outcomes. One of the major ways that IES fulfills its missions is through grants that can be used to identify and study educational challenges, develop and test innovative solutions, and improve the research field.
Today (March 28, 2016), IES' National Center for Education Research (NCER), released the funding announcements for two of its Fiscal Year (FY) 2017 grants competitions<http://ies.ed.gov/funding/>-Education Research Grants (84.305A) and Statistical and Research Methodology in Education Grants (84.305D). Full information is available on IES Funding Opportunities website<http://ies.ed.gov/funding/> and the Federal Register<https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2016/03/08/2016-05155/applications-for-new-awards-education-research-and-special-education-research-grant-programs#page-12091>. The IES Funding Opportunities website also has information about funding webinars.
The remaining grant competitions, including those from the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER), will be announced later this week.
Education Research Grants
The Education Research Grants focus on outcomes and challenges on a broad range of topics at all levels, including early childhood, elementary, secondary, postsecondary, and adult education. Grants can be funded for up to five years and support many kinds of projects, including exploratory research, development and pilot-testing of new interventions, efficacy and effectiveness studies, and measurement studies. For this year's competition, NCER has added three special topics for which it will accept applications:

  *   Arts in Education: Research investigating the relationship between arts participation and education outcomes or the effects of arts programs on education outcomes;
  *   Career Technical Education (CTE): Research on policies, programs, and practices that are aimed at increasing career readiness in K-12 students. IES is particularly interested in understanding what types of CTE programs work best, for whom, and under what conditions. (Read a blog post on the need for more CTE research<http://ies.ed.gov/blogs/research/post/career-technical-education-is-growing-research-must-follow>); and
  *   Educating Highly Mobile Students: Research to improve the education of students who are highly mobile, including those who are homeless, in foster care, from migrant backgrounds, or are from military families. These students often face many learning challenges and IES is interested in developing a body of evidence on effective policies and practices that support the educational needs of highly mobile students.
As in previous years, IES is accepting applications for research in Cognition and Student Learning; Early Learning Programs and Policies; Education Leadership; Education Technology; Effective Teachers and Effective Teaching; English Learners; Improving Education Systems; Mathematics and Science Education; Postsecondary and Adult Education; Reading and Writing; and Social and Behavioral Context for Academic Learning.
Statistical and Research Methodology in Education
As part of its commitment to improve the quality and quantity of research, IES funds projects that seek to advance education research methods and statistical analyses. The long-term outcome of this research program will be a wide range of methodological and statistical products that will better enable education scientists to conduct rigorous education research.
For the FY 2017, there are two topics in this area: Regular Grants and Early Career Grants for researchers who completed their doctorates on or after April 1, 2012. Grants can be funded for up to three years.
Visit the IES website to view previously funded grants in all competition areas<http://ies.ed.gov/funding/grantsearch/index.asp>.
Important Links:

  *   IES Funding Opportunities Website<http://ies.ed.gov/funding/>
  *   Federal Register Announcement<https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2016/03/08/2016-05155/applications-for-new-awards-education-research-and-special-education-research-grant-programs>


...connecting research, policy and practice

You have received this message because you subscribed to a newsflash service through IES or one of its centers.
Change your options or unsubscribe from this service<http://ies.ed.gov/newsflash/?email=lindstrm%40uoregon%2Eedu>.
By visiting Newsflash<http://ies.ed.gov/newsflash/> you may also sign up to receive information from IES<http://ies.ed.gov/> and its four Centers NCES<http://nces.ed.gov/>, NCER<http://ncer.ed.gov/>, NCEE<http://ncee.ed.gov/>, & NCSER<http://ncser.ed.gov/> to stay abreast of all activities within the Institute of Education Sciences (IES).
To obtain hard copy of many IES products as well as hard copy and electronic versions of hundreds of other U.S. Department of Education products please visit http://www.edpubs.org or call 1-877-433-7827 (877-4-EDPUBS).







Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: Library'
html:
b'
It appears Spring has finally arrived!

As the fiscal year ends - if there are titles you want the library to purchase (textbooks not included),  let me know.

Is your class doing research - do you think they could use some pointers or a refresher, let me know.

Working on an accreditation report, need some library data and information, let me know.

Working on a grant and need some help with your information quest, let me know.

Want to talk about other library or information topics and need an office visit or want to meet for a cup of coffee, let me know.

Cheers,

Katy

subject: b'coe-fac: winter curriculum update'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Well as we begin spring I want to update you on the curriculum efforts that happened this past term.
Course and Program Review for Winter 2016

*         Course Review

*         Program Review
Looking ahead to Spring 2016

*         Important dates and Curriculum Committee Membership

*         COE Curriculum Resources

*         New Programs review for spring

*         Foundations of educational research workgroup

*         Curriculum Policy and Procedures
Course and Program Review for Winter 2016

Course Review. The following eight courses were moved forward in the UO Curriculum process.

*         SPED 633: Transition Planning and Instruction I

*         SPED 634Transition Planning and Instruction II. CPSY 611 Ethics Discussion for Counseling Psychology

*         CDS 201: Communication Disorders in Society and Media was submitted to be considered for multicultural requirement

*         FHS 216 Diversity in Human Services was submitted to be considered for multicultural requirement

*         CPSY 645 Health Psychology title was changed to CPSY 645 Health Promotion and Equity

*         CPSY 633 Epidemiology title was changed and the new prefix for Prevention Science was added PREV 633 Contemporary Issues in Public Health

*         EDST 663 Fronteras Pedagogicas: Education and Immigration title was changed to EDST 633 Education and Immigration

*         SPSY 630 Introduction to Consultation was changed to variable credits
The new Prevention Science prefix was approved by the UO.

Program review. No new programs were reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee in winter term.

Two of the programs reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee in Fall were approved by UO: Quantitative Research Methods Graduate Specialization and Foundations in Special Education Undergraduate Certificate.

One program was sent back for more information (Family and Human Services Minor) and one has yet to be submitted to UG Council (Educational Foundations: Secondary Undergraduate Certificate).



Looking Ahead to Spring 2016
Dates for winter term
April 21st  - new course proposals are due in CourseLeaf (approval by UOCC will not be until Fall)
May 13  -1:00-2:00 in 260 U Information (Q &A) for faculty submitting new courses or programs
May 16 - 10:00-12:00 in 260 U COE Curriculum Committee Meeting - Courses only

You committee representatives are listed below. I strongly recommend that you keep them informed of any course or program modifications or additions.

o   EMPL: Gina Biancarosa, Jo Smith

o   EDST: Lisa Mazzei, Jeanne Hall

o   SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

o   CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The COE Curriculum resources are available at https://coe.uoregon.edu/governance/curriculum-review-policies. Please be sure to use the most current syllabi information when preparing your courses (https://coe.uoregon.edu/governance/course-additions-and-modifications/).

New Programs. A new CDS 4+1 program is in front of the Committee this week. We anticipate one more new program from EMPL focused on leadership at the UG level to be submitted this spring.

Foundations of educational research course workgroup (Robert Horner, Kent McIntosh, Jerry Rosiek, Lisa Mazzei Elizabeth Skowron, Atika Khurana, Michael Bullis, Gina Biancarosa, chair) has identified the content for the course. They are targeting the completion of the syllabi for college approval in the spring or early fall.  This course is the college wide required course for all doctoral students. They are also proposing that is 2017-2018 this course be offered in the fall. A scheduling group will meet this spring to identify a time and any other needed changes to course sequences.

Curriculum policy. The COE Curriculum Committee has been reviewing and making recommendations to the current COE policy and procedures. The plan is to circulate it for faculty comment this spring.

Thanks for all the work of faculty to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions check in with your Program Director, Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative attend the Q & A session(February 26) or if necessary schedule a time to meet with me.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496

text:
b'Faculty,

Well as we begin spring I want to update you on the curriculum efforts that happened this past term.
Course and Program Review for Winter 2016

*         Course Review

*         Program Review
Looking ahead to Spring 2016

*         Important dates and Curriculum Committee Membership

*         COE Curriculum Resources

*         New Programs review for spring

*         Foundations of educational research workgroup

*         Curriculum Policy and Procedures
Course and Program Review for Winter 2016

Course Review. The following eight courses were moved forward in the UO Curriculum process.

*         SPED 633: Transition Planning and Instruction I

*         SPED 634Transition Planning and Instruction II. CPSY 611 Ethics Discussion for Counseling Psychology

*         CDS 201: Communication Disorders in Society and Media was submitted to be considered for multicultural requirement

*         FHS 216 Diversity in Human Services was submitted to be considered for multicultural requirement

*         CPSY 645 Health Psychology title was changed to CPSY 645 Health Promotion and Equity

*         CPSY 633 Epidemiology title was changed and the new prefix for Prevention Science was added PREV 633 Contemporary Issues in Public Health

*         EDST 663 Fronteras Pedagogicas: Education and Immigration title was changed to EDST 633 Education and Immigration

*         SPSY 630 Introduction to Consultation was changed to variable credits
The new Prevention Science prefix was approved by the UO.

Program review. No new programs were reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee in winter term.

Two of the programs reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee in Fall were approved by UO: Quantitative Research Methods Graduate Specialization and Foundations in Special Education Undergraduate Certificate.

subject: b'coe-fac: Implicit Bias Symposium - April 15, 2016 - UO Eugene OR'
html:
b'
Implicit Bias Symposium

April 15, 2016    University of Oregon    Eugene, Oregon

Information and Registration:

https://law.uoregon.edu/explore/out-of-the-shadows

From the University's website:

Join us for an Implicit Bias Symposium called "Out of the Shadows: Implicit Bias, Institutional Responses." We are developing a full-day of interesting debates, trainings, and workshops, such as:

  *   Basic Implicit Bias Training. Professor Erik Girvan will present a basic implicit bias training \xe2\x80\x93 intended to teach the audience about the unconscious responses we all have.
  *   Science of Intervention. Professor Eugene Borgida from the University of Minnesota will co-lead the Advanced Implicit Bias training, and will present the science of intervention. This training will show you what to do once you\xe2\x80\x99ve recognized that you\xe2\x80\x99re having an implicitly biased response.
  *   Advanced Implicit Bias Breakout Session. Professors Girvan and Borgida will challenge attendees with a series of scenarios meant to engage what they have learned about intervention and implicit bias.
  *   Institutional Implicit Bias Workshop. This workshop will bring together members of a variety of institutions so we can work together and create plans to dispel implicit bias in our institutions.
  *   Evening Lecture. Professor Michael Z. Green from Texas A&M will present the evening lecture. Prof. Green\xe2\x80\x99s research focuses on racial bias in workplace disputes \xe2\x80\x93 including labor negotiations and employment discrimination cases. Prof. Green also recently authored a chapter about negotiating while black.
  *   Public Reception. Symposium attendees and members of the community are welcome to join our public reception!



-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20160330/a060053a/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: UO Law Symposium'
html:
b'
Faculty

I want to draw your attention to a symposium being sponsored by the law school - it was also featured in the Around the O last week....See information below

Brigid
From: Katie Steiner <ksteiner at uoregon.edu<mailto:ksteiner at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Tuesday, March 29, 2016 at 12:51 PM
To: Cody Pinkston <cpinksto at uoregon.edu<mailto:cpinksto at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: UO Law Symposium

Mr. Pinkston,

My name is Katie Steiner and I am a third-year law student here at Oregon. I am also the Symposium Editor of the Oregon Law Review (OLR). This year, Oregon Law Review's symposium will be celebrating the career and life of Dave Frohnmayer, former University of Oregon president. Unless the College of Education has already received information about the symposium, I was hoping you could forward information about the symposium to faculty members in the College.

If you are able to email this information out, I've provided an attachment with more information and a small blurb below. If you are unable to send out this information I understand. Thank you for your time.

Best,
Katie Steiner

--

The Oregon Law Review Symposium: Celebrating the Career of David B. Frohnmayer will take place this Friday, April 1 from 9:30 am - 4:45 pm at the Sentinel Hotel in Portland. Please find attached a pdf with more details regarding the event. Here is the link to register: http://www.uoalumni.com/s/1540/uoaa/index.aspx?sid=1540&pgid=5277&gid=3&cid=11126&ecid=11126&post_id=0. If you have problems registering online please contact me directly. My email address is ksteiner at uoregon.edu<mailto:ksteiner at uoregon.edu> and phone number is 480-326-9479.

-
Katie Steiner
Compliance Intern
University of Oregon Athletics
J.D. Candidate, Expected May 2016
University of Oregon School of Law
(480)-326-9479
ksteiner at uoregon.edu<mailto:ksteiner at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Curriculum Committee 2016-2017 - NEED members from\tEDST and EMPL'
html:
b'
Faculty,

There are two positions open on the COE Curriculum Committee starting in 2016-2017: EMPL (Tenure track faculty member) and EDST (Tenure track faculty member).  According to the Internal Governance Policy:

*         Nominated individuals will be placed on a ballot for a college-wide vote and serve for a three-year term.

*         If a department has no self- nominations, a department head may appoint qualified faculty to be listed on the ballot.

Due to the volume of courses an new programs the committee has been meeting 2-3 times per term and then contribute time outside of meetings for review of materials and gathering input from department faculty.

If  you are interested in serving on this committee and from EMPL or EDST please send your nomination to Brigid (brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>) by May 1st.

Thanks
Brigid
brigidf at uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Teaching Development Opportunity - Thursday, April 7 - Creating inclusive and identity safe learning communities'
html:
b'
Dear College of Education Community,



The Teaching Effectiveness Program will sponsor the following event this week.  For accommodations, please contact Lee Rumbarger, Director of TEP.



Best,

Krista





Keeping it Real, Lively and Strong: Engaged Mindfulness Practices for Resilient Learning Communities
with University of San Francisco Professor of Law Rhonda Magee

Thursday, Apr. 7, 3:30-5:00pm
Knight Library Browsing Room
Doors open and refreshments served beginning at 3:00pm


How might we foster classroom-based learning communities with the strength to deal with crises and controversy as they arise? In this lecture and interactive discussion, Professor Magee will explore the imperative of working to create inclusive, identity-safe and resilient learning communities in the 21st century. She'll share some of the research-based contemplative teaching and learning practices that she and others are using to help create resilient spaces for intellectual and inner life development on college campuses.

Rhonda Magee is professor of law at the University of San Francisco. Her scholarly work focuses on race law and policy as well as on humanizing legal education and the practice of law. She is an expert in contemplative and identity-sensitive pedagogy and has served as president of the national board of the Center for Contemplative Mind in Society and co-director of USF's Center for Teaching Excellence.



_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education
5251 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5251
https://education.uoregon.edu/users/chronister
www.access-dv.org<http://www.access-dv.org/>
(off) 541.346.2415
(fax) 541.346.6778

subject: b'coe-fac: NCFDD membership - Are You Ready For A 14-Day Writing\tChallenge?'
html:
b'
COE Faculty,

A reminder of some of the on-line faculty research and other professional development resources available to you \xe2\x80\x93 free - from the NCFDD.

Thank you,
Krista

Click here to view as a web page<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fpage%2Fapril2016newsletter>












[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Logos/ncfdd_header495x95.png]<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2F>


NCFDD April Newsletter
Are You Ready for a 14-Day Writing Challenge?


Dear Krista,

I have to admit I\xe2\x80\x99m feeling particularly energized heading into April!

The reason why is pretty simple. It's because we keep growing at such a fast pace! Since January, we've added seven new Institutional Members and more than 2,700 new faculty, post-docs and graduate students into our community. And of course, as we continue to grow, we keep looking for new ways to support our members and help them grow and become highly productive.

Because we\xe2\x80\x99re focused on productivity heading into the summer, we\xe2\x80\x99ve got some exciting opportunities for you! First and foremost, the registration for our summer bootcamp (the Faculty Success Program<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2F%3FFSProgramDescription>) has officially opened. Last session we filled up before the end of registration, so don\xe2\x80\x99t wait to register (we're already 62% full).

We also have a great line-up of professional development training this month! Professor Mindi Thompson (University of Wisconsin-Madison) will be teaching our core curriculum webinar on Mastering Academic Time Management<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fevents%2FEvent%5FDetails%2Easp%3Fid%3D697242%26legacy%3D1>, and Professors Cynthia Ganote (Saint Mary's College), Floyd Cheung (Smith College), and Tasha Souza (Boise State University) will be offering the last installment of our series on Campus Incivility with a webinar on Micro-Aggressions, Micro-Resistance, and Ally Development in the Academy<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fevents%2FEvent%5FDetails%2Easp%3Fid%3D749467%26legacy%3D1>.


[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email2/groupphoto496x303.jpg]



NCFDD Campus Workshop Facilitator Joy Gaston Gayles at the
Rochester Institute of Technology




Additionally, this month we're introducing you to one of our Certified Workshop Facilitators (Professor Joy Gayles, North Carolina State University) who is available to visit your campus. And our feature article asks one simple question: Are You Ready For a 14-Day Writing Challenge?<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fpage%2FApril16Newsl%23feature> That\xe2\x80\x99s right, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to join our popular two week, pop-up community for developing a daily writing habit. It\xe2\x80\x99s a great way to experiment with best practices in a supportive community (see our feature article below to learn more). I hope this month's resources will help you to amp up your productivity, get focused, and move towards the summer with a focus on your writing!

Warmly,

[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email/karsignature117x45.png]

Kerry Ann Rockquemore, PhD
President and CEO
National Center for Faculty Development & Diversity


________________________________

[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email2/pena125x140.png]


Faculty Success Program Spotlight

Find out how the Faculty Success Program helped Professor Edlyn Vallejo Pe\xc3\xb1a (California Lutheran University) complete four manuscripts in one semester. Click here<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fpage%2FApril16Newsl%23spotlight> to read more.


________________________________

[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email2/ka125x140.png]


Summer Bootcamp Registration is Open!

If you\xe2\x80\x99re interested in learning more about the Faculty Success Program, click here<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fpage%2FApril16Newsl%23fsp> to read more. You can also register for our upcoming 14-Day Writing Challenge and/or our preview webinar entitled 5 Secrets to a Super Productive Summer<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fevents%2FEventDetails%2Easpx%3Fid%3D786874>.


________________________________

[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email2/umdb125x126.jpg]


Institutional Membership

Welcome to our newest Institutional Members, the University of Maryland, Baltimore, University of Kansas, Bowling Green State University, and Virginia Commonwealth University! text:
b"COE Faculty,

A reminder of some of the on-line faculty research and other professional development resources available to you \xe2\x80\x93 free - from the NCFDD.

Thank you,
Krista

Click here to view as a web page<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fpage%2Fapril2016newsletter>












[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Logos/ncfdd_header495x95.png]<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2F>


NCFDD April Newsletter
Are You Ready for a 14-Day Writing Challenge?


Dear Krista,

I have to admit I\xe2\x80\x99m feeling particularly energized heading into April!

The reason why is pretty simple. It's because we keep growing at such a fast pace! Since January, we've added seven new Institutional Members and more than 2,700 new faculty, post-docs and graduate students into our community. And of course, as we continue to grow, we keep looking for new ways to support our members and help them grow and become highly productive.

Because we\xe2\x80\x99re focused on productivity heading into the summer, we\xe2\x80\x99ve got some exciting opportunities for you! First and foremost, the registration for our summer bootcamp (the Faculty Success Program<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2F%3FFSProgramDescription>) has officially opened. Last session we filled up before the end of registration, so don\xe2\x80\x99t wait to register (we're already 62% full).

We also have a great line-up of professional development training this month! Professor Mindi Thompson (University of Wisconsin-Madison) will be teaching our core curriculum webinar on Mastering Academic Time Management<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fevents%2FEvent%5FDetails%2Easp%3Fid%3D697242%26legacy%3D1>, and Professors Cynthia Ganote (Saint Mary's College), Floyd Cheung (Smith College), and Tasha Souza (Boise State University) will be offering the last installment of our series on Campus Incivility with a webinar on Micro-Aggressions, Micro-Resistance, and Ally Development in the Academy<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fevents%2FEvent%5FDetails%2Easp%3Fid%3D749467%26legacy%3D1>.


[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email2/groupphoto496x303.jpg]



NCFDD Campus Workshop Facilitator Joy Gaston Gayles at the
Rochester Institute of Technology




Additionally, this month we're introducing you to one of our Certified Workshop Facilitators (Professor Joy Gayles, North Carolina State University) who is available to visit your campus. And our feature article asks one simple question: Are You Ready For a 14-Day Writing Challenge?<http://www.facultydiversity.org/link.asp?e=kmg@uoregon.edu&job=2365182&ymlink=4836551&finalurl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Efacultydiversity%2Eorg%2Fpage%2FApril16Newsl%23feature> That\xe2\x80\x99s right, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to join our popular two week, pop-up community for developing a daily writing habit. It\xe2\x80\x99s a great way to experiment with best practices in a supportive community (see our feature article below to learn more). I hope this month's resources will help you to amp up your productivity, get focused, and move towards the summer with a focus on your writing!

Warmly,

[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email/karsignature117x45.png]

Kerry Ann Rockquemore, PhD
President and CEO
National Center for Faculty Development & Diversity


________________________________

[https://facultydiversity.site-ym.com/resource/resmgr/Email2/pena125x140.png]

Find out how the Faculty Success Program helped Professor Edlyn Vallejo Pe\xc3\xb1a (California Lutheran University) complete four manuscripts in one semester. subject: b'coe-fac: Collections Reduction Review, 2016-2017'
html:
b'
Dear College of Education community,

Due the lack of increases to cover expected inflationary costs and the UO's current budget-realignment process, the UO Libraries will undergo a process to cut the collections budget.  A memo from Dean Lim describing the circumstances appears below and is attached.

Target cuts and details regarding the process will be coming shortly.  I will be communicating with you regarding the particulars of the collections review as soon as I have more information and will be working closely with the COE Library Committee to involve all of you in the process.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks,

Katy


MEMORANDUM

Date:   April 6, 2016
To:   All UO Colleges, Schools, and Departments
From:  Adriene Lim, Dean of Libraries
Subject:  Collections Reduction Review, 2016-2017

The UO Libraries must prepare for cuts to our collections budget of approximately $565,000 in FY 2016/2017. This figure represents an actual cut of $115,000 in our collections budget due to the UO's current budget-realignment process, and a reduction of $450,000 due to the lack of increases to cover expected inflationary costs.

With this note, we are initiating a collaborative review process with colleagues across the University's colleges, schools, and departments to identify journals, databases, and other resources for cancellation in FY 2016/2017. Subject liaison librarians will work with UO faculty to share details about the collections review, including the timeline for the process, information about the Libraries' commitment to provide interlibrary loan services for cancelled titles, and other methods we will use to minimize the negative impact of the cancellations. More details about the process will be posted on the Libraries' website in the coming days.

The loss of collections funding is challenging, but we must join with our campus colleagues in collective efforts to help the University realign its resources to support new strategic priorities. Thank you in advance for your advice and support as we work through this collections review and cancellation process.

subject: b'coe-fac: Reimagine Education'
html:
b'
Faculty - FYI,

ODE and Chief Education Office are hosting eleven community forums across the state to Reimagine Education in Oregon - to help the State receive community input to develop a framework for a State Plan required by the Every Child Succeeds Act. The Eugene forum is May 10th @ 6 pm at SEHS


http://www.ode.state.or.us/superintendent/priorities/or-education-forum-listing.pdf

Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: Commencement Regalia Rental for Faculty'
html:
b'
Hello,
For those of you who don't own your own regalia, the COE will pay for your rental for our graduation ceremony.  Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. To guarantee exact hood colors please make your order by April 29.  After that time it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.  The cut off for ordering faculty regalia is May 13.

On the order form, choose the Spring ceremony.  As the COE covers the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, choose 'bill department' in the payment area.

Order your regalia here:
https://uoduckstore.com/form/faculty/regalia/  For some unknown reason this link still include 2014 dates.  I have been assured by the Duck Store folks that the information is being collected correctly for 2015.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Services
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: Commencement Regalia Rental for Faculty'
html:
b'
Hello,
For those of you who don't own your own regalia, the COE will pay for your rental for our graduation ceremony.  Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater.  Although the cut off for ordering regalia is May 13, if you want exact hood colors you need to make your order by the end of the day tomorrow, April 29.  After that time it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.

On the order form, choose the Spring ceremony.  As the COE covers the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, choose 'bill department' in the payment area.

Order your regalia here:
https://uoduckstore.com/form/faculty/regalia/  For some unknown reason this link still include 2014 dates.  I have been assured by the Duck Store folks that the information is being collected correctly for 2015.

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.

Thanks,
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: EDUC Instructors needed'
html:
b'
Faculty,

We will need two additional instructors in 2016-2017 for EDUC courses.  I have re-opened up the nomination process until June 1st.  The courses available are:

EDUC

610

"Foundations of Educ'l Research"**

4.00 cr.

1700-2050

t

EDUC

632

Qual Meth II: PostCritical Inquiry

4.00 cr.

1700-2050

w


The syllabi for Qual methods  II is attached.  The foundation course - all 1st year doctoral students should take.  For the past few years students took EDST Philosophy of Research. A cross department committee has worked this year to develop a new syllabi that should be available by end of spring or early fall.

Please use this link to share your information if you are interested in teaching either of this courses in winter of 2017.
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_9YK57o44vHtvunP

Thanks
Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: FACULTY COMMENT- COE Curriculum POLICY'
html:
b'
Faculty,

As I have mentioned in prior curriculum updates, this year the COE Curriculum Committee has been working on a revision to the COE Curriculum Policy.  These efforts were to a) align with current practices (this document is both a policy and procedure document), b) align with any changes in COE policy from CBA, and c)  clarify areas in which members and the Associate Dean received requests for clarification or more information.

I have attached the 2016 COE Curriculum Policy and Procedures.

Please review the policy and share comments through this Qualtrics link. The form is set up so you can insert comments for each section of the document as well as overall.
https://oregon.ca1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_9XiK7wIoAGbyeR7

The comment period closes next Friday June 3rd at 4 pm.
If you have questions feel free to contact myself or your curriculum representatives.

Thanks
Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: Are you attending Commencement?'
html:
b'
Hello,
Our COE Commencement is fast approaching on Monday, June 13th from 3-5 pm in the Matthew Knight Arena.  Below is the list of faculty who have ordered regalia from the Duck Store, so I'm assuming all those below are attending.  I have also added members of the platform party and those who are hooding students.  If you are not on the list and plan on attending, could you please let me know?  I need a rough count so I can make sure there are enough chairs for faculty seating and so I can send you updates on commencement if necessary.  Just reply to this email to let me know.  If everything is fine, no reply is necessary.

Those with a "Yes" in the first column have ordered regalia from the Duck Store.  If that column is blank and you need regalia, please let me know right away as we are past the cut-off date for ordering.  Regalia will be delivered to the HEDCO office the week of June 6 and we'll let you know when it has arrived.  For those who ordered regalia for both commencement and President Schill's investiture, they just want you to keep the same set of regalia to use for both ceremonies.

Let me know if you have any questions.
Thanks,
Lisa



Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

Thanks,
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: VOTE Curriculum Policy'
html:
b'
Please vote by June 20, 2016 on the COE Curriculum Policy https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_0OLSwwl4sw7RxFX

Thanks to those who took time to review the policy and send comments. The committee received several comments that will increase the clarity of the policy. Those have been made and are included as track changes in this copy. The other comments are below.

The Curriculum Committee


Additional comments:

1)      How is the curriculum committee formed etc. The policy refers to the Internal Governance Policy so if changes only need to change one policy.

2)      Difficult to include College wide research courses in programs. No change in this policy from past. Programs can petition for waiver.

3)      Length of time until approval. This policy shortens it from before. The committee will continue to look at this but because of the number of committees and people that need to review these it just takes a long time.

4)      Feedback loop regarding the EDUC course quality, etc. There is nothing in the policy at this time. The Curriculum Committee has this on the agenda for next year - stay tuned.

5)      Requiring a full review when there is substantial change in the content of a  course (e.g., objectives) is overreach...

subject: b'coe-fac: Regalia for Commencement Pick UP'
html:
b'
Hello,
If you ordered regalia through the Duck Store for commencement, it is now available for pick up in HEDCO 130.  If you had regalia ordered for investiture, it is assumed that you kept it and will use it again for commencement.  After commencement is over, you may return the regalia to the Duck Store, or bring it down to HEDCO 130 and we'll take it over for you.

Thanks,
Lisa



Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon

subject: b"coe-fac: Reading Ta-Nehisi Coates' - Between the World and Me"
html:
b'
Dear College Faculty:

Author Ta-Nehisi Coates' award-winning book, Between the World and Me, has been selected as the 2016-17 UO common reading book selection http://commonreading.uoregon.edu/ ; all incoming first-year undergraduate students will read and discuss the book during the 2016-17 academic year.  Also, Coates will visit our campus on February 18, 2017 as the Ruhl Lecturer at the School of Journalism and Communication http://journalism.uoregon.edu/events/ruhl-lecture/.

If you are interested in reading Between the World and Me and joining in a small, casual summer group discussion about the text and its application to our teaching, please contact me by August 1.  I will email all of those who are interested to arrange an early September time to meet and eat.  We have a few free copies of Between the World and Me in the SAS office.

Thank you,
Krista

_________________________________________
Krista M. Chronister, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Counseling Psychology &
Assistant Dean for Equity and Inclusion
College of Education
5251 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-5251
https://education.uoregon.edu/users/chronister
www.access-dv.org<http://www.access-dv.org/>
(off) 541.346.2415
(fax) 541.346.6778


[cid:image001.gif at 01CE1104.B9070730][cid:D6D06192-19A7-41CE-ABDC-5707DE50B987 at uoregon.edu]

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: VOTE Curriculum Policy'
html:
b'
Please vote by June 20, 2016 on the COE Curriculum Policy https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_0OLSwwl4sw7RxFX

Thanks to those who took time to review the policy and send comments. The committee received several comments that will increase the clarity of the policy. Those have been made and are included as track changes in this copy. The other comments are below.

The Curriculum Committee


Additional comments:

1)      How is the curriculum committee formed etc. The policy refers to the Internal Governance Policy so if changes only need to change one policy.

2)      Difficult to include College wide research courses in programs. No change in this policy from past. Programs can petition for waiver.

3)      Length of time until approval. This policy shortens it from before. The committee will continue to look at this but because of the number of committees and people that need to review these it just takes a long time.

4)      Feedback loop regarding the EDUC course quality, etc. There is nothing in the policy at this time. The Curriculum Committee has this on the agenda for next year - stay tuned.

5)      Requiring a full review when there is substantial change in the content of a  course (e.g., objectives) is overreach...

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Message from UO Senate President'
html:
b'

From: deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu [mailto:deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu] On Behalf Of Kathy Warden
Sent: Thursday, June 23, 2016 12:58 PM
To: 'deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu' <deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>
Subject: deans-dirs: Message from UO Senate President

Sent on behalf of Bill Harbaugh.  Please share with your department's personnel.

Dear Senate Constituents:

UO is beginning the search for a new provost, and President Schill has asked the Senate to provide nominations for the search committee. In an effort to ensure wide participation in the composition of the search committee we are sending this message to current and past Senators and all committee members in the Senate database. Please forward it to your constituents and colleagues.

The deadline for responses is 5PM this Friday, June 24.

To make a nomination follow the link below to a Google form. After you submit the form you will be taken to a new form, where you can make additional nominations if you wish, etc. While it's good practice to check with a nominee to make sure they are willing to serve, it is not necessary given the time limit. After we have collected these nominations we will collect input from the elected Senators and then send the complete list of nominees, and the Senate input, to President Schill. (Senators will get an email about this process soon.)

President Schill has said that he will be responsible for choosing the search committee members. While our nominations and input are only advisory, I believe that they will helpful to the President. While tenure track faculty will comprise the majority of the search committee, we encourage nominations for members from all Senate constituencies.

Yours,

Bill Harbaugh, Senate President
Chris Sinclair, Senate Vice President

Nominations form: http://goo.gl/forms/qyMEARfHbvjImRT42
_______________________________________________
Econ_faculty_staff mailing list
Econ_faculty_staff at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:Econ_faculty_staff at lists.uoregon.edu>
https://lists.uoregon.edu/mailman/listinfo/econ_faculty_staff

subject: b'coe-fac: spring curriculum update'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Well as you all begin your summer, I hope you find some time to relax as next year will be another busy one here at COE.


Course and Program Review for Spring 2016

*         Course Review (approved by COE -spring and approved by UOCC and Senate- winter and spring)

*         Program Review

*         Academic Extension (winter and spring)
Looking ahead to Fall 2016

*         CourseLeaf for Programs

*         Course/Program dates for fall term

*         New Programs in Fall

*         Curriculum Committee Membership

*         COE Curriculum Resources

*         Philosophical Foundations of Educational Research Workgroup

*         EDUC Courses

*         Curriculum Policy and Procedures
Course and Program Review for Spring 2016

Course Review. Though seven courses went out for comment to the faculty and COE Curriculum Committee this spring only one proceeded through the Curriculum process: CPSY 420 Positive Psychology. This have moved forward to Dean approval. The other courses reviewed in spring are part of the proposed Leadership minor in EDLD and will be reviewed and voted in fall when the program is reviewed.

The PREV (prevention Science) prefix was approved and the open ended numbers (e.g., reading, research) were approved by the UOCC and the Senate. Also the following courses were approved by the UOCC and the Senate in winter and spring:
EDLD 623 Cultural Adaptation of Evidence-Based Practices
EDLD 624 Leading for Equity CPSY 645 Health Psychology title change to Health Promotion and Equity
EDLD 661 Item Response Theory I
EDLD 662 Item Response Theory II
EDST 422/522 Technology Education (add prerequisite; Effective spring 2016)
FHS 216 Diversity in Human Services approved as multicultural requirement Category B
FHS 321 Instructional Methods in Early Childhood II (Effective winter 2016)
HS 322 Instructional Methods in Early Childhood III (Effective Spring 2016)
PREV 633 Contemporary Issues in Public Health (Effective Fall 2017)
PREV 631 Introduction to Prevention Science (change from CPSY)
PREV 632 Risk and Resilience in Adolescents (change from CPSY)
PREV 634 Implementation Science (change from CPSY)
CPSY 633 Epidemiology (deactivated)
CPSY 217 Foundations of Student Health and Well-Being
CFT 412/512 Healthy Relationships
CFT 621 Professional and Ethical Issues title change to Ethics Discussion
CFT 629 Intimate Partner Couples title change to CFT 629 Intimate Partner Therapy
SPED 633 Transition Panning and Instruction I
SPED 634 Transition Panning and Instruction II
CDS 201 Communication Disorders in Society approved as multicultural requirement Category B
CDS 462/562 Acquired Disorders of Communication (effective spring 2016)
CDS 458 Audiological Assessment title change to CDS 458 Audiology Disorders and Treatment
CDS 655 Stuttering (credit change)
SPSY 630 Introduction to Consultation ( changed to variable credit)

Program review. One new program was reviewed by the COE Curriculum Committee in spring term and approved by the Graduate School and the Senate: Communication Disorders and Sciences 4+1 program.

The faculty from two of the programs reviewed earlier in the year by the COE Curriculum Committee plan to send their plans forward to the UG council in 2016-2017: Family and Human Services Minor and Educational Foundations: Secondary Undergraduate Certificate.

Academic Extension
The course approved through Academic Extension during winter and spring are listed below.  They are all under the workshop course number 608.

Department Course Title
EDST            Lane County Economy & Employment: An Intro for Educators
EDST            Foundations of Math
EMPL           Promoting Equitable School Practices I
EMPL           Skillful Leader 3: High Expectations Teaching
EMPL           Skillful Leader 4: Analyzing Teaching for Student Results
EMPL           Promoting Equitable School Practices II
EMPL           Carrying It Forward-Equity Leadership Seminar
SPED            Real Solutions in classroom management
SPED            Direct Instruction (San Antonio)
SPED            Direct Instruction (Eugene)
SPED            Explicit Instruction Academy Train Trainers (Portland - 2 sessions)

Looking Ahead to Fall 2016
CourseLeaf for Programs
This year we used CourseLeaf as the course management system. Next year a new CourseLeaf program for management of  programs will be used. As we decided with the system for courses we will comment and vote using the Qualtrics system though all documentation will be in CourseLeaf. I have seen the prototype and it operates similar to the course management system. I will work this summer to get a tip sheet together as we did for course system and host a training at beginning of the fall term.

Course/Program dates for Fall term: I am in the process of setting these with the COE Curriculum Committee once we have the UOCC dates  - probably due end of October

New programs in Fall: Early Fall watch for the new minor in Leadership from EMPL. Remember all new programs must have the synopsis approved by the Department Head Council before going forward with a full proposal. See flow chart at back of the new Curriculum Policy.

The COE Curriculum Committee representatives are listed below. I strongly recommend that you keep them informed of any course or program modifications or additions. Welcome to Keith Zvoch and Audrey Lucero.

o   EMPL: Keith Zvoch, Jo Smith

o   EDST: Audrey Lucero, Jeanne Hall

o   SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

o   CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The COE Curriculum resources are available at the Governance page (see bottom of the COE website) https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/display/governance/Curriculum+Review+Policies. I will be updating and rearranging based on feedback I have received already this year.

Please be sure to use the most current syllabi information when preparing your courses. I have not received any updates from UO so waiting to update until mid-July. Will post and send email when it is completed.

Philosophical Foundations of Educational Research Course Workgroup (Robert Horner, Kent McIntosh, Jerry Rosiek, Lisa Mazzei Elizabeth Skowron, Atika Khurana, Michael Bullis, Gina Biancarosa, chair) has identified the content for the course. They will begin the COE/UO approval process in the fall.  This course is the college wide required course for all doctoral students.

EDUC Courses: The course schedule and instructors will be available on the Curriculum Resources webpage. I am in the process of building a 3 year timetable.  All current syllabi are available in PubDocs/EDUC syllabi. We will update this by the end of each term.

It was discussed at the department head meeting and decided that EDUC Philosophical Foundations of Educational Research will not be offered in 2016-2017. This is still a required course for incoming PhD students so programs should plan on new students taking this required course in 2017-2018. It will be offered each Fall (not winter) and this resulted in changes to the terms the Qual classes are offered. New times are below.

 2017-2018
Fall 2017: EDUC 616 Phil Found 1200-150 W/F
Winter 2018: EDUC 630 Qual I 1700-2050  W
Spring 2018: EDUC 632 Qual II 1700-2050  W

2018-2019
Fall 2018: EDUC 616 Phil Found 1200-150 W/F
               EDUC 634 Qual III 1700-2050 W
Winter 2019: EDUC 630 Qual I 1700-2050  W
EDUC 636 Qual METH: New Materialism
Spring 2019: EDUC 632 Qual II 1700-2050  W
               (Qual V EDST course)

Curriculum Policy. The COE Curriculum Committee has revised the current COE policy and procedures. The policy has been circulated and approved by the faculty June 21, 2016. I anticipate there will be some adjustments over the next year as the UO updates policies such as online courses and programs.

Thanks for all the work of faculty to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions check in with your Program Director, Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative or myself.

Enjoy your summer.
Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>


-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20160624/4a803ea9/attachment-0001.html>
'

I anticipate there will be some adjustments over the next year as the UO updates policies such as online courses and programs.

Thanks for all the work of faculty to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions check in with your Program Director, Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative or myself.

Enjoy your summer.
Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215

subject: b'coe-fac: UPCOMING WORKSHOP: IRB Submission and Protocol Development (8/2) - REVISED'
html:
b'
My apologies - the first email did not include the full message.  Have a great weekend!


Hello COE Faculty,

Please see the email below from Research Compliance Services about a workshop August 2nd on the IRB application process and protocol development. This could be a useful workshop for faculty, researchers, or graduate students who are planning research activities and are newer to the process. Please also share this announcement as relevant with your students. Registration is required (link below).

Thanks,
Leslie

***********
Leslie Leve, PhD
Professor and Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education, University of Oregon
Associate Director, Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon

Phone: 541-346-9601
Web: https://education.uoregon.edu/users/leslie-leve

[Macintosh HD:Users:tjordan:Documents:current-jobs:__UO branding main:__UO Brand Elements Jun15:UO Business Papers:Electronic letterhead:UO Secondary Sig LH:UO Digital LH - COE:COE-3435-CGY11-4C.png]





Dear UO Research Community,

Do you or your students plan to conduct research with human subjects this summer or fall?  Have questions about submitting an application to the UO IRB (Institutional Review Board) or how to develop a protocol?

Research Compliance Services (RCS) is offering a workshop on the IRB application process and protocol development Tuesday, August 2, from 1-2pm, on the 5th Floor of Peace Health North (677 East 12th Avenue, Suite 500).  A map and directions can be found here: http://rcs.uoregon.edu/content/contact-us.

The session will include a brief overview of the IRB application process and how to develop a complete protocol for IRB review.  The workshop will touch on key components of the subject recruitment and consent process/materials; issues related to subject privacy, data confidentiality and security; and how to respond to IRB revision requests.

Ample time will be set aside for researchers to ask questions about the IRB application process in general, as well as questions about their specific research projects and protocol development.

Researchers at any stage of a research project involving human subjects are encouraged to attend. Bring your laptops and IRB materials; hands on assistance will be provided!

Contact Caitlin Alcorn (541-346-1964 or calcorn at uoregon.edu<mailto:calcorn at uoregon.edu>) or Carolyn Craig (541-346-1845 or craig3 at uoregon.edu<mailto:craig3 at uoregon.edu>) with questions.

Please register for this workshop here: http://orsa.uoregon.edu/pcf/training/ (or RSVP to researchcompliance at uoregon.edu<mailto:researchcompliance at uoregon.edu>).

Share this message with anyone you think might be interested in this session.

We look forward to seeing you on August 2 at 1 pm!
Caitlin and Carolyn
Senior Research Compliance Administrators
Research Compliance Services | University of Oregon
P: 541-346-1964 | Email: calcorn at uoregon.edu<mailto:calcorn at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Opportunity to share your knowledge and expertise'
html:
b'
Faculty,
We have a chance to get perspective undergraduate students excited about all the great work being done in the COE and all they can learn if they chose the UO! Please review and let us know if you are willing to help.
Duck Preview is major recruiting activity here at UO and one of the events is 20-minute Catalytic Learning Sessions (see below).  If you scan the list below you will see last year Leslie Leve did a session on Prevention Science in Action and Atika Khurana on Understanding and Preventing Adolescent Risk Behaviors.
These sessions will be in the afternoon of October 4 & 21 and November 4 & 19 and are looking for  a commitment of 1 hour. They are hoping that interested faculty can commit to at least 2 of the 4 dates.
We would like to have a strong COE representation at these sessions because it can help attract high caliber students to our COE undergraduate majors. Please look at your calendar and let Brigid (brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>) know if you are available. She will share your names and they will then contact you directly to answer questions and obtain information your availability.
Thanks and we hope you can represent the COE at Duck Preview Days!
Leslie Leve and Brigid Flannery
Subject: FW: Catalytic Learning Sessions - Duck Preview

Duck Preview, the University of Oregon's fall open house events for prospective students, will take place on October 4 & 21 and November 4 & 19. I'm writing on behalf of my assistant director in charge of visit programs, Allyson Tr\xc3\xb3chez.

We are looking for faculty from all schools and colleges to provide dynamic and engaging, lecture-style presentations to our prospective students and their families. The goals of these lectures, or Catalytic Learning sessions (as we like to call them), are:
1.     Showcase research top faculty are conducting at the UO in various fields of study and how it benefits undergraduate students;
2.     Demonstrate an engaging lecture and get students excited about studying at the UO;
3.     Most importantly, share how students can gain transferrable skills with nearly any degree.

We had a tremendous response from visitors about last year's selection of Catalytic Learning Sessions, which were:


\xc2\xb7         Japanese Literature and Film, Alisa Freedman, East Asian Languages

\xc2\xb7         Understanding and Preventing Adolescent Risk Behaviors, Atika Khurana, Family and Human Services

\xc2\xb7         What is Comics Studies?, Ben Saunders, English/Comic Studies

\xc2\xb7         Creativity and the Performing Arts: How to Save the World while Losing All Respect for Yourself, Brian McWhorter, Music

\xc2\xb7         What can a liberal arts education do for you?, Chris Chavez, Journalism and Communication

\xc2\xb7         Dance Dance Revolution: Bloodsport, Politics, and American Sports Poetry, Corbett Upton, English

\xc2\xb7         Legal Studies, David J Koller, Law

\xc2\xb7         Environmental Impacts of Everyday Objects, David Tyler, Chemistry

\xc2\xb7         The Grimms' Fairy Tales: Portals between Fantasy and Reality,Dorothee Ostmeier, German and Scandinavian Studies

\xc2\xb7         Psychology of Group Dynamics, Holly Arrow, Psychology

\xc2\xb7         Engaging the First-Year Experience with Art and Science, Julie Voelker-Morris, Arts and Administration

\xc2\xb7         Free Speech in America in the 21st Century: A UO Professor's Unending Real-Life Passion, Kyu Ho Youm, Journalism and Communication

\xc2\xb7         Affinity and Inspiration: Why I Teach Literature, Leah Middlebrook, Comparative Literature

\xc2\xb7         From War Games to Warfare: An anthropological exploration, Marcela Mendoza, Education

\xc2\xb7         Harlem Hellfighters: World War One and African American Literature, Mark Whalan, English

\xc2\xb7         German Language and Culture, Matthias Vogel, German and Scandinavian Studies

\xc2\xb7         Breaking Language Barriers: How we learn language throughout life, Melissa Baese-Berk, Linguistics

\xc2\xb7         Are economists right about ANYTHING?, Mike Urbancic, Economics

\xc2\xb7         A Forward Look for Astronomy at the UO, Scott Fisher, Physics

\xc2\xb7         Social Identity: Predicting Consumer and Audience Attitudes In The 21st Century, Troy Elias, Journalism and Communication

\xc2\xb7         Prevention Science in Action, Leslie Leve, Prevention Science

Here is a little more information about Duck Preview:

Duck Preview aims help prospective high school seniors and transfer students, and their families, get to know the university. For a vast majority of prospective students, college selection is predicated on one very important question: does the institution offer the academic programs I am interested in? Our aim for Duck Preview is to give them the opportunity to answer that question, and discover how the university's liberal arts education will benefit them for years to come. On average, 20% of the prospective students who attend Duck Preview will apply the week following Duck Preview and ultimately half of the prospective students who attend Duck Preview will apply for freshman admission.
  If you have questions regarding any of the information here, please contact Allyson by telephone at 6-1248 or via email at trochez at uoregon.edu<mailto:trochez at uoregon.edu>.

Cora Bennett
Director, Student Orientation Programs
Address :: Ford Alumni Center, Suite 119 | 1720 E. 13th Avenue | Eugene, OR 97403
ph ::  541-346-1142 | e :: corab at uoregon.edu<mailto:corab at uoregon.edu>
w :: http://orientation.uoregon.edu<http://orientation.uoregon.edu/> and http://visit.uoregon.edu

subject: b'coe-fac: Jerry Patterson'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Dr. Leslie Leve


Dear COE faculty,

It is with great sadness that I share the news that Gerald Patterson (Jerry) passed away peacefully this morning. He celebrated his 90th birthday surrounded by family, friends, and colleagues a few weeks ago.

As many of you know, Jerry was an icon in the area of behavior science, observational research, parent training, and clinical research. He started his career as a faculty member in the Department of Psychology at UO, before moving to Oregon Research Institute in the 1960's, and then founding the Oregon Social Learning Center in 1976.

His meticulous efforts to understand the nature of aggression and the role of parents, peers, partners, schools, and siblings in the maintenance and escalation of youth aggression and related behavioral and school problems has had a profound impact on the field, including clinical research in the COE. He was an ardent believer in the value of using data to guide clinical practice.

Jerry's quest to understand the nature of human aggression was a life-long endeavor. In addition to the scholarly articles and books that he is famous for in academic circles, he also published poetry on the topic of aggression, and he was working on the application of his coercion model to the societal problem of war. Rumor has it that he was watching videotapes of parent-toddler interactions to further refine his coercion theory as recently as a week or two ago. Incredible!

The tremendous impact he had on theory, clinical research, and study design will leave a lasting footprint on our discipline that will endure well beyond his time here. He will be deeply missed.  Information concerning the family wishes and possible service arrangements will be shared as they become available.







-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20160822/e09e5528/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Honoring Jerry Patterson'
html:
b'
Dear COE Faculty,

Please see the message below from the Oregon Social Learning Center and ISII regarding a celebration of life for Jerry Patterson.





There will be a celebration of life for Jerry Patterson from noon to 4 pm on Sunday, August 28, 2016, at the Veterans Memorial Building, 1626 Willamette Street, Eugene, OR 97401; 541.338.4074. This event will be open to the public.



In lieu of flowers, the Patterson-Forgatch family invite you to celebrate Jerry's love of nature by planting a tree for future generations to enjoy. To plant a tree as a living tribute in memory of Jerry, please visit www.alivingtribute.org<http://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.alivingtribute.org%2F&h=TAQEUTmGUAQEPwTz050hsZsDXtdgA-t9yzRlI5Ez9k9hWeQ&enc=AZNNdSkHZO2fQm_9IyaLeXAb9a6KVF7rAfrU72hU4OSH7PIQuON0RHYsz5C1_GqIQ7TUbalYWKs1uOjhWeLULNtGKI8WHP0TpryxKYIG0mTE8s4VQ5sP78K8GlmSM4u054GwR2MUDNgshWAEC6DoznSA2pT8nsdz3YTu7XbBF6gxgX6wXIL8Dj8CvjeCRFRVOGOu2jK0Hkg650DKqA_oewnG&s=1> where you can purchase a single tree or a grove. During the checkout process you will be given the option to choose a preferred park or forest location for your tree. If you don't choose a preferred park, your tree will be planted in Oregon. Each tree planting includes a commemorative card which you can personalize with a message. You will also need to provide a mailing address for the card. Please use ISII's business address at: 10 Shelton-McMurphey Blvd, Eugene, OR 97401 c/o Kelly Bryson for your card. Thank you!

b"Dear COE Faculty,

Please see the message below from the Oregon Social Learning Center and ISII regarding a celebration of life for Jerry Patterson.





There will be a celebration of life for Jerry Patterson from noon to 4 pm on Sunday, August 28, 2016, at the Veterans Memorial Building, 1626 Willamette Street, Eugene, OR 97401; 541.338.4074. This event will be open to the public.



In lieu of flowers, the Patterson-Forgatch family invite you to celebrate Jerry's love of nature by planting a tree for future generations to enjoy. To plant a tree as a living tribute in memory of Jerry, please visit www.alivingtribute.org<http://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.alivingtribute.org%2F&h=TAQEUTmGUAQEPwTz050hsZsDXtdgA-t9yzRlI5Ez9k9hWeQ&enc=AZNNdSkHZO2fQm_9IyaLeXAb9a6KVF7rAfrU72hU4OSH7PIQuON0RHYsz5C1_GqIQ7TUbalYWKs1uOjhWeLULNtGKI8WHP0TpryxKYIG0mTE8s4VQ5sP78K8GlmSM4u054GwR2MUDNgshWAEC6DoznSA2pT8nsdz3YTu7XbBF6gxgX6wXIL8Dj8CvjeCRFRVOGOu2jK0Hkg650DKqA_oewnG&s=1> where you can purchase a single tree or a grove. During the checkout process you will be given the option to choose a preferred park or forest location for your tree. If you don't choose a preferred park, your tree will be planted in Oregon. Each tree planting includes a commemorative card which you can personalize with a message. You will also need to provide a mailing address for the card. Please use ISII's business address at: 10 Shelton-McMurphey Blvd, Eugene, OR 97401 c/o Kelly Bryson for your card. Thank you!

subject: b'coe-fac: Convocation on September 25th'
html:
b'
Hello,
All faculty are invited to Convocation on Sunday, September 25, 2016 at 3:30 pm at the Matthew Knight Arena.  Convocation calls together the whole campus community to celebrate the engaging, innovative, and intellectually curious environment in which our students, faculty, and staff thrive. It is one of the UO's proudest traditions and the culminating event of Week of Welcome. We hope you will join us in this campus-wide celebration of academic excellence!

New tenure-track faculty will be introduced at Convocation and are invited to join the UO's leadership and current faculty for a welcome reception prior to the ceremony. Please RSVP by September 15 by emailing Cora Bennett at corab at uoregon.edu<mailto:corab at uoregon.edu>.

During new faculty orientation (this is the UO orientation held on Sep. 21), we will have a photographer take portraits of those planning to attend Convocation. If you do not already have your own regalia, please order yours from the UO Duck Store<http://www.uoduckstore.com/regalia-rental-form>.  The UO will be covering the cost of any regalia rented.

All faculty and staff are encouraged to participate in the processional at Convocation. Any member of the UO community who has a bachelor's degree or higher is invited to wear academic regalia for this event. You may place your order<http://uoduckstore.com/facultyinfo/regalia/renting-regalia/> directly with the UO Duck Store.  Again, the UO will cover regalia costs.

Let me know if I can answer any questions for you.
Lisa


Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: Fwd: Faculty-Led Study Abroad Program Development Grant'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Well we are off to a new year. Ever thought about taking some students to study abroad. GEO is offering modest grants to support international travel for the purpose of developing new,faculty led study-abroad programs.

I encourage you to think about applying for one of these grants to provide COE  students an opportunity to study abroad during 2017. Applications are due Nov 1st.

Please be sure to talk to and get approval from your department head and program director.

Brigid


Sent from my iPhone

Begin forwarded message:

From: "GEO (Global Education Oregon)" <geoinfo at uoregon.edu<mailto:geoinfo at uoregon.edu>>
Date: September 8, 2016 at 12:33:41 PM PDT
To: Brigid Flannery <brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: Faculty-Led Study Abroad Program Development Grant

        [https://s3.amazonaws.com/agilecrm/panel/uploaded-logo/1470255710229?id=tinymce_image_upload] <https://globaleducation.agilecrm.com/click?u=http%3A%2F%2Fgeo.uoregon.edu%2F&c=5725447602044928&s=5395364643340288>



Faculty-Led Study Abroad Program Development Grant

Grant Applications Deadline: November 1, 2016

Grant Description. GEO (Global Education Oregon)<https://globaleducation.agilecrm.com/click?u=http%3A%2F%2Fgeo.uoregon.edu%2F&c=5725447602044928&s=5395364643340288> will award modest grants to support international travel for the purpose of developing new, faculty-led study abroad programs. Grants can help fund a visit to a single site or to multiple sites within one country or world region. Proposed activities may occur during the 2017 calendar year.

Grant amounts. Grant amounts will range up to $3,000 per award. Grant applicants are expected to submit a trip itinerary and budget, as described below.

Eligibility. UO Tenure line faculty and career NTTF are eligible to apply.

Faculty from GEO\xe2\x80\x99s institutional partners are also eligible and encouraged to apply. Submissions from partner campuses will only be considered for the following GEO center locations: Rosario, Argentina; Angers, France; Accra, Ghana; Athens, Greece; Siena, Italy; Quer\xc3\xa9taro, Mexico; Fes, Morocco; Oviedo, Spain; Segovia, Spain; London, UK. To be eligible, the partner faculty\xe2\x80\x99s home campus must sponsor the proposed GEO program site as an approved study abroad program.

Prospective applicants with specific questions about eligibility should contact Michael Price, GEO Program Coordinator, at michaelp at uoregon.edu<mailto:michaelp at uoregon.edu>.

Qualifying expenses. Qualifying expenses include: round-trip travel costs (airfare and ground transportation); appropriate per diem up to but not exceeding published rates (see http://ba.uoregon.edu/staff/travel-reimbursement<https://globaleducation.agilecrm.com/click?u=http%3A%2F%2Fba.uoregon.edu%2Fstaff%2Ftravel-reimbursement&c=5725447602044928&s=5395364643340288>); on-the-ground costs related directly to programmatic research (e.g., admissions to cultural or historic sites under review for the program proposal); and reasonable travel costs within the region and related to possible program activities.

Priorities. There are several priorities for funding to be dispersed through this grant program, as described below. These priorities are given in no particular order; and, applicants who are otherwise eligible, but whose proposals do not comply with any of these priorities, may still apply.


  *   Applicants intending to work with GEO sites abroad.
  *   Applications that document matching funds from the applicant\xe2\x80\x99s home department, personal research fund, or other source. Matching funds from the home department and/or college or school are particularly sought as a demonstration of departmental/college or school support for the development of the program to be proposed.
  *   Applications leading to proposals that will significantly increase the accessibility of studying abroad for students, with particular emphasis on students of limited economic means (i.e., lower-cost programs) and students in underrepresented populations (e.g., students of color, students with disabilities, students in STEM majors).

Application instructions: There is no application form for this grant program. Instead, applicants must submit the items listed below by Tuesday, November 1, 2016. Submissions will be accepted by email only. Please send them, with all attachments included in one single email with the subject line \xe2\x80\x9cFACULTY-LED DEVELOPMENT GRANT APPLICATION,\xe2\x80\x9d to the attention of Michael Price (michaelp at uoregon.edu<mailto:michaelp at uoregon.edu>). The items to submit include:


  *   Grant application letter. The grant application letter should describe your background and qualifications, and the program you intend to propose.
     *   Please identify yourself and your academic unit or department. Describe your employment history at your university or college (e.g., assistant professor, 2007 to present). Describe your academic background and areas of specialization. Please also describe your qualifications to serve as faculty-led program leader.
     *   Please briefly describe the program you intend to propose. General information is useful here: term and approximate dates of proposed program; topic/theme; total credits; course goals; target student population and recruitment potential; etc.
     *   Please specify the amount of funding requested and identify all matching funds and the amounts that will be matched. Where appropriate, please include a letter of support from a Dean, department head, or other official.
  *   Statement of support for the proposed activity from relevant department head or program director.
  *   Proposed itinerary. Please describe the tentative itinerary of the proposed travel. We understand that you may not have made definitive travel arrangements, but please describe what you intend to do. A brief summary of your intended activities will suffice.
  *   Budget. Please include a brief budget for the proposed travel. The only expenses that you need to document are those listed under \xe2\x80\x9cQualifying expenses\xe2\x80\x9d above. Please exclude costs for other travel objectives that may be pursued during the same trip (e.g., academic research, attending a conference, personal travel, etc.), including the proportionate amount of round-trip travel costs (pro-rated by days spent on each activity) related to those objectives. Please itemize your budget, using the cost categories given above, and provide a projected total. At the bottom of the budget, please identify your proposed sources of funding, including the amount requested under this grant program, other amounts requested or secured, and any other sources.

Grant decisions and procedures. A GEO committee will make award decisions. We expect that final decisions on funding will be made by January 16, 2017. Faculty will be responsible for making their own travel arrangements, documenting expenses, and submitting receipts. Grantees are expected to submit either a completed proposal for a new Faculty-Led Program or a brief, narrative report on the outcome of the proposed travel within two months of return from the trip.
