subject: b'coe-fac: Help us welcome new women faculty to campus!'
text:
b'


View this email in your browser<http://us14.campaign-archive2.com/?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=05f9768439&e=90b13b1de4>






[https://gallery.mailchimp.com/0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62/images/0499c853-658b-4b82-982c-2d31ef3b73e0.jpg]<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=b7ac249ccb&e=90b13b1de4>






While this event is titled as a reception for new women faculty, CSWS welcomes everyone whose scholarship deconstructs and reconstructs approaches to gender, and we invite like-minded souls to join us at our reception.




[https://gallery.mailchimp.com/0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62/images/004563ce-6512-4661-92de-3843baf2e893.gif]<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=1a286efa5f&e=90b13b1de4>

The Center for the Study of Women in Society
and the Office of the Provost and Academic Affairs
invite you to a reception to welcome new women faculty to campus.
New and current women faculty at the University of Oregon are invited to attend this event, which will be an opportunity for participants to learn about one another\xe2\x80\x99s research and work, and to inspire
collaboration, community, and support across campus.
Please join us in welcoming new women faculty members to our community.
Light refreshments will be served.

Welcome Reception for New Women Faculty<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=75beb36e82&e=90b13b1de4>
Tuesday, October 4, 2016
4:00 \xe2\x80\x93 5:30 p.m.
Gerlinger Alumni Lounge
Gerlinger Hall
1468 University Street
Eugene, Oregon

RSVP to Angie Hopkins at ahop218 at uoregon.edu<mailto:ahop218 at uoregon.edu> or 541.346.5015
no later than September 28, 2016



RSVP Online<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=46197c719a&e=90b13b1de4>






Questions? Contact CSWS Director Michelle McKinley at michelle at uoregon.edu<mailto:michelle at uoregon.edu> / 541.346.5524 or CSWS Operations Manager Dena Zald\xc3\xbaa at dzaldua at uoregon.edu<mailto:dzaldua at uoregon.edu> / 541.346.2262.

For more than 40 years, the Center for the Study of Women in Society has funded feminist scholarship at the University of Oregon. Our mission is simple: we create, fund, and share research on the complexity of women\xe2\x80\x99s lives and the intersecting nature of gender identities and inequalities.
csws.uoregon.edu<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=a8609bf2be&e=90b13b1de4>

The Office of the Provost and Academic Affairs upholds, provides leadership on, and carries out the academic mission of the University.
academicaffairs.uoregon.edu<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=be3d3baac2&e=90b13b1de4>









[https://cdn-images.mailchimp.com/icons/social-block-v2/color-twitter-48.png]<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage1.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=2d63b2f269&e=90b13b1de4>




[https://cdn-images.mailchimp.com/icons/social-block-v2/color-facebook-48.png]<http://uoregon.us14.list-manage.com/track/click?u=0997b296260d28ab8b84c0b62&id=9831cdc0a7&e=90b13b1de4>

Copyright \xc2\xa9 2016 Center for the Study of Women in Society, All rights reserved.
You are receiving this email because you are the head of or budget manager for a UO department.

Our mailing address is:
Center for the Study of Women in Society
1201 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1201

subject: b'coe-fac: Welcome back - Curriculum Update'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Hope 2016 is off to a good start for you. This email will update you to the curriculum happenings during the Fall term and expectations for Winter.

Course and Program Review for Fall 2016

*         Important dates and Curriculum Committee Membership

*         COE Curriculum Resources

*         Program Review

*         Course Review
Important Dates and COE Curriculum Committee
Your committee representatives are listed below. I strongly recommend that you keep them informed of any course or program modifications or additions.

*         EMPL: Keith Zvoch, Jo Smith

*         EDST: Audrey Lucero, Jeanne Hall

*         SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

*         CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The COE Curriculum Resources are available on the COE Governance page: https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/display/governance/COE+Governance+and+Policies

On this site you will find such things as:

*         Current syllabi information

*         Approved COE Curriculum policy

*         EDUC courses

*         Calendars of COE program and course process
There are a number of forms and policies that people often look for but have difficulty finding. I have temporarily made a section on the Governance page titles "Forms and Policies" that has some of these. If there are others we should add let Mercedes know (mercedr at uoregon.edu<mailto:mercedr at uoregon.edu>) and we will try and locate and link it.

Course and Program Review for Fall 2016

Course Review. The UO is still using CourseLeaf. All courses can be reviewed throughout the year through CourseLeaf Management System (https://nextcatalog.uoregon.edu/courseadmin/).

Six courses associated with the Lead minor were reviewed for comment and will come for vote along with the program later in Fall term. Revised courses from EMPL DEd will be reviewed and voted on this fall as well.

The due date for course submissions for review this Fall are October 21.  I do expect to see the Foundations of Educational Research course for review this Fall. You can check out any of the dates on the calendar in the Curriculum Resources website mentioned above.

Due to the visibility of comments and voting we will continue to use a Qualtrics system for voting.

Program Review. Three programs will be reviewed this fall. Three are Expedited: Prevention Science MS and PhD Programs (change in number of credits for the program) and EMPL DEd Program (request to offer the program outside of Oregon); CPSY PhD program (change in number of credits for the program). These will be shared during the comment period, but because these are Expedited Programs, they will only be voted on by the COE Curriculum Committee.

The DEd Program also has a series of courses that will need to be voted on. These are revisions of the courses in their current DEd program, and thus will be the courses for the expanded program. As you are aware, when a program moves to the council, they request that any experimental courses (e.g. 410, 510, 610) go through the process of course approval.

One program, EMPL minor, will come through as a Full Review. First, you will see it and be allowed to comment. Then after a review by the COE Curriculum Committee, it will come for a COE faculty vote and the six affiliated courses (commented on last spring) will be voted on as well.

There is work underway on a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) Program. This will be a certificate program and it is anticipated it will be submitted during the winter timeline.

Notification about commenting and voting on curriculum will occur through email as the CourseLeaf Management System for Programs is not ready to be released. Again, remember that you share comments with a Committee Member from your department but you vote through a Qualtrics survey that will be sent via email.

Teacher Engagement Program (Aka Teacher Effectiveness Program)
The TEP program has redesigned their website and added many resources so I recommend you take a look. http://tep.uoregon.edu/

Common Read
UO's Common Read this year is Ta-Nehisi Coates - Between the World and Me.  There is a website with reading resources, campus resources and teaching resources. http://commonreading.uoregon.edu/current-book-btwam/

Thanks for all the work by faculty and staff to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions, check in with your Program Director, Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative or schedule a time to meet with me if necessary.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>

text:
b'Faculty,

Hope 2016 is off to a good start for you. This email will update you to the curriculum happenings during the Fall term and expectations for Winter.

Course and Program Review for Fall 2016

*         Important dates and Curriculum Committee Membership

*         COE Curriculum Resources

*         Program Review

*         Course Review
Important Dates and COE Curriculum Committee
Your committee representatives are listed below. I strongly recommend that you keep them informed of any course or program modifications or additions.

*         EMPL: Keith Zvoch, Jo Smith

*         EDST: Audrey Lucero, Jeanne Hall

*         SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

*         CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The COE Curriculum Resources are available on the COE Governance page: https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/display/governance/COE+Governance+and+Policies

On this site you will find such things as:

*         Current syllabi information

*         Approved COE Curriculum policy

*         EDUC courses

*         Calendars of COE program and course process
There are a number of forms and policies that people often look for but have difficulty finding. I have temporarily made a section on the Governance page titles "Forms and Policies" that has some of these. If there are others we should add let Mercedes know (mercedr at uoregon.edu<mailto:mercedr at uoregon.edu>) and we will try and locate and link it.

Course and Program Review for Fall 2016

Course Review. The UO is still using CourseLeaf. All courses can be reviewed throughout the year through CourseLeaf Management System (https://nextcatalog.uoregon.edu/courseadmin/).

Six courses associated with the Lead minor were reviewed for comment and will come for vote along with the program later in Fall term. Revised courses from EMPL DEd will be reviewed and voted on this fall as well.

The due date for course submissions for review this Fall are October 21.  I do expect to see the Foundations of Educational Research course for review this Fall. You can check out any of the dates on the calendar in the Curriculum Resources website mentioned above.

Due to the visibility of comments and voting we will continue to use a Qualtrics system for voting.

Program Review. Three programs will be reviewed this fall. Three are Expedited: Prevention Science MS and PhD Programs (change in number of credits for the program) and EMPL DEd Program (request to offer the program outside of Oregon); CPSY PhD program (change in number of credits for the program). These will be shared during the comment period, but because these are Expedited Programs, they will only be voted on by the COE Curriculum Committee.

The DEd Program also has a series of courses that will need to be voted on. These are revisions of the courses in their current DEd program, and thus will be the courses for the expanded program. As you are aware, when a program moves to the council, they request that any experimental courses (e.g. 410, 510, 610) go through the process of course approval.

One program, EMPL minor, will come through as a Full Review. First, you will see it and be allowed to comment. Then after a review by the COE Curriculum Committee, it will come for a COE faculty vote and the six affiliated courses (commented on last spring) will be voted on as well.

There is work underway on a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) Program. This will be a certificate program and it is anticipated it will be submitted during the winter timeline.

Notification about commenting and voting on curriculum will occur through email as the CourseLeaf Management System for Programs is not ready to be released. Again, remember that you share comments with a Committee Member from your department but you vote through a Qualtrics survey that will be sent via email.

Teacher Engagement Program (Aka Teacher Effectiveness Program)
The TEP program has redesigned their website and added many resources so I recommend you take a look. http://tep.uoregon.edu/

Common Read
UO's Common Read this year is Ta-Nehisi Coates - Between the World and Me.  There is a website with reading resources, campus resources and teaching resources. http://commonreading.uoregon.edu/current-book-btwam/

Thanks for all the work by faculty and staff to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions, check in with your Program Director, Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative or schedule a time to meet with me if necessary.

Brigid

K. Brigid Flannery
Associate Dean of Academic Affairs, College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1215
541-346-2496
brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Merit Increase Policy comment'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

As you may be aware, the Provost's Office has requested clarification and consistency across campus regarding the timeline within which colleges review eligible faculty and staff for merit increases.

Our College of Education's existing policy is current and otherwise appropriate, however, because the most recent merit increase cycle occurred in January 2016, our policy, along with others across campus, will need an update to the "Period of Review" section.

To ensure consistency across colleges, see the changes suggested to us by the Office of Academic Affairs (AA) and reviewed by the dean's office below:

[Existing/current Language] Period of Review: In general, the period of review for a merit evaluation will be no longer than twelve months, ending at the date of the merit determination.  For the purposes of the Spring 2014 merit evaluation, the evaluation period is extended from January 1, 2008 until the date of review.

[Language suggested by AA] Period of Review: In general, the period of review for a merit evaluation will extend at least to the last merit increase (or increase cycle).

This proposed change to the language will have minimal impact on existing practice but is intended to result in improved efficiency of our review process and allow for consistency in process across campus.

Keeping in mind that only the language in the "Period of Review" is open for comment at this time, please respond to the very brief survey https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_37oQ3UL3Che2oGV by Tuesday October 11th,  2016 if you have a comment.


Best,

Dianna

Dianna Carrizales-Engelmann, Ph.D.,

Director of Administration and
Teacher of Clinical Practice and Performance Assessment
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
(541) 346-5407

subject: b'coe-fac: Merit Increase Policy comment'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

Thank you for your participation in the survey to clarify the review cycle for Merit Increases for our college. Based on comments and feedback we received on the single sentence, the wording that we will be submitting to the Provost's office for the Faculty Merit Policy is:

The period of review for a merit evaluation will extend to the last performance assessment and will include any supplemental information necessary to document relevant recent activity.

As before, this proposed change to the language would have minimal impact on existing practice.

Best,
Dianna

Katy

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: Clark Honors College Call for Course Proposals\tAY2017-18'
html:
b'
Dear Colleagues,

The Clark Honors College (CHC) invites course proposals from faculty for the 2017-18 academic year. Proposals are due November 16, 2016 and should be submitted online<https://forms.uoregon.edu/forms/list/Clark%20Honors%20College>.

The CHC offers opportunities to teach small groups of highly motivated students with strong academic skills. Students enrolled in the CHC major in a broad range of disciplines on our campus but come together in their Honors College classes to learn and to share their perspectives in the context of a liberal arts and sciences curriculum. Teaching a course at CHC may offer opportunities for interdisciplinarity, as well as for pedagogical experimentation and innovation.

Course proposals for 200-level introductory courses and 400-level colloquia are welcome from all faculty \xe2\x80\x93 tenured, tenure-related, and NTTF - from across all colleges and fields at UO. Further details on course types are available on the CHC website<http://honors.uoregon.edu/content/submit-course-proposal>. All courses should be designed for a maximum of 19 students in a class, should be relevant for students pursuing various majors, and should encourage critical and creative thinking, writing, reading, and discussion skills.

Submitting your proposal:

Course proposals must be submitted via the Clark Honors College Affiliated Faculty Course Proposal<https://forms.uoregon.edu/forms/list/Clark%20Honors%20College> online form. All documents require electronic signatures from your department head - and from your dean if you are a non-CAS faculty member \xe2\x80\x93 and must be submitted by November 16, 2016 at 5pm. This deadline makes it possible for the CHC Curriculum Committee to review proposals and make agreements with UO departments in a timely manner.

CHC affiliated faculty are generally compensated at the standard UO course buyout rate, and through various mechanisms consisting of buyouts, direct hires, overloads, and in some cases trades/exchanges. Any deviation from standard compensation options and/or exchanges must be explicitly agreed to by the CHC Assistant Dean.

If you have any questions, or if you would like to discuss ideas for courses in more detail, you\xe2\x80\x99re welcome to get in touch with me at rlindner at uoregon.edu<mailto:rlindner at uoregon.edu>. We look forward to hearing from you.

With thanks and best wishes,
Rebecca

Dr. Rebecca Lindner
Assistant Dean, Robert D. Clark Honors College
University of Oregon

subject: b'coe-fac: Thinking of committing your FTE???'
html:
b'
Quick reminder\xe2\x80\xa6.
I just sent an announcement for new courses for the Clark Honors College. It served as a prompt for me to remind you that if you submit a proposal for teaching a course outside your department/unit or to teach a FIG, or to develop an ARC, or anything that commits your FTE \xe2\x80\x93 PLEASE be sure to get approval from your department head or your research unit director prior to submitting the proposal.

Thank you,
Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: MakerSpace'
html:
b'
I wanted to alert COE community:  the MakerSpace<https://library.uoregon.edu/scilib/dearmond-makerspace> in the Price Science Commons and Research Library is now open.

subject: b'coe-fac: EDUC teaching opportunities- Please apply'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Well it is that time of year again Please consider nominating yourself or a peer as an instructor for any of the 2017-2018 EDUC research design and methodology courses (Due Dec 28, 2016). Faculty - instructional or research are eligible to apply. You can nominate by completing the Qualtrics form and uploading a CV if applicable.
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_erqlwRragy99rcp

Find out more information about these courses on the Curriculum Resources website (e.g., course descriptions, courses offered next year, operating procedures) (https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/display/governance/Curriculum+Resources).
Also you can find the current EDUC syllabi in the pubdocs folder on the COE server.

Feel free to contact me if you have questions.

Thank you,
Brigid

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic - Tutoring Opportunity'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

As we move towards the end of the term, the CTL Reading Clinic is seeking your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in the clinic this winter. In 2016-2017, we are offering tutoring services to struggling readers in Grades K-2 at the HEDCO Clinic. Selected students will participate in two hours of small group reading and/or math instruction, Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday each week, delivered by trained tutors.

Tutors will receive training and orientation during Weeks 1 and 2 of the term, and begin teaching intervention groups in Week 3. Students may tutor two or four days per week. Students may also tutor for credit to complete a field experience requirement, or volunteer. This is an excellent opportunity for UO students who are interested in instruction in literacy or math or are considering a career in K-12 education.

Please see the attached application and feel free to pass it on to interested tutors. Alternatively, students can find out more about the CTL Reading Clinic at our website: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.

If students have any questions, they can contact me, Sarah E Carlson (carlsons at uoregon.edu)<mailto:carlsons at uoregon.edu)> or Anna Ingram our administrative assistant (annad at uoregon.edu<mailto:annad at uoregon.edu>).

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic and our mission, which includes providing meaningful training opportunities to COE students!

Best,
Sarah E Carlson, Clinic Coordinator
Nancy Nelson, Clinic Director

--
Sarah E. Carlson, Ph.D.
Research Associate
Reading Clinic Coordinator
University of Oregon
Center on Teaching and Learning
1600 Millrace Drive, Suite 207
Eugene, OR 97403-5292
Office: (541) 346-8363
Fax: (541) 346-8353
Email: carlsons at uoregon.edu<mailto:carlsons at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: President Schill to meet with COE Faculty - December 7th'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty:


Following the election and recent racist events on our campus, President Schill would like to meet with COE faculty so that he can listen, learn, and answer questions.  He is committed to helping the campus heal and improve, and he believes that starts with an open dialogue.


Please come to meet with President Schill on Wednesday, December 7, from 11:15-11:45AM, room HEDCO 144.


Thank you,

Krista


_______________________________________________________________

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Scholarship Information - Slide for your Lectures'
html:
b'
COE Faculty,

The COE was able to give over $600,000 to over 100 COE students this academic year. Currently, the COE is accepting applications for scholarships that will be distributed in 2017-18. It's important that all our students are aware of the funding opportunities available to them. Please consider inserting the attached PowerPoint slide regarding available scholarship funding from the COE to your lecture slides at the beginning or end of your classes from now until January 31, 2017.

The slide contains information about our upcoming information session on January 13 at 3:30 pm in 220 HEDCO. However, I am also available to speak your class or speak to your cohort about our scholarship application process. Please contact me to schedule.

If you have any questions about who is eligible or the process for applying, don't hesitate to contact me.
Thanks!
~Andrea

________________________________

From: <deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu>> on behalf of David O Conover <dconover at uoregon.edu<mailto:dconover at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Tuesday, December 6, 2016 at 9:52 AM
To: "deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>" <deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Cc: Lynn Stearney <stearney at uoregon.edu<mailto:stearney at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: deans-dirs: Interdisciplinary Awards in the Humanities and Social Sciences

Please share this announcement with your faculty.


Thanks to the generosity of the University of Oregon Foundation, I am delighted to announce a new internal award program sponsored by the Foundation and administered by my office.  This internal award will furnish seed funding for scholars and researchers in the humanities and social sciences.

For the 2017 and 2018 award cycles, Interdisciplinary Awards in the Humanities and Social Sciences will support projects in the environmental humanities and social sciences.  We are seeking innovative projects that investigate the interrelationships between human activity and the environment and that employ humanistic and social scientific modes of investigation.

I anticipate making up to three awards of up to $25,000 each which will furnish seed funding and support the preparatory work necessary to develop competitive external funding proposals.  Proposed projects should rely on collaborative partnerships across departments and colleges.

The deadline for applications for 2017 awards is February 6, 2017.

For additional details, please visit the guidelines<http://rds.uoregon.edu/sites/default/files/.sites/default/files/2017-2018%20Environmental%20H%20SS%20Award%20Program%20FINAL_0.pdf> located on the Research Development Services Internal Funding Opportunities webpage.

Questions may be directed to Lynn Stearney<mailto:stearney at uoregon.edu>, Director of Research Development Services, 346-8308.



David O. Conover, PhD
Vice President for Research and Innovation
Professor of Biology
1266 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1266

541-346-2090
[cid:3E1C3528-DA6B-4FC2-BAA1-7D01A53712FD]

subject: b'coe-fac: UO Global Corners Award - FUNDS FOR PROSPECTIVE & ENROLLED INTERNATIONAL GRADUATE STUDENTS'

subject: b'coe-fac: Ever thought about teaching EDUC research courses? -\tPlease apply'
html:
b'
Faculty (academic and research),
 Please consider nominating yourself or a peer as an instructor for any of the 2017-2018 EDUC research design and methodology courses (Due Dec 28, 2016). Faculty - instructional or research are eligible to apply. You can nominate by completing the Qualtrics form and uploading a CV if applicable.
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_erqlwRragy99rcp

Find out more information about these courses on the Curriculum Resources website (e.g., course descriptions, courses offered next year, operating procedures) (https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/display/governance/Curriculum+Resources).
Also you can find the current EDUC syllabi in the pubdocs folder on the COE server.

Feel free to contact me if you have questions.

Thank you,
Brigid

brigidf at uoregon.edu<mailto:brigidf at uoregon.edu>
6-2496

html:

Best,
Leslie

From: <deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu>> on behalf of Senior Vice Provost <srviceprovost at uoregon.edu<mailto:srviceprovost at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Wednesday, December 7, 2016 at 9:35 AM
To: "deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>" <deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Subject: deans-dirs: Announcing the new Sustainability Faculty Fellowship

Dear Colleagues,
We are pleased to direct your attention to the Office of Sustainability's newly announced<http://around.uoregon.edu/content/faculty-invited-apply-new-sustainability-fellowship> Sustainability Faculty Fellowship.
The Office of Sustainability is seeking faculty members who are interested in developing community-engaged learning opportunities around sustainability. The Sustainability Faculty Fellowship will provide opportunities to connect with prominent community partners and provide fellows with a network of colleagues (across discipline and rank) who seek to incorporate issues of sustainability into their curricula.
Faculty fellows will receive a $500 award and will take part in a three-day workshop discussing issues of sustainability and methods for designing community-engaged learning experiences. The workshop will feature site visits, field trips and guest presentations from governmental, non-profit, and for-profit organizations, giving fellows the opportunity to establish partnerships for community-engaged learning experiences. Fellows can receive an additional $500 award for submitting curriculum that has been revised or newly created to incorporate issues of sustainability.
Faculty from all disciplines and experience levels are encouraged to apply, particularly those with no previous experience in integrating sustainability in their curriculum or research. Interdisciplinary team applications will also be accepted.
For more information, please see this week's Around the O story<http://around.uoregon.edu/content/faculty-invited-apply-new-sustainability-fellowship> and the Office of Sustainability website<https://sustainability.uoregon.edu/programs-projects/active/sustainability-faculty-fellowship>.
Best wishes,
Susan and Doug
Susan Anderson
Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs
Doug Blandy
Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs

subject: b'coe-fac: Four free COE workshops on R in Winter term!'
html:
b'
Greetings COE faculty!

Following on the announcement at the COE faculty-staff meeting a few weeks ago, I wanted to announce the free methodology workshops offered this Winter term for COE faculty. We are very fortunate to have experts in the R software program in our college. One of those experts (Daniel Anderson) will lead the workshops, which will provide an excellent foundation for faculty interested in learning R and/or faculty wanting to support graduate students in the future as they learn the program. See below or attached flier for details.

Thanks, and have a good holiday everyone,
Leslie



A Taste of R
Free Workshop for Faculty

R is a free, open-source, and tremendously powerful and flexible software for data analysis. Thousands of users across the globe contribute to R on a nearly daily basis, providing users with access to cutting edge analyses and, often, some of the most modern thinking in statistical methodology. Many educational and statistical doctoral programs have begun adopting R as the primary software for statistics courses.

Dr. Daniel Anderson of the Center on Teaching and Learning (CTL) and the Behavioral Research and Teaching Center (BRT) will offer 4 free workshops on R.

Purpose: To provide faculty with a basic introduction to R (no advanced statistical prerequisite skills required) that will orient faculty as to why R is a unique, powerful, and flexible tool for manipulating, summarizing, and visualizing data.

When: 12:00- 2:00 pm, on the following dates: January 20, February 3, February 17, March 3. Workshop topics are listed below. Daniel will also be available for individual or research group meetings outside of the workshops. In the spring term, Daniel will offer a formal course open to faculty, doctoral, and masters students.

Where: A COE classroom TBA. Sessions will also be recorded for later viewing.

How do I sign up?: Email us at daniela at uoregon.edu<mailto:daniela at uoregon.edu> and leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>

Workshop #1: What is R and why should I care?

\xc2\xb7      This session introduces R and external packages, addressing the basics of a reproducible workflow and data visualizations.  A broad overview is provided for the R landscape, illustrating both its power and flexibility.

Workshop #2: Tidy data

\xc2\xb7      The concept of tidy data, introduced by Hadley Wickham, is a technical term to describe a specific data structure. As Hadley notes, "Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way". This session introduces the concept of tidy data, explains why it is useful, and covers tools to help get your data into a tidy format through R.

Workshop #3: Data visualization

\xc2\xb7      Numerous data visualization packages are discussed with an emphasis on fast and powerful exploratory plotting.

Workshop #4: Bring your own data

\xc2\xb7      The final session focuses on individual participant datasets to tackle real challenges. One or two datasets will be explored in depth, including data manipulation, visualization, and basic analysis.



***********
Leslie Leve, PhD
Professor and Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education
Associate Director, Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon

Phone: 541-346-9601
Web: https://education.uoregon.edu/users/leslie-leve

subject: b'coe-fac: New Librarian'
html:
b'
I am delighted to announce the arrival of Katherine Donaldson - your new Education Librarian!

Katherine was most recently Librarian-in-Residence at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, where she has worked since 2014, and prior to that time, served in consecutive positions as the Special Projects Librarian and Online Learning Assistant for the University of Washington.

Here is a quick list of things she can assist you with:


*         Want to suggest books or DVDs?

*         Thinking of a new program or area? Want to know if we have the materials to support it?

*         Students need some research guidance?  Want a class presentation?

*         Candidate interviews - want tour of Library?

*         Writing a grant?

*         Writing accreditation report  - need a report on library resources?

*         Would you like an office visit to talk about setting up bookmarks for databases, or instructions on setting up a system to alert you to new books or journal articles, or talk about other research/instructional issues?

*         EndNote, Zotero, or Mendeley questions?

Her contact information:  email:

kdonalds at uoregon.edu<mailto:kdonalds at uoregon.edu>

   Phone:  541-346-4132

  https://library.uoregon.edu/users/kdonalds

I don't want to steal any of Katherine's thunder but I would like to take a paragraph to thank you for a wonderful experience being your subject specialist - 30 years went by so fast!  I have told Katherine she could not ask to be affiliated with better program - the COE faculty, students, and staff have always been so warm, welcoming, and a personal and intellectual delight to work with.  I will still be around - continuing to serve as subject specialist for Linguistics and Language Teaching, Foundation Database consultant, and EndNote contact as well adding my new role as Head of Research & Instructional Services.

Thank you,

Katy






-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20170110/a7b0c2e4/attachment-0001.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: End of Fall Curriculum Update'
html:
b'
Faculty,

Hope you had a good break in December and have unburied for all this "weather". This email will update you to the curriculum happenings from Fall term and some expectations/dates for Winter.


\xc2\xb7         Permanent Course and Program Review during Fall 2016

\xc2\xb7         Academic Extension

\xc2\xb7         EDUC Courses and Requirements

\xc2\xb7         Senate Policies: Graduate hybrid courses

\xc2\xb7         Curriculum Committee Membership and Resources

\xc2\xb7         New education librarian

Permanent Course and Program Review during Fall 2016

Course Review. The UO is still using CourseLeaf. All courses can be reviewed throughout the year through CourseLeaf Management System (https://nextcatalog.uoregon.edu/courseadmin/).

One course, EDST 225 School and Representation in Film (Expedite),  was reviewed by the COE CC.  This is a permanent course that as requesting approval to count for UO multicultural requirement: Approved to move forward to Dean and UOCC.
Six courses associated with the Lead minor were approved as well as a set of revised courses from EMPL DEd.

The following were approved by the Senate (Full report at https://registrar.uoregon.edu/faculty-staff/curriculum-reports ):

\xc2\xb7         The title change for EDST 663: Fronteras Pedag\xc3\xb3gicas: Education and Immigration
The due date for course submissions for review this winter is Feb 3.

Program Review.
Four programs we reviewed and approved by COE this fall. Prevention Science MS and PhD Programs (change in number of credits for the program) and EMPL DEd Program (request to offer the program outside of Oregon); CPSY PhD program (change in number of credits for the program); and EMPL leadership minor.  The Leadership minor was approved with the recommendation to a) consider use of 4xx/5xx courses, and to explore the GPA requirements for the program to be sure they are rigorous but competitive.

The following were approved by the Senate (Full report at https://registrar.uoregon.edu/faculty-staff/curriculum-reports ):

\xc2\xb7         Certificate in Educational Foundations: Secondary

\xc2\xb7         Reduction in the required credits within the Doctor of Philosophy degree in Counseling Psychology from 175 to 165 credits.

\xc2\xb7         Curriculum changes to the Doctor of Philosophy and Master of Science degrees in Prevention Science.

\xc2\xb7         Hybrid delivery of the Doctor of Education degree program in Educational Leadership to students outside the state of Oregon.
The due date for program submissions for review this winter is Feb 22.

Academic Extension
There were four course requests for approval for Academic Extension courses.

\xc2\xb7         EDLD 608 Critical Issues (CCR3): Building Leadership Skills to Improve Schools by Solving Critical Educational Problems (1 cr) Offered Fall, winter and spring

\xc2\xb7         EDLD 608 Critical Issues-Based Leadership Institute: Creating a College and Career Readiness System (1 cr)
Just a quick reminder to faculty. When you approve an AE course at the department level you are indicting that the course meets your department standards for course content and level of rigor. These courses will be on the participant's transcripts with your department/program prefix and in most cases a graduate credit.

EDUC Courses and Requirements
The Curriculum Committee has been charged by The Dean to review the EDUC coursework and requirements based on the budgetary process and the request for waivers recently received by the committee. They will begin this work in winter term.

Senate Policies
The senate last year approved an UG policy on hybrid online courses.  This year the Senate approved US16/17-05: Policy on Graduate Online & Hybrid Courses: Student engagement (Effective Fall 2017). Available at http://senate.uoregon.edu/2016/10/11/us1617-05-graduate-online-hybrid-courses-policy-proposal/

COE Curriculum Committee and Curriculum Resources
Your committee representatives are listed below. I strongly recommend that you keep them informed of any course or program modifications or additions.

\xc2\xb7         EMPL: Keith Zvoch, Jo Smith

\xc2\xb7         EDST: Audrey Lucero, Jeanne Hall

\xc2\xb7         SPECS: Chris Murray, Angie Whalen

\xc2\xb7         CPHS: Deanna Linville-Knobelspiesse, Kathy Moxley-South
The COE Curriculum Resources are available on the COE Governance page: https://coedocs.uoregon.edu/display/governance/COE+Governance+and+Policies

On this site you will find such things as:

\xc2\xb7         Current syllabi information

\xc2\xb7         Approved COE Curriculum policy

\xc2\xb7         EDUC courses

\xc2\xb7         Calendars of COE program and course process
There are a number of forms and policies that people often look for but have difficulty finding. I have temporarily made a section on the Governance page titles "Forms and Policies" that has some of these. If there are others we should add let Mercedes know (mercedr at uoregon.edu<mailto:mercedr at uoregon.edu>) and we will try and locate and link it.

UO Education Librarian

We have a new Education Librarian Katherine Donaldson . Thank you Katie Lenn for all your work over all these years!!!

Her contact information is
email:  kdonalds at uoregon.edu<mailto:kdonalds at uoregon.edu>
Phone:  541-346-4132
  https://library.uoregon.edu/users/kdonalds


Thanks for all the work by faculty and staff to improve our programs and courses. If you have curriculum questions, check in with your Program Director, Department Head, COE Curriculum Committee representative or schedule a time to meet with me if necessary.

Brigid

Eugene, OR 97403-1215

subject: b'coe-fac: Four free COE workshops on R in Winter term! REMINDER TO REGISTER IF YOU ARE INTERESTED'
html:
b'
Hello faculty,

A reminder to faculty to sign up for the free R workshops if you plan to attend. The first session is January 20th, 12-2 pm, in Hedco 340. Lunch (sandwich bar) will be provided.

See attached flier for more information.

Thanks,
Leslie



From: <coe-fac-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu>> on behalf of leve <leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Thursday, December 22, 2016 at 11:07 AM
To: "coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>" <coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Subject: coe-fac: Four free COE workshops on R in Winter term!

Greetings COE faculty!

Following on the announcement at the COE faculty-staff meeting a few weeks ago, I wanted to announce the free methodology workshops offered this Winter term for COE faculty. We are very fortunate to have experts in the R software program in our college. One of those experts (Daniel Anderson) will lead the workshops, which will provide an excellent foundation for faculty interested in learning R and/or faculty wanting to support graduate students in the future as they learn the program. See below or attached flier for details.

Thanks, and have a good holiday everyone,
Leslie


A Taste of R
Free Workshop for Faculty

R is a free, open-source, and tremendously powerful and flexible software for data analysis. Thousands of users across the globe contribute to R on a nearly daily basis, providing users with access to cutting edge analyses and, often, some of the most modern thinking in statistical methodology. Many educational and statistical doctoral programs have begun adopting R as the primary software for statistics courses.

Dr. Daniel Anderson of the Center on Teaching and Learning (CTL) and the Behavioral Research and Teaching Center (BRT) will offer 4 free workshops on R.

Purpose: To provide faculty with a basic introduction to R (no advanced statistical prerequisite skills required) that will orient faculty as to why R is a unique, powerful, and flexible tool for manipulating, summarizing, and visualizing data.

When: 12:00- 2:00 pm, on the following dates: January 20, February 3, February 17, March 3. Workshop topics are listed below. Daniel will also be available for individual or research group meetings outside of the workshops. In the spring term, Daniel will offer a formal course open to faculty, doctoral, and masters students.

Where: 340 Hedco (Jan 20) and 230T Hedco (Feb 3, Feb 17, March 3). Sessions will be recorded for live or later viewing.

How do I sign up?: Email us at daniela at uoregon.edu<mailto:daniela at uoregon.edu> and leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>

Workshop #1: What is R and why should I care?

\xc2\xb7      This session introduces R and external packages, addressing the basics of a reproducible workflow and data visualizations.  A broad overview is provided for the R landscape, illustrating both its power and flexibility.

Workshop #2: Tidy data

\xc2\xb7      The concept of tidy data, introduced by Hadley Wickham, is a technical term to describe a specific data structure. As Hadley notes, "Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way". This session introduces the concept of tidy data, explains why it is useful, and covers tools to help get your data into a tidy format through R.

Workshop #3: Data visualization

\xc2\xb7      Numerous data visualization packages are discussed with an emphasis on fast and powerful exploratory plotting.

Workshop #4: Bring your own data

\xc2\xb7      The final session focuses on individual participant datasets to tackle real challenges. One or two datasets will be explored in depth, including data manipulation, visualization, and basic analysis.


***********
Leslie Leve, PhD
Professor and Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education
Associate Director, Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon

Phone: 541-346-9601
Web: https://education.uoregon.edu/users/leslie-leve

subject: b'coe-fac: Winter Term Workshops'
text:
b"Below you will see a number of workshops offered by Academic Affairs. Some are for Unit Heads but others are for faculty and staff.
Please review the list and try to take advantage of these opportunities to gain important information related to teacher evaluations and promotions.

Brigid

Sent from my iPhone


From: deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu> [mailto:deans-dirs-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu] On Behalf Of Academic Affairs Office of
Sent: Wednesday, January 11, 2017 9:32 AM
To: deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>; departmentheads at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:departmentheads at lists.uoregon.edu>
Subject: deans-dirs: Winter Term Workshops

Dear Colleagues,

As you may have seen in last week's Around the O<http://around.uoregon.edu/content/winter-academic-workshops-are-offered-faculty-and-staff>, registration is now open for the Office of the Provost and Academic Affairs' winter workshops and trainings.

In addition to informing you of opportunities available for faculty and staff, we would like to draw your attention to the trainings available for unit heads. The unit heads training series is designed for academic and research leadership, and is produced in partnership with Human Resources, the Office of the Vice President for Research and Innovation, and the Office of the Vice President for Finance and Administration.

Jan. 20 - Unit Heads Training - Institutional Finances<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/unit-heads-training-institutional-finances>

Jan. 24 - NTTF Coming up for Promotion - Am I ready yet?<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/workshop-nttf-coming-promotion-am-i-ready-yet>

Feb. 9 - CoDaC Winter Quarter Luncheon Workshop on Teaching Evaluations<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/workshop-codac-winter-quarter-luncheon-workshop-teaching-evaluations>

Feb. 14 - Promotion & Tenure for Candidates Who Will Undergo Review<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/workshop-promotion-tenure-candidates-who-will-undergo-review> (Note: This workshop has been rescheduled from Jan. 17.)

Feb. 21 - Unit Heads Training - Q&A with the Business Bunch<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/unit-heads-training-qa-business-bunch>

Feb. 23 - Preparing the TTF and NTTF Promotion & Tenure File for Unit Heads, Office Managers and Staff<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/workshop-preparing-ttf-and-nttf-promotion-tenure-file-unit-heads-office-managers-and-staff>

March 9 - Unit Heads Training - Mid-Term/Third-year Pre-tenure Review<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/unit-heads-training-mid-termthird-year-pre-tenure-review>

March 16 - Unit Heads Training - Nuts and Bolts of Departmental Personnel Actions<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/unit-heads-training-nuts-and-bolts-departmental-personnel-actions>

Save the Date: March 22 - Mid-year Academic Leadership Retreat<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/mid-year-academic-leadership-retreat-save-date>

For more information, please see the Academic Affairs website<http://academicaffairs.uoregon.edu/dates-deadlines> or email academicaffairs at uoregon.edu.

Best wishes,

The Office of the Provost and Academic Affairs

subject: b'coe-fac: Four free COE workshops on R in Winter term! **WORKSHOP FULL, BUT E-PARTICIPATION AVAILABLE**'
html:
b'
Hello COE Faculty,

We have reached capacity for this workshop (30 attendees), and need to close registration at this time in order to ensure effective delivery of the content.

However, we have moved the location of all four workshops to Lokey 115, in order to provide virtual access for anyone who has not yet registered and would like to hear the workshop content.

See the attached Guide for instructions of how to log on and participate via remote access to the workshops.

For those attending in person, a sandwich buffet will be provided. Please arrive a ~15 minutes early if you would like to make a sandwich before the session starts.

We are excited about the enthusiastic faculty response to this workshop series!

Leslie

text:
b'Hello COE Faculty,

We have reached capacity for this workshop (30 attendees), and need to close registration at this time in order to ensure effective delivery of the content.

However, we have moved the location of all four workshops to Lokey 115, in order to provide virtual access for anyone who has not yet registered and would like to hear the workshop content.

See the attached Guide for instructions of how to log on and participate via remote access to the workshops.

For those attending in person, a sandwich buffet will be provided. Please arrive a ~15 minutes early if you would like to make a sandwich before the session starts.

We are excited about the enthusiastic faculty response to this workshop series!

Leslie


From: leve <leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Wednesday, January 11, 2017 at 6:56 PM
To: "coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>" <coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Cc: Daniel J Anderson <daniela at uoregon.edu<mailto:daniela at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: coe-fac: Four free COE workshops on R in Winter term! REMINDER TO REGISTER IF YOU ARE INTERESTED

Hello faculty,

A reminder to faculty to sign up for the free R workshops if you plan to attend. The first session is January 20th, 12-2 pm, in Hedco 340. Lunch (sandwich bar) will be provided.

See attached flier for more information.

Thanks,
Leslie



From: <coe-fac-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu>> on behalf of leve <leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Thursday, December 22, 2016 at 11:07 AM
To: "coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>" <coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Subject: coe-fac: Four free COE workshops on R in Winter term!

Greetings COE faculty!

Following on the announcement at the COE faculty-staff meeting a few weeks ago, I wanted to announce the free methodology workshops offered this Winter term for COE faculty. We are very fortunate to have experts in the R software program in our college. One of those experts (Daniel Anderson) will lead the workshops, which will provide an excellent foundation for faculty interested in learning R and/or faculty wanting to support graduate students in the future as they learn the program. See below or attached flier for details.

Thanks, and have a good holiday everyone,
Leslie


A Taste of R
Free Workshop for Faculty

R is a free, open-source, and tremendously powerful and flexible software for data analysis. Thousands of users across the globe contribute to R on a nearly daily basis, providing users with access to cutting edge analyses and, often, some of the most modern thinking in statistical methodology. Many educational and statistical doctoral programs have begun adopting R as the primary software for statistics courses.

Dr. Daniel Anderson of the Center on Teaching and Learning (CTL) and the Behavioral Research and Teaching Center (BRT) will offer 4 free workshops on R.

Purpose: To provide faculty with a basic introduction to R (no advanced statistical prerequisite skills required) that will orient faculty as to why R is a unique, powerful, and flexible tool for manipulating, summarizing, and visualizing data.

When: 12:00- 2:00 pm, on the following dates: January 20, February 3, February 17, March 3. Workshop topics are listed below. Daniel will also be available for individual or research group meetings outside of the workshops. In the spring term, Daniel will offer a formal course open to faculty, doctoral, and masters students.

Where: 340 Hedco (Jan 20) and 230T Hedco (Feb 3, Feb 17, March 3). Sessions will be recorded for live or later viewing.

How do I sign up?: Email us at daniela at uoregon.edu<mailto:daniela at uoregon.edu> and leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>

Workshop #1: What is R and why should I care?

\xc2\xb7      This session introduces R and external packages, addressing the basics of a reproducible workflow and data visualizations.  A broad overview is provided for the R landscape, illustrating both its power and flexibility.

Workshop #2: Tidy data

\xc2\xb7      The concept of tidy data, introduced by Hadley Wickham, is a technical term to describe a specific data structure. As Hadley notes, "Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way". This session introduces the concept of tidy data, explains why it is useful, and covers tools to help get your data into a tidy format through R.

Workshop #3: Data visualization

\xc2\xb7      Numerous data visualization packages are discussed with an emphasis on fast and powerful exploratory plotting.

Workshop #4: Bring your own data

\xc2\xb7      The final session focuses on individual participant datasets to tackle real challenges. One or two datasets will be explored in depth, including data manipulation, visualization, and basic analysis.


***********
Leslie Leve, PhD
Professor and Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education
Associate Director, Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon

Phone: 541-346-9601
Web: https://education.uoregon.edu/users/leslie-leve

subject: b'coe-fac: Prohibited Discrimination Reporting training: 1/18 @ 9AM'
html:
b'
?Please help spread the word about an upcoming Title IX training:
Prohibited Discrimination Reporting: Understanding and Reporting Prohibited Discrimination and Harassment.

The training is January 18th, 9 - 11:30am in EMU Crater Lake North.

This is an introductory training where we will discuss University policies prohibiting discrimination and harassment, the types of behavior that constitute inappropriate treatment or discriminatory harassment, and your role in helping to create a community where such behavior is not tolerated.  We will also discuss employee reporting obligations, response to typical scenarios as well as resources that are currently available to you and/or to the students you serve. This course will include Title IX, Title VII, Child Abuse Reporting and Clery Campus Security Authority obligations.

To register, please go to: http://odt.uoregon.edu/registration/course_view.php?crse_id=709


Gina Van Dusen
Interim Executive Assistant to AVP/TIXC
ginav at uoregon.edu<mailto:ginav at uoregon.edu>
Hours: 8:00 - 4:00 M-Th.
T: 541-346-8032

[UO]

subject: b'coe-fac: Associate Dean for Academic Affairs -- Nomination Process'
html:
b'
The following email is sent on behalf of Dean Randy Kamphaus:

Dear Faculty,

The principle of shared governance in American higher education is one of our most honored traditions.  This practice provides our institutions with both the continuity and change needed to enhance our academic excellence.   In that spirit, I am launching an internal search for the position of Associate Dean for Academic Affairs to build on the work of Professor Brigid Flannery.  I am keenly aware that the Associate Dean role is among the most challenging in the academy.  As you know, Brigid has numerous accomplishments to cite and treasure.

Our COE Internal Governance describes the role of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs and provides the following procedures for (a) identifying candidates and (b) selecting a department head:

\xe2\x80\x9cThe Associate Dean for Academic Affairs (ADAA) is responsible for overseeing and guiding the academic mission and providing oversight of academic processes and policies in the COE, including curriculum, and faculty/student grievances. In addition, the ADAA provides leadership to and supports the integration of the academic and research enterprises within the academic programs.\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cThe Associate Deans shall be selected by the Dean from COE career faculty members at the rank of Associate Professor or higher\xe2\x80\xa6 The Dean shall solicit and consider nominations from representative faculty. Preference for [both of] these positions shall be given to candidates with the rank of full Professor, Senior Research Associate II, or Full Research Professor and relevant University level experience. The Dean shall consult with constituent faculty (i.e., department heads, unit directors, Program Directors) in the final decision making process.\xe2\x80\x9d

To begin this process, please forward any candidate nominations to me prior to 5 pm on January 27.  This schedule should allow me to make an appointment prior to Spring break.

 Gratefully, and with best wishes,\xe2\x80\x8b

Randy



-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20170117/7f6ac855/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Tutoring Resources for Faculty'
html:
b'
The COE offers FREE tutoring to all COE students. Currently, Tutoring Services offers tutoring in APA format, academic writing, English as a second language, math, science, and CDS courses - please visit education.uoregon.edu/tutors<file:///C:/Users/emathis/AppData/Local/Microsoft/Windows/Temporary%20Internet%20Files/Content.Outlook/QBA8XPW8/education.uoregon.edu/tutors> for detailed descriptions. We offer both drop-in hours and one-on-one tutoring appointments.

Drop-in hours are listed below and also on our webpage: education.uoregon.edu/tutors<file:///C:/Users/emathis/AppData/Local/Microsoft/Windows/Temporary%20Internet%20Files/Content.Outlook/QBA8XPW8/education.uoregon.edu/tutors>

  *   Math/Writing/Science with Sarina: Tues 10:00 am-2:00 pm
  *   Writing/Linguistics/CDS with Tani: Tues 1:00 pm - 5:00 pm
  *   Math 211/212/213 with ZIxin: Mon/Wed 12:30 pm - 2:30 pm
To schedule a one-on-one writing tutor appointment online, visit coe.uoregon.edu/tutor/ <https://coe.uoregon.edu/tutor/>

We also offer course specific tutoring. To collaborate with us, or make tutoring an extension of your classroom, please look to the pdf attached herewith. Some examples of course specific tutoring include:

  *   Group tutoring sessions
  *   Require or offer one-on-one tutoring as part of your course
  *   International student help sessions
  *   Workshops specific to your course

If you have any questions, concerns or suggestions about tutoring, you can email coetutor at uoregon.edu<mailto:coetutor at uoregon.edu>, or call at (541) 346-8130. Or, if you'd rather talk to someone in person, the Winter 2016 Tutor Coordinator office hours are Tues: 10:00 - 11:00, and Thurs: 11:00 - 12:00 in HEDCO 130.




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: BE Hopeful: Dr. Donna Beegle - Poverty Prevention'
html:
b'
Hello BEseries Partners and Friends,

BE Hopeful: Dr. Donna Beegle, author of See Poverty/Be the Difference

The BEseries is excited to partner with the College of Education to bring Dr. Donna Beegle to the UO.

Donna M. Beegle, Ed.D. is an authentic voice who speaks, writes and trains across the nation to break the iron cage of poverty. She is the author of "See Poverty... Be The Difference" and also took part in CNN's panel, "The Other America." Dr. Beegle has received national acclaim and standing ovations for her ability to passionately and succinctly address the issue of poverty. Educators need to know about poverty and its impact on students. Dr. Beegle's lived experiences and emphasis on education as the key pathway out of poverty makes this an especially pertinent presentation for all educators and researchers. Dr. Beegle offers us a story of hope during challenging times, please join us for BE Hopeful.

We are asking our wonderful BEpartners to help us spread the word! We are also hoping those of you who are instructing courses this term are willing to offer your students extra credit for attending this event on Tuesday, February 7th, 7:00pm in EMU Redwood Auditorium.  We will be giving away four of Dr. Beegle's books and dessert will be provided after the presentation.

Please find attached: a) PDF of the event poster and b) photo of Dr. Beegle for your use. Here are the related event links: UO Calendar: https://calendar.uoregon.edu/event/be_series_2717#.WIwDAX1uwVs Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/thebeseries/ Please let me know if you have any questions or need any more information.

Thank you,

Carolina
[cid:68BF952C-0EBE-42BC-8258-76C9F6E249E6]

Carolina Arrendondo Sanchez Lira
BEseries Academic Liaison, Center for Student Involvement (CSI)
Erb Memorial Union, University of Oregon
University of Oregon Room 213,
Eugene, Oregon 97403
e: carrendon at uoregon.edu<mailto:carrendon at uoregon.edu>
Pronouns: she/her/her's

subject: b'coe-fac: AERA 2017 Save the Date Sunday, April 30'
html:
b'
Hello,
For those faculty and students who are starting to plan travel to the AERA Conference in San Antonio, once again University of Oregon College of Education will be hosting a reception to showcase the great COE faculty and student research that is presented at the conference.  The reception will be held on Sunday, April 30 from 6:30 pm - 8:30 pm at Boudro's Texas Bistro<http://www.boudros.com/>.  In addition to our own AERA attendees, we are inviting local COE alumni, giving them the chance to hang out, chat with faculty and students, and learn about the world class research the COE does.
This is just a preliminary save the date.  I'll be sending out an RSVP link and asking for brochure information in March.
Let me know if I can answer any questions.
Thanks,
Lisa


Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20170201/47def6e9/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Tutoring email update'
html:
b'
Tutoring Services one-on-one online scheduling system down!

Have you been trying to make an appointment with one of our awesome COE tutors? If you've found that you can't make an appointment, you aren't alone! Currently, our online scheduling system is not functioning and we're working to fix it. So, in the meantime, if you need to make an appointment, please email Emily Mathis, the Tutoring Services Coordinator, to set up an appointment.

Lastly, we have started offering online writing appointments where students can email a tutor their paper and the tutor will look it over and return it with comments and suggestions. If you'd like to make an online appointment, again, please email Emily.

Here's Emily's information:
email: coetutor at uoregon.edu
phone: 541-346-8130
Office: HEDCO 130

Please don't hesitate to contact Emily with questions, concerns, or suggestions for tutoring services. We're here to support you!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thanks so much for your help getting the word out!
Emily


_________________________________________

Emily Ann Mathis
PhD Candidate - Critical Socio-cultural Studies in Ed University of Oregon _________________________________________
'

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: BE Hopeful: Dr. Donna Beegle - Poverty Prevention'
html:
b'
Hello,
If any faculty members are planning on providing extra credit to their students who attend the BE Hopeful event, could you please let me know?  They want to make sure they note which students are there plus they\xe2\x80\x99d like to see if the extra credit results in more students attending.  Just send me an email with the course number to let me know.

Thanks,
Lisa
From: Suzanne Hanlon
Sent: Wednesday, February 01, 2017 11:45 AM
To: Lisa Fortin <lfortin at uoregon.edu<mailto:lfortin at uoregon.edu>>; Krista Chronister <kmg at uoregon.edu<mailto:kmg at uoregon.edu>>
Cc: Hallie Frost <hallief at uoregon.edu<mailto:hallief at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: RE: BE Hopeful: Dr. Donna Beegle - Poverty Prevention

Lisa and Krista-
Thanks so much for promoting this! If it is possible to get a list of which professors are offering extra credit, our BEteam can keep count of how many COE students turn out for extra credit. This might help COE and BEteam estimate how extra credit effects turn out (that and the cupcake incentive!).
Thanks so much!
Suzanne
Cc: Hallie- BElogistics

From: coegr-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coegr-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu> [mailto:coegr-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu] On Behalf Of Lisa Fortin
Sent: Monday, January 30, 2017 2:43 PM
To: 'coeug at lists.uoregon.edu' <coeug at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coeug at lists.uoregon.edu>>; 'coegr at lists.uoregon.edu' <coegr at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coegr at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Subject: coegr: BE Hopeful: Dr. Donna Beegle - Poverty Prevention


Hello BEseries Partners and Friends,

BE Hopeful: Dr. Donna Beegle, author of See Poverty/Be the Difference

The BEseries is excited to partner with the College of Education to bring Dr. Donna Beegle to the UO.

Donna M. Beegle, Ed.D. is an authentic voice who speaks, writes and trains across the nation to break the iron cage of poverty. She is the author of "See Poverty... Be The Difference" and also took part in CNN's panel, "The Other America." Dr. Beegle has received national acclaim and standing ovations for her ability to passionately and succinctly address the issue of poverty. Educators need to know about poverty and its impact on students. Dr. Beegle's lived experiences and emphasis on education as the key pathway out of poverty makes this an especially pertinent presentation for all educators and researchers. Dr. Beegle offers us a story of hope during challenging times, please join us for BEHopeful.

This event will be on Tuesday, February 7th, 7:00pm in EMU Redwood Auditorium.  We will be giving away four of Dr. Beegle's books and dessert will be provided after the presentation.

Here are the related event links: UO Calendar:https://calendar.uoregon.edu/event/be_series_2717#.WIwDAX1uwVs Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/thebeseries/ Please let me know if you have any questions or need any more information.

Thank you,

Carolina


Carolina Arrendondo Sanchez Lira

BEseries Academic Liaison, Center for Student Involvement (CSI)

Erb Memorial Union, University of Oregon
University of Oregon Room 213,

Eugene, Oregon 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: Summer Session Policy'
html:
b'
Dear College of Education Faculty,

The College of Education's DRAFT Summer Session Policy template is attached. The draft template was provided to our college by the Office of Academic Affairs for review and approval by the dean. It has now been reviewed by our dean with additional input from the faculty advisory committee. This policy was unique in that Academic Affairs did not require development by a full ad hoc committee and instead colleges were provided with preferred template language for brief review.  However, because this was not developed by a COE committee, we would like your feedback before we submit it to Academic Affairs on February  10th (Academic Affairs' deadline).

Substantial changes, or changes recommended after the February 10th Academic Affairs submission deadline will go through the typical college policy amendment process.

Please contact me directly if you have any feedback that you would like considered before this is returned to Academic Affairs on February 10th.


Best Regards,

Dianna Carrizales-Engelmann Ph.D.,
Director of Administration

subject: b'coe-fac: Developing International Learning Opportunities'
html:
b'
Are you a faculty member who has been thinking it would be nice to work with some students internationally?
Have a current program you need to transition to GEO?

Come on February 24, 2017 1:00-2:30 in 220 HEDCO
Lillian Dur\xc3\xa1n (SPECS) and GEO staff

(Note: We know you may not have the full 90 minutes available but feel free to come for what part you can)

Developing International Learning Opportunities for Students

Organizing an international learning opportunity for your students is easier than you may think. Faculty are invited to learn about the process of initiating a study abroad program here at UO through the Global Engagement Office (GEO). Dr. Dur\xc3\xa1n will share her experiences in developing a program in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico focused on bringing students from the COE to work in special education programs. The nuts and bolts of program development, working with GEO, and tips for leading a trip will be discussed. A GEO representative will co-present to provide information about the supports offered to faculty and to describe the formal process for program approval.

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20170206/8bf19c01/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Fwd: deans-dirs: Faculty in Residence Information Session'
html:
b'
FYI

Sent from my iPhone

Begin forwarded message:

From: "VP and Dean, Undergraduate Studies" <vpugs at uoregon.edu<mailto:vpugs at uoregon.edu>>
Date: February 22, 2017 at 8:34:03 AM PST
To: "deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>" <deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Subject: deans-dirs: Faculty in Residence Information Session

Dear Colleagues,

Please consider applying or encouraging enthusiastic candidates to apply for the Faculty in Residence (FIR) program, a collaboration between Undergraduate Studies and University Housing.

Currently, UO hosts one faculty member, Dr. Julie Sykes, along with her family, in Global Scholars Hall as a part of the FIR program. Next year, we will have an additional position in the brand new residence hall, located at the corner of 17th and Moss Street, behind the Global Scholars Hall.

The FIR program positions faculty members to create a dynamic living-learning environment in the UO residence halls. The FIR program is a part of the network of academic connections and support for our undergraduate students. This program affirms a culture of inquiry as the heart of the entire UO undergraduate experience, and connects research faculty with students from the beginning of their college career.

The new residence hall will be completed during the summer of 2017, and will feature four Academic Residential Communities (ARCs) and several innovative pedagogical spaces on the first floor designed to explore the themes and curricula of the ARCs. The FIR apartment is a nicely furnished and outfitted 2 bedroom apartment and office in the new hall.  Candidates will be able to see renderings of the apartment during the recruitment process, which will conclude before the end of the 2016-2017 academic year. Anticipated closing date is March 1, 2017, which will be followed by an interview for all qualified candidates.

In order to find the full position description and apply to be an FIR, please click the link:
http://careers.uoregon.edu/cw/en-us/job/519784/faculty-in-residence-uo-residence-hall

We are hosting an information session for all interested candidates to find out more about the program and the position on February 28th at 5:30PM in Dr. Julie Sykes' GSH FIR apartment.  RSVP for this information session by emailing Sara Bowman at sarabow1 at uoregon.edu<mailto:sarabow1 at uoregon.edu>


All best,
Lisa Freinkel
Vice Provost and Dean, Undergraduate Studies




_______________________________________________
deans-dirs mailing list
deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:deans-dirs at lists.uoregon.edu>
https://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/mailman/listinfo/deans-dirs

The FIR program is a part of the network of academic connections and support for our undergraduate students. This program affirms a culture of inquiry as the heart of the entire UO undergraduate experience, and connects research faculty with students from the beginning of their college career.

The new residence hall will be completed during the summer of 2017, and will feature four Academic Residential Communities (ARCs) and several innovative pedagogical spaces on the first floor designed to explore the themes and curricula of the ARCs. The FIR apartment is a nicely furnished and outfitted 2 bedroom apartment and office in the new hall.  Candidates will be able to see renderings of the apartment during the recruitment process, which will conclude before the end of the 2016-2017 academic year. Anticipated closing date is March 1, 2017, which will be followed by an interview for all qualified candidates.

In order to find the full position description and apply to be an FIR, please click the link:
http://careers.uoregon.edu/cw/en-us/job/519784/faculty-in-residence-uo-residence-hall

We are hosting an information session for all interested candidates to find out more about the program and the position on February 28th at 5:30PM in Dr. Julie Sykes' GSH FIR apartment.  RSVP for this information session by emailing Sara Bowman at sarabow1 at uoregon.edu<mailto:sarabow1 at uoregon.edu>


All best,
Lisa Freinkel
Vice Provost and Dean, Undergraduate Studies

subject: b'coe-fac: Exciting College of Education Grant and Contract News'
html:
b'
Hello COE community,

The first half of fiscal year 2017 (July 2016 - December 2016) marked another period of research excellence for our college. Faculty in the College of Education were awarded a total of 29 new grants and contracts during this 6-month period, totaling $18.9M for this fiscal year. These grants and contracts came from a diverse set of funding agencies, such as the National Institutes of Health, the National Science Foundation, the Oregon Department of Education, the US Department of Education, the Spencer Foundation, as well as contracts from a range of external university and community partners.

Each of these new projects has been awarded funding for specific research, training, and outreach activities that will contribute new knowledge about youth development, student learning, educational systems, and family and community supports, as well as provide new training opportunities for students, and new outreach services to thousands of children and families. A list of the new projects is presented below.

Please join me in congratulating our faculty and their research and outreach staff teams (it takes a team to do this work) in their recent successes!

subject: b'coe-fac: CTL Reading Clinic - Tutoring Opportunity'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

As we move towards the end of the term, the CTL Reading Clinic is seeking your help in recruiting UO students to tutor in the clinic this spring term.

In 2016-2017, we are offering free tutoring services in reading and math to struggling students in Grades K-2 at the HEDCO Clinic. Selected students will participate in two hours of small group reading and/or math instruction, Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday each week, delivered by trained tutors.

Tutors will receive training and orientation during Weeks 1 and 2 of the term, and begin teaching intervention groups in Week 3. Students may tutor two or four days per week. Students may also tutor for credit to complete a field experience requirement, or volunteer. This is an excellent opportunity for UO students who are interested in instruction in literacy and/or math, or are considering a career in K-12 education.

Please see the attached flyer and application. Feel free to pass it on to interested students. Alternatively, students can find out more about the CTL Reading Clinic at our website: http://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/.

If students have any questions, they can contact me, Sarah E Carlson (carlsons at uoregon.edu)<mailto:carlsons at uoregon.edu)> (Reading Clinic Coordinator) or Anna Ingram our administrative assistant (annad at uoregon.edu<mailto:annad at uoregon.edu>).

Thank you for your continued support of the CTL Reading Clinic and our mission, which includes providing meaningful training opportunities to COE students!

Best,
Sarah E Carlson, Clinic Coordinator
Nancy Nelson, Clinic Director

--
Sarah E. Carlson, Ph.D.
Research Associate
Reading Clinic Coordinator
University of Oregon
Center on Teaching and Learning
1600 Millrace Drive, Suite 207
Eugene, OR 97403-5292
Office: (541) 346-8363
Fax: (541) 346-8353
Email: carlsons at uoregon.edu<mailto:carlsons at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: Conflict of Interest in Research Brown-bag Workshop for COE faculty - REMINDER'
html:
b'
Dear COE faculty and staff,

A reminder about the workshop this Friday on conflicts of interest in research and intellectual property. Hear from our UO experts about these important issues, they are here to help us navigate the systems and get our work out to the public. Please extend this invitation to your graduate students, as relevant.

Hope to see you there,
Leslie

From: <coe-staff-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-staff-bounces at lists.uoregon.edu>> on behalf of leve <leve at uoregon.edu<mailto:leve at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Wednesday, February 15, 2017 at 12:25 PM
To: "coe-staff at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-staff at lists.uoregon.edu>" <coe-staff at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-staff at lists.uoregon.edu>>, "coe-faculty at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-faculty at lists.uoregon.edu>" <coe-faculty at lists.uoregon.edu<mailto:coe-faculty at lists.uoregon.edu>>
Cc: craig carolyn <craig3 at uoregon.edu<mailto:craig3 at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: coe-staff: Conflict of Interest in Research Brown-bag Workshop for COE faculty

Dear COE faculty and staff,

Staff from the UO's Research Compliance Services (RCS) are hosting a dynamic conversation exploring conflicts of interest in research for College of Ed faculty. Together we will discuss challenges to identifying and managing conflicts of interest in research.  Staff from Innovation Partnership Services will also be present to answer questions about intellectual property (IP), start-ups, and other matters related to commercializing innovation from research.

This will be a really informative workshop- for both newer faculty, as well as those who have been in the COE for some time, and both sponsored and non-sponsored research activities. Please consider attending, and invite your research-active graduate students to join as well.

Date:  Friday, March 3
Time: 1 pm - 2:30 pm
Location:  230T (Hedco, 2nd Floor)
Questions? Contact:  Carolyn Craig, craig3 at uoregon.edu<mailto:craig3 at uoregon.edu>; 541-346-1845

Feel free to bring a brown-bag lunch.  No RVSP necessary, but if you have a specific question you would like addressed, please email me and Carolyn (copied here).

-Leslie


***********
Leslie Leve, PhD
Professor and Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education
Associate Director, Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon

Phone: 541-346-9601
Web: https://education.uoregon.edu/users/leslie-leve
