subject: b'coe-fac: 2018 Undergraduate Research Symposium'
html:
b'


[iversity of Oregon]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/0dy7u/40210g/4ssw3i>







Dear Colleagues:

We are writing to you with information on the 2018 Undergraduate Research Symposium in hopes that you will encourage your undergraduates to submit their work and that you will save the date so you can attend and help to celebrate the extraordinary creativity and ingenuity of our students. Since its inception in 2011, the Symposium has grown to become a major campus event to showcase our top scholars, with the 2017 Symposium including 292 presenters and 177 faculty mentors, and spanning 60 majors and eight colleges.

Additional information about the Symposium is available on our website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/>. Here are the highlights:

  *   The 2018 Symposium will take place on Thursday, May 17 in the EMU and will include a catered reception at 5pm with a keynote address and a ceremony to announce the recipients of the Excellence in Faculty Mentoring Award.
  *   Abstracts for student presentations at the 2018 event are due by 11:59 pm PST on Friday, March 16 and are submitted via the Undergraduate Research Symposium website (http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/<https://t.e2ma.net/click/0dy7u/40210g/0duw3i>).
  *   The abstract submission link will \xe2\x80\x9cgo live\xe2\x80\x9d on December 7, 2017. Questions about submissions should be directed to ugresearch at uoregon.edu<mailto:ugresearch at uoregon.edu>.
  *   We have two information sessions for students planned for Thursday, January 11 from 3-4pm and Monday, March 5 from 4-5pm in the Global Scholars Hall Learning Commons.
  *   The full event agenda will be available on the Symposium website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/> on January 1, 2018, including poster, oral, creative work, FIG/ARC, and Data Stories sessions.
  *   The schedule for winter and spring term workshops for abstract writing, poster design, and oral presentations is available on the Symposium website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/>.
  *   The list of 2018 presenter awards and eligibility criteria will also be updated on the Symposium website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/>.
If you'd like to be involved as an abstract reviewer, panel moderator, or judge, or have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us.

Thank you for your help making this event a success!

Sincerely,

Josh Snodgrass                                                                      Kevin Hatfield
Associate Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies         Director of Academic Residential & Research Initiatives

text:
b"


[iversity of Oregon]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/0dy7u/40210g/4ssw3i>







Dear Colleagues:

We are writing to you with information on the 2018 Undergraduate Research Symposium in hopes that you will encourage your undergraduates to submit their work and that you will save the date so you can attend and help to celebrate the extraordinary creativity and ingenuity of our students. Since its inception in 2011, the Symposium has grown to become a major campus event to showcase our top scholars, with the 2017 Symposium including 292 presenters and 177 faculty mentors, and spanning 60 majors and eight colleges.

Additional information about the Symposium is available on our website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/>. Here are the highlights:

  *   The 2018 Symposium will take place on Thursday, May 17 in the EMU and will include a catered reception at 5pm with a keynote address and a ceremony to announce the recipients of the Excellence in Faculty Mentoring Award.
  *   Abstracts for student presentations at the 2018 event are due by 11:59 pm PST on Friday, March 16 and are submitted via the Undergraduate Research Symposium website (http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/<https://t.e2ma.net/click/0dy7u/40210g/0duw3i>).
  *   The abstract submission link will \xe2\x80\x9cgo live\xe2\x80\x9d on December 7, 2017. Questions about submissions should be directed to ugresearch at uoregon.edu<mailto:ugresearch at uoregon.edu>.
  *   We have two information sessions for students planned for Thursday, January 11 from 3-4pm and Monday, March 5 from 4-5pm in the Global Scholars Hall Learning Commons.
  *   The full event agenda will be available on the Symposium website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/> on January 1, 2018, including poster, oral, creative work, FIG/ARC, and Data Stories sessions.
  *   The schedule for winter and spring term workshops for abstract writing, poster design, and oral presentations is available on the Symposium website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/>.
  *   The list of 2018 presenter awards and eligibility criteria will also be updated on the Symposium website<http://undergradsymposium.uoregon.edu/>.
If you'd like to be involved as an abstract reviewer, panel moderator, or judge, or have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us.

Thank you for your help making this event a success!

Sincerely,

Josh Snodgrass                                                                      Kevin Hatfield
Associate Vice Provost for Undergraduate Studies         Director of Academic Residential & Research Initiatives

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: NCAASE Launch of Did You Know'
html:
b'
Hello COE Faculty,

The following message is being forwarded to you on behalf of Ed Kame'enui, Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development.

________________________________
From: Gerald Tindal <gerald.tindal at icloud.com<mailto:gerald.tindal at icloud.com>>
Date: Friday, December 15, 2017 at 8:39 PM
To: Uk O <Jacquelyn.Buckley at ed.gov<mailto:Jacquelyn.Buckley at ed.gov>>
Subject: NCAASE Launch of Did You Know


The National Center on Assessment and Accountability for Special Education (NCAASE) is a 12 million dollar research center funded by the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) over the past five years with Joe Stevens and myself as PI's and Joe Nese as a Director. The NCAASE is launching a series of Did You Know or (DYK), research briefs based on our recent studies we are completing or have recently completed. These documents are designed to display an important finding with an 'easy to read' graph that can be quickly scanned and interpreted.

The research findings focus on several issues with large-scale assessment systems: Growth and gaps for students with disabilities, outcomes from interim assessments and their relations with state tests, alternate assessment outcomes, and opportunity to learn in a standards-based environment.

We have attached the first DYK and hope you find it useful. This and future DYKs will be available at the NCAASE website (ncaase.com<http://ncaase.com>) along with other publications, technical reports, In-Briefs, and presentations.  Please go to the link in this email to get all the information on the center.

We plan on distributing them on a regular basis as we consolidate our past five years of research. Please distribute to others you believe would benefit from having access to these documents.


Thank you.

NCAASE Researchers: Steve Elliott - ASU, Joe Nese - UO, Ann Schulte - ASU, Joe Stevens - UO, and Gerald Tindal - UO

subject: b'coe-fac: Questions about Revised Common Rule'
html:
b'
In preparation for implementation of the revised Common Rule going into effect January 19th, 2018, RCS in collaboration with members of the institutional board are seeking questions about the changes in the regulations from researchers in the College of Education and other colleges conducting research involving human subjects. As Vice Chair of the IRB, I have been charged with collecting questions from researchers in the College of Education specifically. I have developed a link to a Qualtrics survey in which you can enter all your questions, https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_50B2OExeNKClykd. The questions will be compiled into a question and answer document that will be developed and disseminated by RCS. Please take a moment to submit your questions.

If you are not familiar with the revised regulations, you can review the Common Rule Web page found here: http://rcs.uoregon.edu/content/research-involving-human-subjects/changes-to-common-rule. The webpage covers some of the key changes including:

  *   Revisions and additions to the exempt review categories and the addition of a limited IRB review process for some exempt research

  *   Changes to continuing review requirements, including elimination of continuing review for many studies that pose minimal risk to participants
  *   Changes to the informed consent process and form, including a new requirement for presenting key information and a new requirement for clinical trials to post the informed consent form on a public website
  *   Additional provisions for handling, storage and maintenance of identifiable information and biospecimens
  *   Requirements for single-IRB oversight starting in 2020 for most collaborative research projects.  Note: NIH has separate single-IRB requirements for multi-center studies which go into effect in late January 2018.

Please follow the survey link to ask your questions about the revised common rule: https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_50B2OExeNKClykd
Thank you,

---
Dawn A. Rowe, Ph.D.
Research Associate Professor/Technical Assistance Provider
University of Oregon
National Technical Assistance Center on Transition
541-346-8412
drowe3 at uoregon.edu
http://transitionta.org/

subject: b'coe-fac: Reminder: State of UO Research Talk, 3 p.m., Jan. 9'
text:
b'The following message is being forwarded to you on behalf of Ed Kame'enui, Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development:

Greetings ROC and COE Faculty:  I am forwarding the email below to remind everyone about David Conover's talk tomorrow, Tuesday, January 9th at 3 p.m. on The State of UO Research in the ERB Memorial Union Crater Lake South/North Rooms.  I encourage you to attend-rumor has it that COE research will be highlighted.

All the best, Ed


From: David Conover <vpri at uoregon.edu<mailto:vpri at uoregon.edu>>
Reply-To: V P for Research & Innovation Office <vpri at uoregon.edu<mailto:vpri at uoregon.edu>>
Date: Monday, January 8, 2018 at 10:31 AM
To: "Dr. Kame'enui" <ekamee at uoregon.edu<mailto:ekamee at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: Reminder: State of UO Research Talk, 3 p.m., Jan. 9

A message from David Conover



[niversity of Oregon]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/o89f5l>





[ffice of the Vice President for Research and Innovation (OVPRI)]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/40ag5l>






Dear Members of the UO Research Community:



I'd like to invite you to attend my talk on The State of UO Research <https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/ktbg5l> tomorrow, Jan. 9, at 3 p.m. in the Erb Memorial Union Crater Lake South/North Room. UO President Michael S. Schill and Provost Jayanth Banavar will give opening and closing remarks, respectively.
It's an exciting time for research at the UO right now, and I look forward to celebrating some of our recent successes with all of you. As we reflect on where we've been and look ahead to the future, I will take questions from you and outline some goals for our continued growth and evolution as a research institution.
I hope you will join me for an engaging and informative look at discovery and innovation at the UO.




[avid Conover]

David Conover
Vice President for Research & Innovation,
vpri at uoregon.edu<mailto:vpri at uoregon.edu>
541-346-2090









[ffice of the Vice President for Research and Innovation (OVPRI)]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/0lcg5l>

About OVPRI<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/gedg5l>



The Office of the Vice President for Research and Innovation (OVPRI)<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/w6dg5l> promotes excellence in research at the University of Oregon - the state's only Association of American Universities member. Research, both basic and applied, is fundamental to the mission of the University and is essential to Oregon's economic and civic vitality. The office is committed to enhancing these efforts by providing administrative and financial support for sponsored programs, including identification of funding opportunities, proposal submission, research compliance, and contracts and grant administration.








Find Oregon Research online:



[witter]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/czeg5l>

[acebook]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/srfg5l>

[nstagram]<https://t.e2ma.net/click/cfrsz/wah90g/8jgg5l>






Office of the Vice President for Research and Innovation
677 E 12th Ave. Suite 500, Eugene, OR 97401




You are receiving this email because you are an active faculty member, currently enrolled graduate student, or supporter of research and graduate education at the University of Oregon.







Share this email:

[http://d1v4jtnvxv2013.cloudfront.net/media/images/themes/editor/img/socialnetworks/social-email.png]<https://t.e2ma.net/share/outbound/e/cfrsz/wah90g>

[http://d1v4jtnvxv2013.cloudfront.net/media/images/themes/editor/img/socialnetworks/social-twitter.png]<https://t.e2ma.net/share/outbound/t/cfrsz/wah90g>

subject: b'coe-fac: Welcome back from the UO Libraries'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

Happy first day of winter classes! I hope you had a good intersession.

I hope you will get in touch with me this term if I or the Libraries can support your teaching or research. As a reminder, I can visit your class (or they can visit the library) for library instruction. Also, if you have any purchase suggestions for our library collection (particularly books/ebooks, DVDs/films, or children's books for the  juvenile collection), pass them along and I'll be happy to consider them, budget permitting.

I'm also available for research consultation appointments<http://uoregon.libcal.com/appointment/24599> if you'd like to send any of your students my way.

I look forward to working with you this term.

Best,
Katherine

--
Katherine S. Donaldson
Social Sciences/Education Librarian
University of Oregon Libraries
1299 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1299
Phone: 541-346-4132
kdonalds at uoregon.edu<mailto:kdonalds at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: 2018-19 COE Scholarship Application - Due January 19!'
html:
b'
Apply for a 2018-19 College of Education Scholarship: http://education.uoregon.edu/scholarships



The College of Education scholarship program provides a significant number of donor-supported awards to COE students. Most awards are from $1,500-$10,000. Instructions and applications are available online at: http://education.uoregon.edu/scholarships.



APPLICATION DEADLINE: Friday, January 19, 2018 by 4:00 pm.



Please contact Andrea Olson with any questions regarding these scholarships. Phone: 541-346-5943, email: coescholarships at uoregon.edu<mailto:coescholarships at uoregon.edu>.

________________________________
I support all students regardless of immigration status or country of origin. As a DREAMer Ally, I support Dreamer students and promote their sense of belonging and safety as thy pursue their higher education goals. For more information and resources please visit our Dreamers<https://blogs.uoregon.edu/dreamers/> page and the Find Support<https://blogs.uoregon.edu/dreamers/find-support/> page. I commit to keeping your status confidential if you reveal it to me, but also remind you that when interacting with faculty, staff, and offices around campus you are never required to reveal your immigration status.
________________________________

subject: b'coe-fac: Opportunity to encourage freshmen students of color to consider your major and research by agreeing to a brief interview this term'
html:
b'
The following message is being forwarded to you on behalf of Ed Kame'enui, Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development:

Dear COE faculty researchers,
*Are you interested in involving underrepresented undergrad students in your research?

*Would you be willing to talk briefly (approx. 15 min.) this term to one of our students from the Community for Multicultural Scholars Academic Residential Community (CMS ARC) regarding your research?

If you said "Yes" to either question, please provide your contact information on this Qualtrics link by Friday, Jan. 26.
https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_6QgMv6CLJ7epdad

Sincerely,
Jeanne Nagayama Hall
CMS ARC faculty director

P.S. For more information:
Freshmen students have an opportunity to live in a residential floor that is a designated ARC (academic residential community) for a particular academic or identity interest.  Those students in the Multicultural Scholars ARC wish to support students of color in their cultural and other identities, including their identity as scholars.
Many freshmen only know of their general career interest, and they are not aware of the many different research possibilities in your academic area. Also, for underrepresented students, and especially for first-generation college students, students may not have heard how to specifically develop their undergraduate years in order to prepare themselves for graduate school and a career.
During this term, the CMS ARC students will be assigned to very briefly interview (approx. 15 min.) a faculty researcher in their interested academic area. If you are open to being briefly interviewed, please fill out the above Qualtrics link to be on our list of available faculty researchers. Our students will then choose to contact a faculty researcher based on their interest. The student will email the faculty person before Week 7, and then set up a brief interview appointment within Weeks 7-9.


-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: Message from Research Compliance Services'
html:
b'
Hi all. I apologize if you have already received this message. RCS has received notice from the Office of Human Research Protections (OHRP) that the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and 15 other federal departments and agencies have announced an Interim Final Rule (IFR) that delays the revised \xe2\x80\x9cFederal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects\xe2\x80\x9d (also known as the Common Rule) which was scheduled to go into effect January 19, 2018.  The IFR delays the effective date and general compliance date of the revisions to the Common Rule to July 19, 2018.  For the full text of the federal register notice, click here<https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/01/22/2018-00997/federal-policy-for-the-protection-of-human-subjects-delay-of-the-revisions-to-the-federal-policy-for>.

Until July 19, 2018, institutions are required to comply with the pre-2018 Common Rule.  RCS has reviewed our most recently developed and issued materials to ensure only those that continue to comply with the pre-2018 Common Rule are available to the research community.

RCS will continue to keep the research community informed through our dedicated Revised Common Rule<http://orcr.uoregon.edu/content/research-involving-human-subjects/changes-to-common-rule> website.  Please feel free to contact Research Compliance Services with any questions.

We request that you share this message with your colleagues conducting human subject research to ensure they are informed of this news.

Thank you,
Research Compliance Services

Research Compliance Services
researchcompliance at uoregon.edu<mailto:researchcompliance at uoregon.edu>
541-346-2510
rcs.uoregon.edu<http://rcs.uoregon.edu/>


---
Dawn A. Rowe, Ph.D.
Research Associate Professor/Technical Assistance Provider
University of Oregon
National Technical Assistance Center on Transition
541-346-8412
drowe3 at uoregon.edu
http://transitionta.org/

subject: b'coe-fac: Delay of the Revised Common Rule Protecting Human Subjects in Research'
html:

The following message is being forwarded to you on behalf of Ed Kame\xe2\x80\x99enui, Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development:

Dear Research Community,

 We received notice from the Office of Human Research Protections (OHRP) that the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and 15 other federal departments and agencies have announced an Interim Final Rule (IFR) that delays the revised \xe2\x80\x9cFederal Policy for the Protection of Human Subjects\xe2\x80\x9d (also known as the Common Rule) which was scheduled to go into effect January 19, 2018.  Until July 19, 2018, institutions are required to comply with the pre-2018 Common Rule.  RCS has reviewed our most recently developed and issued materials to ensure only those that continue to comply with the pre-2018 Common Rule are available to the research community.

 RCS will continue to keep the research community informed through our dedicated Revised Common Rule<http://orcr.uoregon.edu/content/research-involving-human-subjects/changes-to-common-rule> website.  Please feel free to contact Research Compliance Services with any questions.

subject: b'coe-fac: RSVP today: Free Workshop with The Conversation Executive\tDirector'
html:
b'
Hello all,

The executive director of The Conversation, Bruce Wilson, will be on campus February 15-16. While there will be a broader session for all faculty on campus, I have negotiated for us to have our own COE focused workshop for our faculty members interested in learning how to write for the site\xe2\x80\x99s non-academic audiences.

What: Free COE Workshop with The Conversation
When: Thursday, February 15 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm
Where: HEDCO 230-T

As a recap from Kyle Henley and Molly Blancett\xe2\x80\x99s presentation at our last Faculty and Staff meeting, The Conversation is an independent, nonprofit publisher of commentary and analysis, authored by academics and edited by journalists for the general public. The site publishes short articles (800-1,000 words) by academics on timely topics related to their research. By writing, academics can reach audiences in publications locally, nationally, and internationally. Stories are regularly republished in large national outlets such as The Washington Post, Time, Newsweek, CNN, Scientific American and many more. Through partnerships with The Associated Press and Community Newspaper Holdings, Inc. articles are picked up in local newspapers \xe2\x80\x93 providing analysis in communities that may not otherwise hear from these academics. Many of our peer faculty at other universities across the country and around the world are also paying attention to what The Conversation is publishing, or stories that are republished from this site.

During the workshop, Wilson will guide attendees through how to craft a pitch and advise them on what it takes to write for The Conversation.

Wilson is a former publisher of The Chronicles of Higher Education and Philanthropy. He also served as the director of higher education at NBC Learn.

To learn more about The Conversation, click on this link<http://theconversation.com/us/introduction?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Expert%20Request%20the%20lure%20of%20unhealthy%20food%20Taye%20lawsuit%20and%20more&utm_content=Expert%20Request%20the%20lure%20of%20unhealthy%20food%20Taye%20lawsuit%20and%20more+CID_e29ed45ef36e76082e9c68567d669480&utm_source=campaign_monitor_us&utm_term=send%20them%20this%20link>.

To attend, email Molly Blancett at blancett at uoregon.edu<mailto:blancett at uoregon.edu>.

While we encourage you to attend this workshop specific to the COE, if you are unable to make this time, you are encouraged to join the university-wide workshop scheduled the following day:
What: All UO Workshop with The Conversation
When: Friday from 10:30 am -11:30 am
Where: EMU Lease Crutcher Room 23.

I hope you all can attend.

Best,
Jessica

Jessica Roberts
Director of Communications
College of Education
541.346.8979

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20180201/8eec2757/attachment.html>

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Professional Development Funds Available - Applications Due February 19'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Randy Kamphaus

Dear Faculty,

I continue to be impressed with the professional development activities in which you engage to advance the quality and reach of your scholarship and teaching. I want to further support these activities. I am providing Faculty Professional Development funds for which all College faculty may apply. A total of $2,500 may be requested each academic year. Current applications will be accepted until February 19.  Applications for expenses that have been incurred within the last 6 months may be reimbursed. Funding priority is given to professional development activities that advance your research productivity and/or teaching quality.

To apply, please click on the link below. Please direct any questions about the application to Andrea Olson, andreao at uoregon.edu<mailto:andreao at uoregon.edu>.

https://coe.uoregon.edu/facultyfundawards/request-for-professional-development-funds/

Thank you,
Randy

For scheduling, please contact Maggie Bosworth at  magboz at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20magboz at uoregon.edu> or 541-346-6467.
________________________________
[COE logo]

R.W. Kamphaus, Ph.D. | Professor and Dean
randyk at uoregon.edu<mailto:randyk at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-3405
HEDCO 130
1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: SAVE THE DATE: Cocktails with Oregon COE in NYC Saturday,\tApril 14'
html:
b'
For those attending the AERA conference, here is our \xe2\x80\x98Save the Date\xe2\x80\x99 for the event.  We\xe2\x80\x99ll be sending out an invitation with an RSVP link at the beginning of March.


Mark this date on your calendar for the annual College of Education Cocktail Reception during the AERA conference
View this email in a web page<http://www.uofoundation.org/controls/email_marketing/admin/email_marketing_email_viewer.aspx?sid=1540&eiid=9409&seiid=0&usearchive=1&puid=4971c251-1235-4bee-81bb-d8e449743c8b>
[UO Logo]



[http://www.uofoundation.org/s/1540/images/gid2/editor/stewardship/email_content/aera2018_w-logo_640x300.png]

SAVE THE DATE


Join us for our AERA Cocktail Reception
Hosted by: University of Oregon College of Education

When: Saturday, April 14
6:30 p.m.\xe2\x80\x938:30 p.m.

Where: University Club of New York, 9th Floor
One West 54th Street

The AERA Annual Meeting is the largest gathering of scholars in the field of education research. It is a showcase for ground-breaking, innovative studies in a diverse array of areas related to education. This year\xe2\x80\x99s conference will feature numerous research projects from faculty members and researchers from the University of Oregon\xe2\x80\x99s College of Education.

We invite you to join us for cocktails and conversation to learn more about our research while we are in NYC for this compelling event, and celebrate our faculty's exciting discoveries during this important event.

QUESTIONS? Email Lisa Fortin at LFORTIN at UOREGON.EDU<mailto:LFORTIN at UOREGON.EDU>


Invitations with complete details will be sent in March.




education.uoregon.edu<http://education.uoregon.edu/>

University of Oregon
College of Education
coeevents at uoregon.edu<mailto:coeevents at uoregon.edu>
541-346-1607



<http://www.education.uoregon.edu/>








You are receiving this message based on your affiliation with the University of Oregon.
University of Oregon \xe2\x80\xa2 1720 E. 13th Avenue, Suite 312 \xe2\x80\xa2 Eugene, OR 97403-2253

If you wish to be removed from this group's mailing list, click here<http://www.uofoundation.org?sid=1540&gid=2&pgid=37&cid=51&seiid=0&ecatid=29&puid=4971c251-1235-4bee-81bb-d8e449743c8b>

Invitations with complete details will be sent in March.

subject: b'coe-fac: REMINDER PLEASE RSVP: Workshop with The Conversation Executive Director'
html:
b'
Hello all,

This is just a reminder and some encouragement to attend The Conversation workshop scheduled for Thursday February 15, 3:30-4:30 in HEDCO 230T.

As I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you\xe2\x80\x99re all too aware, one of the key things that can help to establish your reputations as leading national experts is publishing. This of course first refers to peer-reviewed research, but then secondly as published editorial content to a broader audience both nationally and globally. The latter helps us increase the interest of others in our peer-reviewed research, both mainstream audiences and peer researchers who may have missed journal publications. Secondly, inclusion of our experts in mainstream news outlets can elevate the reputation of our college and increase recruitment amongst Master\xe2\x80\x99s and Doctoral students \xe2\x80\x93 we know from surveys and research that students are drawn to colleges with esteemed faculty - particularly graduate level students who will often be researching alongside these experts. While I am here to support our college in establishing greater awareness of our programs and faculty, pieces crafted directly by faculty that are published by The Conversation (and then often re-published by larger national outlets) is by far one of the best ways to highlight your work and expertise.

I encourage you to attend this great workshop to establish a connection with the Executive Director of The Conversation, and to also gain tips and insights on what makes a topic most appealing for publication.

Please RSVP via email Molly.Blancett at uoregon.edu<mailto:Molly.Blancett at uoregon.edu> or Robertsj at uoregon.edu<mailto:Robertsj at uoregon.edu> so we can ensure we have enough space and an appropriate set-up for the number of participants.

If you cannot attend our COE-specific workshop, we encourage you to attend the university-wide workshop the following day (details in the message below).

Best,
Jessica

Jessica Roberts
Director of Communications
College of Education
541.346.8979


From: Jessica Roberts <robertsj at uoregon.edu>
Date: Thursday, February 1, 2018 at 9:58 AM
To: "coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu" <coe-fac at lists.uoregon.edu>
Cc: Molly Blancett <blancett at uoregon.edu>
Subject: RSVP today: Free Workshop with The Conversation Executive Director

Hello all,

The executive director of The Conversation, Bruce Wilson, will be on campus February 15-16. While there will be a broader session for all faculty on campus, I have negotiated for us to have our own COE focused workshop for our faculty members interested in learning how to write for the site\xe2\x80\x99s non-academic audiences.

What: Free COE Workshop with The Conversation
When: Thursday, February 15 3:30 pm - 4:30 pm
Where: HEDCO 230-T

As a recap from Kyle Henley and Molly Blancett\xe2\x80\x99s presentation at our last Faculty and Staff meeting, The Conversation is an independent, nonprofit publisher of commentary and analysis, authored by academics and edited by journalists for the general public. The site publishes short articles (800-1,000 words) by academics on timely topics related to their research. By writing, academics can reach audiences in publications locally, nationally, and internationally. Stories are regularly republished in large national outlets such as The Washington Post, Time, Newsweek, CNN, Scientific American and many more. Through partnerships with The Associated Press and Community Newspaper Holdings, Inc. articles are picked up in local newspapers \xe2\x80\x93 providing analysis in communities that may not otherwise hear from these academics. Many of our peer faculty at other universities across the country and around the world are also paying attention to what The Conversation is publishing, or stories that are republished from this site.

During the workshop, Wilson will guide attendees through how to craft a pitch and advise them on what it takes to write for The Conversation.

Wilson is a former publisher of The Chronicles of Higher Education and Philanthropy. He also served as the director of higher education at NBC Learn.

To learn more about The Conversation, click on this link<http://theconversation.com/us/introduction?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Expert%20Request%20the%20lure%20of%20unhealthy%20food%20Taye%20lawsuit%20and%20more&utm_content=Expert%20Request%20the%20lure%20of%20unhealthy%20food%20Taye%20lawsuit%20and%20more+CID_e29ed45ef36e76082e9c68567d669480&utm_source=campaign_monitor_us&utm_term=send%20them%20this%20link>.


To attend, email Molly Blancett at blancett at uoregon.edu<mailto:blancett at uoregon.edu>.

While we encourage you to attend this workshop specific to the COE, if you are unable to make this time, you are encouraged to join the university-wide workshop scheduled the following day:
What: All UO Workshop with The Conversation
When: Friday from 10:30 am -11:30 am
Where: EMU Lease Crutcher Room 23.

I hope you all can attend.

Best,
Jessica

Jessica Roberts
Director of Communications
College of Education
541.346.8979

-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: FW: UO Student Success Summit'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Mike Jefferis


Please share with faculty and advisors in your department.  This message sent on the behalf of the Student Success Summit Planning Committee.
Save the Date! UO Student Success Summit, Friday, April 27, 2018
"UO Connected, UO Committed: Integrative Practices for Student Success"
Dear UO Colleagues:
Please save the date for our first UO Student Success Summit, "UO Connected, UO Committed: Integrative Practices for Student Success."
We are hoping that this inaugural summit will provide an opportunity for faculty, administrators, advisors, librarians, and other staff across campus to explore the perspectives, behaviors, and needs of successful students; to reflect on current and best practices; and to consider areas for enhancement.  The day is designed to be a dynamic, productive gathering focused on better understanding the success and the obstacles to success for undergraduates:

*         When: Friday, April 27, 2018, 9:00 am to 3:00 pm

*         Where: Global Scholars Hall Great Room

*         Keynote speaker: Tia Brown McNair, Vice President, Office of Diversity, Equity, and Student Success, Association of American Colleges and Universities

*         Remarks by President Michael Schill, Provost Jayanth Banavar, and Associate Vice Provost for Student Success Doneka Scott
There will be limited seating, so we are trying to gauge interest.  If you might be interested in attending, please fill out this very short form (https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_40Ytcr05bSTgZhz), and please save the date.
If you have any questions, please contact Shelley Harshe.
Shelley Harshe, UO Libraries
on behalf of the Planning Committee
Phone: 541-346-1891
Fax: 541-346-3485
Email: sharshe at uoregon.edu<mailto:sharshe at uoregon.edu>


-------------- next part --------------

subject: b'coe-fac: AERA Reception Invite, Saturday April 14'
html:
b'
Hello,

For those faculty and graduate students who are attending the AERA Conference in New York, the University of Oregon College of Education will be hosting a reception to showcase the great COE faculty and student research that is being presented.  The reception will be held on Saturday, April 14th from 6:30 \xe2\x80\x93 8:30 pm at the University Club of New York.  In addition to AERA attendees, we are inviting local COE alumni, giving them the chance to hang out, chat with faculty and students, and learn about the world class research the COE does.

Could you please let us know:

1)            If you will be in attendance at this conference; click here to RSVP<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_9RKrNNyhWW07pvT>;

2)            If you are making a presentation let us know what that presentation title is, along with the names of any co-presenters/authors;

3)              If you will be receiving any special recognition;

4)            Names and email addresses of any colleagues from other universities you would like us to personally invite.  Our event will be announced in the AERA conference program, so all AERA attendees will know about the reception.

Packing Note:  Please be advised of the University Club\xe2\x80\x99s dress code, which is in effect at all times. Men are required to wear jackets, dress shirts, and ties. Women are required to wear clothing meeting similar standards. Jeans, corduroy, shorts, capris, denim, sneakers, flip flops and other such casual sportswear are not considered appropriate attire.

I\xe2\x80\x99d like to add that they have put this dress code on every piece of communication that they have sent me, so I think they take it fairly seriously and may not admit people in what they deem inappropriate clothing.  Please make sure that guests you invite are aware of this.

Let me know if you have any questions!

Thanks,
Lisa



Mark this date on your calendar for the annual College of Education Cocktail Reception during the AERA conference

text:
b"Hello,

For those faculty and graduate students who are attending the AERA Conference in New York, the University of Oregon College of Education will be hosting a reception to showcase the great COE faculty and student research that is being presented.  The reception will be held on Saturday, April 14th from 6:30 \xe2\x80\x93 8:30 pm at the University Club of New York.  In addition to AERA attendees, we are inviting local COE alumni, giving them the chance to hang out, chat with faculty and students, and learn about the world class research the COE does.

Could you please let us know:

1)            If you will be in attendance at this conference; click here to RSVP<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_9RKrNNyhWW07pvT>;

2)            If you are making a presentation let us know what that presentation title is, along with the names of any co-presenters/authors;

3)              If you will be receiving any special recognition;

4)            Names and email addresses of any colleagues from other universities you would like us to personally invite.  Our event will be announced in the AERA conference program, so all AERA attendees will know about the reception.

Packing Note:  Please be advised of the University Club\xe2\x80\x99s dress code, which is in effect at all times. Men are required to wear jackets, dress shirts, and ties. Women are required to wear clothing meeting similar standards. Jeans, corduroy, shorts, capris, denim, sneakers, flip flops and other such casual sportswear are not considered appropriate attire.

I\xe2\x80\x99d like to add that they have put this dress code on every piece of communication that they have sent me, so I think they take it fairly seriously and may not admit people in what they deem inappropriate clothing.  Please make sure that guests you invite are aware of this.

Let me know if you have any questions!

Thanks,
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Night at the Faculty Club this Wednesday, March 7 from 5 to 6:30 pm'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

Please join me for an evening at the Faculty Club on Wednesday, March 7th from 5 - 6:30 pm. The Faculty Club operates weekly in the March\xc3\xa9 space at the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art. I hope you will be able to drop by and visit with your colleagues from throughout campus.

This COE Night at the Faculty Club is a joint effort between the University Senate and me. Our Senate leaders, Chris Sinclair and Bill Harbaugh, are seeking ways to encourage more faculty to seek positions on the Senate or any of the Senate's 30+ committees. The University Senate is scheduling similar events this term for as many of the colleges and schools as possible as it prepares for elections and the selection of committees that will occur during Spring Term.

I look forward to seeing you on Wednesday.

Randy


For scheduling, please contact Maggie Bosworth at  magboz at uoregon.edu<mailto:%20magboz at uoregon.edu> or 541-346-6467.
________________________________
[COE logo]

R.W. Kamphaus, Ph.D. | Professor and Dean
randyk at uoregon.edu<mailto:randyk at uoregon.edu> | 541-346-3405

1215 University of Oregon | Eugene, OR 97403

subject: b'coe-fac: UO Libraries Digital Scholarship Center Faculty Grants (April 30, 2018)'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

I wanted to pass along this message about the UO Libraries Digital Scholarship Center\xe2\x80\x99s new internal grant program for UO faculty. Please see more information below. You can email dsc at uoregon.edu<mailto:dsc at uoregon.edu> with any questions or to consult on any project ideas.

Best,
Katherine


--
Katherine S. Donaldson
Social Sciences/Education Librarian
University of Oregon Libraries
1299 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1299
Phone: 541-346-4132
kdonalds at uoregon.edu<mailto:kdonalds at uoregon.edu>





It\xe2\x80\x99s my absolute pleasure to share with you the CFP for the Digital Scholarship Center Faculty Grant Program and to ask for your help in sharing widely:

CFP: Digital Scholarship Center Faculty Grant Program<https://dsc.uoregon.edu/funding/faculty-grants>

The University of Oregon Libraries\xe2\x80\x99 Digital Scholarship Center (DSC) has begun a new internal-UO grant program for faculty (individuals and small groups) interested in developing digital projects for research and teaching. This year, the Libraries will accept proposals until April 30, 2018, end of day. The Libraries will work with grant award winners to implement the selected digital projects sometime during the 2018-2019 academic year or earlier, depending upon the faculty members\xe2\x80\x99 availability. As needed, grantees will receive DSC design services, project management support, digital collection development, technology support, metadata consultation, and more from the Libraries. Collaborative projects that combine internal and external funding and other special programs are welcome.

Criteria for selection of projects and other guidelines are listed here: http://bit.ly/dscgrantfaq, but we particularly welcome projects that leverage UO Libraries\xe2\x80\x99 physical and digital resources and collections, and that address issues related to diversity, inclusion, and equity. Examples of proposals within the scope of the grants program include:


  *   Projects exploring open models for scholarly publishing, including journals, interactive reading experiences, digital storytelling, and TEI-encoded editions
  *   Digital exhibits featuring collections that are already held by the University of Oregon, which are instrumental in supporting learning, teaching, and research at University of Oregon. (Final selection of materials will be subject to ability to clear copyright, if required.)
  *   Projects exploring how data from a variety of disciplines can be visualized and mined to answer research questions

To complete a detailed grant proposal, please use this form: https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3JfzdLBAX02dpAh. You may download a copy of this form here: http://bit.ly/dldscproposal

No previous experience with digital tools or platforms is needed. If you are unsure about some of the questions or fields in the proposal form, please send us an email at dsc at uoregon.edu<mailto:dsc at uoregon.edu> and the Libraries\xe2\x80\x99 digital scholarship team will consult with you about your project idea and the proposal process. Please write to us or visit our website<https://dsc.uoregon.edu/funding/faculty-grants> for more information about our services.

Franny Gaede
Head, Digital Scholarship Services
University of Oregon Libraries
Knight Library 143
541-346-1854
library.uoregon.edu/dss<http://library.uoregon.edu/dss>

subject: b'coe-fac: Mock NIH and IES Grant Review Panels - Pls. respond by 3/16'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Ed Kame'enui and Elizabeth Skowron

The COE associate dean for research's office and I are organizing a set of mock NIH and IES grant review panels in Spring term for junior and mid-level faculty to learn about the grant review process.  Highlights:  COE faculty who are experienced NIH reviewers will engage in an authentic review of a funded research proposal (e.g., NIH R series:  R01, R21).  The grant proposal will be shared with attending faculty in advance.  During a 90-minute session devoted to NIH review, and a second 90-minute session focused on an IES review, we'll provide an overview of what happens during a study section/or review panel meeting, watch the review process unfold, and allocate ample time for Q & A.  Light refreshments will be provided.

https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_09DNgcg44gsUSIB

Please complete your response by Friday, March 16th.





[COE-3435-CGY11-2]

subject: b'coe-fac: AERA brochure listing'
html:
b'
Hello,
As AERA is just around the corner, we are pulling together the information for our AERA brochure.  This brochure is a listing of all the presentations, poster sessions and etc., that have the participation of someone from the College of Education.  Attached is a rough draft of the brochure text.  If you are on the list below, please review the attached document to ensure your sessions are listed correctly.  Unfortunately, the NCME online program only lists presentations by the session title and does not include the name of the presenter.  If you are presenting at NCME and haven't yet done so, please send me the title and time of your presentations so we can add them to the list.
For faculty who are attending, but don't appear on the list below, please email me and let me know you are attending AERA so we can add your name to our brochure.
Thanks,
Lisa

subject: b'coe-fac: Updates from the UO Libraries'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

I hope you enjoyed spring break! Since it's the beginning of a new quarter I thought I would share a couple new resources we have at UO Libraries as well as a few quick reminders.

Over spring break, the UO Libraries implemented BrowZine<https://browzine.com/libraries/38/subjects>, a new service that allows you to discover, browse, and read scholarly journals. This service aims to improve the discovery and customized viewing of the library's e-journal content. The E-journals A-Z list on the library main page will now take you to BrowZine, however the old A-Z list is still accessible if you need it. For more information and FAQs about BrowZine, please see this page: https://researchguides.uoregon.edu/browzine If you have any feedback, please send it my way.

I also wanted to let you know if you were not aware that we now have access to the Education Week site<https://login.libproxy.uoregon.edu/login?qurl=https%3a%2f%2fwww.edweek.org%2few%2findex.html>. Due to IP address complications with the vendor, you will need to login to use this resource even if you are on campus, but they are working on a solution.

As always, if you'd like me to do an instruction session on library resources/information literacy, I'd be happy to visit your class or host your class in one of the library classrooms. I'm also available for research consultation appointments<http://uoregon.libcal.com/appointment/24599>.

Please get in touch if I can support your teaching or research this term or if you have any questions or suggestions about library resources.

Best,
Katherine

--
Katherine S. Donaldson
Social Sciences/Education Librarian
University of Oregon Libraries
1299 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403-1299
Phone: 541-346-4132
kdonalds at uoregon.edu<mailto:kdonalds at uoregon.edu>

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20180402/57a946f7/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: COE FACULTY FUND AWARDS - CALL FOR PROPOSALS'
html:
b'
COLLEGE OF EDUCATION FACULTY FUND AWARDS
Proposal for Project Grant<https://coe.uoregon.edu/facultyfundawards/>
PRELIMINARY PROPOSAL DEADLINE: APRIL 13, 2018

The College of Education's Faculty Fund Awards provide financial support for the innovative ideas that contribute to the development of the early career of our faculty members. Funding is meant to catalyze projects and help faculty members achieve sustainability.
Eligibility:

*         All College of Education faculty (FTE of .5 or greater) are eligible to apply for awards, both NTTF and Tenure Faculty.

*         The Kruger Award is available for the three career development units (IntoCareers, CIS, and Destny).

*         The Skippen Award is available for EMPL faculty only.

*         All COE department faculty are eligible for the Andrea Wiggins Fund for Faculty Outreach and the Judson and Elise Taylor Fund.
Applications will be based on meritorious factors that include:

*         Projects not currently funded by internal or external sources and require an investment to position the work for external research support in the future,

*         Projects for which few sources of external funding are available, and

*         Applicants that have not received a faculty fund award in the past three years.
APPLICATION STEPS:

*         Complete and submit the proposal application by April 13, 2018: Proposal for Project Grant<https://coe.uoregon.edu/facultyfundawards/>

*         Deans of the College of Education will notify applicants being considered by April 23, 2018.

*         Preliminary proposal applicants chosen will submit fuller proposals that:

o   Develop the design and implementation plans

o   Propose a plan to evaluate the initiative

o   Propose a detailed budget. Please get input from your business manager as you develop a budget to insure that all proposed costs are reasonable and allowable.

*         Final applications will be due April 27, 2018. Applications will be reviewed and award decisions made by the deans of the College of Education. The COE Office of

Development will review applications for alignment with the fund's intention.
Project funding will be announced by May 4, 2018.

*         Lead faculty in any funded project will give an annual written update to the donor. The awardees will also provide the COE Office of Development with necessary narrative and fiscal information to submit an annual report to the donor on the use and impact of funds.




________________________________

subject: b'coe-fac: COE BANEY FUND GUEST SPEAKER AWARD - CALL FOR PROPOSALS'
html:
b'
Baney Fund Guest Speaker Award
Proposal for Guest Speaker Grant from the Hope Baney Fund Award<https://coe.uoregon.edu/facultyfundawards/>
PRELIMINARY PROPOSAL DEADLINE: APRIL 13, 2018

The College of Education's Hope Baney Fund provides financial support for faculty presentations and outreach. Funding is available to host up to four guest speakers to the UO College of Education. Awards will be $3,000 each.

The Hope Baney Fund was established through the will of Hope Baney to support lectureships on significant issues affecting education and short term projects undertaken by College of Education faculty.

Eligibility: All College of Education faculty (FTE of .5 or greater) are eligible to apply for awards, both NTTF and Tenure Faculty.

APPLICATIONS WILL BE BASED ON MERITORIOUS FACTORS THAT INCLUDE:


*         Speakers which are not yet funded or have no other funding sources available

*         Speakers in a current area of priority or importance for the college

*         High visibility projects


Application Steps:

*         Complete and submit this proposal application by April 13, 2018.

*         Deans of the College of Education will notify applicants being considered by April 23, 2018.

*         Preliminary proposal applicants chosen will submit fuller proposals that:

o   Develop the design and implementation plans

o   Propose a plan to evaluate the initiative

o   Propose a detailed budget

*         Final applications will be due April 27, 2018. Applications will be reviewed and award decisions made by the deans of the College of Education. The COE Office of Development will review applications for alignment with the fund's intention.

*
Project funding will be announced by May 4, 2018.

*         The awardees will provide the COE Office of Development with necessary narrative and fiscal information.


________________________________

subject: b'coe-fac: Workshop on Conducting Human Subject Research Involving Children & Teens'
html:
b'
Hello faculty and staff in the college of education.  I am excited to announce a workshop being offered by Research Compliance Services for the College of Education. Please join your colleagues on May 3, 2018 at 2pm in HEDCO 230T to learn more about ethical considerations, Instructional Review Board (IRB) requirements, and best practices in conducting human subject research involving children and teens. See attached flyer for more details including a link for registration.

If you are not available May 3rd, RCS is offering other workshops. Below are some of the planned workshops.  Visit RCS\xe2\x80\x99s education and outreach page for more information about their education and outreach program, future offerings, and the current office hours schedule: http://rcs.uoregon.edu/content/education-training.

Upcoming Workshops*
IRB Submission and Protocol Development

April 11, 2018; 2:00 - 3:30 p.m.

How to Write a Research Plan for IRB Review

April 12, 2018; 2:00 - 3:30 p.m.

Human Subject Research with Children & Teens

May 3, 2018; 2:00 \xe2\x80\x93 4:00 p.m.

IRB Submission and Protocol Development

May 8, 2018; 10:00 - 11:30 a.m.

How to Write a Research Plan for IRB Review

May 9, 2018; 10:00 - 11:30 a.m.

IRB Submission and Protocol Development

August 22, 2018; 10:00 - 11:30 a.m.

How to Write a Research Plan for IRB Review

August 23, 2018; 10:00 - 11:30 a.m.


*Registration for faculty and staff is facilitated through HR MyTrack<http://odt.uoregon.edu/registration/>.  Students not employed by the UO can register by contacting our office.

---
Dawn A. Rowe, Ph.D.
Research Associate Professor/Technical Assistance Provider
University of Oregon
National Technical Assistance Center on Transition
541-346-8412
drowe3 at uoregon.edu
http://transitionta.org/

subject: b'coe-fac: April 30th Deadline for UO Libraries Digital Scholarship Center Faculty Grants'
html:
b'
Hello COE faculty,

I wanted to remind you of the opportunity to apply for the UO Libraries Digital Scholarship Center's (DSC) new internal grant program for UO faculty. This grant is for faculty members who are interested in developing digital projects for research and teaching. The deadline for proposals is April 30th by end of day.

Please see the attachment for more information. Contact dsc at uoregon.edu<mailto:dsc at uoregon.edu> with questions or to consult on any project ideas.

Best,
Katherine

--
Katherine S. Donaldson
Social Sciences/Education Librarian
University of Oregon Libraries
1299 University of Oregon

subject: b'coe-fac: Freedom of Expression Symposium -- College of Education, University of Oregon'
html:
b'
Dear  Faculty and Students,

The College of Education is hosting an event as part of the School of Journalism\xe2\x80\x99s Freedom of Expression series. This interactive event is entitled \xe2\x80\x9cRaising Student Voice: Freedom of Expression Symposium\xe2\x80\x9d and is dedicated to exploring the challenges and questions that high school and college educators, policymakers, administrators, and students face when enacting policies and practices intended to strengthen supports for freedom of expression on their respective campuses.

We also hope to identify ways to ensure that students who are entering higher education can be prepared for an environment in which ideas may be more challenging, and more frequently challenged, than in their previous educational settings. We believe that open and honest discourse is a good first step towards fostering a better understanding of the different points of view and considerations that will ultimately help us as we craft best-practice solutions for future educational stakeholders.

 Please read on for full details and to RSVP (below).

What: Raising Student Voice: Freedom of Expression Symposium involving high school students, policymakers, higher education researchers, and educational professional and leaders

Who: High school students, COE Faculty, state and local education leaders, and other community members who are either currently involved in or preparing to enter our educational systems

Learn more about:


  *   What does \xe2\x80\x9cfree speech\xe2\x80\x9d mean in Oregon schools? How is it fostered in developmentally appropriate ways?
  *   How do schools empower student voice and nurture ideas, even when the ideas are potentially controversial?
  *   How do schools support the students in developing skills to engage in discourse about uncomfortable ideas/opinions?
  *   Can schools support \xe2\x80\x9cfreedom of expression\xe2\x80\x9d and yet remain neutral spaces for learning?
  *   How do educational professionals develop learning opportunities for students when they\xe2\x80\x99re exposed to potentially controversial expressions?

When: April 30, 2018  12:00 \xe2\x80\x93 3:00 p.m. PST

Where:  Erb Memorial Union (EMU) UO Campus, Redwood Room. Refreshments will be served.

The event will feature a tiered-panel discussion to address these, and other, key questions. Professor and Knight Chair Charles Martinez, who is also Chairperson of the Oregon Board of Education, will serve as the university convener and moderator and will address these questions.
The event will feature three sections each lasting approximately one hour:
\xc2\xb7         Framing of the issues
\xc2\xb7         Student panel discussion
\xc2\xb7         Discussion roundtable with all participants
Due to the interactive nature of this event, we request that you RSVP to hold your spot at a table.  Click here to RSVP.<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_8cOWZkAmTzXGT09&Q_JFE=0>
This event is part of a series of Freedom of Expression events<https://president.uoregon.edu/free-expression> that are being held by the University of Oregon.

We hope that you can attend.


Dianna

Dianna Carrizales-Engelmann, Ph.D.,

Director of Administration
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
(541) 346-5407

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20180410/c7b05db6/attachment-0001.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: NIH Mock Grant Review Workshop'
html:
b'
The following message is from the Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development, Dr. Edward J. Kame\xe2\x80\x99enui, and Dr. Elizabeth Skowron, Professor, Department of Counseling Psychology and Human Services (CPHS):

Dear Colleagues:

Please join us for an NIH Mock Grant Review Workshop hosted by the UO College of Education on Wednesday, April 18, 2018, 3:30 to 5:00 pm in the Gerlinger Lounge. Light refreshments will be served.

The purpose of the workshop is to provide faculty with an introduction to the NIH submission and review process, learn about the NIH R-mechanisms (e.g., R01, R21, R03), and observe a \xe2\x80\x9cMock Panel\xe2\x80\x9d comprised of experienced NIH reviewers, discuss, review, and score an NIH grant proposal.  Following the mock review, the panelists will invite audience questions and discussion.  The NIH grant proposal to be reviewed will be sent in advance to attendees who register for the workshop.

Moderator: Elizabeth Skowron
Reviewers:  Rob Horner, Dave DeGarmo, & Elliot Berkman

Register here: https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_bDdHNeM7emCjMMZ



Edward J. Kame'enui, Ph.D.
Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education
Office Phone: (541) 346-1644
Email: ekamee at uoregon.edu<mailto:ekamee at uoregon.edu>

subject: b'coe-fac: IES Announcement Question'
html:
b'
The following message is from the Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development, Dr. Edward J. Kame'enui, and Dr. Elizabeth Skowron, Professor, Department of Counseling Psychology and Human Services (CPHS):

Dear Colleagues:

Please join us for an IES Mock Grant Review Workshop hosted by the UO College of Education on Wednesday, May 2, 2018, 3:30 to 5:00 pm in the Gerlinger Lounge. Light refreshments will be served.

The purpose of the workshop is to provide faculty with an introduction to the NIH submission and review process, learn about the NIH R-mechanisms (e.g., R01, R21, R03), and observe a "Mock Panel" comprised of experienced IES reviewers, discuss, review, and score an IES grant proposal.  Following the mock review, the panelists will invite audience questions and discussion.  The IES grant proposal to be reviewed will be sent in advance to attendees who register for the workshop.

subject: b'coe-fac: REMINDER:  NIH Mock Grant Review Panel tomorrow'
html:
b'
Tuesday, April 17, 2018


Please join us tomorrow for the first in a series of two workshops that the COE is sponsoring.  Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s workshop is a NIH \xe2\x80\x9cMock Panel\xe2\x80\x9d grant proposal review that provides faculty an opportunity to observe UO faculty researchers engaging in a Mock Panel discussion and review of a NIH grant proposal.  You are strongly encouraged to read the NIH proposal prior to attending to maximize your participation in tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s workshop.

Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s workshop runs from 3:30 \xe2\x80\x93 5 p.m. in the Gerlinger Lounge.

I hope you have a wonderful evening.

Diana


*** As a reminder the second workshop on Wednesday, May 2nd is an IES Mock Panel Workshop and is now open for registration.


Diana Jamison
Administrative Assistant
Dean\xe2\x80\x99s Office
College of Education
HEDCO 130
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR  97403-1215
541-346-6592
dianaj at uoregon.edu<mailto:dianaj at uoregon.edu>

You are strongly encouraged to read the NIH proposal prior to attending to maximize your participation in tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s workshop.

Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s workshop runs from 3:30 \xe2\x80\x93 5 p.m. in the Gerlinger Lounge.

I hope you have a wonderful evening.

Diana


*** As a reminder the second workshop on Wednesday, May 2nd is an IES Mock Panel Workshop and is now open for registration.


Diana Jamison
Administrative Assistant
Dean\xe2\x80\x99s Office
College of Education
HEDCO 130
1215 University of Oregon
Eugene, OR  97403-1215
541-346-6592

subject: b'coe-fac: Local Metrics Sessions scheduled'
html:
b'
The following message is sent to you on behalf of Dean Kamphaus:

Dear Faculty,

The deadline for colleges to submit their local metrics (college-specific research metrics associated with both TTF and NTTF research success) has been extended until June 1. The provost's office will be hosting a series of sessions on the topic of these metrics in an effort to support colleges in their individual discussions. The COE session is scheduled for Tuesday May 8th 12:00 - 1:00 in HEDCO 230T. All faculty are encouraged to attend.

Attached please find a spreadsheet that reflects some early cross-department thinking about the local metrics that may best define our (College of Education-specific) work. These were drafted from initial discussions with Department Heads (based on their early solicitations with department faculty), and the Faculty Advisory Committee.

An initial overview of the local metrics from the Provost's office is also attached.

Please use the following Qualtrics survey link https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_2gF622CIRoYz2jr to share any additional insights you may have in advance of the May 8th session hosted by the provost office. We will use the information you provide to enter that discussion with a shared sense of what may best represent and measure our research successes. The survey will remain open until May 18th to allow for adjustments after the session and to permit time for us to finalize our response as a college.

Randy



Dianna

Dianna Carrizales-Engelmann, Ph.D.,

Director of Administration and
College of Education
1215 University of Oregon
(541) 346-5407

subject: b'coe-fac: REGISTRATION REMINDER:  IES Mock Grant Review Workshop'
html:
b'
The following reminder is from the Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development, Dr. Edward J. Kame'enui, and Dr. Elizabeth Skowron, Professor, Department of Counseling Psychology and Human Services (CPHS):

Dear Colleagues:

Please join us for an IES Mock Grant Review Workshop hosted by the UO College of Education on Wednesday, May 2, 2018, 3:30 to 5:00 pm in the Gerlinger Lounge. Light refreshments will be served.

The purpose of the workshop is to provide faculty with an introduction to the IES submission and review process, learn about the IES R-mechanisms (e.g., R01, R21, R03), and observe a "Mock Panel" comprised of experienced IES reviewers, discuss, review, and score an IES grant proposal.  Following the mock review, the panelists will invite audience questions and discussion.  The IES grant proposal to be reviewed will be sent in advance to attendees who register for the workshop.

Moderator: Gina Biancarosa
Goal 2 Reviewers:  Hank Fien (R1), Keith Zvoch (R2), Ilana Umansky (R3), Ben Clarke (Note-taker)
Goal 3 Reviewers:  Kent McIntosh (R1), Ben Clarke (R2), Ilana Umansky (Note-taker)

Register here: https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_5tMr4kSeHWSbaAZ


Edward J. Kame'enui, Ph.D.
Associate Dean for Research and Faculty Development
College of Education
Office Phone: (541) 346-1644
Email: ekamee at uoregon.edu<mailto:ekamee at uoregon.edu>

Elizabeth A. Skowron, Ph.D.
Professor, Counseling Psychology & Human Services
Research Scientist, Center for Translational Neuroscience &
Prevention Science Institute
University of Oregon
Eugene, OR 97403
https://education.uoregon.edu/cphs
http://ctn.uoregon.edu/
http://psi.uoregon.edu/index.html
Tel. 541-346-0913

subject: b'coe-fac: Faculty Regalia Rental and Commencement Information'
html:
b'
Hello,
For those of you who don't own your own regalia, the COE will cover the cost for your rental for our graduation ceremony.  Rental regalia includes standard black gown and the appropriate hood for your Alma Mater. To guarantee exact hood colors please use the link below to make your order by May 11.  After that time it may be necessary to substitute a hood with the closest available colors or Oregon colors.
On the order form, choose the Spring 2018 ceremony.  As the COE covers the cost of renting regalia for the ceremony, choose 'bill index' in the payment area and just put in CCFGEN or COE.

Order your regalia here:
http://www.uoduckstore.com/regalia-rental-form

If you had any problems with your regalia last year, please let me know so we can make the necessary corrections.  If you have questions about what you should order, feel free to contact me or the Duck Store regalia expert Stacy Miller at smiller at uoregon.edu<mailto:smiller at uoregon.edu>.
The week prior to graduation, the Duck Store will deliver the regalia to HEDCO 130 and we'll get it distributed to your office.  On graduation day (Monday, June 18), we ask that you show up in your regalia at Matt Knight Arena at 3:15 pm (about 45 minutes before the ceremony begins).  There will be COE staff on hand to show you where to line up and walk in.  There will be a few presentations, we will hood our doctoral students and then the remaining students will cross the stage and shake the dean's hand while their names are read.  The ceremony lasts about 2 hours.
I'll be sending out more specific information with exact times and locations, but feel free to ask me any questions.  I also love talking with students about Commencement, so let me know if I can do any class visits or provide them any information.
Thanks,
Lisa




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

-------------- next part --------------
An HTML attachment was scrubbed...
URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20180507/80553ab9/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Conference at SOU'
html:
b'
Sent on behalf of Ross Anderson

Join in on presentations on the latest in creativity research, representing a wide array of academic fields, as well as applied workshops providing working professionals opportunities to participate in hands-on activities designed to develop and leverage creativity in the workplace.

The conference will include creativity scholars from around the world, who are doing some incredible work, much of it directly embedded in the education field.  Click on the link below for more information.

http://www.soucreativityconference.com/

subject: b'coe-fac: COE Local Metrics Submission'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

The updated local metrics file that is being submitted to the Provost's office is attached. Thank you for your input in various meetings and via survey.

Thanks to that input, and to advice based on robust discussions with the FAC and Department Heads, we have spelled out acronyms, clarified some of the wording, and included the following newly suggested metrics from the faculty survey:

1)      Refereed technical papers(under publications)

2)      State contracts and grants (under grants)

3)      Manuscript reviews (under other)

We will keep you apprised of any updates or feedback we receive from the Provost's office on our submission.

Dianna

Dianna Carrizales-Engelmann, Ph.D.,

Director of Administration and
Teacher of Clinical Practice and Performance Assessment
College of Education

I hope everyone is looking forward to Commencement next Monday.  Attached are instructions for faculty participation and a map that shows you the line-up area at the lower level of Matt Knight Arena. subject: b'coe-fac: Request for support at SAIL'
html:
b'
Dear Faculty,

As many of you know, each year, our college is one of many colleges on campus who spend time in support of the SAIL (Summer Academy to Inspire Learning) program.  SAIL offers free summer programs to students from local high schools where they spend a week during the summer, where they travel to campus every day to learn some of the important steps they need to know about college life and gaining access to college. Programming typically includes offerings that provide information on the administrative side of things such as registration and financial aid, as well as introductory presentations around the various different majors and disciplines on campus.

This year, once again we have staff from all of our undergraduate majors and minors who have volunteered to be part of SAIL and to provide a session or two in which they will share information about a specific program in the College of Education. Our presentations are typically very engaging and they tend to peak high schoolers' interest in how they might impact or become advocates for social change.

I'm writing today because we still need one or two more volunteers to provide about 3 hours of COE-specific programming for this year's SAIL cohort of high-schoolers. We have a slot open on Tuesday, July 17 from 1:15 pm - 3 pm and another spot from 2 pm - 3 pm on Wednesday, July 18.  Ideally, we would fill those two slots with two different presentations (or activities).

For those who may never have presented for a SAIL cohort before, we typically provide programming that is part lecture and information (providing insight into a college experience), and part engagement (something that gives the students an opportunity to fully engage with the speaker and each other around the topic at hand). This year we will have 20-25 rising juniors and seniors in our class.

I had a presenter who ended up being unable to present at the last minute, so please forgive the short notice request this year. However, if you are interested in taking one of these programming spots and spending time with this year's cohort of high-schoolers for an afternoon this summer, please let me know no later than Friday July 6th.

Thanks,
Lisa




Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607

subject: b'coe-fac: Grad Welcome Week 2018 BBQ'
html:
b'
Hello,
The College of Education has been invited to participate in a welcome lunch for new graduate students.
--If you wish to attend, you will have to RSVP to the Graduate School at the link below prior to August 1st, and then let me know if you plan on being there so we can get an idea of how many folks are attending.  The RSVP only takes 30 seconds as it just asks for your name and academic program.

--New students will be invited by the Graduate School and they have a separate RSVP process.  However, it would be helpful if you'd reach out to your incoming graduate students and invite them personally to have lunch with you at this event.  They are more likely to attend if they feel they will have someone to chat with.

Please let me know what I can do to facilitate this.  I'll be attending the lunch as well and I'll get there early to find our table, so just look for me when you arrive.

Thanks,
Lisa



Lisa Fortin
Director of Events and Student Recruitment
College of Education, University of Oregon
Ph:  541-346-1607



From: Tori Byington
Sent: Tuesday, July 10, 2018 11:46 AM
To: Lisa Fortin <lfortin at uoregon.edu<mailto:lfortin at uoregon.edu>>
Subject: Grad Welcome Week 2018 BBQ


As we gear up for Grad Welcome Week 2018 I am reaching out to ask you to help us welcome new graduate students by hosting a "Lunch with Your College" table at the  Graduate School's New Graduate Student Welcome Barbeque September 18th, 11:45 to 1:00 pm on the 'O' at the EMU Green. This is a wonderful opportunity for colleges to join us as we welcome our students into our community.

While students have appreciated exposure to the broader graduate community during Grad Welcome Week, they let us know that one of the things they truly want at our orientation is a chance to connect to their new academic home and colleagues.  Many ideas have been discussed but, meeting faculty or administrators and other students at orientation and the barbeque seemed to garner the most support.

All of this is free to you and your students.  We will provide a pre-marked table and a BBQ ticket for those who staff your college's table.  We welcome any items you want to add at the orientation, such as a table covers and additional information about your college or its services.

If you would like to join us, all we ask is that you let us know by August 1st  who will be at your venue by filling out the "Lunch With Your College"<https://oregon.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_6QKEMCrn0PP32uN> RSVP so we can be sure we send them a calendar invitation and have a host name tag ready for them.

Also, here is a link to more information about New Graduate Student Orientation and about Grad Welcome Week: https://gradschool.uoregon.edu/orientation

Sincerely,


Tori C Byington, Ph.D.

Assistant Dean

Graduate School

University of Oregon

541-346-2461

byington at uoregon.edu<mailto:byington at uoregon.edu>

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20180716/4b3df4ca/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: Meeting with Randy'
html:
b'
The following message is sent on behalf of Dean Randy Kamphaus:

Dear Faculty and Staff,

It is during the many planned and impromptu meetings with you that I learn most about your work, the problems and road blocks that need my attention, and the opportunities that we should pursue. Because of their value for informing the work of our college, I have asked Maggie to schedule some time for me to have an agenda-free individual discussion with you in the coming months. I do hope that we can arrange these meetings in the very near future.

Expect to see Maggie's scheduling attempts in the coming weeks. However, to initiate and facilitate scheduling, I wanted to start by first dedicating the following three dates this quarter, Friday, Oct. 26th, Monday, Oct. 29th and Tuesday, Nov. 13th to these meetings. If there is a time that can work for you on one of these dates, please reach out to Maggie to identify the top three spots that might work for you. Once these times have been exhausted Maggie will continue scheduling into other available spots in the quarter.

I look forward to speaking with you,

Randy

-------------- next part --------------

URL: <http://lists-prod.uoregon.edu/pipermail/coe-fac/attachments/20180918/31d84f0b/attachment.html>
'

subject: b'coe-fac: HEDCO CTL clinic: Opportunity for students to tutor reading and/or math'
html:
b'
Dear faculty,

wishing your fall term is starting up successfully!

If relevant, and appropriate for your students enrolled in your courses/programs, please consider sharing this tutoring opportunity for fall term (and the whole academic year) at the Center on Teaching and Learning (CTL) housed in the HEDCO Clinic.

Undergraduate students and graduate students from the College of Education at the University of Oregon are encouraged to apply to tutor at the CTL Clinic. Tutors will gain valuable experience planning and delivering research-based reading or math instruction to K-2nd grade students, monitoring their academic progress, and writing weekly progress reports and a summary report to parents. The clinic is a great site to complete field experience hours. Tutors can expect to spend 4 hours per week to earn 1 credit at the clinic. Of those four hours, tutors will work face-to-face with an assigned individual or group of students for two 50-minute sessions a week.  Remaining time will be dedicated to lesson preparation, data summary for parents, and ongoing feedback/training sessions with an assigned supervisor. U of O students who wish to work more hours at the clinic (e.g. 6-7 hours a week for 2 credits) can be assigned to tutor for two hours 2 days per week or one hour 4 days per week. Tutors may apply for a single term or tutor for multiple terms.

Our Reading and Math Intervention Assessment and Intervention Clinic offers group and individual tutoring services for school-age children (currently, kindergarten - 2nd grade) who are struggling in the areas of reading or math due to learning and attention difficulties and disabilities, including dyslexia and dyscalculia. Our trained, supervised undergraduate and graduate student tutors deliver instructional interventions that are backed by rigorous research evidence and teach critical concepts and skills in reading and math, as defined by decades of research, including the National Reading Panel (2000), the National Research Council (2001), and the National Math Advisory Panel (2008).

Tutor Application and flyer can be accessed directly from our website:
 https://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/tutors.html?

Find flyer enclosed in this email if easier to print and share.
Link here: https://ctlreadingclinic.uoregon.edu/forms/tutor-flyer-fall2018.pdf?

Do not hesitate to reach me, or Anna Ingram at annad at uoregon.edu, with any questions.

Best,?



Ruby Batz, PhD.
Research Associate
Center on Teaching and Learning
College of Education, University of Oregon
     1600 Millrace Drive, Suite 245
